abstract: The London Times has been attacked with a sudden fever of anxiety about the future of Italy. The forms in which this disease manifests itself vary from day to day; but its virulence is only to be likened to the fury with which the endemics of southern climes seize upon the constitution of a newly-imported stranger.
lead_paragraph: The London Times has been attacked with a sudden fever of anxiety about the future of Italy. The forms in which this disease manifests itself vary from day to day; but its virulence is only to be likened to the fury with which the endemics of southern climes seize upon the constitution of a newly-imported stranger. The Times is infinitely more distressed about Italy than are the Italians themselves. Only a year ago nothing could exceed the temperance and patience which the Times felt disposed to exercise in regard to the Peninsula. It was true, certainly, that Englishmen could not look with approbation on the Governments of Austria, Rome and Naples. It was not to be expected that Britons could exactly commend a system which degraded the rulers and the ruled alike, and which a British Chancellor of the Exchequer had felt himself compelled to expose and denounce. But then the peace of Europe was so highly important, and the political capacity of the Italians was so very problematical, that the Times could not find it in its heart to encourage the Lombards to rescue their children from the drill-sergeants' cane, or the Romagnoles to shake off the stifling authority of a corrupt priesthood, or the Neapolitans to eject a King who sent his Ministers to the galleys, and exposed the wives of his subjects to the license of his soldiery.

abstract: The telegraph will by this time have informed you that the first successful attempt to cross over to Calabria took place during the evening of Wednesday last. GARIBALDI directed a party of about 250 men, picked from the different volunteer corps, under the command of Maj. MISSORI, to cross the strait and land on the opposite coast between Scylla and Forte del Cavallo.

abstract: As a general thing, the men appointed to office by Mr. BUCHANAN have not won any very brilliant laurels in the public service. The President himself has achieved so much distinction as probably to discourage rivalry. Secretary FLOYD, however, seems likely to prove an exception to this general rule.
lead_paragraph: As a general thing, the men appointed to office by Mr. BUCHANAN have not won any very brilliant laurels in the public service. The President himself has achieved so much distinction as probably to discourage rivalry. Secretary FLOYD, however, seems likely to prove an exception to this general rule. He entered upon the duties of his office apparently with a fixed purpose to place it at the head of the several Executive Departments, and conspicuous in the history of the country, as at once the most corrupt and the most imbecile branch of the public service. And he seems to be the only member of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration who will realize the dreams of his ambition. He will achieve the distinction at which he aimed. He will go out of office "infamous and contented."

abstract: The removal of Gov.  BANKS from Massachusetts to Illinois has excited considerable comment from the Press, and been ascribed to various motives. Disgust with political life, inability to support his family, and a desire to connect himself with the industrial interests rather than the political contests of the country, are among the motives generally assigned to him.
lead_paragraph: The removal of Gov. BANKS from Massachusetts to Illinois has excited considerable comment from the Press, and been ascribed to various motives. Disgust with political life, inability to support his family, and a desire to connect himself with the industrial interests rather than the political contests of the country, are among the motives generally assigned to him. It is not very strange that a man who is not wealthy should be willing to exchange an office worth $3,500 a year for one worth $10,000. But we see no necessity for assuming that he has quit political life, or abandoned all thought of high office. Certainly, the step he has taken does not render necessary any such abnegation.

abstract: OPENING OF MESSRS. STEINWAY & SONS' PIANO-FORTE MANUFACTORY. -- The Messrs. STEINWAY & SONS, Piano manufacturers, opened their new factory, comprising a full block, fronting on Fourth-avenue and extending from Fifty-second to Fifty-third-street, yesterday. There was a large and very respectable number of visiters present. The firm of STEINWAY & SONS consists of STEINWAY, Sr., and four sons, all of them practical piano-makers. The family came to this country some eleven years ago, from Brunswick, Germany, where HENRY STEINWAY, Sr., had had a Piano-forte manufactory for over twenty-five years. He brought some capital to America, but before starting in business, himself and sons workedfor three years as journeymen in the various important manufactories in this City, thus adding to their former Old World experience the practical developments of the New World. The following is a description of their factory. The front on Fourth-avenue has a length of two hundred and one feet, with a depth of forty feet. The wing on Fifty-third-street is one hundred and sixty-five feet in length, and is forty feet in depth. The whole building is six stories high, including the basement. The architecture is of the modern Italian style, with brick lintel arches, brown-stone trimmings, and brick dental cornices. In the yard there are four drying houses, each of which is heated by 2,000 feet of steam-pipe, and contains about 60,000 feet of lumber, so that there are about 240,000 feet of lumber, constantly under the process of kiln-drying. There are about 350 men constantly employed, who turn out about thirty square and five grand pianos every week. All the heavier portion of the machinery is located in the basement. In this room are three large planers, one of which is certainly one of the largest instruments of its class existing, planing the largest piano tops or bottoms at once. There are also four up-and-down saws, several circular saws, besides turning lathes, &c. The three stories above are occupied by the case-makers, who take all the single parts made below, put them together, and veneer and finish the cases ready to go up to the top floor, or varnishing room, where every case remains from three to four months, to be thoroughly varnished. On each case-making floor there are three large warming boxes, constructed of sheet-iron, and covered with wood, with sufficient steam-pipes in them to raise the heat to 200Â°. The varnishing department comprises the top floor, extending the whole length of the front and side building -- a length of three hundred and sixty-six feet. From this floor the completely varnished cases are taken one floor lower down in the front building -- the sounding-board floor -- where the sounding-boards are fitted in. In the floor below, the instruments are strung, the action and key-boards fitted in, and the tops, legs, and lyres adjusted and put on. The partly-finished instruments are then taken first to the floor below, where the action is regulated, thence to the first-floor, where the hammers and the tone are regulated; after which, the final polish is put on the cases, and the perfect piano is ready to be sent down to the salesroom. The front basement contains all the iron-work, plates and bars, drilling-machines, japanning works, and the rosewood veneers. Of the latter the stock on hand is rarely of less value than $8,000. Every part of the factory is heated by means of steam-pipes -- 30,000 feet of which line the interior. The wood-heating apparatus is also warmed by steam, which also heats the kilns for japanning, etc., etc There are about six hundred pianos constantly in course of construction, and these, in connection with the hardware, machinery, engine, veneers, lumber, &c., represent at least the sum of $350,000, exclusive of the buildings. The cost of the building and ground is about $150,000. At the entertainment which followed the inspection of the building, interesting speeches were made by H.L. STUART, Esq., Dr. GARDINER, and others.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 17th ult., in answer to a question propounded by Mr. MONSELL, Lord PALMERSTON said: My honorable friend, the member for Bath, has asked whether any instructions had been given for the purpose of endeavoring to rescue from the harems those unhappy women who were carried off in great numbers from Damascus.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 17th ult., in answer to a question propounded by Mr. MONSELL, Lord PALMERSTON said: My honorable friend, the member for Bath, has asked whether any instructions had been given for the purpose of endeavoring to rescue from the harems those unhappy women who were carried off in great numbers from Damascus. Lord DUFFERIN has instructions, when he visits Syria, to take steps with this end in view, and communications will also be made to the Ambassadors at Constantinople to induce them to cooperate with Lord DUFFERIN in endeavoring to accomplish this object. The two chiefs, KURSCHID PASHA and OSMAN BEY, have, it is true, been sent to Constantinople for the purpose of being tried. Whether one of them, being a military officer, was received with the military honors attaching to his rank I do not know, and cannot consequently inform the House; but it is also true that they have, been sent back to Syria, to be there tried for their crimes. Evidence will, of course, be more easily obtained on the spot; and I hope and trust that when they are arraigned they may receive the reward due to their atrocities. [Cheers.] My honorable friend the member for Limerick has entered into the general-question of the state of Syria. He seems to imagine that these recent events were the result of the tyranny of the Turks. So far from that being the case, they have in a great degree resulted from the absence of direct authority on the part of the Turkish Empire. [Hear, hear.].

abstract: --The Astor Library will be reopened on Monday, Sept. 3, and the public will be admitted as usual thereafter, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., daily. Dr. COGSWELL, who is now in Europe on business connected with the development of this noble institution, is expected to sail for home about the middle of September, and will be in New-York in time to attend the great sale of the late Mr. BURTON's unique and valuable Shakespearian library.

abstract: The news by the Africa, whose arrival was announced in a portion of yesterday morning's edition, is of an interesting character. The report that the Austrian Cabinet had declared its intention to assume the offensive if GARIBALDI should succeed in effecting a revolution in Naples, is not officially confirmed. It is certain that up to the 15th ult., no Austrian note embodying any such views had reached Turin.
lead_paragraph: The news by the Africa, whose arrival was announced in a portion of yesterday morning's edition, is of an interesting character. The report that the Austrian Cabinet had declared its intention to assume the offensive if GARIBALDI should succeed in effecting a revolution in Naples, is not officially confirmed. It is certain that up to the 15th ult., no Austrian note embodying any such views had reached Turin. Authorities differ as to weather the document is really in existence. A statement made in the Constitutionnel by M. GRAUNGUILLOT, publishing secretary of the French Government, that "within two months Italy would be free and completely independent, or Austria would again reign, and this time from Messina to Turin -- has excited considerable attention in political circles, and drawn from the London Times an article of the alarmist type. Most interesting accounts have been received of the departure of the first Italian expedition to invade the main coast. It seems to be still a matter of doubt whether or not GARIBALDI in person landed in Calabria. One body of men successfully disembarked, and, making their way to the mountains, have been there reinforced. We shall probably hear by the next mail of the transportation of the entire Garibaldian army across the narrow straits which divide Sicily from the main land. According to Le Nord, a written protocol has been drawn up of the points arranged between the Emperor of Austria and the Prince of Prussia at the late Toplitz interview. The Regent is said to have admitted that the possession of Venetia was of real importance to the Austrian Empire, but he declined to interfere in the question so long as other Powers shall abstain from intervention.

abstract: The Douglas State Convention met here at noon yesterday Dr. CHAS, J. FOX, of Charlotte, President. Resolutions indorsing the Cincinnati and Charleston Platforms were passed, and a full Douglas Electoral ticket was put in the field. R.P. DICK and DUNCAN K. McRAE were chosen the Electors at Large.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: From the scanty reports of the movement of affairs in the interior of China, furnished by French and English journals, it is satisfactory to turn to the letter of our correspondent at Shanghai, given elsewhere in the present issue of the TIMES. Such accounts as we have hitherto had have told us in general terms that the rebellion had recently assumed new vigor; that the opposition of the Imperial troops had been fruitless; and that the movement was steadily northward, from the ancient, toward the actual capital of the Empire.
lead_paragraph: From the scanty reports of the movement of affairs in the interior of China, furnished by French and English journals, it is satisfactory to turn to the letter of our correspondent at Shanghai, given elsewhere in the present issue of the TIMES. abstract: -- The returning world of New-York will be welcomed to our noble Central Park by the charms of art as well as of nature. The "law's delays" and other obstacles being finally and fairly conquered, the pleasant institution of music for the million revived again on Saturday last, and will be in full force again to-day. Under the direction of a well-known amateur, Mr. MOULD, DODWORTH is performing in the Park new and choice arrangements of themes from the finest works of the best composers. BEETHOVEN, MENDELSSOHN, SPHOR will in this way become the familiar friends of our population. The stands for the music have been wisely transferred from the Ramble to the Central Mall, and the hour of the performances is fixed at 4 P.M.
lead_paragraph: -- The returning world of New-York will be welcomed to our noble Central Park by the charms of art as well as of nature. BEETHOVEN, MENDELSSOHN, SPHOR will in this way become the familiar friends of our population. The stands for the music have been wisely transferred from the Ramble to the Central Mall, and the hour of the performances is fixed at 4 P.M.

abstract: ALLEDGED PARRICIDE. -- On the 19th of August last, JOSEPH BOHON, residing in Montrose-avenue, Eastern District, got into an altercation with his son, JOSEPH BOHON, Jr., in front of the residence of the former, during which the elder BOHON received a severe cut with some sharp instrument in the left arm, just above the elbow, severing an important artery. Medical aid was promptly obtained, the flow of blood was stopped, and the wound had commenced to heal, but in some manner it was torn open again a few days ago, and resulted in his death yesterday morning. A short time before he died, Coroner MURPHY was called to take his deposition as to the manner he received the fatal wound, when he made the following statement.

abstract: A little over a year ago, Mrs. SOLOMON COLE, wife of a well-to-do farmer, of the town of Wantage, Sussex County, New-Jersey, died under circumstances which afforded ground for the suspicion that she had been murdered in order to obtain a considerable sum of money, for which, a short time previous to her demise, her life had been insured. The case excited a great deal of interest at the time, on account of the social position of the parties implicated in the matter, and the fearful developments of the depth of degradation to which a lust for gold would lead persons of apparent respectability. From the published statements of the affair, it appeared that a few weeks before the anticipated confinement of deceased, COLE was induced by one DAVID D. WICKHAM, a practicing physician, residing at Hamburgh, a place ten miles distant from Wautage, to insure his wife's life in a New-York Company, for which the doctor acted as agent. An agreement was entered upon by which COLE was to pay the first instalment of the premium, after which, WICKHAM was to pay the annual interest. If, however, Mrs. COLE died during her confinement, then the insurance money was to be divided equally between the husband and the physician, who also had engaged to attend her during her illness. WICKHAM happened to be absent from the county when Mrs. COLE was taken sick, and another physician attended her until after the fifth day from the birth of her child, when he resigned his charge, apparently under favorable circumstances, to the care of the accused. Almost immediately after the administration of a mixture, which WICKHAM had prepared for her, the poor woman was thrown into convulsions, and her death soon resulted. Notwithstanding her sudden decease, no suspicion attached to WICKHAM until some days subsequent to the funeral, when it became known that he had entered a claim for the insurance upon Mrs. COLE's life, in accordance with the arrangement adverted to. The matter having been canvassed, it was finally decided to exhume the body and hold a post-mortem examination, which demonstrated, upon the chemical analysis of the contents of the stomach and intestines by Dr. DOREMUS, that the woman's death had been produced by strychnine. An inquest was held, and the jury rendered a verdict implicating both COLE and the doctor. The accused were arrested, and the husband was tried for the murder, but the evidence would not sustain the charge, and he was acquitted. Meanwhile Dr. WICKHAM had been placed under heavy bonds to answer, but he escaped from the custody of the officer who was conveying him to prison, and managed to elude pursuit. Diligent search has since been made for him, and a reward of $500 was offered by the New-Jersey authorities for his apprehension, but no trace of him was obtained until Saturday afternoon, when he was arrested by Officer NIVEN, of the Second Precinct. The prisoner was seen in Chatham-street, walking with his wife, by Mr. WM.C. WARDELL, NO. 22 Beekman-street, who formerly resided in Sussex County and was perfectly familiar with the appearance of the fugitive. Mr. WARDELL at once communicated with the policeman, and WICKHAM was taken into custody. He was conducted to the Station-house, where at first he persisted in denying his identity, asserting that his name was JAMES LAMONT, and that he had just returned from Europe. Being confronted, however, with several persons who were acquainted with him at his former residence, he remarked, "It is no use; I may as well own up," and unfastening his vest, displayed the name of DAVID D. WICKHAM upon his shirt. He expresses his willingness to return to New-Jersey with the officer, without awaiting the formality of a requisition, and he will be taken to Sussex County today.

abstract: -- The Tax Collector in East Bridgeport, Conn., caught a hard customer the other day. He attempted to sell a piece of land for the payment of a tax which had been refused, when the lady-like proprietor of the grounds warned him off the premises. As he did not comply with her orders, she produced a cowhide, and belabored him with it most lustily, her husband standing by and encouraging her by shouting, "Go in old gal," "It won't cost any more to give him a big whipping than a small one," &c., &c.
lead_paragraph: -- The Tax Collector in East Bridgeport, Conn., caught a hard customer the other day. He attempted to sell a piece of land for the payment of a tax which had been refused, when the lady-like proprietor of the grounds warned him off the premises. abstract: The second concert of the season was given in Central Park on Saturday afternoon, and drew a much larger audience than that of the Saturday previous. There were not less than 3,000 people collected on the Mall and the adjacent grounds, at least one half of whom were ladies. All the seats beneath the two big tents were occupied at an early hour, and those who arrived later were obliged to seek a resting-place on the steps of the terrace, or on the rising knoll at the cast of the Mall. Large numbers, particularly of the male sex, preferred to take the music standing, or rather walking, and under the pretence of looking for a seat, availed themselves of the opportunity to take an individual and collective survey of the female beauty and loveliness of the entire audience. The result must have been highly satisfactory, for it was a general subject of remark that the audience combined more of female beauty, of intelligence, of dress, and of that undefined word called "respectability," than any out-door collection of the same size ever seen in New-York. The gay carriages of the wealthy, the aristocratic, the luxurious, or the lazy, halted, one after another, as they rolled past the Mall, to catch the "voluptuous swell" of the music, until at one time not less than a hundred steeds were dancing and pawing the earth to the music of Dodworth's band. The more romantically inclined, to whom the enchantment of music, like that of mountains, lies in the distance, rambled off to the "Ramble," where, reclining upon the grass, they drank in the floating echoes as they "began and died upon the gentle wind." Each one enjoyed himself in his own way, and all were entertained, delighted, enchanted. Even the Hamburg swans seemed to forget the death of their companions when they heard the sweet strains of Fatherland and the notes of the great German composers sailing in the upper air, and as they came floating down the lake towards the mall, with their snow-white bosoms "rising graceful o'er the wave;" they bent their necks in courtesy and apparent thankfulness to the Park Commissioners for their joy of the entertainment. The Central Park concerts, judging from the manner in which they have been received thus far, are destined to become one of the institutions, and not the least popular one of Manhattan Island. The programme of Saturday comprised the "Overture Due D'Olone," "Andante and Polinaise," "Last Rose of Summer," "March der Tannhauser," selections from the "Huguenots," "Daisy Medley," "Overture Stradelier," "Hungarian March," selections from "Massaniello," "Bell Brandon," &c. The band comprised twenty-five pieces, under the direction of HARVEY B. DODWORTH.

Even the Hamburg swans seemed to forget the death of their companions when they heard the sweet strains of Fatherland and the notes of the great German composers sailing in the upper air, and as they came floating down the lake towards the mall, with their snow-white bosoms "rising graceful o'er the wave;" they bent their necks in courtesy and apparent thankfulness to the Park Commissioners for their joy of the entertainment. The Central Park concerts, judging from the manner in which they have been received thus far, are destined to become one of the institutions, and not the least popular one of Manhattan Island. The programme of Saturday comprised the "Overture Due D'Olone," "Andante and Polinaise," "Last Rose of Summer," "March der Tannhauser," selections from the "Huguenots," "Daisy Medley," "Overture Stradelier," "Hungarian March," selections from "Massaniello," "Bell Brandon," &c. The band comprised twenty-five pieces, under the direction of HARVEY B. DODWORTH.

abstract: TO "MANY CITIZENS OF CHARLESTON."  In your communication addressed to me, in the Courier of the 24th inst., you ask whether my recent letter, or my resolutions in the Legislature last Win  ter, "is intended to be considered my opinion?" and "a candid answer is desired." In all candor and sincerity, I answer both, and will adhere to both with all that "honesty" which you say you have heretofore given me credit for.

abstract: The American schooner Plumes of Dennis, which came ashore in the norther twelve days ago, driven high and dry on the beach, has been got off, and is afloat again. She was sold at public auction, by order of the Captain, on Saturday last; price, $1,000.  A.LEMPARTE was her purchaser. The hull seems to sit well enough on the water. One mast is standing. The rest and the bowsprit are good.
lead_paragraph: VALPARAISO, Friday, Aug. 3, 1860.

abstract: That a person, famous for passing Niagara River on a bridge of hemp, is to perform feats of the same character and hardly less daring in this City during the present week, is ineffaceably proclaimed upon the dead walls. M. BLONDIN, envious of Metropolitan applause, is coming to town.
lead_paragraph: That a person, famous for passing Niagara River on a bridge of hemp, is to perform feats of the same character and hardly less daring in this City during the present week, is ineffaceably proclaimed upon the dead walls. M. BLONDIN, envious of Metropolitan applause, is coming to town. In the tallest grove of the island a cord is to be suspended, upon which this human spider is to display his superhuman adhesiveness, at a distance above the level of the sea which is utterly irreconcilable with the safety of the reckless performer. There will be dancing under circumstances from which Tam O'Shanter's witches might recoil; wheelbarrows will be driven, with living freight, over perilous chasms; suspended by a thread from the middle of his tight-rope, the indestructible monster is engaged to rotate with the velocity of a tee-totum, and turn summersaults with the agility of a jumping jack. Such achievements have scores of times drawn admiring thousands together at Niagara, and Rochester has poured forth its entire population to do homage to similar skill time and again. It is high time that these tourists of the provinces should at once astonish, appal and delight the expectant multitudes of the capital. And in the fullness of time, they are come.

abstract: A summary of the political advices by the Fulton, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in Saturday morning's TIMES, has reached us. Large bodies of revolutionists had landed in Cala  bria, where they had been joined by insurgents to the number of two thousand, with whom they had retired temporarily to the mountains.
lead_paragraph: A summary of the political advices by the Fulton, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in Saturday morning's TIMES, has reached us. Large bodies of revolutionists had landed in Cala bria, where they had been joined by insurgents to the number of two thousand, with whom they had retired temporarily to the mountains. Two Companies of Neapolitan dragoons were reported to have gone over to GARIBALDI, whose forces on the mainland must by this time amount to quite a formidable army. Meantime, preparations for the defence of Naples continued, though, from the nature of our advices, there is little doubt that the city will be captured with comparatively little trouble, on account of general disaffection against the Government. Decisive news may be expected very soon. Austrian preparations also continued on a large scale, the intention being announced to increase the Marine Budget by 100,000,000 florins.

abstract: -Gen. HOUSTON has actually withdrawn his name from the Presidential canvass. His "chances of success," he says, "are not so apparent" -- as to warrant his continuing a candidate, he probably intended to add. He thinks all the other candidates ought to follow his example, and promptly abandon the field. They have no chance of success, and if they persist in running, the Republican nominee is sure to be elected. He calls upon his countrymen to "forget him," and to forget the "claims of all office seekers." We fear it will be much easier to do the first than the last. If all thought of office were laid aside, we suspect there would be very little interest in the election. Patriotism is a very, excellent sentiment, -- but it leads very few men now-a-days to perform heroic acts of self-sacrifice.

abstract: The Countess Donna Pedro, otherwise known by the plebeian patronymic of Sarah Jane Corkery, whose arrest and examination on a charge of having defrauded Mr. William Grigg and other reputable people by royal representations, based upon falsehood, has been duly chronicled, was on Saturday fully.
lead_paragraph: The Countess Donna Pedro, otherwise known by the plebeian patronymic of Sarah Jane Corkery, whose arrest and examination on a charge of having defrauded Mr. William Grigg and other reputable people by royal representations, based upon falsehood, has been duly chronicled, was on Saturday fully committed for trial by Justice CONNOLLY, and now pines in prison because of her inability to procure a bondsman. Her bail has been fixed at $500, and she considers it strange that no gallant knight will advance the paltry amount to confer upon her a boon of such magnitude. Miss Corkery indignantly denies the allegations that have been made against her, and hints at most astounding revelations which will be made when her case shall be brought to trial. She says that her life has been an eventful one; that site has traveled a great deal, and numbers among her acquaintances many of the most prominent characters of the present age. Her main hope of relief from the condition in which she finds herself placed is to have her "strange, eventful history" dramatized and represented to a New-York audience, herself acting the part which in reality she has performed. Wide-awake managers will take heed and avail themselves of this tide in the lady's affairs, which possibly may lead to a fortune for all concerned.

abstract: This grand affair, which was got up in honor of His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, took place in Longueuil Bay, in the St. Lawrence River, on Thursday last. Six steamers, and the Committee's barge in tow of another, took 3,000 persons to the Bay, in which were anchored the war steamers Valorous and Styx.
lead_paragraph: This grand affair, which was got up in honor of His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, took place in Longueuil Bay, in the St. Lawrence River, on Thursday last. Six steamers, and the Committee's barge in tow of another, took 3,000 persons to the Bay, in which were anchored the war steamers Valorous and Styx. A large number of ladies were present, and the shores were lined with people. There were five regular races for shore-boats and canoes, and three for ships' boats, in which boats from Upper and Lower Canada, and the men-of-war and packet steamers, took part. The distance, 1 1/2 miles and return, being with and against the stream 2 1/2 miles.

abstract: The curiosity of the Artillery officers, and of the guests at Old Point was gratified yesterday by the first firing of the great "Floyd" Gun of which I have before spoken. The first shell weighing 360 pounds was thrown fifteen hundred and forty yards at an angle of five degrees and striking the sand, bounced seven hundred and fifty yards further. The charge of powder was twenty pounds.

abstract: -- One week ago Thursday night, the house of WM.M. HYDE, at East New-York, was entered by a burglar and robbed of clothing worth $50; and on the same night the house of Rev. CHARLES CLEVELAND, Rector of the Episcopal Church of East New-York, was entered and robbed of between $400 and $500 worth of clothing and jewelry. A servant girl was arrested on suspicion, but subsequently discharged for want of evidence. On the night after the burglary, WILLIAM GARBUTT, a painter residing at East New-York, was married by Rev. Mr. CLEVELAND to a young woman of the place. On Monday, night succeeding there was a wedding party at the house of the bride's father. A person present saw on the table a silver cup bearing the name of "WM.M. HYDE," and communicated the fact to the police. On Friday morning last Rev. Mr. CLEVELAND, on passing GARBUTT's house, saw some linen and other articles hanging on the clothes-line which he recognized as his own. With these facts in their possession, the police examined the premises and found a portion of the property, and pawn-tickets for a quantity pledged in Canal-street, New-York. Officer LATINVILLE, of the Fifth Precinct, soon after arrested GARBUTT on the return of the latter from New-York. On the way to the Station-house, in a Broadway car, the prisoner attacked the officer, knocked him down and made a desperate effort to escape. The officer, after a violent struggle and the free use of the butt of his pistol, as he had no club, succeeded in securing GARBUTT, who was locked up.

abstract: Commodore JAMES McINTOSH, one of the ablest officers in the Navy, is dead. He breathed his last on Thursday, at Pensacola, where he was Commandant of the, Navy-yard. Forty-nine years ago, a short time previous to the war of 1812, Commodore McINTOSH donned his cadet's jacket, and has since performed 32 years' service, of which 20 were spent on sea, and the remainder on land. His unemployed time counts over 13 years.
lead_paragraph: Commodore JAMES McINTOSH, one of the ablest officers in the Navy, is dead. He breathed his last on Thursday, at Pensacola, where he was Commandant of the, Navy-yard. Forty-nine years ago, a short time previous to the war of 1812, Commodore McINTOSH donned his cadet's jacket, and has since performed 32 years' service, of which 20 were spent on sea, and the remainder on land. His unemployed time counts over 13 years. He served on all squadrons, and in nearly every national vessel afloat. The date of his last campaign is September, 1850. His opinions relative to the distribution of vessels on squadrons was always highly valued. Commodore MCINTOSH's decease advances a step, in the line of promotion, all the captain's names on the Register, his relative position being now occupied by Commodore TATTNALL, late Commander-in-Chief on the China station. As usual in such cases, all ships of the Navy at home go into mourning in a day or two, by half-masting their flags during the day, and firing a salute of minute guns at noon. The same ceremony will be performed by those on foreign squadrons, when their commanders receive official notification of the melancholy event. Of course a new Commandant for the Pensacola Navy-yard will soon be appointed.

abstract: The long-pending differences between the Mother Country and this Colony, in reference to the transfer of the Post-office Department from Imperial to local control, have at length been settled. The act to effect the transfer, passed during the late special  session of the Legislature, held in the month of April last, has received the assent of her Majesty the Queen, and the Department has been formally handed over to the management of the Colonial Government.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: We publish a second capital letter from Col. PERRY, of South Carolina, in another part of this morning's TIMES. It is like the first,  which we copied a week or two ago, able, independent and full of common sense. The appearance of such documents in the South at the present time is quite a phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: We publish a second capital letter from Col. PERRY, of South Carolina, in another part of this morning's TIMES. It is like the first, which we copied a week or two ago, able, independent and full of common sense. The appearance of such documents in the South at the present time is quite a phenomenon. They are as remarkable as the Meteor, and quite as worthy of being watched and studied. Any man in the extreme South, who ventures, in these days of feverish excitement and irrational apprehension, to look facts fairly in the face, and talk to his countrymen as men of sense, will certainly make himself an object of curiosity and possibly of admiration. Col. PERRY belongs to that class of men, which is becoming rare in the South, who having eyes and brains, venture to use them. He does not take his opinions from the clamor of demagogues, or his policy from the plots of selfish cowards. He studies events for himself, -- forms his own conclusions and gives them to the public for whatever they may be worth.

abstract: The Committee of the Fire Department appointed to arrangement for the procession in honor of the Prince of Wales, held a meeting at the residence of the Chief Engineer, JOHN DECKER, on Saturday evening. There were present, besides the Chief Engineer, Robert Gamble; of Hook and Ladder No. 16, Wm. Sterrett, of Engine Co. No. 15, Wm.H. Racy, of Truck No. 40, and S. Buck, of Hose Co. No. 36. A good deal of time was spent in talking over various matters connected with the procession, but nothing definite was arrived at, further than that the display should come off on the evening of the 13th of October, which will be the evening succeeding the ball at the Academy of Music, and the second evening after the Prince's arrival in the City. Mr. DECKER stated that he had as yet received no official report from the individual companies in the Department, but he had no doubt the entire Department, which now numbered upwards of 4,000 men, would take part in the procession. It was suggested that the procession be divided into fifteen divisions, each division to be headed by a band of music. With regard to the expenses of the turnout, which the Committee was appointed mainly to consider, it was announced that Mayor WOOD had pledged his individual purse to the amount of $2,500, or more if required. This part of the programme was therefore considered to be definitely settled, and the consideration of the details of the procession was postponed to a future meeting to be called by the Chief Engineer.

abstract: SPECIAL ELECTION. -- Alderman CHRISTIE having resigned his seat in the Board of Aldermen in Jersey City, a special election is to be held on Tuesday, in the Fourth Ward, to fill the vacancy. Meetings were held on Friday night, and the following nominations were made: Republican -- Isaac Houston; Democratic -- Henry F. Cox; National Union -- Henry F. Cox. A resolution was offered in the Democratic meeting opposing a fusion with any other party, and in favor of electing their candidate, if at all, by Democratic votes. The resolution was voted down.

abstract: On Friday afternoon, Coroner MURPHY, of the Eastern District, held an inquest on the body of JOSEPH BEBON, who died that day from the effect of wounds inflicted by his son, JOSEPH BEBON, Jr., on the 19th inst. Dr. JOHN A. BRADY was the first witness examined.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, Coroner MURPHY, of the Eastern District, held an inquest on the body of JOSEPH BEBON, who died that day from the effect of wounds inflicted by his son, JOSEPH BEBON, Jr., on the 19th inst. Dr. JOHN A. BRADY was the first witness examined. He testified that he was called to see the deceased thirteen days previously; that he found three wounds on the left arm, from the loss of blood from which deceased was much prostrated; that he bandaged the wounds and prescribed treatment for the patient. The witness described the progress of the case until Monday last, when the wounds were in course of healing. He said that when he called to see the patient on Friday he found him dead; was told that he died of bleeding at about half-past one that morning. He gave it as his opinion that the deceased got out of bed during the night, and in so doing reopened the wounds, and that a fatal bleeding resulted. He believed death was caused by the wounds described, which were inflicted by a sharp instrument driven into the arm.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer is an amiable journal, almost as amiable as it is sensible. It is just now in a mood of malignant glee, because the State of Virginia has concluded to have the arms and munitions of war, with which she proposes to dissolve the Union, made at home, instead of buying them in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer is an amiable journal, almost as amiable as it is sensible. It is just now in a mood of malignant glee, because the State of Virginia has concluded to have the arms and munitions of war, with which she proposes to dissolve the Union, made at home, instead of buying them in Massachusetts. The fact per se would be a legitimate subject for exultation; -- but what delights the Enquirer particularly is the fact, that this change of purpose was effected by an article in the NEW-YORK TIMES, and that a Northern manufacturer has "lost a contract" through a Northern paper. We trust he will survive the loss. We find our consolation in the reflection that we have stirred up the State of Virginia to a sense of the absurd figure she makes, in proclaiming war against States on which she must depend for every musket which she musters.

abstract: Among the many terrors which just now haunt the path of John Bull, it is doubtful whether the fear of the French naval supremacy or of American competition in mercantile shipping, is predominant. Early in the recent session of Parliament a committee was appointed in the Commons to investigate the condition of the shipping interest.
lead_paragraph: Among the many terrors which just now haunt the path of John Bull, it is doubtful whether the fear of the French naval supremacy or of American competition in mercantile shipping, is predominant. Early in the recent session of Parliament a committee was appointed in the Commons to investigate the condition of the shipping interest. It reported, quite recently, in a very long and able paper, which discussed the various influences operating to the disadvantage of trade, and presented various measures as appropriate remedies. A deficiency in the sources of information was ascribed to the neglect of Government, which had been at no pains to collect statistics, and had no compilation of tariffs and commercial reports, from which the facts necessary to a thorough mastery of the question might have been derived. The Committee, however, obtained light enough to satisfy itself that the prolific parent of mischief, is the failure of the United States to reciprocate in any degree the liberal concessions afforded by the repeal of the Navigation acts. The immediate effect of that act was the admission of the shipping of all nations to unrestricted competition in the British colonial trade. The field was a wide one, and the profits incalculable; for British Colonies beset all the pathways of the world, and British markets are of all the most desirable. American merchants embarked eagerly in the new career.

abstract: Our Kansas Correspondent, whether writing at the dictation of stern facts, or of infirm nerves, sends us a gloomy and threatening picture of affairs in that much-enduring Territory. Forlorn, dejected and oppressed; weary of waiting for that long-promised popular sovreignty, which they are supposed by the Douglas Democracy to be actually en- ...
lead_paragraph: Our Kansas Correspondent, whether writing at the dictation of stern facts, or of infirm nerves, sends us a gloomy and threatening picture of affairs in that much-enduring Territory. Forlorn, dejected and oppressed; weary of waiting for that long-promised popular sovreignty, which they are supposed by the Douglas Democracy to be actually enjoying, but of which they have thus far had no substantial taste, the people of the land are represented to be quite ripe for any counsels, however desperate, that offer the opportunity for self-government. This malcontent spirit, on the part of the people, has been fostered, by a variety of mishaps, which have brought ruin to their doors. Crops have failed; estates have been forfeited; creditors always swift-footed when debtors lag, have been urgent and merciless; the actual season and its harvests have brought no relief; there is the universal cry of famine and the universal wail of despair.

abstract: -It is dangerous to have any one who knows your secrets become your enemy, -- provided you have done anything to be ashamed of. Bits of private history, which may have come to the knowledge of that enemy before he ceased to be a friend, may some day be paraded before the community with very unpleasant results. A case in point is the contest now waging between the Columbus (O.) Statesman and the Evening Bulletin; the latter sheet being an offshoot of the former, edited by men who were formerly in the Statesman's employ, and know the history of the establishment. In the course of a controversy, the Bulletin has divulged the fact that Hon. S.S. COX, a member of Congress from Ohio, was in the habit of writing self-adulatory letters to the Statesman from Washington. One of these, signed "J.," has been exhumed. Mr. COX therein alludes to himself as "the youthful orator;" tells how he demolished JOHN SHERMAN and spoiled TOM CORWIN's chances for the Speakership, and closes by asking his constituents to be proud of him! It only needed this stroke to put the finish to Mr. SHERMAN's recent castigation of COX. The Statesman was unwise in quarreling with its old cronies, if the Bulletin has many more such revelations to make.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF A BAR-ROOM BRAWL. The circumstances relating to the decease of DANIEL HORRIGAN, a native of Ireland, 20 years of age, who was fatally injured on the night of the 20th ult., during the progress of a fight between a number of persons, in the bar-room of AUGUSTUS FENDAGO, corner of West and Cedar-streets, were investigated on Saturday by Coroner O'KEEFE.
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF A BAR-ROOM BRAWL. The circumstances relating to the decease of DANIEL HORRIGAN, a native of Ireland, 20 years of age, who was fatally injured on the night of the 20th ult., during the progress of a fight between a number of persons, in the bar-room of AUGUSTUS FENDAGO, corner of West and Cedar-streets, were investigated on Saturday by Coroner O'KEEFE. Much testimony was taken, but it was of so contradictory a character, that the jury were unable to determine at whose hands the deceased had received his injuries. His brother PATRICK HORRIGAN, deposed that the fracas grew out of a dispute between LORENZO STEVENS, one of the bar-keepers, and the deceased, with reference to the price of the drinks, and that STEVENS struck him on the face with a bottle and afterwards followed him to the street and threw empty bottles at him. Subsequently STEVENS ran away. FREDERICK HYNE, another of the bar-keepers in the saloon in question, testified that deceased commenced the fight by throwing a tumbler at STEVENS, who returned the blow with his fist. THOS. ENRIGHT then came in to drink, and deceased turned upon and struck him with a bottle, knocking him down. FRANK ENRIGHT, brother of THOMAS, interfered at this stage of the fight, and gave deceased a severe beating. Deceased then crawled out into the street. Several witnesses deposed that STEVENS was not present when HORRIGAN was injured. Upon the arrival of the police THOMAS ENRIGHT and deceased were taken to the New-York Hospital. The former soon recovered sufficiently to leave the institution, but HORRIGAN, whose skull was found to be fractured, died on Friday night. Notwithstanding the fact that the jury failed to implicate any person as the perpetrator of the violence which caused HORRIGAN's death, Coroner O'KEEFE deemed it proper to detain STEVENS, the bar-keeper, to await the action of the Grand Jury, and to issue a warrant for the arrest of FRANK ENRIGHT.

abstract: The meteorology of this country appears to be as unsettled as the condition of the mines. Last Summer and Fall the principal characteristic of the weather was an almost uninterrupted dryness. Between the 1st of May and the 1st of December the aggregate fall of rain did not exceed five inches.

abstract: The Irish Company will find one day to their cost that they have engaged precipitately in an undertaking not so profitable as they expected; that, as in the case of the beet-root sugar manufactory, they have suffered themselves to he duped by the exaggerated profits promised to them by interested parties, who were sure to be gainers, no matter how affairs went. They will find it rather an expensive plaything, and many years may not elapse before the contract, by the unanimous consent of all parties, will be transferred to the Canadian Company. It is utterly impossible that the present Imperial arrangements can last for any time; that the British taxpayers will be satisfied to pay the sum of Â£320,000 a year on this playing at cross-purposes; while Brother Jonathan looks quietly on enjoying the fun, but keeping his pockets hermetrically sealed. The United States profit in every way as much as England does from the subsidies. The American enjoys on his voyage to Europe all the advantages in point of comfort and safety that are possessed by the Cunard ships, at the same cost as the Englishman, and both pay alike for carriage of letters and goods, while the latter alone contributes to the subsidy. No one can blame the people of the United States for availing themselves of the liberality of European nations. England kindly undertakes the task of carrying her letters and transporting goods and passengers at a rate by which the loss incurred must be made good out of the Imperial exchequer.

abstract: The Board of Health had a long and stormy meeting yesterday, with closed doors. One of their acts, however, leaked out, and for that the residents in the vicinity of First-avenue, Thirty-sixth, Thirty-seventh, Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth streets, as well as others much further West, will fell boundlessly grateful. During the Summer the dumping-ground extending along the First-avenue fox the distance of the four blocks above-named, and down to the East River was so loudly complained of as a nuisance, even by parties in Lexington-avenuie, that the Board passed a resolution directing; that the space thus occupied should not be longer used for such purposes. Yesterday, however, the matter came up again on the petition of the parties who have heretofore used that space for a dumping-ground, and after a stormy debate, the farmer resolution was rescinded, and the residents in that vicinity will have the full benefit of it.

abstract: The Commissioners of Health met yesterday afternoon, at the Mayor's Office. Dr. GUNN, the Health-Officer, reported the arrival of three vessels having seven cases of yellow fever on board, two vessels from Cienfuegos, and the other from Sagua la Grande. The infected vessele were ordered to be detained at be lower anchorage. The sick had already been transferred to the Floating Hospital. The two ports above-mentioned are reported to be the most unhealthy at the present time. Few cases, as yet, had made their apperance at havana, and as late as the 25th of August, no case had been reported at New-Orleans. There were previously four cases of yellow fever on board the Falcon, all of which were reported as convalescing. These three late arrivals are the only vessels in the Lower [???]ay, and only some five or six at the upper anchorage. The Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: Stewart Prime, a young carpenter, residing in the tenement-house No. 159 West Thirty-first-street, was yesterdsy committed for trial by Justice CONNOLLY on three complaints of burglary, preferred by Joseph W. Freeman, George W. Koch and Simon L. Woodman, all of whom occupied apartments in the same premises with the accused.
lead_paragraph: Stewart Prime, a young carpenter, residing in the tenement-house No. 159 West Thirty-first-street, was yesterdsy committed for trial by Justice CONNOLLY on three complaints of burglary, preferred by Joseph W. Freeman, George W. Koch and Simon L. Woodman, all of whom occupied apartments in the same premises with the accused. It appeared from the affidavit of Officer Irving, of the Twentieth Precinct, that the prisoner was observed by him to leave the house in question with a bundle under his arm, and, suspecting that it had not come honestly into his possession, he determined to follow and learn what disposition would be made of it. Prime took the package, which proved to be several numbers of a serial publication, entitled the Life of Washington, to the store No. 27 Beekman-street, and offered it for sale, but failing to obtain a purchaser there, he went to No. 109 Nassau-street, and endeavored to dispose of the books for $2. At this stage, Irving took him into custody on suspicion, and upon searching him, found several pawn-tickets, which represented property that was subsequently identified as having been stolen from the complainants. Prime confessed to the officer that he had taken advantage of his familiarity with the apartments of his fellow tenants to commit the burglaries, which were effected by the aid of skeleton keys, and also gave information which led to the recovery of the articles which had not been pawned. In addition to the publications belonging to Mr. Freeman, which were found in possession of the prisoner at the time of his arrest, a gold watch, valued at $50, was also taken from him, while the aggregate value of the articles stolen from Messrs. Koch & Woodman amounted to $41.

abstract: The City Inspector, in his report of deaths for the past week, says there were 524 deaths in the City for the week ending Sept. 1, viz: 86 men, 81 women, 193 boys, and 164 girls; being a decrease of 25 on the preceding week, and less 57 than during the corresponding week in 1859. Of the number 320 were under 5 years of age. The principal diseases were: apoplexy, 6; cholera infantum, 103; congestion of brain, 8; infantile convulsions, 37; cancer, 5; consumption, 56; dropsy, 8; do. in head, 24; diarrhoea, 27; diphtherite, 8; scarlet fever, 31; do., typhus, 6; disease of heart, 7; inflammation of bowels, 5; do. brain, 7; do. heart, 4; do. lungs, 5; marasmus, infantile, 43; measles, 5; small-pox, 6; teething, 7; casualties, 8; drowned, 7; old age, 10; premature birth, 8. abstract: By the steamship City of Manchester, which was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press off Cape Race yesterday, we received European advices one day later.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship City of Manchester, which was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press off Cape Race yesterday, we received European advices one day later. A Paris telegram announces that a serious disturbance had occurred in Basilicata, a Province of Naples lying in the mountains about eighty miles southeast of the capital. Several corps of Garibaldians are stated to have landed there, and to have been received with welcome. It is also announced, on the authority of the London Daily News, that the Calabrians were in open revolt in favor of GARIBALDI. The exact whereabouts of the Dictator appeared not to be known. The project of raising Spain again to the dignity of a great Power is stated to have been abandoned for the present.

abstract: Mr. JAMES T. BRADY, in his recent letter  accepting the nomination of part of the Demcratic Party for Governor, speaks of the necessity of "rescuing the American Union from any danger which the creeds or practices of the Republican Party may have brought upon it."
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES T. BRADY, in his recent letter accepting the nomination of part of the Demcratic Party for Governor, speaks of the necessity of "rescuing the American Union from any danger which the creeds or practices of the Republican Party may have brought upon it." Mr. BRADY is a lawyer of astuteness and experience, and not likely to jest on a subject of practical importance. We are bound to assume, therefore, that he really means to assert that the Republican Party has actually adopted, and practices a creed which threatens the very existence of the Union. In this view of the case, we cannot help considering Mr. BRADY as the most interesting phenomenon which has appeared in the Metropolis since ELLA BURNS. The union of so much talent and learning with so much childlike simplicity, is something with which the public is not yet sufficiently familiar to view, it without wonder and admiration. Nobody can help pondering with awe over the mysterious dispensation of Providence which deprives a learned and able lawyer of all his perspicacity and astuteness, the moment he is clothed with the empty honors of "standard-bearer," and makes him see danger to the Government in the Republican Platform at Chicago, and in the attempt of those who believe in it to elect their own candidate in the mode prescribed by the Constitution.

abstract: About one hundred members of the Twentysecond Ward Democracy assembled last evening at their head-quarters, which are located in a liquorstore, corner Thirty-fourth-street and Second-avenue.
lead_paragraph: About one hundred members of the Twentysecond Ward Democracy assembled last evening at their head-quarters, which are located in a liquorstore, corner Thirty-fourth-street and Second-avenue. The Chair was taken by Mr. GEO. W. MCLEAN, who stated that extensive preparations were in progress for a mass meeting to be held at Jones' Wood, the 12th inst., at which, beside a host of talent, might be expected an address from Mr. DOUGLAS, and probably one from Mr. JOHNSON. He further stated that he had reported the Club as being three hundred strong, and assured them that what was wanting in strength would be made up in enthusiasm.

abstract: A slave brig, whose name is not definitely ascertained probably the Triten came into the Capes Monday, and anchored at Quarantine yesterday morning, in charge of Midshipman N. H. FARQUHAR, fortyone days from Loango, on the west coast of Africa.
lead_paragraph: A slave brig, whose name is not definitely ascertained probably the Triten came into the Capes Monday, and anchored at Quarantine yesterday morning, in charge of Midshipman N. H. FARQUHAR, fortyone days from Loango, on the west coast of Africa. She was captured on the 16th of July, off Black Point, by the United States steamer Mystic, Lieut. Commanding LEROY. The brig cleared from New Orleans about the 1st of March last for Cuba, and as soon as she arrived off that island, the American captain with a portion of his crew left her, and a Spanish captain and crew went on board and took the vessel in charge.

abstract: -- One morning last week the wife of JOHN BUTLER was found in the Rondout Creek. At first it was thought to be a case of accidental drowning, but during the Coroner's investigation the evidence of a girl of ten years of age, named MARY ANN VAUGHN, renders it pretty conclusive that she has been murdered by her husband. It appears that BUTLER, who lives near Wilbur, just below the Washington Company's ice-houses, on Sunday evening had some friends from Rondout at his house, and after an evening of drinking, singing and dancing, he and his wife went, about 10 P.M., part of the way to the village with their guests. The party stopped at FLANNERY's grocery, where JOHN and one of his friends drank; went then some two hundred yards, where the company parted, JOHN and his victim turning homeward again. The villain contrived to lead his wife to the dock at the South Rondout ferry slip, evidently to get her overboard, and eventually drown her. This he accomplished, though not without a struggle in the water, whither she probably dragged him, as there is the mark of a blow on her upper lip, and of his grip on the body of the poor creature. He then went home, took off his wet clothes, concealed them where they were found by the Coronor, went to bed and slept till morning. His hat was afterwards found near the ferry slip. BUTLER worked for one of the ice companies, and has resided thereabouts for some years. His wife was 29 years of age, and leaves three children. It is said that they lived unhappily together, and that BUTLER had frequently threatened to do her violence. Sheriff DEYO has offered a reward of $50 for the arrest of BUTLER.

abstract: The  accomplished American gentleman who writes the editorials of the British organ in this City, the Albion, is in an unhappy frame of mind. He has learned that three copies of each leading American newspaper have been ordered for Queen VICTORIA. These newspapers contain reports of the Prince's visit.
lead_paragraph: The accomplished American gentleman who writes the editorials of the British organ in this City, the Albion, is in an unhappy frame of mind. He has learned that three copies of each leading American newspaper have been ordered for Queen VICTORIA. These newspapers contain reports of the Prince's visit. The Queen's object is to ascertain how that event has been treated by our daily Press; and from the style of that treatment American journalism will be judged abroad. The crisis appals our sensitive neighbor by its importance and by his apprehensions that American journalism will not survive it. The Press has an opportunity, he says, to "turn the fair side to London;" -- and yet, he is horrified to say we haven't done it. We have treated the Prince with too little reverence. We have mentioned the most trivial circumstances, and have put big head-lines to our reports. Jenkins has been flippant, libelous, mousing, sarcastic, destitute of "gentle breeding," and utterly lacking in an appreciation of the occasion. And so our British-American friend bewails the unhappy condition of the American Press, and deplores the ill repute into which it will fall when it reaches England.

abstract: This Match took place at Bedford, L.I, Monday, and resulted in favor of Sadler, who is an old single-wickle player, his style of batting beating Brett's best efforts to take his wicket, by his plan of giving out at good length [???]lls many of which passed him. He also put up any cumber of catches for a full match. In his score of 23 were seven wides, 4 doubles and singles, got by good leg hits and drives and dashing play. He received 180 balls from Brett, who was bowled by him in the first innings' on the thirteenth ball. A drinking tent was erected, and drinking and betting were going on during the match, which practice is well calculated to bring Cricket into disrepute.

abstract: The doors of that social temple of Janus, the Academy of Music, are once more open; the truce of the Summer is over, and the war of the "world" is once more begun.
lead_paragraph: The doors of that social temple of Janus, the Academy of Music, are once more open; the truce of the Summer is over, and the war of the "world" is once more begun. Asain the small peddlers of Fourteenth-street cry themselves hoarse with tempting offers of "books of the operer, Eytalian and English;" again the venders of perennial bouquets besiege the lobby; again the sons, and daughters of fashion in complete panoply resume the tournament of ton. The formal inauguration of the "season" took place last night with due solemnity.

abstract: The brilliant results of the harvest, and of the yet ungathered crops, not only manifest themselves in the money and stock markets, but lend unprecedented activity to all departments of business.
lead_paragraph: The brilliant results of the harvest, and of the yet ungathered crops, not only manifest themselves in the money and stock markets, but lend unprecedented activity to all departments of business. The Fall trade has opened with the utmost animation. Strangers, anticipating the return of fashionable New-York, are in possession of the City, -- thronging the streets and the stores, testing the capacity of our hotels and places of amusement; and buying and seeing with attentive vigor, and with a desirable economy of time. In expectation of this state of affairs, it is understood that our merchants have made the most liberal preparations. The stocks laid in by jobbers have been larger than in any previous year. Great attention has been paid to the selection and elaboration of the finer articles of dry goods; and, if luxury and self-indulgence be not balked by some unlooked-for reverse, we may expect to see the reign of extravagance which preceded and was temporarily checked by the revulsion of 1857, resumed with augmented sway during the forthcoming season. It is so easy to unlearn the lessons of experience.

abstract: TURNVEREIN FESTIVAL.-The German Turnverein Society of Jersey City celebrated their fourth anniversary yesterday by a pic-nic and festival in Hudson City, which was attended by several similar associations from New-York, Hoboken, Newark and Paterson, together with a large number of their friends. The Greenville Guard, a section of the Hud
lead_paragraph: TURNVEREIN FESTIVAL.-The German Turnverein Society of Jersey City celebrated their fourth anniversary yesterday by a pic-nic and festival in Hudson City, which was attended by several similar associations from New-York, Hoboken, Newark and Paterson, together with a large number of their friends. The Greenville Guard, a section of the Hudson County Artillery, and the German-American School of Jersey City, also accompanied them and marched in procession to the grounds. Here the day was passed in singing, dancing, athletic feats, hearing an address, and the presentation of an elegantly-wrought silk flag to the Turners from their lady-friends in Jersey City. The day passed pleasantly and all appeared to enjoy themselves to the utmost.

abstract: The wife of a compositor in St. Louis surprised her husband a few days ago. He gave her $300 to defray the expenses of a visit which she was desirous of making to her friends in this City. Some days elapsed without his hearing anything of her arrival here, and he became so thoroughly convinced that something was wrong, that he put the case in the hands of a detective. Inquiry satisfied the officer that the woman had gone no further than Cairo, and after searching St. Louis for a day or two, he discovered her domiciled with a well-known merchant. The injured husband was at once informed, and in company with the officer paid his faithless wife a visit. What passed between them is not known, but the woman persisted in clinging to her paramour.

abstract: Some days ago an article appeared in the World, and has since been copied into the columns of several papers, purporting to be a European criticism of certain etymologies in Worcester's Dictionary. The anonymous writer of this may be a European, for there can be found Europeans as well as Americans who would write such an article. We strongly suspect, from the tone of the piece, and from his evident want of a real knowledge of the subject he is struggling with, that the writer is some nameless literary hack hired to make this ferocious assault. Certainly no scholar would have written such an article.

abstract: The sorrows of JOBSON, known for some time in New-York as DAVID WEMYSS "of that ilk," appear to have reached a climax. On the 16th of August, JOBSON was brought up for the last time in the London Central Criminal Court, and was found guilty of libeling the character of Sir JAMES FURGURSON, an Ex-Lieutenant of the Guards, and a present M.P. for Ayrshire. Sir JAMES fought with his regiment at Alma and Inkermann, and, after a year's service, returned home to his parliamentary duties. JOBSON, in a series of letters to Sir JAMES and Lady EDITH, his wife, charged the former with cowardice in the presence of the enemy, and gave this as his motive for leaving the Crimea. The trial of JOBSON was remarkable, from the fact that some of the most eminent men in England were summoned as witnesses, and appear to have been questioned, and cross-questioned by the defendant with extraordinary latitude. The following scene is one among others that occurred:

abstract: There are those in this City who have cogent reasons, though they are exceedingly unsatisfactory to themselves, for not "going into the country" this season. There are several hundred thousand of such ...
lead_paragraph: There are those in this City who have cogent reasons, though they are exceedingly unsatisfactory to themselves, for not "going into the country" this season. There are several hundred thousand of such people, and they are the bone and sinew of the Metropolis. And they all -- or at least a very large portion of them -- are firm believers in the absolute necessity of a change of scene and air, and relaxation from business during the hottest months, to a continuance of the health and strength required for the successful performance of their duties during the remainder of the year. To this vast multitude the various parks and other well-wooded grounds, within an hour's travel from the densely populated portions of the City, offer an irresistible attraction. Every day in the week, and most of all on Sundays, these parks and "gardens" are crowded.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail, when considerable routine business was disposed of, as well as other business of more general interest.
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail, when considerable routine business was disposed of, as well as other business of more general interest. The matter pertaining to a County Court House was called up, and made the special order for consideration at the next meeting. In the meantime the duty is devolved upon a special committee to report at the same meeting as to the condition of the property purchased by the county several years ago on Vanderbilt-avenue, for a site for a Court House.

abstract: The attempt to prove Mr. LINCOLN a radical Abolitionist, which was so eagerly entered upon at the outset of the canvass, seems to lag.
lead_paragraph: The attempt to prove Mr. LINCOLN a radical Abolitionist, which was so eagerly entered upon at the outset of the canvass, seems to lag. It is getting to be decidedly up-hill work. Even the Herald, the longest-winded trumpeter of the tribe, falters, and shows signs of exhaustion. That reliable exponent of history and constitutional law, started with the assertion that Mr. LINCOLN was pledged to liberate all the slaves by writ of habeas corpus; -- but as even the slaveholders did not seem to be greatly startled by this prospect, it has pitched its tune upon a somewhat lower key. Mr. BUCHANAN's other organ at Washington is somewhat more guarded in the positions it assumes, but its general drift is the same, -- to hold up the Republican candidate as belonging to the radical Anti-Slavery wing of the Republican Party, and as pledged, if elected, to make vigorous and effective war upon the institution of Slavery by all the agencies which his office may put in his hands.
headline: {'main': 'Lincoln and Slavery Conservatism of the Republican Candidate.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lincoln and Slavery Conservatism of the Republican Candidate.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: JNO. F. LEWIS, of the town of Penfield, was arrested on Tuesday night, by Deputy Sheriff PIERCE, of Rochester, upon a warrant issued by Police ...
lead_paragraph: JNO. F. LEWIS, of the town of Penfield, was arrested on Tuesday night, by Deputy Sheriff PIERCE, of Rochester, upon a warrant issued by Police Justice BARDWELL, on the 27th day of August. It sets forth that "upon the oath of WILLIAM VAN ANTWERP, one JOHN F. LEWIS, at the town of Parma, in the County of Monroe, on the 17th day of July, 1860, did marry and take to wife, one ALICE VAN ANTWERP, well knowing that the said ALICE was a married woman and the wife of one WM. VAN ANTWERP." Mr. LEWIS, the defendant in this affair, was engaged in the nursery business in Penfield, and had hired VAN ANTWERP to sell fruit-trees at the West. While the latter was away from home he received letters informing him that all was not as it should be, and urging him to return immediately. He did so and found his wife living at home with her children, but he was satisfied that she had been unfaithful, and availed himself of her temporary absence from the house, to search for letters and documents, which he had good reason to think that he could find. At length he discovered in the bottom of a bonnet box, beneath a piece of newspaper, letters which had passed between his wife and Mr. Lewis, and a certificate that she had been married to him on the 17th of July 1860, by Rev. ELISHA SAWYER of Parma. This he considered sufficient evidence on which to found a complaint, and MR. LEWIS was arrested, as is stated above, and held to bail to answer a charge of seduction at the Oyer and Terminer. Some think that MRS. VAN ANTWERP expected soon to remove to Texas with her new husband, and others, that LEWIS thought no action for seduction could be sustained, if he went through the form of marrying the woman.
headline: {'main': 'An Unfaithful Wife.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Unfaithful Wife.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Matter of Fanny Krugg. -- This was a writ of habeas corpus, now returnable before Justice INGRAHAM, at Chambers of the Supreme Court. The application was made to obtain the custody of a female child, five years of age, and claimed to be of illegitimate birth. The relator claimed that the father of the child, Louis Ephraim, was an improper person to have the care of it, and that he treated it in a cruel manner. These charges were denied by Ephraim, who averred that the child was born in wedlock.

abstract: -- Quite a little excitement was created in New-Orleans a few days ago, by the strange freaks of a lunatic. He managed to mount to the top of a two-story grocery and began to amuse himself by pulling bricks from the chimney, breaking them with a hatchet and then hurling them at the passers-by. After he had continued this sport for some hours a great crowd collected in the vicinity, and it became a very interesting problem to the Policemen how they should remove the madman from his peril. Finally, one of the fire companies brought its engine to the spot and directed a powerful stream upon him. So surprised was he at this novel mode of attack that he lost his foot-hold, slid down the roof and came to the ground in a sitting posture. Before he had recovered from the effects of the jar he was in custody.

abstract: The Public Schools of the City were reopened yesterday, after a vacation of five weeks, and a large proportion of them presented a full attendance.
lead_paragraph: The Public Schools of the City were reopened yesterday, after a vacation of five weeks, and a large proportion of them presented a full attendance. The Fifteenth, Sixteenth, Eighteenth, Twentieth and Twenty-first Wards showed less than the average number of scholars, many of the children of these localties not having yet returned from their rural excursions. During the vacation just closed, the various school buildings have undergone thorough repairs, while several have been enlarged. For this purpose, various appropriations have been made by the Board of Education, amounting in the total to $37,339. Several new buildings are also in course of erection at various points of the City, for which appropriations have been made amounting to $154,000. Among these, that in course of erection for Ward School No. 14, located on East Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth streets, deserves notice, in view of its peculiar structure as a model school building. It will be the largest school building in the City, and is to be fitted up with all modern improvements; the total cost of which will be $54,000. It will be "fire proof," having floors of cast-iron beams, filled in with brick arches and concealed. It was commenced a year ago, and will be ready for use in May next. The following school buildings have undergone repairing, painting, &c., and were opened yesterday:

abstract: GERMAN FESTIVALS, Amongst the various German Festivals which took place yesterday, the following three were the most prominent: The first in rank ...
lead_paragraph: GERMAN FESTIVALS, Amongst the various German Festivals which took place yesterday, the following three were the most prominent: The first in rank was the Summernights Festival of the German Liederkranz, at Conrad's Yorkville Park. The Park and the spacious platform in front of the hotel were decorated and illuminated. There was a concert, both of vocal and instrumental music, fireworks and various other amusements. In the morning the Social Reformers turned out in great numbers, together with their wives and children, numbering about 7,000 or 8,000, to participate in the festival arranged for the presentation of a new banner; handsomely-embroidered by Mrs. FRANCES KLEIN. The banner represents on one side the Goddess of Liberty, with the inscriptions, "Liberty, Equality and Fraternity," and below, "E Pluribus Unum." On the other side is represented an eagle holding the American shield, surrounded by a wreath of oak-leaves, with the inscription, "Presented to the Social Reformers by the Ladies, Sept. 3, 1860." The presentation was accompanied by speeches by the ladies presenting the banner, and the gentlemen receiving the same. The oration of the day was delivered by Mr. ROEDEL. The third festival was at Landmann's Hamilton Park, for the benefit of the St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum, and was also largely attended.

abstract: The Councilmen last night did not touch the Japanese bill. The reason, we believe, was that the Committee to which it was re  ferred have not yet considered the matter.
lead_paragraph: The Councilmen last night did not touch the Japanese bill. The reason, we believe, was that the Committee to which it was re ferred have not yet considered the matter. We suggest that they lose no time in doing so. The LELANDS are impatient, and reasonably so, for their pay. If they have incurred the expenses alleged, they are entitled to their money. There is neither sense nor justice in keeping them out of it any longer.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board yesterday, the resignation of Patrolman BUTTERFIELD, of the Twenty-third Precinct, was accepted, and a report from the Superintendendent of the House of Detention for Witnesses, showing that the current expenses of the establishment for the past month amounted to $389 50, was received. Sergeant LORD, among his other sanitary recommendations, urged that a family, consisting of BRINGET TRACY, her two sons, nineteen pigs, two horses, three goats and two dogs, who lived harmoniously at No. 323 West Twenty-eighth-street, should be broken up, and their domicil receive a visit from the scavengers. The recommendation was adopted and the Board adjourned.

abstract: -It is some months  since JOHN BROWN, Jr., applied to President GEFFBARD for some account of the enthusiastic subscription of the Haytians in behalf of his father's family. The subscription having been closed, the entire fund is found to be $184.50.
lead_paragraph: --It is some months since JOHN BROWN, Jr., applied to President GEFFBARD for some account of the enthusiastic subscription of the Haytians in behalf of his father's family. The subscription having been closed, the entire fund is found to be $184.50. The sum does not, even at first sight impress the reader with a sense of its magnitude and liberality; but when we add that the dollars in question are of the Haytian paper currency, each worth no more than six American cents; and that the grand total is actually only eleven dollars and seven cents, the splendor of this national testimonial may be realized.
