abstract: The threatening attitude of Austria in the presence of GARIBALDI and the Neapolitan revolution proves, as we have believed from the first it would prove, to be simply a sort of cave canem affixed to the frontier line of Venetia. The much trumpeted "note to Count CAVOUR" is still to be sent, and Austria, in spite of Toplitz interviews and Salzburg hob-nobbings, has too little faith in Prussian loyalty and Bavarian might, to risk herself on a sortie of intervention south of the Po.
lead_paragraph: The threatening attitude of Austria in the presence of GARIBALDI and the Neapolitan revolution proves, as we have believed from the first it would prove, to be simply a sort of cave canem affixed to the frontier line of Venetia. abstract: We published yesterday a telegraphic dispatch from New-Orleans, announcing that a battle had taken place at Lagos, between DEGOLLADO and MIRAMON. After five days of hard fighting, the latter is reported to have been totally routed, and to have fled, leaving his artillery and such of his army as remained, in the hands of his antagonists. If true, this news is the most important we have chronicled from Mexico since that of the defeat and retreat of MIRAMON before Vera Cruz in April last.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a telegraphic dispatch from New-Orleans, announcing that a battle had taken place at Lagos, between DEGOLLADO and MIRAMON. abstract: Two Judges of the Supreme Court in this district have within the last few days given directly contradictory expositions of the law regarding vagrants. In other words, Judge SUTHERLAND has given a definition of the word "vagrant," which takes prostitutes and divers other persons of foul or unlawful callings out of that category, while Judge INGRAHAM defines...
lead_paragraph: Two Judges of the Supreme Court in this district have within the last few days given directly contradictory expositions of the law regarding vagrants. In other words, Judge SUTHERLAND has given a definition of the word "vagrant," which takes prostitutes and divers other persons of foul or unlawful callings out of that category, while Judge INGRAHAM defines it in such manner as to include them. The result is to place the Police and Police Magistrates in this City in such total uncertainty as to the exact state of the law with regard to a very important portion of their duties, as will effectually prevent, for the present at least, all attempts on their part to repress or mitigate one of the worst of the metropolitan nuisances. What makes the matter worse is that both these decisions have been rendered on returns to writs of habeas corpus, and are consequently, we believe, not subject to review; or, if they are, nobody is sufficiently interested in having them reversed to carry them up to any higher tribunal, and the matter must consequently remain as it is for the present.
headline: {'main': 'Legal Inconsistencies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Legal Inconsistencies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SUPREME COURT -- SPECIAL TERM -- BEFORE JUDGE BROWN -- THE PROSPECT HILL PARK ACT. -- Due notice having been given, application was made to this Court yesterday, by E.W. FISK, a Commissioner named in the Prospect Park bill, for the appointment of three Commissioners, as called for in the said act, to estimate and assess the value of land proposed to be taken. Messrs. GILBERT, TAYLOR and REYNOLDS, appeared in behalf of the application and Messrs. SILLIMAN and VAN COTT, in behalf of certain tax-payers, oppose the appointment of Commissioners. The application was opposed for the following principal reasons: The act gives to three irresponsible Commissioners extreme power to expend public money, subjecting a part of the city (Western District) to onerous taxation, while other portions equally or more directly benefited, will not be subjected to such taxation; the act is in violation of the section of the Constitution which declares "that in a local bill not more than one subject shall be embraced and that it shall be clearly expressed in its title, and this act is vitiated on this ground; first, because it provides for the laying out of a Park; second, for a parade-ground; and third, alteration of the Commissioners' map. The act also embraces other subjects in no way indicated in the title, viz.:

abstract: One of those  chronic spasms of activity to which our Police Department is subject, occurred yesterday. Superintendent KENNEDY mustered a strong force of his officers, dispensing with the usual indications of their business, and suddenly dispersing them over the region southward of Canal-street, succeeded in capturing one hundred persons, who were carried to the Lower Police Court.
lead_paragraph: One of those chronic spasms of activity to which our Police Department is subject, occurred yesterday. Superintendent KENNEDY mustered a strong force of his officers, dispensing with the usual indications of their business, and suddenly dispersing them over the region southward of Canal-street, succeeded in capturing one hundred persons, who were carried to the Lower Police Court. The seizure seems to have been indiscriminate. It was left entirely to the policeman to select his captive; and, while it is possible that a majority of the arrests were of the ill-defined class of vagrants, it is almost certain that numbers wholly unentitled to that distinction must have been taken.

abstract: MARINE LOSSES FOR AUGUST. -- The Underwriters? losses for August have been smaller than any previous month this year. The average monthly losses in 1859 were over $3,000,000; this month they are less than $1,000,000. In August, 1859, they were $3,214,300; in August, 1860, they are $956,301, or only about 30 per cent. In no other corresponding month was there any such variation. Should so remarkable a decrease be shown the next few months, the change could only be attributed to the fact that advanced rates of freight had removed the temptation to make foul losses. The wrecks this month have been 4 steamers, 10 ships, 11 barks, 12 brigs, and 14 schooners. Value of cargoes, $462,400; vessel and freight, $493,900. The losses this year have been:

abstract: The adjourned game played between these clubs at Elysian Fields resulted yesterday (Tuesday) in another tie -- the first game standing 25 and 25. It is rather singular that the Gothams have tied in four games this season -- one with the Jeffersons stood 13 and 13, and one with the Eagles stood 18 and 18. Gotham plays the Eagles again on the 11th inst. The game was played in the presence of a large number of persons, with the most perfect good temper.

abstract: The steamship Palestine passed Father Point yesterday morning on her way to Quebec, having left Liverpool on the 23d, and Londonderry on the 24th ult. Her advices are consequently one day later than those by the City of Manchester, published yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Palestine passed Father Point yesterday morning on her way to Quebec, having left Liverpool on the 23d, and Londonderry on the 24th ult. Her advices are consequently one day later than those by the City of Manchester, published yesterday morning. It is reasserted, on the authority of a letter from Vienna, that a threatening note from Austria, on the subject of the Garibaldi expedition, would shortly be forwarded to the Court of Turin. It is also announced, on semi-official authority, that Russia is concentrating fresh troops in Bessarabia, and increasing her naval forces in the Mediterranean. The Duke of Modena, one of the petty sovereigns deposed by the will of the people, who preferred living under the rule of VICTOR EMANUEL, is reported to be raising volunteers, and purchasing horses, probably with a view of regaining his lost dominions should a favorable opportunity occur -- a contingency, however, which is hardly to be looked for. The suggestions made by Prussia for the reorganization of the army of the German Confederation, are strongly opposed by the minor German States, who refuse to abdicate so much of their sovereign power as would be rendered necessary in case the proposition should be carried into effect. Advices from China to June 29 are received. Lord ELGIN and Baron GROS had arrived at Shanghai, which was still protected by the Allies, in view of the expected descent of the rebels. Trade with the interior was entirely suspended. Hostilities had not yet commenced at the Pei-ho.

abstract: GARIBALDI has gone away on a reconnoissance, it is supposed some say to Palermo. It is very probable that both stories are true; at all events one fact is certain, the Dictator went on board one of the steamers, the Washington, and crossing to about mid-way in the strait, very leisurely reconnoitered the coast. He has always a glass in his hands.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the London News.

abstract: The friends of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE attempted to organize a club in Hartford on Saturday evening, and according to the report in the Hartford Courant had a happy time of it. Mr. W.W. EATON presided, and Mr. BURR, of the Times, offered the resolutions.
lead_paragraph: The friends of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE attempted to organize a club in Hartford on Saturday evening, and according to the report in the Hartford Courant had a happy time of it. Mr. W.W. EATON presided, and Mr. BURR, of the Times, offered the resolutions. Mr. EATON was called on for a speech, and he attempted to comply with the wishes of his friends, but Mr. STEPHEN ROPER persisted in asking impertinent questions until Mr. ISAAC N. BOLLES invited him to behave himself, politely informing him at the same time that he was "a puppy," "a fool," " a leatherhead." Mr. EATON called the meeting to order, but the more he called the more it wouldn't come. Finally, Mr. HAMERSLEY succeeded in informing Mr. ROPER that the meeting had been called by the friends of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, and that if he desired to speak as one of that class he would be heard. Mr. ROPER said he would spake as a "Dimmychrat." Mr. HAMERSLEY asked the meeting if it would hear Mr. ROPER. The meeting said no in an enthusiastic manner, when Mr. HAMERSLEY said Mr. ROPER could not speak. Mr. ROPER said very well, and started to go out. The crowd hissed. Mr. ROPER turned and said to his countrymen who were engaged in the business, "Hiss Arrishmen, Hiss." The storm increased in violence and he returned to his seat, and resumed it. A Breckinridge man resumed it with him, and calling him by no very endearing name said, "Mr. ROPER had got to keep still now." Mr. ROPER didn't see it so. His Breckinridge friend showed it to him by blacking his eye. Mr. ROPER stepped to the Chairman to show his eclipsed, vision, when Mr. BURR took ROPER by the nape of the neck and put him down the stairs. As ROPER left the room he told his Breckinridge friend that he'd call round and see him about that eye some other time. The rowdy having been disposed of, Mr. HAMERSLEY made a speech and the meeting went on without further disturbance. About 175 names were enrolled on the club book.

abstract: The public are more than usually curious to-day about the movements of GARIBALDI. The Dictator suddenly left Messina eight days ago, after addressing the citizens of the town a speech on the necessity of harmonious and energetic action in order to maintain the liberty they had acquired. It has been asserted and denied that during this time he has been at Naples.

abstract: THE WEST-WASHINGTON MARKET CASE NoTICE OF THE CORPORATION ATTORNEY. Judge BRONSON, the Corporation Attorney, has caused a notice to be served upon MARCELLUS EELS, the Collector of rents for Messrs. TAYLOR  BRENNAN, upon the West Washington Market property, not to collect any more rents, and that if he should persist in doing so, he would be arrested by attachment for disobeying the order of the Court.
lead_paragraph: THE WEST-WASHINGTON MARKET CASE NoTICE OF THE CORPORATION ATTORNEY. Judge BRONSON, the Corporation Attorney, has caused a notice to be served upon MARCELLUS EELS, the Collector of rents for Messrs. TAYLOR BRENNAN, upon the West Washington Market property, not to collect any more rents, and that if he should persist in doing so, he would be arrested by attachment for disobeying the order of the Court. A portion of the tenants have paid Mr. TAYLOR, and another portion the City Collector, but it is now generally agreed among the tenants of this property, that they will best consult their interests by refusing to pay rent to either party until the further action of the Courts.

abstract: A very, important movement was yesterday inaugurated by the General Superintendent of Police, having for its object the suppression of professional mendicancy. For a long time the business of street-begging has been permitted to prosper, without the least effort on the part of the authorities to prevent it, and it had grown into an evil of proportions so gigantic that scarcely a street in the City has been free from the presence of the creatures whose importunacy offended the busy and whose misery saddened the re[???]ecting portion of the community. In view of this state of facts, coupled with a generally-expressed desire that some action should be taken in the premises, an order was issued on Monday night, from the Police Head-quarters, directing the Captains of the various Police Precincts, excepting these of the Eleventh, Twelfth, Nineteenth and Twenty-second, to have their respective commands in readiness at 11 o'clock A.M. yesterday, to carry out a plan of operations that had already been formed, by which the apprehension of a vast number of the offenders would be effected. The Eleventh and other three wards mentioned as not participating in the foray, were excluded, as the former is the abiding place of a large proportion of the vagrants, who never ply their vocation so near their domiciles, and the others, which, comparatively speaking, are sparsely populated, are not greatly troubled with the presence of vagabonds. The order specified that the Police were to be mustered in plain clothes, but the business upon which they were to enter was kept a secret, not even the Captains, many of whom could scarcely restrain their curiosity within decent bounds, being informed of its meaning. But anxiety was in due time relieved. Promptly at the hour named directions were simultaneously transmitted throughout the City, by telegraph, to send each officer upon his ordinary post for the purpose of arresting every beggar, vagrant and idler, regardless of age or sex, that he might meet. The officers entered with spirit and energy upon their work, and disguised as they were, the unwary objects of their attention fell easy victims into their hands. In a remarkably short space of time the several Police Courts were crowded with the prisoners, but it being "recess hour," the magistrates and clerks were absent at luncheon, consequently some delay was caused before a commencement was made in the disposition of the cases. No blame, however, can be attached to the Justices on this account, as they were all taken by surprise, and locked in blank amazement at the motley [???]orde which greeted them upon their return to Court.

abstract: R.H. SMART, the well-known English Elocutionist and Lexicographer, under date of London,  Aug. 7, 1860, writes: "I have examined as far as time has permitted the splendid volume you did me the honor to transmit last week the Pictorial Edition of Webster's Dictionary, unabridged, 1859. Take it all together, it must be considered, in America, at least, as the surpassing work of its kind.
lead_paragraph: R.H. SMART, the well-known English Elocutionist and Lexicographer, under date of London, Aug. 7, 1860, writes: "I have examined as far as time has permitted the splendid volume you did me the honor to transmit last week the Pictorial Edition of Webster's Dictionary, unabridged, 1859. Take it all together, it must be considered, in America, at least, as the surpassing work of its kind. I say in America, because Webster's name no doubt there carries an authority with it which our English public are not willing to yield when difference of opinion or practice exists -- e.g., in the spelling of honour, favour, etc. I must at the same time acknowledge there is great consistency in Webster's practice, and that if it could be enforced here, as I understand it is in America by the greater force of his name, our common language would be liberated from many of its inconsistencies."

abstract: The advantage to France of having a telegraphic cable laid down between her own coasts and those of the United States, is pointed out by the Constitutionnel, in an article which directs attention to the principal conditions of the convention passed between the Minister, of the Interior and the Company represented by MM. abstract: A large and enthusiastic meeting of "Citizens of the Ninth Ward in favor of the Union Electoral Ticket," was held at the Bleecker Building last evening, pursuant to call which announced among the speakers who would address the meeting, Hon. HIRAM KETCHUM, Hon. A.K. HADLEY, SAMUEL HALLETT and ELI P. NORTON.
lead_paragraph: A large and enthusiastic meeting of "Citizens of the Ninth Ward in favor of the Union Electoral Ticket," was held at the Bleecker Building last evening, pursuant to call which announced among the speakers who would address the meeting, Hon. HIRAM KETCHUM, Hon. A.K. HADLEY, SAMUEL HALLETT and ELI P. NORTON. This list of orators, combined with the more noisy attractions of a brass band, which aroused the neighborhood for blocks around with its patriotic blasts, drew together a collection of Ninth Warders which quite filled the large hall, and must have numbered five hundred persons.

abstract: Those who have had occasion to pass the TIMES Buildings during a few days past, will have noticed a new occupant in the commodious promises adjoining the publication office of this paper, and extending from No. 41 Park-row through to No. 151 Nassau-st. The American Agriculturist, now closing up its nineteenth year, has deserted its ancient habitation among the agricultural warehouse's on Water-street, and taken up its abode for the next ten years, at least, in the very centre of the great newspaper establishments of the City that have for some time past been concentrating around "Printing-House-square." The eminent success of the American Agriculturist, which now counts its 50,000 subscribers, while due in part to the correct policy of the publisher, viz. -- to get up the best possible paper without regard to expense, and hen to make it widely known by liberal advertising -- is an indication of the greatly-increased desire on the part of cultivators for information upon the best methods of tilling the soil. The present circulation of the Agriculturist, it may be remarked, is greater than that of the entire agricultural press only a few years ago. When this journal started there were but two or three agricultural papers in existence; the agricultural journals now number full forty.

abstract: Shortly after 1 o'clock, on Monday night, two young ruffians, named John Hughes and Jeremiah O'Brien, entered the oyster saloon, kept by Robert Hyde, at No. 70 Vandam-street, and demanded "fries." Confident that he would not receive pay if the bivalves were furnished, Hyde refused to furnish them, whereupon Hughes seized the money-drawer and fled, followed by his companion O'Brien. The fugitives were pursued by Hyde, who called "Police," and Officer Van Cleef, of the Eighth Precinct, having joined in the chase, soon overtook and arrested them. Hughes had thrown the money-drawer away in his fight, and it was picked up in Hudson-street with its contents intact. Justice QUACKENBUH, before whom the prisoners were taken, committed them each in default of $1,000 bail to answer for the larceny.

abstract: The speech of Gov. SEWARD, delivered at Detroit, on the threshold of the Great West, will be found in other columns. The orator, recurring to the early history of Slavery as affiliated with politics, traces its relations with successive partisan organizations; demonstrating that its encroachments commenced with the failure of parties to sustain their leaders in opposing its pretensions, and attained their present inordinate and arrogant proportions through active offensive alliances with an ambitious and reckless partisanship. The only term to be placed to its advances, Mr. SEWARD pronounces to be the election to the Presidency of a statesman like Mr. LINCOLN, who can command the support of a powerful party in defending the Constitutional landmarks; and while expressing confidence in this event, he scorns the idea that any dangers, disasters, or calamities will befal the Union as consequences of its occurrence.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last night, the Committee on Normal Schools having resolved that it would be expedient to reduce the force of Normal School teachers, dismissed four teachers, the dismissal to date from the 1st of September.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Education, last night, the Committee on Normal Schools having resolved that it would be expedient to reduce the force of Normal School teachers, dismissed four teachers, the dismissal to date from the 1st of September. Their action came up for approval, when Mr. WATERBURY offered a resolution disapproving of their action and annulling the same. He stated that the Committee had no power to dismiss the teachers. The resolution, he said, was not acted upon by a full committee.

abstract: The Emperor had made a speech at Lyons in response to addresses by the authorities. He condemned the unjust distrust excited abroad, and declared that nothing should make him deviate from the path of moderation and justice.
lead_paragraph: The Emperor had made a speech at Lyons in response to addresses by the authorities. He condemned the unjust distrust excited abroad, and declared that nothing should make him deviate from the path of moderation and justice. His sole desire was the general interest of France, and he urged them to give themselves up with confidence to works of peace. He was determined, with God's assistance, that France should not degenerate under his dynasty.

abstract: With the completion of their State ticket the Republicans have entered into the campaign in earnest. Hon. JOHN A. ANDREWS, the nominee for Governor, was serenaded by his friends at North Hingham on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: With the completion of their State ticket the Republicans have entered into the campaign in earnest. Hon. JOHN A. ANDREWS, the nominee for Governor, was serenaded by his friends at North Hingham on Monday evening. The address which he made, acknowledging the compliment, was almost entirely local in its character. On Saturday evening the Republicans of North Adams ratified the State ticket. Hon. HENRY L. DAWES, one of the prominent candidates for the Gubunatorial nomination, made a long speech. He wondered that he had been thought worthy, not of so few, but of so many votes, in the late Convention. The ticket, as it stands, was eminently worthy the support of all Republicane. Mr. DAWES discussed national politics at some length, claiming that Slavery was now and would continue to be the issue until limits should be set to its existence. At a meeting held in Boston on Monday evening, Senator WILSON promised to discuss the position of the Bell Party at an early day.

abstract: While kings, kaisers and newspaper correspondents are discussing the proprieties of diplomatic interference with the subversive operations of GARIBALDI, and contriving pleasant devices for keeping Naples free under the Bourbon dynasty, the steady march of events is making all their wisdom idle and all their schemes ridiculous. On the 21st of August the advanced guard of the liberating army of Sicily made themselves masters of the important...
lead_paragraph: While kings, kaisers and newspaper correspondents are discussing the proprieties of diplomatic interference with the subversive operations of GARIBALDI, and contriving pleasant devices for keeping Naples free under the Bourbon dynasty, the steady march of events is making all their wisdom idle and all their schemes ridiculous. On the 21st of August the advanced guard of the liberating army of Sicily made themselves masters of the important town and fortifications of Reggio, on the mainland, commanding from the cast the same straits which Messina watches from the west. Once established at Reggio, GARIBALDI held Naples in his hand, to be won or lost by a single decisive effort, and it is more than probable that the miserable FRANCIS II. is at this moment safely housed in some one of the many palatial mansions of his hospitable cousin of Austria. The English Premier, in the House of Commons, has officially declared that Austria will occupy for the present an attitude of strict neutrality, and there can be no reason for supposing that the formal annexation of the entire Neapolitan Kingdom to the Sardinian crown will encounter any foreign obstacles half so troublesome as the domestic difficulties by which GARIBALDI, after taking up his victorious abode at Caserta, will find his tact and his talents more sorely tried than they ever yet have been.

abstract: -- A few days ago a Washington correspondent of the TIMES exposed very sharply and severely the alleged misconduct of Mr. War-Secretary FLOYD in connection with certain canceled contracts. The gist of the accusation brought against this official was, that he had willfully awarded to at least one contractor a large sum of money to which he was wholly unentitled. A more damning accusation against a public man of high position could not be asked for by his bitterest political enemy. Yet the closest political friend of the War-Secretary and of his chief, Mr. BUCHANAN; (we mean, of course, the New-York Herald,) could find no better defence for its protege than a virtual confession of the Secretary's ill-behavior, coupled with the mitigating hypothesis that if Mr. FLOYD had been a Republican he would probably have wasted twice as much of the public money.

abstract: POLITICAL MATTERS. -- The Republican General Committee have ordered the primary meetings to be held in the several Wards and towns embraced within the limits of Kings County, on the evening of the 17th inst. abstract: The Prince of Wales has, for the first time, met with an unpleasant check in his progress through America. The Royal party, for reasons which every right thinking person will appreciate, declined to land in Kingston on Tuesday, and thus openly signified their determination to discountenance a demonstration of a partisan and offensive character.
lead_paragraph: The Prince of Wales has, for the first time, met with an unpleasant check in his progress through America. The Royal party, for reasons which every right thinking person will appreciate, declined to land in Kingston on Tuesday, and thus openly signified their determination to discountenance a demonstration of a partisan and offensive character. An Irish Protestant organization, widely known as the "Orange Society," had erected characteristic arches, mottoes, and insignia in the streets of Kingston, and, upon the arrival of the Prince, they proposed to march, in procession, with banners and badges that one-half of the population would have considered an insult to themselves and to their faith. In these circumstances the Prince very properly refused to land or to sanction in any manner this barbaric display.
headline: {'main': 'The Prince and the Orangemen.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Prince and the Orangemen.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. BRECKINRIDGE has at last yielded to the clamor of doubting friends, and confessed himself. The occasion of his utterance was supplied by a barbecue at Lexington, where many thousands assembled yesterday to partake of a savory holocaust, with appetites previously whetted by Vice-Presidential elo- quence.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRECKINRIDGE has at last yielded to the clamor of doubting friends, and confessed himself. The occasion of his utterance was supplied by a barbecue at Lexington, where many thousands assembled yesterday to partake of a savory holocaust, with appetites previously whetted by Vice-Presidential elo- quence. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE was not mindful that his speech preceded, not followed, the dinner. He spoke at much length; omitted none of the counts in the popular indictment; met the most insignificant cavils with elaborate minuteness of response; in short, placed stays and props wherever about his shaky reputation the parts seemed to require strengthening. Whether or not he has succeeded in amending his position before the country, however, is very questionable indeed.

abstract: THE NEW FOURTH-AVENUE CROTON PIPES. -- The history of the progress and delay in the prosecution of the important work of connecting the receiving and distributing reservoirs by four-foot pipes, running through the Fourth-avenue, is familiar to the readers of the TIMES, through the action of the Common Council, and the subsequent correspondence between the Croton Board and the Mayor, all of which have been published at length. The action of the Board of Aldermen, last Monday evening, in non-concurring with the Councilmen in a resolution directing the work heretofore performed by the day to be stopped, and that proposals be advertised for doing it by contract, would seem to justify the Croton Board in proceeding with this most necessary improvement as originally authorized by the Common Council -- i.e., by day work; but the last letter of the Mayor, requesting a suspension of the work until further action of the Common Council, is a stumbling block. The resolution authorizing the prosecution of the work by the day, has never been repealed, the Aldermen refusing to do so; but although the authority to proceed is evidently vested now in the Board, they decline to act until further advised by the Mayor. The laying of these pipes is considered of more importance by the Board than that of the new 7-foot pipe over the High Bridge; for if this work is not completed this Fall, and a large fire should occur during the Winter, it would be impossible, with the present conduits, to supply a sufficient head of water for its extinguishment. The Board will communicate again with the Mayor at an early day, and for the sake of the City, now that the Common Council have refused to act in the premises, it is to be hoped that there will be no further delay.

The laying of these pipes is considered of more importance by the Board than that of the new 7-foot pipe over the High Bridge; for if this work is not completed this Fall, and a large fire should occur during the Winter, it would be impossible, with the present conduits, to supply a sufficient head of water for its extinguishment. abstract: Charles Earle et al. vs. Julius Tode. The defend- ant in this ease is the defaulting agent of an English house, whose exploits have been so much published of late. An application was now made before Justice...
lead_paragraph: Charles Earle et al. vs. Julius Tode. The defend- ant in this ease is the defaulting agent of an English house, whose exploits have been so much published of late. An application was now made before Justice INGRAHAM, at Chambers of the Supreme Court, for an order of arrest and an attachment against the defendant, the plaintiffs alleging that Rudolph Tode had been their agent at St. Petersburgh, and that, having power to substitute, he had substituted the defendant, who was his brother. The defendant had received the proceeds of the sale of a certain steamboat, and decamped with the amount, about $75,000.

abstract: The arrivals from Europe put us in possession of advices four days later. The steamship America, from Liverpool on the 25th and Queenstown on the 26th ult., passed Cape Race on Tuesday afternoon, and was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press.
lead_paragraph: The arrivals from Europe put us in possession of advices four days later. The steamship America, from Liverpool on the 25th and Queenstown on the 26th ult., passed Cape Race on Tuesday afternoon, and was intercepted by the news yacht of the Associated Press. The Prince Albert, from Galway on the 28th, arrived at St. John, N.F., yesterday on her way to New-York. The news by these arrivals is highly important. The invasion of Calabria by GARIBALDI is fully confirmed. In fact, at last accounts, he had already pushed his operations with such vigor that several important positions of the Neapolitans were in his possession. Great numbers of insurgents were joining him, and a general and decisive battle was looked for. It is thought probable in some quarters, however, that Naples may fall into his hands without bloodshed, as it is believed that the Neapolitan army cannot be relied upon at all for its defence. It was positively denied by Lord PALMERSTON in the House of Commons, that Austria either has sent or contemplates sending a threatening note to Sardinia on the subject of the invasion of Naples. Orders have been given by the French Emperor to concentrate troops to the number of 100,000, with all munitions of war, to be ready to march at a moments' notice. The Emperor and Empress had gone to Savoy and Nice. At Lyons, in response to addresses, the Emperor made a speech, in which he deprecated the attempts which had been made to create a misunderstanding as to his motives. The weather in England and France had continued unfavorable for the crops.

abstract: Yesterday the grounds were alive with people. Snug farmers -- the results of whose Summer toil were already arranged there for exhibition, came riding to the fair in all manner of country vehicles, with their families, attired as for a holiday. The roads were thronged with carriages, and the cars arrived every half hour heavily laden. The principal event of the day was the review of the troops who were assembled to compete for a prize to be awarded to the best-drilled. Gov. OLDEN and staff, COL. HALSTEAD, (the President of the Agricultural Society,) and ex-Col. DURYEE, of the New-York Seventh Regiment, were the judges; and before them the military, numbering about three hundred and fifty men, marched and countermarched, manoeuvred and practiced, firing by files and by companies. The commands were given by the sound of the bugle, and were executed with a creditable, degree of precision. Of the companies present, only two were competitors for the prizes, and each of them will receive one. These were a detachment of the Newark battalion, Major SCHALK, and the Washington Rifles, Capt. LUTZ, Brigadier-General WHITEHEAD had command of the entire force. The examination of horses commenced at 2 o'clock P.M. There were no animals of note there, and, so far as we learned, none whose pedigree can be traced back to Bucephalus; yet there were many born of very respectable parents, and some whose relatives have achieved fame and the fortunes of their proprietors. A jet black half-brother of Patchen was very much admired. The best horses of New-Jersey have gone to the National Horse Show at Springfield. The exhibition will be open for two days more. To-day there will be trials of speed, equestrianism and a plowing match. To-morrow the premiums will be announced.

abstract: The first of the two days' races of the Regatta took place at Poughkeepsie yesterday, in presence of an immense concourse of spectators. The distance to be rowed was five miles. The first race was for single scull working boats -- first prize $16, second prize $8, for which there were seven entries, of whom only three started: the Maggie, of New-York; Oregon, Jr., of Hudson; and the H. Genet, of New-York, all 17 feet long. The H. Genet came in first, in 48 minutes 26 seconds, and the Maggie in 49 minutes. The second race was for shell boats, two pair sculls: first prize $40, second prize $20; four entries. Three entered: Endora, of Newburgh, 27 feet, rowed by Gilbert Ward and John Hancon; Fanny, of Newburgh, 31 feet, rowed by Jacob Bartley and W. Sarvis; and the Ultra, of New-York, 31 feet, rowed by Timothy Donohue and David Brown. After a pretty close race for the most of the way, the Ultra won in 38 minutes 26 seconds; the Endora, second, in 38 minutes 36 seconds. The third race was for six-oared boats, which was most exciting, as the crews were from the rival boating head-quarters of Poughkeepsie and Newburgh. The first prize was $100; second prize, $40. The entries were the James McCay, 48 feet, built by James McCay, Brooklyn, and rowed by a Poughkeepsie crew -- W. Stevens, J. Best, Ezehiah Beneway, H. Woodin, D. Leroy and Madison Ezan. The second was the Gersh Bancker, 43 feet, built by Geo. N. Shaw, Newburgh, and rowed by the celebrated Joshua Ward, Chas. H. Sarvis, W.H. Tuttle, Peter Hunt, Wm.B. Marvin and Geo. N. Shaw; contrary to general expectation -- as two to one was bet on Ward's boat -- the James McCay won easily in 32 minutes, 40 seconds. The time of the Gersh Bancker was 33 minutes, 3 seconds. The greatest race takes place to-day -- a two-pair scull race; single scull shell boat race: and four-oared shell boat race.

abstract: James Jay Howard vs. George C. Bennett.  This is an action of libel against the defendant, who is the proprietor of the Williamsburgh Daily Times.
lead_paragraph: James Jay Howard vs. George C. Bennett. This is an action of libel against the defendant, who is the proprietor of the Williamsburgh Daily Times. The action is founded upon a publication respecting the same transaction, for noticing which the NEW-YORK TIMES is sued for libel. The action is brought in the Supreme Court, and now came up in Chambers before Justice INGRAHAM, on a motion for judgment on the frivolousness of the answer. The answer alleged that the matters stated in the article published, were substantially true, and plaintiff's counsel urged that such an averment was frivolous and constituted no defence. Counsel contended that the answer must not only aver that the statement published was true, but set forth the grounds of the belief. The Court so held, and granted the motion.

abstract: We had occasion some days since to make a passing comment upon an opinion recently rendered by Mr. Attorney-General BLACK, to the President, in relation to a joint prayer of the Legislature of California, asking Executive interference in a great suit now pending before the Courts of that State.
lead_paragraph: We had occasion some days since to make a passing comment upon an opinion recently rendered by Mr. Attorney-General BLACK, to the President, in relation to a joint prayer of the Legislature of California, asking Executive interference in a great suit now pending before the Courts of that State. As this opinion, formally put forth by the first law officer of the Government, reached us, nothing apparently could be more plain than the justice of the views which it expressed. We are not commonly given to a blind admiration of the existing Administration, and our readers will bear us witness that we have never exhibited any extravagant tendency to applaud the acts of Mr. BUCHANAN and his Cabinet, on the mere faith of their political position. But it seemed to us so unquestionably correct for the President to reject a petition looking to his intervention in a matter still under judicial examination, that we could not find it in us to refuse our tribute of praise to the soundness of Mr. Attorney-General BLACK's official advice given to the same effect. Still, the importance of the interests at stake in the particular case out of which the necessity had arisen for Judge BLACK to void, and for the President to receive so much legal wisdom, was so singularly illustrated by the extraordinary conduct of the Legislature of California, that we could not refrain from entertaining some doubts as to the absolute recklessness of our Pacific brethren in the premises. The Attorney-General of the United States, even at the close of the term which is conceded to him for the exercise of his talents, is a considerable personage, certainly. But it may fairly be presumed when the people, the Press, and the representatives of a sovereign State unite with scarce a dissenting voice in demanding a special service of the Federal Government, that they are not actuated simply by a mad determination to violate the first principles of social order. A calm inquiry into the circumstances out of which the application of California to the President arose, will prove, we fear, not merely the justice of this presumption, but the exceeding rashness also, to brand it by no harsher name, which has been displayed by the Attorney-General in his whole management of this great case of the New Almaden Mines, which is to fake its place among the imperishable causes celebres of the Western Continent.

abstract: For several months past, Mr. William Boardman, a dealer in wool, at No. 74  Pine-street, has been a heavy loser by the depredations of a gang of thieves upon his stock, and the operations of the rogues have been conducted in so mysterious a way that not until yesterday did the efforts which have been made for their detection result in their arrest.
lead_paragraph: For several months past, Mr. William Boardman, a dealer in wool, at No. 74 Pine-street, has been a heavy loser by the depredations of a gang of thieves upon his stock, and the operations of the rogues have been conducted in so mysterious a way that not until yesterday did the efforts which have been made for their detection result in their arrest. On several occasions an invoice of, say 100 bales, would be received during an afternoon, and next morning the discovery would be made that only 98 of the packages remained in the store. At first it was thought that the clerks must have made an error in counting, and particular care was afterwards exercised to obviate such mistakes in future. Notwithstanding this fact, on the morning after the reception of the goods the inevitable discrepancy of two bales between the number received and the quantity in the store would be apparent. Mr. Boardman engaged an experienced man to watch his place of business, but this effected no diminution of the robberies, which had by this time amounted to the value of $1,000. At this stage of the matter Capt. Walling, of the Detective Police, was made acquainted with the circumstances, and he directed Officer Eustace to take the case in hand. He accordingly spent several nights in watching the premises, but the thieves eluded his vigilance and managed to carry away a bale of the wool during that time. Eustace was astonished at the fact, although not discouraged, knowing well that the exercise of patience and tact would result in the capture of the rogues. On Saturday night, therefore, he took a position on the roof of Mr. Boardman's store, and awaited further developments. A few hours elapsed and his attention was attracted by the noise made by some person within the building, who cautiously opened a window on the fifth story, in the rear, and almost immediately thereafter pushed a bale of wool out, which fell into the yard. From the yard easy access was had to the shop of Andrew Ryan, a dealer in old junk, located directly in the rear of the wool-merchant's place, and there the officer suspected that the wool was disposed of. The whole mystery of the robbery having been thus explained satisfactorily to his mind, he did not go rashly to work and arrest the thief then within the building, prefering to make the case so clear that all implicated in the transaction should receive their merited punishment. It being a difficult matter to identify stolen wool, the detective next day proposed to Mr. Boardman to procure some handbills and deposit them in in the bales, by which means their identity could be established. The suggestion was acted upon, and time having been given for the perpetration of another robbery, the junk-shop was searched, and two bales of wool, which were identified by means of the hand-bills, as the property of Mr. Boardman, were found. Ryan stated that he had purchased the wool a long time ago, but the proof to the contrary was strong against him, and he was arrested on a charge of having received stolen goods. Subsequent inquiries developed the fact that John Aggerton, the porter of the store, had been accustomed to lock one of the laborers, named John McDonald, within the building, for the purpose of stealing the wool, and the theft was accomplished in the manner described. Aggerton and McDonald were accordingly taken into custody, and conducted before Justice WELSH at the Tombs Police Court, who held them to answer fer the larceny. Ryan was also held by the same magistrate on the charge of receiving stolen goods.

abstract: The first day of a Fair is the last day to visit it -- in point of choice, we mean, and not in point of time. In the beginning, every exhibition of this kind, like the heavens and earth, must be made; and the morning and the evening of the first day generally are devoted to the important work of the creation. Not that the articles that are to constitute the show are manufactured within that brief period, -- the fruit grown, the patent instruments of labor fashioned, the horses, and swine, and poultry, all brought into being in a single day, as theatrical managers would phrase It, "for this occasion only." -- but the Fair itself, which is the congregation of all these, is fairly given an existence on this first day. And thus probably it will always be while Fairs have a seat on this distracted globe -- exhibitors will be dilatory in their preparations, and the people who go to see will be forgiving. Yet if it could be brought about in any one instance that all the preliminaries might be settled on the day before the first day of the exhibition who managed the matter would be greatly praised.
lead_paragraph: The first day of a Fair is the last day to visit it -- in point of choice, we mean, and not in point of time. abstract: We begin to fear that we have done more than justice to the New-York Aldermen. Indeed, it may even prove in the end that the extraordinary aureole of absurdity which now invests the brows of the Gothamite City father should be attributed rather to the superior civilization of his fellow-citizens than to his own preeminence in Aldermanic incapacity.
lead_paragraph: We begin to fear that we have done more than justice to the New-York Aldermen. Indeed, it may even prove in the end that the extraordinary aureole of absurdity which now invests the brows of the Gothamite City father should be attributed rather to the superior civilization of his fellow-citizens than to his own preeminence in Aldermanic incapacity. The people of New-York are themselves so orderly, intelligent and honest, that the average Alderman shines by contrast among them with preternatural lustre. Transferred to another community, and matched with his fellows of another origin, who knows that the immortal BOOLE himself might not lose something of his glory? BARRY, for example, has become with us the type of Aldermanic pugnacity, merely through his feats in the pugilistic line at Jones' Wood and in the City Hall. But what distinction could BARRY hope for in a city like New-Orleans, where the municipal surgeons leave a patient in a gig at the hospital door and exchange shots in the street for the right to his aneurism?

lead_paragraph: The Opera House was last night occupied by what a worthy citizen from the prairie granary who sat in our neighborhood, several times described to his short-waisted, pink-cheeked and green-gloved daughter as a "fashionable and respectable crowd." Crowd" at the West is not necessarily a noun of multitude, but may be applied indiscriminately to a party of four drinking whisky and water, and to a Chicago Convention. We cannot therefore quarrel with our worthy citizen, though no New-Yorker would have been likely to think the Academy uncomfortably jammed last night, had there been New-Yorkers enough present to encourage each other in thinking about it at all.

abstract: That foolish or fabulous author, who is said to have asserted that history never reproduces itself, must have had a very slight acquaintance with any history, and none whatever with the history of Spanish America.
lead_paragraph: That foolish or fabulous author, who is said to have asserted that history never reproduces itself, must have had a very slight acquaintance with any history, and none whatever with the history of Spanish America. In that happy region history appears to addict itself exclusively to the business of reproduction. It would even be possible, we suspect, to state well-defined cycles in which each of the emancipated colonies of Mother Spain returns to some previous and most undesirable state of affairs, wherein, as in the standard drama, we have the same dramatis persona and identical actors, the same heavy men and the same walking, and we may add, returning gentlemen. These periods of historical repetition date back to the period of initial revolution, and advance from that point with the regularity of astronomical epochs, and the most discouraging characteristic of the phenomenon is that there is no average progress in civilization and the arts of peace, in refinement or industrial gain. The turbulence is that of a tempest-stirred pool without an outlet, rather than the forward dash and flow of a torrent.

abstract: -- The people of Dalton, Ga., have been startled out of their propriety by the discovery of an alleged conspiracy among the negroes. A girl belonging to Mr. JAMES LEDYARD revealed the plot. The confessions of the negroes arrested, were to the effect that the town was to be fired on Sunday night, while the citizens were in attendance at the different churches. The Dalton Times remarks "That some black-hearted Abolitionist or Abolitionists, have been trampering with the blacks in this place and vicinity there can be no question, and the owners of slaves and the city authorities cannot be too watchful."

abstract: -- John O'Brien Shenandoah died at the Albany County Hospital on the 20th ult. His father, John O'Brien, was an Irishman of means. He emigrated to this country in 1745, and soon after married a squaw of the Stockbridge tribe of Indians. John was born in 1751 and was sent to France to study. He returned to this country in the same vessel which brought Lafayette, and took an active part in many of the battles of the Revolution. Although 109 years at the time of his death, he retained all his faculties, except his sight, to the last.

abstract: -The Prairie News, published in Okalona, Mississippi, has the following pleasant paragraph: We learn that a bloody affray took place at Gum Pond, seventeen miles above here on the line of railroad. The particulars, as far as we can learn, are as follows: Last Friday evening, Col. THOMAS WILLIAMS and JACK ROBERTS had a quarrel, and the latter presented a pistol to the head of the former and fired, but WASH. DANDRIDGE caught or pushed away ROBERTS' hand just as the pistol went off and the ball grazed WILLIAMS' cheek. Immediately, JOHN CHARLES cracked away at DANDRIDGE and lodged in his breast the contents of a shot-gun. CHARLES fled, but was pursued, arrested and brought back. This ended the business for Friday evening, but it was evident the quiet was not to be of long duration, for ROBERTS, who had shot at WILLIAMS, vowed to kill him before he rested.

abstract: FELLOW-CITIZENS AND FRIENDS OF GEN. HOUSTON: Justly indignant at the frauds and violence of National Conventions, resulting from the intrigues of selfish politicians, the independent. Democrats of New-York determined, some months since, to exercise their rights, as citizens, by the selection of a Presidential ticket, without the dictation of party.
lead_paragraph: FELLOW-CITIZENS AND FRIENDS OF GEN. HOUSTON: Justly indignant at the frauds and violence of National Conventions, resulting from the intrigues of selfish politicians, the independent. Democrats of New-York determined, some months since, to exercise their rights, as citizens, by the selection of a Presidential ticket, without the dictation of party. They adopted this unusual course solely in vindication of a principle, and not in mere devotion to the name of a man. They were assured that the unbiased electors of our State and nation desired to enter their testimony against the loose morality of modern politics, manifested by sectional and factional Conventions, by the huckstering of principles, and by the open sale and transfer of partisan votes. They recognized the present time as an auspicious one for a popular protest against corrupt party machinery, and they hoped, to inaugurate, at least, some movement which honest Democrats could indorse as patriotic.

abstract: Among the recent news from Texas is the curious announcement of that some United. States soldiers, accused of hanging a man who had stabbed one of their comrades in, a barroom, had been liberated from custody by the civil authorities for want of sufficient evidence.
lead_paragraph: Among the recent news from Texas is the curious announcement of that some United. States soldiers, accused of hanging a man who had stabbed one of their comrades in, a barroom, had been liberated from custody by the civil authorities for want of sufficient evidence. We must say that we are greatly surprised at the action of the military authorities in ever allowing them to be subjected to the humiliation and inconvenience of an examination. A man does not. we believe, forfeit his rights as a citizen on becoming a soldier of the Republic, and the right to hang anybody whose personal appearance is disagreeable, or whose previous history is hot well known, seems to be just now the right of all others which the citizens of Texas cherish most fondly. To arrest half a dozen persons for putting a man to death because his conduct displeased them, must certainly, viewed in the light of Texan morals, be considered a gross outrage, even when committed on private soldiers, and every law-abiding citizen will be glad to see that the officials have receded from their odious, and ridiculous position. Each week's mail from that model community bears a stronger and stronger resemblance to the recent accounts from Syria and Montenegro. The citizens seem to have taken to the business of hanging with as keen a relish as the Druses and Montenegrins to cutting off heads. No Turkish Pasha in the days of AMURATH was ever more jocose over a heap of infidel skulls than the newspapers of that Christian and civilized region over the daily murders which are now being perpetrated of every unfortunate stranger whom a drunken mob chooses to accuse of Abolitionism. The San Antonio Ledger, for example, informs us that "a wandering mapseller has just been translated to another sphere of action;" that "a negro boy accompanied him in his permanent suspension from earthly duties." The wit of the Galveston News is still more ghastly when it informs us that the "Abolitionist J.E. LEMON had been prevented by a material impediment from leaving the State; that he had climbed a tree, and we presume had hurt himself in coming down." Merriment of this sort, if it does not strike us, in this latitude, as very promotive of cheerfulness, at least reveals the spirit by which the Pro-Slavery zealots in Texas are now animated. That there is no real excuse for the bloody saturnalia, in which they are indulging, is made manifest by the bogus letter which we published yesterday morning, purporting to be from one Abolitionist incendiary to another. Every line of it contained clear evidence that it was the composition of a stupid and ignorant defender of the "peculiar institution," that the writer was not only a forger, but a blockhead. In times of real danger and distress men do not resort to means of this sort to quicken the public zeal. The realities of the situation are generally found amply sufficient to arouse people into activity. Forged letters are, on the contrary, one of the ordinary accompaniments of gross impostures and delusions, got up by knaves for their own profit and the confusion and terror of their neighbors, and there has never been a bloody outbreak of insane credulity, from the days of DOMITIAN to the days of TITUS OATES. in which they did not figure.
headline: {'main': 'Terrorism in Texas.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Terrorism in Texas.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Justice CONNOLLY yesterday resumed, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, the examination of the circumstances attending the alleged frauds upon several of the Marine Insurance Companies, in connection with the logs of the bark E.A. Kinsman.
lead_paragraph: Justice CONNOLLY yesterday resumed, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, the examination of the circumstances attending the alleged frauds upon several of the Marine Insurance Companies, in connection with the logs of the bark E.A. Kinsman. On Wednesday afternoon, Mr. D.S. Mills, who is charged with being one of the principals in the alleged conspiracy to defraud, was arrested at Southhold, L.I., and he was present during the proceedings. The magistrate fixed his bail at $5,000, and he was placed in custody of Detective Sampson until the required surety should be furnished.

abstract: T. Kock vs. L. Cantel. -- This is an action to wind up a partnership business hitherto existing between the parties. The plaintiff alleged that frequent misunderstandings between himself and his partner led to quarrelling, and that a general derangement of the business had followed, so injuring it that it was no longer profitable, but had become a losing concern. The defendant alleged the contrary in regard to the business, and claimed that an occasional dispute was the only difficulty in the firm.

The advices have been anticipated by late arrivals, but we obtain from our files details of interest. GARIBALDI, before he made his descent upon Southern Italy, appears to have left Cagliari with a force under his immediate command of 5,000 men. According to the Cologe Gazette, an Austrian note is being prepared" in which the foreign Minister declares that the designs of the Emperor are not aggressive, but that he will defend his Italian possessions to the uttermost. An article, which we translate from an influential German print, on the present complications in Europe, will attract attention.

abstract: -- The Coroner's Jury in the case of Lucinda McGinnis, who was found drowned in the Chenango Canal, near Utica, a few days ago, has just found a verdict that Lyman D. George and James Nowlan, two young men of that city of unenviable reputation, murdered her. Jennette Robbins, a depraved woman, swore that George and Nowlan were in her company on the day that Lucinda is supposed to have been murdered; and that seeing her pass they left, threatening to maltreat her. The story of this woman is positively denied by both the accused.

abstract: MEETING OF THE TRUSTEES OF THE GERMAN BENEVOLENT SOCIETY. The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of the above-named Society took place last evening, President JELLINGHAUS in the Chair.
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE TRUSTEES OF THE GERMAN BENEVOLENT SOCIETY. The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of the above-named Society took place last evening, President JELLINGHAUS in the Chair. From the statement made by the agent of the Society, it appears that the number of German emigrants arrived here during the past month amounted to 3,095. They arrived in 42 vessels from various European ports. He also stated that the German emigrant who had been so severely beaten during his passage from Liverpool, on board of the ship Ellen Austin, by the Captain, that he had to be removed to the Hospital for medical treatment, had been induced to leave the City, by giving him a free passage to Chicago. He was also induced to sign a document in which he gave up all claims for damages. The Captain of the vessel and others put it out of the power of the Society to punish him. According to the statement of the Treasurer, there is a balance of $2,167 95 left in the Bank. During the past month $174 62 were distributed among the poor, and the total expenses during the same time amounted to $316 23. 131 men received employment through the agency of the Society. On motion, it was resolved to appropriate $200 to be spent among the poor during the ensuing month. Mr. JELLINGHAUS then reported that he had been on Ward's Island with the Commissioners of Emigration, and expressed himself highly satisfied with the treatment of the inmates and the general management of affairs. He attributed these changes to the new Superintendent, who had adopted a different plan altogether than the two former Superintendents, who had treated the inmates more like criminals than like poor, homeless, unfortunate creatures as they were. He also stated that the Commissioners were about to erect a new building on the Island for the reception and treatment of lunatic paupers. He said that if it was put up according to the plans and specifications it promised to be fit for its purpose. The meeting was then adjourned.

abstract: The second day's live-mile races took place yesterday, with the greatest eclat and a much larger attendance than on the first day. Several steamers accompanied the boats. The first race yesterday was for two pair sculls, working boats, in which were three entries; was rowed for by the Maggie, of NewYork, 17 feet, James Culross and John Eckerson,
lead_paragraph: The second day's live-mile races took place yesterday, with the greatest eclat and a much larger attendance than on the first day. Several steamers accompanied the boats. The first race yesterday was for two pair sculls, working boats, in which were three entries; was rowed for by the Maggie, of NewYork, 17 feet, James Culross and John Eckerson, which took the first prize, $20; time. 44 min. 26 sec. The Cataract, of Yonkers, 17 feet, rowed by Jas. H. Waldron and Abram Benson, took the second prize, $10 -- time, 45 min. 34 sec. It is but justice to Culross to say that his boat Maggie weighs 175 pounds, and himself a light-weight lad. while the H. Genet -- working-boat? -- weighed but oil pounds, ;and Dennis Leary is a powerful heavy weight, who pulled her in the single scull working boat race the first day. Some fair rule should be adopted for boats of this class.

abstract: The surviving members of the Truber family had a reunion at Fairfield, Conn., on the 28th ult. After a collation, Rev. Dr. Osgood, of this City, made some remarks.
lead_paragraph: -- The surviving members of the Truber family had a reunion at Fairfield, Conn., on the 28th ult. After a collation, Rev. Dr. Osgood, of this City, made some remarks. He considered the circumstances in our American life that fended to keep members of the family separate -- such as the constant changes, of home, vicissitudes of condition and intensity of care and competition; and he urged the worth of the sober virtues, household affections, and religious principles that bind parents and children together. The Trubers came originally from Holland, and the three brothers -- David, Samuel and Andrew -- who are now severally eighty-two, seventy-four, and seventy years old, are survivors of a family of eight -- the five deceased members being sisters. The guests accepted Dr. Osgood's invitation, and walked over his grounds, which were adjacent. They were purchased of Mr. David Truber five years ago, and have been handsomely laid out and improved into a beautiful estate.

abstract: -Messrs. JAMES LYONS and A.B. GUIGON as commissioners, yesterday sold at the front door of the City Hall an interest in those valuable race horses Planet and Exchequer, and in the mare Fanny Washington. The sale was conducted by Messrs. GODDIN & APPERSON, by virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, in the case of "HUGHES, HYLLISTEAD & CO., vs. STARKE, &c." The interest of Mr. WM.E. STARKE, of New-Orleans, (formerly called the Cotton King,) in Planets was one-fourth, purchased by FONDREN, WILLIAM & CO., for $2,950; one-half pf exchequer (owned by him) was knocked out to O.P. HARE for THOMAS W. DOSWELL at $1,500, and one-half interest in Fanny Washington was purchased by FONDREN, WILLIAMS & CO. for $3,500. A large number of racing men, including Hon. JOHN M. BOTTS, were on the ground, as were the nags, looking excellently. The bidding was spirited, but the prices obtained are not regarded as extravagant by parties knowing the horses. Planet is entered for a big sweepstake to be run over the Fashion Course on the 28th September, but the purchaser will have no interest in that, should the horse win, his former owner not having represented his interest. -- Richmond Enquirer, Sept. 4.

abstract: We are happy to record the general subjection of the Sunday-Theatre proprietors to the laws of the State.
lead_paragraph: We are happy to record the general subjection of the Sunday-Theatre proprietors to the laws of the State. A single notorious offender still resists public sentiment and defies the authorities; but a little experience of the penalties of violated law, so soon as the indictments hanging over his head can be reached, nay teach him a valuable lesson. We understand that EUSTACHI's Volks Theatre has passed into new and better hands -- the Sunday performances having been abandoned. The Stadt Theatre -- after a parting growl at the "Sunday fanatics," through the Staats Zeitung, for interrupting its Sunday profits, which formerly equaled those of the entire week, -- takes out a new license, and foregoes Sunday exhibitions. The Volks Garten did not fancy the suits of the "House of Refuge," for $500 penalty for its Sunday "sacred concerts," and gives up playing. The Broadway establishments early gave in to the law, and some of them have been compelled to apply for regular theatrical licenses. On the whole, a more general submission to the theatre and Sunday laws has been secured than has been known for twenty years.

abstract: The Douglas and Johnson Central Campaign Club, held a regular meeting last evening, at their rooms in Broadway, when Alderman WILSON, from the Committee of Arrangements, made a verbal report with regard to the great Barbecue to take place on the 12th inst. Mr. WILSON reported that he had been in
lead_paragraph: The Douglas and Johnson Central Campaign Club, held a regular meeting last evening, at their rooms in Broadway, when Alderman WILSON, from the Committee of Arrangements, made a verbal report with regard to the great Barbecue to take place on the 12th inst. Mr. WILSON reported that he had been in communication with Mr. DOUGLAS, and that gentleman would positively speak on the occasion, as would Messrs. JOHNSON, SOULE, GOV. FLETCHER, of Virginia, Ex-Governor SEYMOUR, of New-York, and several other eminent men. He further reported that a large ox had been presented to the Committee, as also several sheep, a calf, a pig, and other articles of that kind. All these would be roasted whole, and would be partaken of by those who would attend the demonstration. He trusted there would be a full attendance, and that as many as could spare time from their work would be present. He also recommended that five volunteers from each Ward club would be requested to assist the Committee. Forty-three clubs had already notified him of their intention to be present. Music would be there in abundance, and the various dancing-stands would be used, the large one being kept exclusively for ladies. Three steamers would run hourly from New-Jersey, and boats would also run from Poughkeepsie, Albany, Rhode Island, and other parts adjacent. The Second-avenue railroad will charge only three cents per trip, and the Railroad from Westchester will run oftener. The police arrangements would be excellent, but he trusted the volunteers would attend and assist.

abstract: A late discussion in the English Parliament on the contemplated "Grand Custom" about to be made by the King of Dahomey, elicited some facts regarding the social condition of Western Africa and the policy of England on the Slave Coast that may be of importance at the present moment.
lead_paragraph: A late discussion in the English Parliament on the contemplated "Grand Custom" about to be made by the King of Dahomey, elicited some facts regarding the social condition of Western Africa and the policy of England on the Slave Coast that may be of importance at the present moment. It seems that BADAHUNG, in honor of his father, the late King GEZO, has determined to surpass all former monarchs in the magnitude of the ceremonies to be performed on the occasion of the "Grand Custom." Two thousand persons will be sacrificed, and a great pit has been dug, which is to contain human blood enough to float a canoe!

abstract: Shortly after the dinner hour yesterday at the Sing Sing Prison, a desperate attempt was made on the part of six of the convicts, employed in the "planking room" of the hat shop, to overpower their guards and escape by means of a small sloop, which was used for the purpose of transporting stone to the institution.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the dinner hour yesterday at the Sing Sing Prison, a desperate attempt was made on the part of six of the convicts, employed in the "planking room" of the hat shop, to overpower their guards and escape by means of a small sloop, which was used for the purpose of transporting stone to the institution. The projector of the plan was TOM KELLY, a notorious fellow, who has lately given a great deal of trouble to the keepers, and who for some time past has been subjected to the ball and chain, as well as the vizor punishment. for his misconduct. It was hoped by KELLY and the few who had become parties to the plot, that by a sudden dash they might murder their guard, seize the sloop, which lay at the prison dock, and during the confusion which was sure to ensue, put off to the mountains on the opposite side of the river, whence it would be easy to make good their escape. They reckoned also that on board the sloop they would find the clothing of the crew in which they could array themselves and further facilitate their design.

abstract: On Tuesday evening, a well-dressed man, known as Henry H. Southwick, alias Simmons, was arrested in the City Hall Park by Officers Phillips, of the Second, and Carr, of the Sixth Precinct, on a charge of having personated a policeman, and, by unauthorized representations, to have obtained considerable sums of money from abandoned women, whom it was his habit to accost in the street and frighten into a compliance with his demands. In this way he is said to have operated for a considerable period, and at length had become so emboldened by his success that he recently approached Officer Phillips and offered him a bribe to secure the release of one Elizabeth Fitzsimmons, a prostitute, who, through the instrumentality of the officer, had been sentenced to the Penitentiary. The accused, at that time, stated that he was a member of the Brooklyn force, and had been detailed for duty at the Barclay-street Ferry; that he possessed considerable influence with the Commissioners, and that he would make it an object for him, in more than a financial sense, to effect the woman's discharge. Phillips refused to act as desired, and, doubting his story, asked to see the prisoner's shield, but he did not exhibit that emblem of a Policeman's authority, offering as an excuse that he had accidentally left it at the Station-house. At the close of the interview, Southwick promised to call on Phillips again. Subsequent inquiry demonstrated that the man was an impostor, and on Wednesday evening the officers again met him and took him into custody. Justice BRENNAN temporarily committed him to await the result of an examination.

abstract: THE NEWARK AND BLOOMFIELD RAILROAD. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Newark and Bloomfield Railroad Company was held in Newark on Tuesday. The Board of Directors of last year was reelected and the annual report was submitted.The receipts for the year ending July 31 were $19,051 70 -- an increase of $6,845 32 over those of the year preceding, while the expenses were but $1,000 greater. The total number of passengers carried over the road was 107,169, against 76,700 to July 31, 1859. Of this increase, 16,847 was to Bloomfield alone. No accident has occurred to any of the passengers during the year. It is contemplated during the ensuing year to build an embankment across Watssessing Lake, to take the place of the present trestle bridge, thereby rendering travel over it safer. Surveys have been made for the proposed extension to the Notch, near Paterson, but nothing further has been done in the matter.

abstract: The first meeting of this Association since June last, was held at the Cooper Institute last evening, Dr. GRISCOM in the chair. The important topic of the evening was the law passed by the last Legislature for regulating the sale of poisons.
lead_paragraph: The first meeting of this Association since June last, was held at the Cooper Institute last evening, Dr. GRISCOM in the chair. The important topic of the evening was the law passed by the last Legislature for regulating the sale of poisons. Dr. GRISCOM called the attention of the Association to the case of CHATHERINE GORDON, a woman of the town, aged 17, who died at the City Hospital on Wednesday evening of last week, from the effects of arsenic, self-administered on the Sunday evening previous. The arsenic was purchased by the girl at a drug-store in West Broadway, without any questions being asked as to her name or residence, without the poison being labeled, and, in fact, without any of the requirements of the law being complied with by the druggist. After the death of the girl, Dr. GRISCOM, who treated her during her sickness, investigated the case, called attention to the violation of the law by the druggist, and tried to have the matter brought to the attention of the proper authorities; but his efforts were frustrated by the hasty and inefficient manner in which the Coroner performed his duty, that official having refused to allow a post-mortem examination, and neglected to summon the proper witnesses, or to take any measure whatever to bring the druggist to justice for his violation of the law, or even to allow the fact to become known to the public. On a further inquiry, the Doctor said he learned that the druggist who sold the poison was a brother-in-law of a prominent City official, the head of one of the Departments. In conclusion the Doctor said he had no doubt whatever-that if the law had been complied with, the girl would not have purchased the poison, and her life would consequently have been saved.

abstract: The Sixth Annual Fair of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society, at Elizabeth City, closed yesterday. It has been a very successful and a very creditable exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The Sixth Annual Fair of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society, at Elizabeth City, closed yesterday. It has been a very successful and a very creditable exhibition. The weather has been propitious, the attendance has been very large, and the visitors declare that the display was the finest that the Society has yet put forth. There were fewer extraneous features of an unpleasant nature about it than are usuallyobservable at gatherings of the kind. Excellent order was maintained, not only within the ground, but, within a certain limit, without. By a special enactment of the Legislature of the State, the Society is given exclusive jurisdiction over the territory immediately surrounding the inclosure in which its fairs are held. The Police of Elizabeth City on this occasion watched over the public peace. The gamblers, who took up their quarters, near the entrance on the first day, were speedily put to flight, and a few drunken men who became nuisances were summarily disposed of. The track on which the horses were put through their paces was kept clear, and riotous customers were under constant surveillance. On Thursday probably 20,000 persons visited the Exhibition. The plowing match, the equestrianism and the trotting were the features of that day.

This, of course, was the musical event of the week, and the Academy was handsomely filled to witness it, the stately and beautiful Mrs. DOUGLAS gracing the auspicious occasion with her presence. The honors of the evening, though they were not shared, have been divided, by the tremendous tenor, with Signor A[???]DIO, whose stage-bearing and action are in better keeping now with his rich and mellow voice, than they have ever before been. BRIGNOLI will strike for his altar and his throne, imperiled last night, and sing Elvino to Miss PATH's charming Amino.

abstract: At the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, Caroline Peet, an intelligent and beautiful girl, 16 years of age, and a native of this City, was brought before Justice WELSH to answer a charge of having stolen $100 in bank bills from Wm. Benthusen, residing in NewJersey; and doing business as a produce dealer at Washington Market.
lead_paragraph: At the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, Caroline Peet, an intelligent and beautiful girl, 16 years of age, and a native of this City, was brought before Justice WELSH to answer a charge of having stolen $100 in bank bills from Wm. Benthusen, residing in NewJersey; and doing business as a produce dealer at Washington Market. The theft was alleged to have been committed at a house of ill-fame in Laurens-street, during an interview between the complainant and the accused. The young woman denied the truth of the allegation, and related a piteous story of the wrongs that she had endured, and the causes which had compelled her to lead a life of dishonor. A year since her parents died and she was left under the protection of a male relative, who took advanvantage of his position to entice her from the path of virtue, and subsequently compelled her to marry a person whom she could neither love nor respect. Their incompatibility of temperament speedily resulted in a separation, and she was cast, a houseless wanderer, upon her own resources. Failing, after an earnest search, to obtain employment, and her scanty means having become exhausted, she thought she had no alternative but to accept the offer of one of those panderers to sensuality by whom houses of prostitution are supplied, and entered the house in Laurens-street. Her nature repelled her lot, and she was frequently tempted to commit suicide. Her statement was made with such apparent sincerity that all who heard it gave their credence. Subsequently her story was partially corroborated, and the testimony adduced against her on the charge of larceny being insufficient to warrant her incarceration she was discharged from custody. Her case was afterwards brought to the notice of some philanthropic ladies, and her present necessities having been attended to, an effort will be made to place her in a reputable condition.
