abstract: The Departments at Washington are perfecting their domestic arrangements. They are getting to be almost as perfect in their internal discipline as the gambling hells and houses of ill-fame that carry on a sharp but not very successful rivalry with them, in the race of corruption and plunder.
lead_paragraph: The Departments at Washington are perfecting their domestic arrangements. They are getting to be almost as perfect in their internal discipline as the gambling hells and houses of ill-fame that carry on a sharp but not very successful rivalry with them, in the race of corruption and plunder. The Department of War seems lately to have added to its corps a pimp and spy, whose special vocation is to be hunting out obnoxious correspondents of the New-York Press, and bullying them into silence. We hope he and his employers will have a good time of it.

abstract: Rachel Kirschein vs. Benjamin Bernstein.  This was an action before Judge ALKER in the Marine Court, to recover damages for an alleged breach of a marriage promise.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Kirschein vs. Benjamin Bernstein. This was an action before Judge ALKER in the Marine Court, to recover damages for an alleged breach of a marriage promise. The plaintiff alleged that the defendant had shown her a great many attentions, and made her a great many presents of various kinds, prior to and since the 27th of May last, and that on that day, or the evening thereof, he "asked and did receive" her hand, or a promise thereof. Since then, it was now complained, the betrothed had proven false to his vows, and was indisposed to many. Hence the action.

abstract: Advices from Europe, two days later, are receiv- ed by the City of Washington, which was boarded off Cape Race by the news-yacht of the Associated Press yesterday afternoon. She left Liverpool on the 29th, and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The British Parliament was prorogued on the 28th.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Europe, two days later, are receiv- ed by the City of Washington, which was boarded off Cape Race by the news-yacht of the Associated Press yesterday afternoon. She left Liverpool on the 29th, and Queenstown on the 30th ult. The British Parliament was prorogued on the 28th. The Queen, in her parting speech, which was read by the Lord Chancellor, says that the relations of the Government with Foreign Powers are satisfactory, and believes that so long as the Italians are left to settle their own difficulties, the general peace of Europe will not be disturbed. She laments the late atrocities in Syria, and [???]presses her willingness cheerfully to cooperate with the other Powers in assisting the Sultan of Turkey to reestablish order. She regrets the failure of negotiations with China, and says that the provisions of the treaty of Tien-tsin will be enforced. She closes with an expression of her satisfaction of the manner in which the Prince of Wales has been received in the North-American Provinces. Latest dispatches from the scene of the Italian Revolution report that the Royalists had again been defeated in Calabria. A report was current at Paris that the King of Naples had taken refuge on board a man-of-war, but the report needs confirmation. Another report states that the Pope had expressed his willingness to agree to the Italian Confederation, but this, too, needs verifying.

abstract: Mr. DOUGLAS' last effort in Baltimore to make such a mixture of the Breckinridge doc- trines and his own as will suit the Southern palate, is hardty as ingenious as energetic.
lead_paragraph: Mr. DOUGLAS' last effort in Baltimore to make such a mixture of the Breckinridge doc- trines and his own as will suit the Southern palate, is hardty as ingenious as energetic. It is only a few weeks since he adopted, without reservation, the least tenable of all the theories of the fire-eaters -- that slaves are property like my other property. That there might be no mistake about what he meant, he likened them, in express terms, to horses or oxen, and then asked, triumphantly, when did any one think of claiming Federal protection in the Territories for their cattle and their furniture? by way of showing the absurdity of the notion that Territorial Legislatures are not entirely competent to do for slaveholders all that slaveholders have a right to require.

abstract: One of the best-contested games of Base Ball that has ever taken place in this vicinity, was played yesterday on the Union ground, at Morrisania. Nine innings were played in two hours and twenty-three minutes, the score ending, Excelsior 7, Union 4 -- one of the smallest scores on record. The fielding on both sides was of the very highest order, the out-fielding being without a flaw, the catching excellent, and the pitching on both sides unusually fine, the muffs being almost entirely confined to the bases. The throwing of the Excelsiors was very beautiful, but one wild throw being made, the Unions not being so efficient in this respect. The innings throughout were closely played.
lead_paragraph: One of the best-contested games of Base Ball that has ever taken place in this vicinity, was played yesterday on the Union ground, at Morrisania. abstract: "True-blue Presbyterian" writes an interesting letter to the Observer, sketching the celebration of the tri-centenary of the Scottish Reformation, which com- menced at Edinburgh on Aug. 14, and continued four days. Rev. Dr. GUTHZIE, one of the most celebrated...
lead_paragraph: "True-blue Presbyterian" writes an interesting letter to the Observer, sketching the celebration of the tri-centenary of the Scottish Reformation, which com- menced at Edinburgh on Aug. 14, and continued four days. Rev. Dr. GUTHZIE, one of the most celebrated and eloquent of Scottish ministers presided, and delivered a powerful address, vindicating the Reformation as the cause alike of civil and religious freedom. He did not hesitate to denounce American Slavery vehemently. The programme of the meeting embraced a great variety of topics, on which papers were to be read and addresses delivered. Dr. MCCRIE, Professor in the English Presbyterian College, discussed the Scottish Parliament of 1860 in a very interesting paper. Then a discussion followed, in which, the tendency of a negative theology, which threatens the Episcopal establishment, was eloquently deplored. Dr. KILLEN, author of the Ancient Church, and Professor of Ecclesiastical History to the Irish General Assembly, traced the "Hand of God in the Reformation" very eloquently. Dr. LINDSAY ALEXANDER, the well-known Independent Minister, Professor LORINER, of London, Dr. WYLIE, of Edinburgh, and Dr. H[???]HERINGTON, Professor, in the Free College, Glasgow, were the most prominent in the discussions which were had during the first days of the celebration. An entire evening was devoted to the subject of "The late revival of Religion in Ireland," Aug. 17, the last day of the exercises, was to be the most interesting of all. Then, Rev. Dr. LYMINGTON, of Glasgow, was to deliver an address, the foundation stone of the Protestant Institute was to be laid, and in the evening the Earl of Shaftesbury was to take the Chair, and addresses were expected from Mr. DALLAS, United States Minister, Rev. Dr. EDGAR, and others. The success of the celebration, as far as it had progressed, was chiefly ascribed to Rev. Dr. BEGG, of Edinburg, the morning spirit of the Reformation Society of Scotland.

abstract: JUVENILE HOUSE OF INDUSTRY The annual public examinations of the Truant Institution at Flatbush were commenced on Thursday and will be brought to a close to-day. The interest of the public in this institution was manifested, yesterday, by a respectable attendance of citizens. The pupils are under the care of Mr. A.C. VAN EPPS as ...
lead_paragraph: JUVENILE HOUSE OF INDUSTRY The annual public examinations of the Truant Institution at Flatbush were commenced on Thursday and will be brought to a close to-day. The interest of the public in this institution was manifested, yesterday, by a respectable attendance of citizens. The pupils are under the care of Mr. A.C. VAN EPPS as superintendent. By the annual report it appears that the whole, number of children admitted since the institution was established is about 500, of which number 162 were admitted during the past year, and 259 were discharged, total number remaining, 101. The institution was organized under the general vagrant act, passed a few years ago, and is designed solely as a home of reformation. All idle children found about the streets who do not attend the public schools, are liable to be arrested by any officer and sent to this place, unless their parents or friends promise to take care of them. If they neglect their duty in this respect, the children are taken there upon a magistrate's order. There are three Truant officers, whose time is exclusively devoted to looking after the class of children for which, this institution was designed. The public schools are under their particular attention. The truants are hunted up and made to attend school or go to the Truant Home, where they are kept until there are unmistakable evidences of a reform. The effect upon the attendance at the public schools has been marked and decided. The children committed during the last year were for the following crimes: idle and truant, 72; homeless, 15; vagrants, 14; insubordination, 45; petty crimes, 8; poverty of parents, 13; total, 167. Of the whole number 39 were fatherless, 28 motherless and 16 were orphans; about 20 per cent. could read and write, passably, and had made some progress in the elementary branches of study; 33 per cent. could read and spell tolerably; 30 per cent. could read and spell in easy lessons, and 17 per cent. did not know their alphabet. The ages of the children range from 5 to 14 years. The scholastic exercises at this institution are substantially the same as in the public schools, with a study hour before breakfast and added hours during the week and on Saturdays, for those who have not exercised proper diligence at the proper time. The school is divided into two departments: In the higher are taught reading, spelling, and defining, arithmetic -- mental and written -- geography, writing and grammar. The manner of teaching writing and grammar is in a practical way. All communications with the superintendent and teacher in the school-room, reports of monitors, committees, &c., are written. This writing is then so marked as to indicate all inaccuracies and returned for correction, when a written answer is given. This is required of all in this department, and has been attended by the most gratifying results -- inducing a readiness and correctness of expression, in many cases, truly remarkable. There is also a class in YOUNG's Government Class Book, treating of the principles of Constitutional Government and the rights and duties of citizens. The Primary Department is devoted exclusively to elementary exercises. There has been but little sickness in the institution during the year and not one death.

abstract: -- John Holden Ormsbee, President of the Union Bank, and of the Manufacturers' Insurance Company, died in Providence, R.I., on Wednesday, in the eighty-first year of his age. He was also President of the Marine Society, and for thirty-six years Agent of the AEtna Insurance Company, Hartford. In early life he engaged in maritime pursuits, and made his first voyage to the East Indies full fifty years age.

abstract: This will was yesterday admitted to probate. The testator was a merchant of high standing, and a bachelor. His life was insured for $10,000 in the Albion Life Insurance Company, London. This he gives to his mother, with power to dispose of it as she pleases by will, or, in the absence of a will, to go to testator's sisters. His brother and one sister he gives a large farm at Ravenna, Portage county, Ohio. The residue of his property is given (with the exception of $2,000 to a nephew,) 3-10 to his brother, 3-10 to one sister, and 4-10 to another. S.C. Davis, P.H. Holt, and J.M. Hood are appointed executors.

abstract: The persons to whom is confided the management of the prison at Sing Sing are clearly under some delusion as to the nature and aim of that institution.
lead_paragraph: The persons to whom is confided the management of the prison at Sing Sing are clearly under some delusion as to the nature and aim of that institution. The State designed it, we are led to suppose, for the correction and reformation of criminals, and the prevention of crime, by temporarily secluding those found to be guilty, and finally restoring them amended to society. The officers have a different theory. They clearly regard the prisoner as an unfinished scholar in the science of wrongdoing, whose education having been left to chance, is imperfect and unmethodical, and who only needs the drill, discipline, and example they are prepared to impart, to resume his place in the world an accomplished scoundrel. At the end of his term he graduates, in fact, with all the honors. He is certified to society as having completed his studies, and as being prepared to perpetrate murder, or burglary, or arson, in the most skillful fashion, at the shortest notice, and upon the most liberal terms.

abstract: latest items of Mexican news, issued from the New-Orleans laboratory, announces a probable fusion of factions upon Ex-President COMONFORT. No event is more improbable. The tergiversation of that Chief toward the close of his political career in January, 1859, was well calculated to destroy the confidence of all parties. If not in his honesty of purpose, at least in his fitness for a revolutionary, crisis. If Gen. COMONFORT is to be acquitted of shameful inconstancy to his party and its principles, it must be on the ground that he was deficient in the moral stamina demanded by a period when sordid interests, religious bigotry and excited partisanship, were waging confined war about him. But let the interpretation to be placed upon his conduct at that time be what it may, there is evidently nothing either in the character or the antecedents of COMONFORT to recommend him as a leader of Liberals, who have fought for two years to recover what his weakness lost them, or of Conservatives, who distrust his absolute devotion and subservience to the Church. The experiment has been put to the test during the present Summer, in Northern and Western Mexico; and the result shows the name to have no value as a rallying cry. The Deus ex machina must be sought elsewhere.

abstract: It is a pleasing tribute to the power of the Press in modern days, that those very Governments which most detest and denounce it, are the busiest of all in using it for their own ends.
lead_paragraph: It is a pleasing tribute to the power of the Press in modern days, that those very Governments which most detest and denounce it, are the busiest of all in using it for their own ends. If a census of canards were taken in Europe at any moment of supreme importance to the legitimate dynasties, it would be found that the most obstructive and restrictive Cabinets of the Continent are of all the most prolific in this kind of production. During the Crimean war the wildest inventions which startled the West, from the Tartar courier, with his news of the sudden fall of Sebastopol, onward, were traced directly to the autocratic regions of the East. Austria and Naples, outdid all the rest of Europe put together in manufacturing current stories of the campaign of 1859 in Italy, and the same Powers have fairly flooded the telegraphs and Presses of the World with extraordinary intelligence since the peace of Villafranca. We owe to them now the interesting information that the Emperors of Austria and Russia are shortly to have a meeting at Warsaw, after the fashion of Baden and Toplitz, and that the policy of the Czar has once more begun to shape itself in harmony with the interests of the Kaiser. ALEXANDER II., we are told, has resolved to abandon the course pursued by him since the peace of Paris, and to resume the important office of grand beadle of Europe, which was so long held by his proud and peremptory father. The autocrat of all the Russias, it is averred, has at last discovered the peril to himself and his successors involved in a triumph of the revolutionary principles which GARIBALDI represents, and he has accordingly made up his mind to exchange the alliance of imperial and subversive France, without whose aid and countenance GARIBALDI might now be melting candles on Staten Island instead of setting Italy in a blaze, for a renewed intimacy with absolutist Austria, the prop and hope of divine right in these disastrous days.

abstract: UP-TOWN IMPROVEMENTS OPENING OF THE EIGHTH-AVENUE FOR TRAVEL TO HARLEM. Among the contracts awarded on the 30th ult., in the Street Commissioner's Department, there was one which, while it was the largest awarded in that Department during this year, is also one of the most important to ...
lead_paragraph: UP-TOWN IMPROVEMENTS OPENING OF THE EIGHTH-AVENUE FOR TRAVEL TO HARLEM. Among the contracts awarded on the 30th ult., in the Street Commissioner's Department, there was one which, while it was the largest awarded in that Department during this year, is also one of the most important to residents in the upper part of the island. The contract is for regulating and grading the Eighth-avenue from Eighty-second to One Hundred and Second-street, and was awarded to GEORGE A. BUCKINGHAM, & CO., at $34,201 77. It embraces 51,000 cubic yards of stone-cutting, and the same amount of filling, with the necessary stone culverts, &c., and the work is to be completed in eighteen months. The avenue, from Fifty-ninth to Eighty-second-street has been under contract for a year to OSCAR TAYLOR, and from One Hundred and Second-street to One Hundred and Four-teenth-Street, to CORNELIUS SMITH, both of whom are pushing forward the work. When the middle section shall have been completed from Eighty-second-street to One Hundred and Second-street, the Eighth-avenue will become the main artery for travel on the western side of the Island, and the Eighth-avenue Railroad Company will gladly avail itself of the completion of the work, to extend their road to Harlem. The present work was awarded last year to a party who finding he had taken a losing job, abandoned the contract and it had to be readvertised. The present contractors are largely engaged in regulating and grading streets, and it is to be hoped that this important work will be pushed to completion with all possible speed.

abstract: Geronelle & Rolland vs. Henry Rosey. -- This was a motion to dissolve an attachment, against the defendant, as a non-resident. abstract: The Committees to negotiate for a union between the Breckinridge and Douglas sections of the Democracy, were commenced in this City yesterday morning, but at 10 o'clock last night nothing had been definitely agreed upon; and, so far as could be ascertained, no progress whatever had been made towards a coalition. It was supposed that the Chairman of the
lead_paragraph: The Committees to negotiate for a union between the Breckinridge and Douglas sections of the Democracy, were commenced in this City yesterday morning, but at 10 o'clock last night nothing had been definitely agreed upon; and, so far as could be ascertained, no progress whatever had been made towards a coalition. It was supposed that the Chairman of the Breckinridge State Central Committee, Mr. JNO. A. GREENE, who has lately arrived from Washington, where he has been in consultation with the President and with the National Executive Committee, had come prepared with an ultimatum for the consideration of the Douglas men, and that the only question in the negotiations would be its acceptance or rejection by them; but it seems that nothing definite was agreed to at Washington, the President having expressed the opinion that he had sufficient confidence in the Breckinridge men of this State to leave the terms of the bargain to their discretion, assuring them that, in case they could not form an honorable union with their opponents, he would back up their forces as an independent organization, with all the patronage of Government. Thus left to their discretion the Breckinridge Committee find it difficult to make their opponents believe that the discretion is a sound one, or that the terms which it proposes are either just or honorable. The Breckinridge Party, demanded ten men on the Electoral ticket. The Douglas men, while asserting that their strength in the State does not entitle them to more than one, nevertheless offer them four. It was rumored that at the last conference, yesterday afternoon, they even went so far as to offer them six; but the Brecks would not budge from their Original stand, and the consequence was that nothing was done. The Breckinridge Committee met at the Astor House at o'clock, (15 out of the 16 members being present,) when they were handed a communication from the Douglas Committee informing them that BENJAMIN WOOD, JOHN A. KENNEDY and Mr. CLAFFLIN had been appointed to confer with them, and that they would be happy to receive any committee they might be pleased to appoint, at Delmonico's. They immediately appointed JOHN A. GREENE of Syracuse, A.H. MILLER of Tioga, and THADDEUS P. MOTT of New-York, to confer with the Douglas Committee, and report the result at the Astor House at 3 o'clock. The conference was had, and the result reported, but as the latter was not satisfactory, the Committee, instructed them to hold another conference and report at 8 o'clock in the evening. At 8 o'clock the Committee met again, heard the report, and after discussing the matter for two hours adjourned, without coming to any decision, to 10 o'clock this morning.

abstract: Mr. Thomas S. Davidson, Clerk of the Hustings and Circuit Court of Danville, Va., and Mr. Joshua A. Young, had an altercation on the 1st inst. regarding a claim against the latter, which had been placed in Mr. Davidson's hands for collection. Mr. Davidson levied on Young's horse, whereat the owner became much excited and applied several abusive epithets to the officer of the law. He replied by striking Young on the breast with his fist, and was belabored in return with a piece of plank. To defend himself, Mr. Davidson drew a pistol and fired at his assailant, who clapped his hands to his stomach, exclaiming "You have shot enough," sank down and expired soon afterwards, Mr. Davidson was committed for trial.

abstract: -- The Albion's indignation over our supposed revelation of its domestic affairs is entirely thrown away. We know very well that the Editor of that paper is an "Englishman by birth, feeling and education:" -- but we know quite as well, from internal evidence, that the snobbish writer who in the editor's absence, assumes an arrogant censorship over the correspondents of the TIMES and other New-York journals, is not. An educated Englishman evinces no such awe of royalty as this person affects, -- nor does he find it at all necessary, in order to prove his loyalty, to drop on both knees every time the Prince's name is mentioned. Such demonstrations can only emanate from an American who fancies it for his interest, or mistakes it for his duty, to grovel a little deeper in the dust than English subjects are expected to do, and who makes still further ostentation of his devotion by vehemently reproaching everybody who declines to imitate his example. We neither know nor care a straw about the authorship of the Albion's tirade, -- nor have we given that print any occasion for its intimation that we have spoken from any knowledge of its internal arrangements. We knew from the articles themselves, -- from their tone and temper, -- that they were written by somebody who was affecting sentiments he did not feel, -- and who was an Englishman only for the time being and for a consideration. The Albion's reply is a confession that we were correct in our conjecture.

We knew from the articles themselves, -- from their tone and temper, -- that they were written by somebody who was affecting sentiments he did not feel, -- and who was an Englishman only for the time being and for a consideration. The Albion's reply is a confession that we were correct in our conjecture.

abstract: The Southern (S.C.) Guardian notices the fact that Col. PERRY'S letters on Disunion have been copied and commented on by the TIMES and other Northern Journals, and adds that "it would be only fair for them to inform their readers that the politics of Col. PERRY, and ...
lead_paragraph: The Southern (S.C.) Guardian notices the fact that Col. PERRY'S letters on Disunion have been copied and commented on by the TIMES and other Northern Journals, and adds that "it would be only fair for them to inform their readers that the politics of Col. PERRY, and the views which he has enunciated in these late epistles, are not indorsed by one hundred of the people of the State." So much the worse for the State, then. The letters are thoroughly sensible, and embody the only views consistent with sound judgment and an enlightened regard for the welfare of the Southern people. If Col. PERRY is alone in holding them, he enjoys the enviable position of being a good deal wiser than his neighbors.

abstract: On Friday morning orders were received by Captain HEKDYKINS, of the Revenue Cutter McClelland, to proceed at once with his vessel to Vera Cruz, and join the Squadron of observation at that place, being subject to the pleasure of the Commander-in-Chief of the home fleet. abstract: James L. Shaw, a resident of Clifton, S.I., was apprehended at the Staten Island ferry, on Saturday night, by Detective Poole, at the instance of Mr. Wm. H. Stone, an Assistant-Marshal of Lynn, Mass., who had obtained the proper authority from Gov. Morgan,
lead_paragraph: James L. Shaw, a resident of Clifton, S.I., was apprehended at the Staten Island ferry, on Saturday night, by Detective Poole, at the instance of Mr. Wm. H. Stone, an Assistant-Marshal of Lynn, Mass., who had obtained the proper authority from Gov. Morgan, for the return of the prisoner to Massachusetts, where he is under indictment on charges of embezzlement and seduction. It is alleged that in May last, while Shaw was temporarily sojourning at Marblehead, Mass., he made the acquaintance of Mrs. Susan Evans, of that place, from whom he obtained $350, which he unlawfully misappropriated. Shaw is also charged with having accomplished the ruin of Mrs. Evans' daughter, under a promise of marriage, and afterwards to have fled from the State. At the time the alleged crimes were committed, the accused had a wife and several children, who are still living on Staten Island. He departed for Massachusetts, last evening, in custody of the officer who effected his arrest.

abstract: On Monday the Academy of Music opened its portals and gave to New-York the cheering conviction that the world of fashion, if not come, was at all events coming home. Everybody, as he entered, looked around the edifice, as after an absence about some "Yarrow Revisited," to which belonged associations more or less sentimental. Faces familar in the establishment last season were soughs out and recognized, congratulatory nods were interchanged.
lead_paragraph: On Monday the Academy of Music opened its portals and gave to New-York the cheering conviction that the world of fashion, if not come, was at all events coming home. Everybody, as he entered, looked around the edifice, as after an absence about some "Yarrow Revisited," to which belonged associations more or less sentimental. Faces familar in the establishment last season were soughs out and recognized, congratulatory nods were interchanged. There was the charming STRAKOSCH, almost too affectionate to be sincere; the admirable GROW and the affable GOSCHE. One little figure alone was wanting to the perfection of the group, ULLMAN was absent. Personne ne pleure pour Logan. The interval of something like four months that had elapsed since all the same parties met in the same place, seemed to fade away like that trance of the monarch in the Eastern tale, who dipped his head into a tub of water, and after passing through a series of adventures in fancy, found on his emersion that they had all taken place in a few minutes. The Academy never puts on, like the other theatres for the opening of the season, a new attire to break this link. The scores of Vesuvius do not more completely preserve the rooms in the house of SALLUST than does the judicious ULLMAN preserve unchanged, from one season to another, the Academy and all its contingent phenomena. There on Monday night was the same affair, all over again, as on the night we left it, and under its most pleasing aspect, too, as being filled in every part.

abstract: The Mercantile Library and the Cooper Institute are reopened to the public, after their summer vacation, to-day.
lead_paragraph: The Mercantile Library and the Cooper Institute are reopened to the public, after their summer vacation, to-day. The Astor Library opened its doors last week, so that we have now fairly entered upon the new year of our chief literary institutions. The event is really a matter of no small moment: these resorts are centres of attraction to thousands of our citizens, and enter largely into the thoughts of readers and students. It needs not to be a bookworm to regard with interest and affection these mental store-houses. He must be insensible to intellectual charms who can walk under the dome of a library such as the Astor, and not feel raised and refined by the influences streaming down upon him from the firmament of bards and sages.

abstract: The indications of rain which were observable early on Saturday afternoon, deterred many who otherwise would have gone, from attending the open air matinee of Dodworth's Band at the Central Park. Only very ardent lovers of music will seek the nightingale at the risk of getting ducked. Yet, although the gathering was comparatively small, it was positively, large. The seats arranged for the accommodation of spectators were all occupied, and the space between the tents, set apart for them, was crowded. On the adjacent roads, the numerous passing carriages and equestrians halted suddenly when they came within ear-shot, and stood as if transfixed by the musical spell. The elevated spots in the vicinity were crowded with people, and here and there on the Mall and through the Ramble were groups of seated or perambulating listeners. The pleasantest part of the Park for hearing the music when Eolus is not there, or when he shakes his bags to the northward, is on the further shores of the pond. There the notes of the different instsuments come across the water to you softened and blended. Distance, the surroundings and the absence of the profanum vulgus add enchantment to the sound. The majority of those present yesterday thought differently. To be sure the wind was in the wrong direction for a resort to the upper shores. Sultry as it was in the lower part of the City there was a delightful breeze from the Northwest blowing through the Park all day long. But then there were green slopes just far enough southeast of the musicians' tent to be pleasant, of which comparatively few availed themselves. The belief seemed to have taken possession of polloi that the nearer they could get to the orchestra the more they would profit by the dulcet melody. A gaping crowd, pressing upon the quarters of the band, and peering into the larger ends of the brass pieces, appeared to be endeavoring to see each note as it issued, or to swallow it. He of the trombone seemed the especial object of curiosity and remark.

abstract: We have re  ceived from our special correspondent, a verbatim report of the speech of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE at Lexington on the 5th. It would fill eight or ten columns of the TIMES, and as we have already published a very full synopsis of it received by Telegraph, we cannot afford space for its publication at length.
lead_paragraph: -- We have received from our special correspondent, a verbatim report of the speech of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE at Lexington on the 5th. It would fill eight or ten columns of the TIMES, and as we have already published a very full synopsis of it received by Telegraph, we cannot afford space for its publication at length. What the public desired to know chiefly, was the ground which Mr. B. would take upon certain prominent political topics of the day. This was indicated sufficiently to satisfy public curiosity, by the Telegraphic report already given, -- and there would be very little general interest, therefore, in wading through the endless columns in which these views are elaborated.

abstract: -- The unfortunate gentlemen who have undertaken the task of making things pleasant in New-York for the Prince of Wales, are in a fair way to learn what perils do environ the man who labors for his fellow-creatures and the public good. They have resolved to give the Prince a ball -- the Prince, indeed, having hinted to them with tolerably Hibernian distinctness, that of all things he most desires a ball to be given him. To give the Prince a ball may seem to the unthinking reader a very simple matter. It is only to subscribe so much money, hire the Academy of Music, purchase an indefinite number of bouquets, engage Dodworth's Band, and lo! thing is done. The unthinking reader, if such be his notions, is just as wide of the mark as usual. Bouquets, bands, dancing-floors and committees go but a small way towards the composition of a ball. After these are all provided, comes the dread necessity of inviting your company -- a task not always pleasant or easy to the private amphitryon, and to a public committee the source of "woes unnumbered." Clearly, it is impossible that of the nine hundred and fifty thousand inhabitants of New-York any considerable proportion can be accommodated within the limits of any public building whatever. To inclose the City Hall Park, board it over, and cover it with a tent, would scarcely offer space for one-third of the people who think themselves, and are thought by their neighbors, likely to ensure the dignity and to enhance the brilliancy of a festive entertainment by their presence. And were this not so, the consideration that to give a ball in the City Hall Park, would be to include the City Hall, and would therefore involve an ex-officio invitation to the City Fathers, must make this idea at once untenable. Our Committee, therefore, must fall back upon the largest theatre in town, with its extreme capacity of three or four thousand guests. How are the wretched men to select this sacred band from the eager myriads of the Gothamite population? Are they to limit themselves, in their choice, to the aristocracy? If so, who are the aristocracy? In France, the recent census assures us there exist more than 150,000 nobles. In New-York alone we far outnumber this beggarly baronial account. Our aristocracy includes every class, all professions, men of old families, men of new families, men of no families at all; dwellers on all the avenues, in all the streets, on all the squares; dwellers in hotels, railway conductors, commercial travelers, and civilized Arabs generally. Who shall be taken, and who shall be left? In despair, the Committee create another committee, and divide among four hundred victims the fearful responsibility of exasperating nine hundred and forty-seven thousand of the inhabitants of the Metropolis. The result of all which is likely to be a ball, no doubt, and we trust a very splendid and agreeable ball; but after the ball is over how many heartburnings, how many quarrels and coolnesses, what untold and unchronicled social conspiracies and unappeasable wrath! Happy are those -- would they but know their own felicity -- whom fate or their foes shall exempt from all share in the calamities prepared for the devoted men who are sacrificing themselves to procure the Prince of Wales a polka and the world of New-York fashion a new sensation.
lead_paragraph: -- The unfortunate gentlemen who have undertaken the task of making things pleasant in New-York for the Prince of Wales, are in a fair way to learn what perils do environ the man who labors for his fellow-creatures and the public good. They have resolved to give the Prince a ball -- the Prince, indeed, having hinted to them with tolerably Hibernian distinctness, that of all things he most desires a ball to be given him. To give the Prince a ball may seem to the unthinking reader a very simple matter. It is only to subscribe so much money, hire the Academy of Music, purchase an indefinite number of bouquets, engage Dodworth's Band, and lo! thing is done. The unthinking reader, if such be his notions, is just as wide of the mark as usual. Bouquets, bands, dancing-floors and committees go but a small way towards the composition of a ball. After these are all provided, comes the dread necessity of inviting your company -- a task not always pleasant or easy to the private amphitryon, and to a public committee the source of "woes unnumbered." Clearly, it is impossible that of the nine hundred and fifty thousand inhabitants of New-York any considerable proportion can be accommodated within the limits of any public building whatever. To inclose the City Hall Park, board it over, and cover it with a tent, would scarcely offer space for one-third of the people who think themselves, and are thought by their neighbors, likely to ensure the dignity and to enhance the brilliancy of a festive entertainment by their presence. And were this not so, the consideration that to give a ball in the City Hall Park, would be to include the City Hall, and would therefore involve an ex-officio invitation to the City Fathers, must make this idea at once untenable. Our Committee, therefore, must fall back upon the largest theatre in town, with its extreme capacity of three or four thousand guests. How are the wretched men to select this sacred band from the eager myriads of the Gothamite population? Are they to limit themselves, in their choice, to the aristocracy? If so, who are the aristocracy? In France, the recent census assures us there exist more than 150,000 nobles. In New-York alone we far outnumber this beggarly baronial account. Our aristocracy includes every class, all professions, men of old families, men of new families, men of no families at all; dwellers on all the avenues, in all the streets, on all the squares; dwellers in hotels, railway conductors, commercial travelers, and civilized Arabs generally. Who shall be taken, and who shall be left? In despair, the Committee create another committee, and divide among four hundred victims the fearful responsibility of exasperating nine hundred and forty-seven thousand of the inhabitants of the Metropolis. The result of all which is likely to be a ball, no doubt, and we trust a very splendid and agreeable ball; but after the ball is over how many heartburnings, how many quarrels and coolnesses, what untold and unchronicled social conspiracies and unappeasable wrath! Happy are those -- would they but know their own felicity -- whom fate or their foes shall exempt from all share in the calamities prepared for the devoted men who are sacrificing themselves to procure the Prince of Wales a polka and the world of New-York fashion a new sensation.

abstract: -- On Saturday afternoon, DANA SCRIPTURE, of North Canton, Conn., while under me influence of liquor, made a murderous assault on his wife. Mrs. S. was stooping over the stove, when her husband came up behind her with an axe, and aimed at her head a blow designed to cleave open her skull. She arose just in time to save her life, the axe striking her head so far on one side as to avoid splitting the skull, but inflicting a frightful gash three inches long and laying bare the bone. The shrieks of Mrs. S. brought in Mrs. STODDARD, a near neighbor, who, by brave efforts, at the risk of her own life, succeeded in rescuing her from certain death, and conveyed her, covered with blood, to her own house -- the infuriated husband threatening to kill both women. Mr. S. was arrested, but whether further proceedings are to be had is not certain. He is overwhelmed with mortification and remorse, and his wife has been persuaded, by his earnest promises, to go back to live with him. He has previously threatened his wife when drunk, and he told a neighbor that on this occasion he meant to kill her. Mr. S. is the father of a grown-up family.
lead_paragraph: -- On Saturday afternoon, DANA SCRIPTURE, of North Canton, Conn., while under me influence of liquor, made a murderous assault on his wife. abstract: SUICIDE OF AN ITALIAN. Coroner O'KEEFE, on Saturday, investigated the circumstances attending the decease of FERDINAND PIERRE ANTONY, an Italian, twenty-five years of age, who shot himself at his boarding house, No. 75 Leonard-street.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF AN ITALIAN. Coroner O'KEEFE, on Saturday, investigated the circumstances attending the decease of FERDINAND PIERRE ANTONY, an Italian, twenty-five years of age, who shot himself at his boarding house, No. 75 Leonard-street. Deceased had been for some time unemployed, and had often expressed his intention to commit self-destruction, saying that he would rather die than beg or steal. On Saturday morning he complained of being ill, and soon afterwards the report of a pistol was heard up stairs. On going to his room, the servant girl found him lying on the floor with a pistol beside him, and the blood flowing from a wound near his heart. A verdict was rendered of suicide, while laboring under temporary aberration of mind.

abstract: -- The sudden departure of the Prince de Joinville from our shores some time since has now been fully explained. The Herald states that His Royal Highness had been invited to a fete at Washington Heights, and immediately left for France. In consequence probably of this untoward event, the Prince of Wales will not be honored in the same manner, Mr. BENNETT, as his organ assures us, having "had enough of Princes." It is to be presumed, also, that Princes have had quite enough of him.

abstract: Last year Dr. THOS. RAINEY, an American, and for many years a resident of Rio Janeiro, obtained from the Imperial Government of Brazil a grant for thirty years of the privilege of establishing a steam ferry from Rio Janeiro, three miles across the bay to Praia Grande, a place of much resort.
lead_paragraph: Last year Dr. THOS. RAINEY, an American, and for many years a resident of Rio Janeiro, obtained from the Imperial Government of Brazil a grant for thirty years of the privilege of establishing a steam ferry from Rio Janeiro, three miles across the bay to Praia Grande, a place of much resort. As soon as the necessary documents were signed, Dr. RAINEY proceeded to establish a joint stock company, and that done he came to this City, and contracted with Messrs. WEBB & BELL, at Greenpoint, for the construction of three steam ferry boats, and with Messrs. D.D. BADGER & CO., architectural iron brokers, for the erection of two iron ferry houses, 50x100 feet, which are to have highly ornamented fronts. On Saturday the first of these steamers was launched from the yard of Messrs. WEBB & BELL at Greenpoint, and was the first steamer built for Brazilian service ever launched in the waters of the United States, though other and smaller steamers have been built and sent out in sections. The steamer (the Primeisa) measures 400 tons -- is 134 feet long by 50 feet wide over the guards. She is built after the model of the North River ferry boats, and is constructed with a view to strength as well as speed, her ceilings and planking being of 2 1/2 inch white oak, with double frames of the same, running from stem to stern, and strongly copper-fastened. The engine, which has been constructed at the Novelty Works, is of the horizontal style, low-pressure, and of 180 horse power, calculated to insure a speed of 12 knots per hour.

abstract: The most fearful catastrophe which it has been our duty recently to record, occurred on Saturday morning on Lake Michigan. The steamer Lady Elgin, which left Chicago on the previous evening, bound for Lake Superior, with from three to four hundred persons on board, including a large party of excursionists, was run into by the schooner Augusta, and sunk in a short time, involving the loss of nearly all on board. The collision oc-
lead_paragraph: The most fearful catastrophe which it has been our duty recently to record, occurred on Saturday morning on Lake Michigan. The steamer Lady Elgin, which left Chicago on the previous evening, bound for Lake Superior, with from three to four hundred persons on board, including a large party of excursionists, was run into by the schooner Augusta, and sunk in a short time, involving the loss of nearly all on board. The collision ocurred about 2 o'clock in the morning, while dancing and other festivities were in progress. A list of the survivors is given elsewhere, together with some of those supposed to have been lost, among whom are Mr. LUMSDEN, of the New-Orleans Picayune, with his family, and HERBERT INGRAHAM, proprietor of the London Illustrated News, and his son.

abstract: The proposed fusion between the Douglas and Breckinridge forces, in this State, has come to an un  happy end. To the negotiations which so abruptly terminated at, the Astor House, last Saturday, there were two parties. The first of these consisted of
lead_paragraph: The proposed fusion between the Douglas and Breckinridge forces, in this State, has come to an un happy end. To the negotiations which so abruptly terminated at, the Astor House, last Saturday, there were two parties. The first of these consisted of CAGGER, CHURCH and Company, who only wished by the proposed, to place the Breckinridge men in a false position, and demoralize their party throughout the State -- there actually being no circumstances possible under which the Albany Regency would have allowed the fusion to be accomplished.

abstract: The Baltimore Sun of Wednesday says: The express train over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, which left the Camden station on Monday afternoon in charge of Conductor PHELPS, met with an accident and detention at 8 o'clock on Monday evening at the trestling bridge, which runs along the Potomac River, about three-quarters of a mile west of Harper's Ferry. Owing to the switch being misplaced, the engine ran off the track upon the bridge, tearing a portion of it up, and opening an aperture, down which was precipitated the engine, tender, baggage car, and a portion of the smoking car. The passenger cars remained on the bridge, and no one was injured. The passengers by the express train east, which reached the scene of the accident several hours later, were transferred to the western train, which being put about, reached the Camden station at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, only a half hour after schedule time. By 8 o'clock yesterday morning the bridge and track were repaired, and everything righted again, and the eastern-bound train returned to the west with the transferred western passengers.

abstract: The application of Mr. E. HOWE, Jr., for an extension of his patent for the needle used in the best sewing machines, which was for some time pending before the Commissioner of Patents, and which has been before noticed in the TIMES, was decided on Saturday last. The grounds on which the application was made ...
lead_paragraph: The application of Mr. E. HOWE, Jr., for an extension of his patent for the needle used in the best sewing machines, which was for some time pending before the Commissioner of Patents, and which has been before noticed in the TIMES, was decided on Saturday last. The grounds on which the application was made as produced in the argument of his Counsel, were, -- that the half million of dollars acquired by the inventor, as profits, was not a sufficient remuneration for the actual advantage derived from the use of the invention; that new branches of industry had been created by its means, and that by its use products had been cheapened and improved and hours of labor lessened, while wages had been increased. After having heard the arguments, the Coumissioner of Patents reserved his decision until Saturday last, when he granted the application and extended the patent for seven years. In making his decision, the Commissioner expressed the opinion that the profits which had accrued to the inventor, were not such as the value of the invention, entitled him to.

abstract: -- The sages and philosophers of the Tribune office, having worked their way to what they no doubt consider respectable height in public esteem, with truly philosophic prudence seem to be making arrangements for a safe and easy descent from that eminence to the level to which they evidently fear they must soon be brought. Yesterday afternoon, a large crowd collected in front of the establishment, and betrayed, by eager upward glances, an expectation of something unusual to happen within or upon that philanthropic pile. At precisely 4 o'clock, when the curiosity of the multitude had reached its height, a window was opened in the upper story of the building, and an iron crane swung therefrom, having a stout rope attached. The apparatus bore so close a resemblance to the gibbet on which traitors are hung, that its design was at once suspected among the spectators to be the capital punishment by strangulation of some political traitor within. The surprise of the throng may be "more easily described than imagined" when, instead of a white coat and soiled boots, encasing the retired partner of a "political firm," a small boy with a ragged jacket, and no shoes, was thrust through the wind wand into the noose, which was not, however, placed about his neck, but under his arms, as in the case of the Paddy, who requested the Sheriff "not to fumble about his neck, as he was so ticklish there he'd die laughing." By an arrangement of wheels and gears attached to the crane, the small boy descended, at a comfortable rate of velocity, which he was enabled to regulate by the manipulation of a clasp about the rope held in his hand. This descent was followed by numerous other aspirants from the crowd ascending the stairs for that purpose, until the candidates for this sliding scale of honor became so numerous that the proprietor of the machine was compelled to refuse applicants, and so the exhibition closed. Of course there were skeptics, as usual, in the crowd, who did not believe that the apparatus had been provided to break the fall of politicians who have climbed too high. Some of these insisted that the whole thing was gotten up by the inventors of a new fire-escape, by which a person descending could regulate his own rate of speed. In support of this theory they referred to advertisements in the morning papers as corroborating their views, and their opinion was rendered somewhat plausible by the fact that the apparatus would really serve as an excellent fire-escape.

abstract: The Orange excitement in Canada West appears to be increasing, rather than subsiding, and the infection of a partisan religious animosity is spreading over the Province. The extreme danger to the public peace, in such demonstrations as those contemplated by the Orange Societies of Kingston and Toronto, is familiar to every one's experience. Bigotry begets bigotry, and hatred begets hatred. In a free country like Canada -- if the people are ambitious to make it a free country -- the very first attempt to renew upon its soil those barbaric feuds that have so stained the civilization of Ireland, should be met and peremptorily rebuked.

abstract: The British Whig published at Kingston, in its  issue of the 7th, tells how the people felt at having the Prince pass by their city. They were determined not to be cheated out of all the fun which they had anticipated, so they had their regatta, and in the evening the Grand Ball came off. At the Supper which accompanied the Ball tyro toasts only were drunk-
lead_paragraph: The British Whig published at Kingston, in its issue of the 7th, tells how the people felt at having the Prince pass by their city. They were determined not to be cheated out of all the fun which they had anticipated, so they had their regatta, and in the evening the Grand Ball came off. At the Supper which accompanied the Ball tyro toasts only were drunk -- "The Queen," proposed by the Mayor, and "The Prince," by the Hon. JOHN A. MACDONALD. Some one mentioned the Governor-General, but it would have been dangerous to propose him, so the officials wisely abstained. After the ladies had risen, the Mayor and the Hon. JOHN A. MACDONALD were severally toasted, and both gentlemen happily responded. It was past three o'clock in the morning, when the last galop was danced, and the whole company went home.

abstract: The grand opening match -- eleven Americans vs. eleven Englishmen -- will take place on the 12th and 13th inst., on the new ground of this Club, at Germantown Pa. The Germantown Committee have invited from New-York, four members from the St. George's Club, one from New-York Club, one from Kings County Club, and five from the Philadelphia Clubs, to represent the English eleven, and from amongst the hundreds of American Cricketers in Philadelphia, the American eleven will be selected, from among Messrs. Barclay, Newhall, Vernon, Stevens, Provoost, Kephardt, Wisters, Davis, Large, Howe, Hall, Fisher, Hunt, Morgan, &c.

abstract: The extension of Mr. Howe's Sewing-Machine patent was announced in yesterday's TIMES. To-day we give somewhat more in extenso, the grown is which governed the decision of the United States Commissioner of Patents, which are those presented in the argument before him, of George Gifford, Esq., counsel for the applicant, in which the merits of the case are fully discussed. Mr. Gifford's argument, which extends over eighty pages of print, is to the effect that it is the law and established practice of the Patent-office to grant or refuse extensions of patents, not according to the profit received by the patentee, irrespective of the public value of the invention, but according to the ratio between the profit and the public value; and that tested by this rule, Howe's is the most meritorious application which has ever been before the Patent-office; that Mr. Howe was the first inventor of the first practical sewing-machine ever known, and not only so, but was the author and introducer of the art of machine-sewing; that that art now is and always has been dependent upon his invention; that his invention was not merely of the needle, (as some have supposed,) but of a combination of four classes of mechanic indispensable in a practical sewing-machine; that all sewing-machines are based upon and employ his inventions; and that the world is indebted to him for machine-sewing. The argument also shows by different modes of computation, that the value of sewing in the United States, capable of being done by the sewing machines, is at least $342,000,000 per year, and that Howe's machine, if applied to this work, in the exact form in which he made his first one in 1845, would save to the public in the United States at least $171,000,000 a year; that the sewing machine has already entered into and revolutionized more than 37 distinct departments of manufacture; that it has created new branches of manufacture, enlarged old ones, diminished importations by enlarging domestic manufactures, cheapened articles to consumers, raised the wages of laboring women, and changed them from unhealthy to healthy employments.

abstract: SHAKESPEARE in NEW-YORK, as of late years in London, seems to be altogether ruled by his old passion for East-Cheap. The West-end and Broadway theatres have surrendered him to Sadler's Wells and the Bowery. Mr. GEORGE WOOD, under whose manage-
lead_paragraph: SHAKESPEARE in NEW-YORK, as of late years in London, seems to be altogether ruled by his old passion for East-Cheap. The West-end and Broadway theatres have surrendered him to Sadler's Wells and the Bowery. Mr. GEORGE WOOD, under whose management the Old Bowery has become one of the neatest, best-appointed and most agreeable of theatres, thoroughly appreciates this fact, and with the help of Mr. and Mrs. J.W. WALLACE, Jr., he has just put the "Winter's Tale" upon his stage in a very thorough and elaborate fashion. That some of his actors in their more inspired moments insist on straddling for sublimity is undeniable, and critical doctors may differ about the truth to nature and to Shakespeare of Mr. WALLACK's Leonies, though none can deny the acrid intensity of the part as he renders it. But for the manager who has ventured upon the experiment of a Shakesperian revival in all the forms in the middle of September, let us have only praise, the more unstinted that the house nightly proves the sagacity as well as the spirit of his undertaking.

abstract: The hour of 2 o'clock yesterday was fixed for the meeting of the Committee appointed by the Board of Aldermen to investigate the charges preferred by the Mayor, against A.W. CRAVEN, Chief-Engineer, and THOS. B. TAPPEN, Vice-President of the Croton Board. Alderman STARR only was present, Messrs. GENET and BOOLE being engaged elsewhere, and in answer to requests of Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPEN to proceed, he declined, declaring that under existing circumstances he felt a delicacy in proceeding, without at least one of his colleagues being present. Mr. CRAVEN reminded him that on the 10th of August he had notified the Committee of his readiness to proceed with the investigation, and he hoped there would be no further postponement, a hope in which Mr. TAPPEN joined. Mr. STARR, however, decided to adjourn until to-day at 1 P.M., promising to sit thereafter daily until the matter was disposed of, and further promising to go on to-day, even if none of his colleagues were present.

Mr. CRAVEN reminded him that on the 10th of August he had notified the Committee of his readiness to proceed with the investigation, and he hoped there would be no further postponement, a hope in which Mr. TAPPEN joined. Mr. STARR, however, decided to adjourn until to-day at 1 P.M., promising to sit thereafter daily until the matter was disposed of, and further promising to go on to-day, even if none of his colleagues were present.

abstract: W.C. Wetmore et al. vs. The Board of Supervisors. -- This was the return to an alternative mandamus in the case, which was argued at Chambers of the Supreme Court, before Justice SUTHERLAND, on the 17th of August, and was stated in the TIMES on the following day. The Court now rendered decision granting a peremptory mandamus, requiring the Board of Supervisors to provide, by insertion in the tax levy or otherwise, for the payment of $80,000 to the Commissioners of Record, to be used in payment for public printing.

abstract: The Douglas Central Committee and every friend of DOUGLAS here repudiate the idea of fusion in NewYork. Hon. MILES TAYLOR has written to New-York protesting against fusion; so has Senator DOUGLAS himself. Hon. HERSCHEL V. JOHNSON passed through here this afternoon, en route for New-York, and will in person resist the proposed arrangement for fusion. It is said that such a step would lose the ticket ten votes where it would add one.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD's maiden effort at a political coup d'etal has not been crowned with a positively brilliant success. The telegraph curtly informs us this morning, that the Albany Regency decline with indignation to stultify themselves on the basis so liberally provided for them by the aspiring brother of his Excellency the Mayor. The letter announcing Mr. WOOD's successful settlement of Democratic differences, was last evening returned without an answer to its writer. The Douglas leaders in the City treat the proposition with equal contumely, and utterly refuse to "fuse."
lead_paragraph: Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD's maiden effort at a political coup d'etal has not been crowned with a positively brilliant success. The telegraph curtly informs us this morning, that the Albany Regency decline with indignation to stultify themselves on the basis so liberally provided for them by the aspiring brother of his Excellency the Mayor. The letter announcing Mr. WOOD's successful settlement of Democratic differences, was last evening returned without an answer to its writer. The Douglas leaders in the City treat the proposition with equal contumely, and utterly refuse to "fuse."

abstract: A shocking occurrence transpired shortly before 12 o'clock, last night, in Clarke-street, near Dominick, resulting in the instantaneous death of RICHARD GRAY, a young fireman, attached to Engine Company No. 29. The circumstances of the tragedy had not been fully ascertained up to the time that our reporter left the Eighth Ward Station-house, where the body of deceased had been removed, but from the facts he succeeded in obtaining, the murderer is probably one of three men whose arrest had been effected. The name of the suspected party is CHARLES MCALDHATTON, a painter, scarce 20 years of age, who lives in the rear of No. 25 Clark-street, to which access is had through an alley-way. He stated that while passing through this passage to the street, at about 11 1/2 o'clock, he came in contact with a man, whom he could not distinguish in the darkness. Inquiring who it was, he was threatened with a beating, when he made his way into the street, followed by the man whom he had addressed and another person whom at first he had not perceived. These instantly fell upon and knocked him down, after which they kicked and beat him. Escaping from his assailants, MCALDHALTON ran down to the corner of Dominick and Varick streets, where he met officer VAN BUREN to whom he related the circumstances. The officer ran into Clarke-street for the purpose of arresting the parties, and on reaching the place, he found the man GRAY lying dead upon the sidewalk, opposite No. 26, with the blood streaming from a wound in his back, which had probably penetrated his heart. A crowd of people were standing around the body, and one Mrs. GAVIN, keeper of a grocery-store at the number alluded to, stated that she had seen a number of young men participating in a fight at the opposite side of the street. One of them, whom she identified as the prisoner, MCALDHATTON, ran into her store, as she was looking at the disputants from the sidewalk, and immediately went back to the combattants and again darted into the store. Soon she heard the cry that a man was stabbed, and on going into her store she discovered the large knife used for cutting meat lying on the table, and its blade dripping with blood. As no other person than MCALDHATTON had been there, the inference is that he had used the weapon to inflict the mortal wound. The officer thereupon detained MCALDHTTON, After the deceased had been taken to the Station-house Capt. HELME and Sergt. MOUNT started in pursuit of the parties said to have been engaged in the affray, and arrested THOS. SLAVIN, who was with the deceased, and BARNARD MCALDHATTON, the brother of the prisoner.

abstract: In concluding the tenth year of their successful business enterprise. BAKER & GODWIN, PRINTERS, TRIBUNE BUILDINGS, feel impelled to acknowledge the very generous patronage extended to them through all the changes of the past decade of years. Beginning business with limited resources -- their entire establishment being continued to one floor, with but a single power press -- they have been compelled, year after year, to extend their premises and increase their presses, till at the expiration of the tenth year they possess an establishment which, for Extent, Number of Presses, Variety of type, and General Completeness, is equaled by few, and excelled by none, in facilities for the Neat and Rapid Execution of Every Description of NEWSPAPER, BOOK, JOB and CARD PRINTING.

abstract: The recent  statement of Lord PALMERSTON in the House of Commons, on the relations of Great Britain and Paraguay, has allayed any apprehension of an outbreak of actual hostilities. The misunderstanding between the two Powers will not, in all probability, result in a more serious stop than the withdrawal of the British Minister from Paraguay.
lead_paragraph: The recent statement of Lord PALMERSTON in the House of Commons, on the relations of Great Britain and Paraguay, has allayed any apprehension of an outbreak of actual hostilities. The misunderstanding between the two Powers will not, in all probability, result in a more serious stop than the withdrawal of the British Minister from Paraguay. It seems that the difficulty was occasioned by the unjustifiable imprisonment of a British subject, who was detained in confinement for a considerable time, and who was only released under the threat of a cruiser that, as an offset, a Paraguayan vessel, then at Buenos Ayres, should be seized and confiscated. The mere meditation of an act of such swift and arbitrary retribution appears to have brought the Paraguayan Government to its senses; and the victim, and the cause of the dispute, was immediately set free. We may, therefore, soon expect to hear that diplomatic relations between Great Britain and Paraguay have been renewed.

abstract: BENEFIT OF THE MUSCULAR McDONALD--The attraction inherent in the name of HEENAN, posted on dead walls, with the announcement that the Champion will give a sparring exhibition, has by no means departed yet. Next in magnitude to the anxiety to see the Prince of Wales, just now, is the curiosity to gaze at the Prince of Whalers. At the City Assembly
lead_paragraph: BENEFIT OF THE MUSCULAR McDONALD--The attraction inherent in the name of HEENAN, posted on dead walls, with the announcement that the Champion will give a sparring exhibition, has by no means departed yet. Next in magnitude to the anxiety to see the Prince of Wales, just now, is the curiosity to gaze at the Prince of Whalers. At the City Assembly Rooms, last night, for the benefit of MCDONALD, HERNAN's trainer, there was a grand muscular set-to. The Benicia Boy, AARON JONES, PRICE, WOODS, "Dublin MIKE," young DAYTON, CUSICK and MCDONALD, took part in the exercises, and an overflowing assemblage of all sorts of people witnessed and applauded. MCDONALD, at the close, made a brief speech, thanking his friends for their substantial aid and comfort, and promising to help any American who should come to England to fight. [Great applause.] The exhibition ended with the speech. Long after the audience had departed crowds stood around the entrance to the building awaiting the exit of the chief of the fighting men; he, however, after patting AARON JONES on the cheek a few times with the boxing-gloves, had departed early in the evening.

abstract: The election for State officers and members of Congress in Maine took place to-day. The vote is probably the largest ever cast in the State. Scattering returns, including several of the larger cities and towns, show Republican gains, and indicate the elec- tion of the full Republican ticket by large majorities. Twenty towns, heard from early in the evening, give WASHBURNE, (Rep.,) for Governor, 2,576 majority.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Monday, Sept. 10.

abstract: It is at length settled that there is to be no fusion between the Breckinridge and Douglas parties in this State. The letter of BENJAMIN WOOD, Chairman of the Douglas Conference Committee, accepting, at the eleventh hour, the terms proposed by the Breckinridge Committee, has been repudiated by DEAN RICHMOND, Chairman of the General Committee; and all further negotiations may be considered closed. Mr. WOOD forwarded the terms of the bargain, as agreed upon, together with the favorable recommendation, as stipulated, to DEAN RICHMOND, at Albany, on Sunday, with a request that an answer might be returned as soon as possible. At 6 o'clocklast evening his communication was returned to him unanswered. It was a subject of general remark among the leading Douglas men of the City yesterday, that Mr. WOOD had no power to contract an alliance on such terms as were proposed by the Breckinridge Committee, and the manner in which his bargain has been ratified, or rather repudiated, would seem to imply that this was the case. The approaching barbecue at Jones' Wood has raised the spirits of the Douglas men wonderfully, and they now declare that they don't want the assistance of the Breckinridge men, but can elect their ticket in this State in spite of both them and the Republicans.
lead_paragraph: It is at length settled that there is to be no fusion between the Breckinridge and Douglas parties in this State. abstract: It is very interesting to all outsiders to watch the developments of the fight between the two factions of the Democracy. In our own State, projects of uniting them both with the Bell men on one ticket, are rife, and the air is full of the rumors of their "sweet bargaining." The tone and attitude of the two parties towards each other, is therefore just now very different from what it was when Mr. DICKINSON appeared at the Cooper Institute in full war paint, and announced his purpose whenever he dealt with the Soft faction again, to be well armed with tomahawk and scalping-knife. But in other sections of the Union, the tone of matters is far different. DOUGLAS denounces BRECKINRIDGE as a Disunionist, and BRECKINRIDGE, repelling the accusation, charges DOUGLAS in turn, with having broken faith, and with representing principles "repugnant alike to reason and the Constitution."
lead_paragraph: It is very interesting to all outsiders to watch the developments of the fight between the two factions of the Democracy. abstract: The guests of the New-York Hotel were thrown into consternation after midnight, on Monday, by the pranks of a burglar who had concealed himself in the house. The fellow was discovered by Patrick Smith, the night-watchman, in the room of one of the boarders, helping himself to the property of the occupant.
lead_paragraph: The guests of the New-York Hotel were thrown into consternation after midnight, on Monday, by the pranks of a burglar who had concealed himself in the house. The fellow was discovered by Patrick Smith, the night-watchman, in the room of one of the boarders, helping himself to the property of the occupant. The watchman called for assistance to capture the thief, who immediately rushed upon and discharged one barrel of a revolver at him, happily without accomplishing his intention of shooting him. Col. Dehor, a guest of the house, ran toward the fellow for the purpose of securing him, when he also was made the target of another shot from the thief's revolver. The ball hit the Colonel in the leg, inflicting a wound which caused him to fall. Meantime the disturbance had attracted a number of persons to the hallway, where the affair transpired, and the desperate man was detained until Officer Pierson, of the Eighth Ward, arrived and took him into custody. The prisoner gave the name of Henry Adams, and stated that he was 20 years of age, and an engineer by occupation. On searching him a quantity of jewelry, clothing, pawn tickets, and 40 door keys, of every variety, was found in his possession. He also had a revolver with two of the chambers discharged. Upon the complaint of Hiram Cranston, proprietor of the hotel, the accused was committed by Justice CONNOLLY for trial on a charge of burglary, several of the rooms having been opened.

abstract: The Neapolitan troops were attacked by Garibaldians near Piale, by whom they were surrounded and defeated. An armistice was then proposed. The commanding officer referred their proposition to the General-in-Chief in order to obtain his decision. In the meantime the enthusiasm of the Neapolitan troops abated. They became disorganized and dispersed, leaving the batteries without any defenders.

abstract: Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, the hero of a hundred fights, appears to be thoroughly used up at last. Many people wonder why he was not used up before; and how it is that, in the face of so many defeats, and in spite of his despotic character, and deplorable lack of adminstrative capacity, he is able again and again to lure American citizens to ruin and to death.
lead_paragraph: Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, the hero of a hundred fights, appears to be thoroughly used up at last. Many people wonder why he was not used up before; and how it is that, in the face of so many defeats, and in spite of his despotic character, and deplorable lack of adminstrative capacity, he is able again and again to lure American citizens to ruin and to death. It is difficult to account for the folly that prompts so many people to follow the standard and desperate fortunes of WALKER, but we trust that his last escapade has completely disenchanted all roving Americans of filibustering tendencies, or has, at least, opened their eyes to the utterly selfish aims and ambition of their former idol.

abstract: To the astonishment of everybody, "La Traviata," which had been advertised to be sung last night at the Academy of Music, was not so sung, but in its place "Il Trovatore." The conscientious adherence of our managers to their programmes in times past had not prepared us for this remarkable volte-face; and we must say to them, as the amiable...
lead_paragraph: To the astonishment of everybody, "La Traviata," which had been advertised to be sung last night at the Academy of Music, was not so sung, but in its place "Il Trovatore." The conscientious adherence of our managers to their programmes in times past had not prepared us for this remarkable volte-face; and we must say to them, as the amiable Frenchman said to a friend whom he detected in a suspicious intimacy with his wife, that "if this thing goes on there will certainly be a coolness between us." Seriously it is infinitely to be regretted that the system of extravagant promises and deceptive performances should not at once be abandoned by the impresarii of the Academy. The day of these things is past, and the public is weary of them.

abstract: BROOKLYN YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. The regular monthly meeting of this Association was held last evening in the Association Rooms, Washington-street Institute. The reading of a portion of Scripture and a prayer, was followed by the usual recess of ten minutes for social intercourse. Upon re-assembling, propositions for membership were received, and the following named gentlemen, proposed at the last meeting, were declared elected: E.L. KALBFLEISCH, A. SUYDAM STATHOFF, FREDERIC HUFAD, E.H. GARBUTT, E.B. DANA.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. -- The regular monthly meeting of this Association was held last evening in the Association Rooms, Washington-street Institute. The reading of a portion of Scripture and a prayer, was followed by the usual recess of ten minutes for social intercourse. Upon re-assembling, propositions for membership were received, and the following named gentlemen, proposed at the last meeting, were declared elected: E.L. KALBFLEISCH, A. SUYDAM STATHOFF, FREDERIC HUFAD, E.H. GARBUTT, E.B. DANA. In place of the usual Essay, a discussion was had upon the duty of the Society towards the inmates of the various public institutions, and with this view, Mr. BEAL, the agent of the Prison Association was invited to be present. Mr. BEAL came forward and said that he was not a speaker, but a worker, and he came to inform them as to the prisons in this country. Crime appears to be seriously on the increase, and regretted the want of time to prepare some statistics. Mr. BEAL then read extracts from prison reports, showing that in 1856 70,950 persons were put into the prisons of New-York and Brooklyn, and the number had greatly increased every year since. Of those arrested during the last year 24.797 were intemperate, and there were thousands of temperate prisoners there who drink occasionally. He then referred to the condition of the prisoners. They are at first placed in a house of detention, where there is no one to care for their souls. Not less than 50,000 men and women will be incarcerated during the present year, without any facilities for washing, and their condition is fairly deplorable. There are no books. This is universally the case. There is a lack of moral appliances in all prisons, and still it is expected that prisoners will come out and walk correctly. The Raymond-street jail, he considered one of the worst prisons in the State of New-York. One or two friends go there on the Sabbath, but there is no sermon, but there ought to be a chapel and sermons there. Persons are imprisoned for years without hearing the Gospel. This should not be, for prisoners are made as we are. This association, he said, was admirably adapted to this work. He was aware that these institutions were under political influence, but he regretted it. It was the duty of every christian to go to the polls and elect good men to take charge of our penal institutions. Mr. BRACE related several incidents in relation to prisoners who had been reformed by kindness. JAMES MCKILLOP, chaplain of the Kings County Penitentiary for the last four years, then spoke of the necessity there was for religious instruction in that institution. Mr. THEODORE TILTON followed in an able address upon the general subject. The meeting was well attended, and considerable interest was manifested, but no decided action was taken.

abstract: Why will the thunder and the lightning, the storm-clouds and the rain, insist upon following His  Royal Highness wherever he goes? I don't expect any answer to this query, but give it utterance as do thousands of loyal Canadians, who really feel aggrieved at the course pursued by the airy Nubes who, regardless of consequences, thrust their dark visages right before the royal nose of the youthful "unattached Colonel."

abstract: Three weeks ago we recorded the experiences of the American astronomical corps on their expedition to observe the total solar eclipse on the coast of Labrador; and certainly the picture Profs. ALEXANDER and BARNARD gave of that barren, lifeless, rock-bound shore was well fitted to raise in one's mind a vivid image of monumental desolation. Now the scene changes, and from the gloomy grandeur of Labrador we are transported to the sunlit hills of radiant and romantic old Spain -- land of Moors and chivalry and the Alhambra -- land of the grave and gallant race -- land of DE VEGA and CERVANTES.
