abstract: Mr. FERNANDO WOOD is likely now to learn, if he has never before appreciated the value of a character. That he is the elected Chief Ma-...
lead_paragraph: Mr. FERNANDO WOOD is likely now to learn, if he has never before appreciated the value of a character. That he is the elected Chief Magistrate of the City of New-York is, unfortunately, not to be denied, but "His Excellency" may as well understand, once for all, that the votes won for him at the polls by the combined misrepresentations of the Herald and the Tribune, do not constitute a valid claim for him on the faith of his fellow-citizens, when he ventures to appear before the tribunal of public opinion as the organ of order and economy. The natural impulse of every honest citizen of New-York in such an emergency, is to suspect some personal passion or some political necessity as the governing spring of the Mayoral action. An appeal against perjury made by TITUS OATES, or a homily against ambition from AARON BURR, would hardly have commanded a more incredulous audience than an advocacy of municipal interests in the mouth of Mr. FERNANDO WOOD. This is a thing to be regretted, certainly, for the sake of the Metropolis, since we are saddled hopelessly with a general responsibility for Mr. WOOD and his ways. But it is a fact of our municipal history, nevertheless, and the revelations yesterday made by Mr. TAPPAN and Mr. CRAVEN, in their examination before a Committee of the Council, inflict upon this fact a mournful prominence.

abstract: Notwithstanding the recent outbreak among the convicts at Sing Sing State Prison, it is neither just nor charitable to punish a thousand men for the misdeeds of a few, nor to withhold from the great majority the means of self-improvement. It may not have occurred to the officers of the Prison that the difficulties with which they frequently have to contend, in reducing their charges to order, are, perhaps, due to the mental destitution of the prisoners. During working-hours,  it is quite possible to enforce discipline and govern the unruly, for the stated requirements of hard labor tend to divert moody thoughts into other channels, and the exercise of the perceptive qualities of the brain readily displaces that of the reflective. Yet there are times in the life of every convict, just as there are moments in all men's lives, when the requirements of task-masters end, and the man begins to think. The prisoner's Sundays hang heavily on his hands, and the hour of daylight which remains to him after the monotonous labor of the other six days, is equally tedious and lonely. That a criminal, destitute of any means of recreation, should improve these opportunities to devise mischief, is no more surprising than for an idle boy to become a prisoner in his turn. It is, therefore, a matter for sincere congratulation that Mr. TILTON's recent appeal in behalf of the State's prisoners is found to have met a hearty and most liberal response. Acting upon the representations of Mr. LUCKEY and other officials, who had urged the expediency of providing mental aliment for the convicts, this appeal invited contributions in aid of the establishment of a Prison Library, which should be freely tendered for the use of the inmates at Sing Sing. We learn that some fifteen hundred volumes have already been given for this purpose, and that donations are still arriving daily. A liberal present of $100 has also been made for the same object by Mr. WM.H. ASPINWALL -- an excellent example for others of our merchants. The contributions already received will form the nucleus of a library, from the free use of which the best results may be hoped. That the prisoners will eagerly avail themselves of their enlarged privilege, is sufficiently indicated by the avidity with which they have read and reread the few volumes that have heretofore occupied the shelves under the chaplain's charge; and that the reformatory influence of this charity will be partially visible, at least, it requires no argument to prove. The right sort of Prison Reform is that which develops the better nature of the convict, -- not that which debases him into a brute, or governs him by terror. Hence, this movement is to be regarded as a step in the right direction.

abstract: The irresistible logic of the times in which we live has at last driven the Austrian Government into a position from which nothing but a decisive resolution for life or death can extricate it.
lead_paragraph: The irresistible logic of the times in which we live has at last driven the Austrian Government into a position from which nothing but a decisive resolution for life or death can extricate it. In the face of the news which we publish to-day from Vienna, all speculations upon the probability of a violent Austrian intervention in the affairs of Italy flagrantly assume the absurdity which we have steadily fixed upon them. The domestic affairs of the Empire of FRANCIS JOSEPH have reached a crisis which makes all thought of a demonstrative foreign policy, for the present at least, impossible. The conviction has become universal throughout the Austrian States, from the Pruth to the Adige, that the day for stifling the constitutional aspirations of the Provinces united under the Apostolic sceptre has hopelessly gone by, and that if the imperial dynasty means to escape the fate which has overtaken the Bourbons in France, Spain and Italy, it must resolutely put itself at the head of the liberal drift of the nation. Gen. BENDEK, the most loyal of Hungarian magnates and Austrian officers, has requested the Emperor to relieve him of his post of Governor-General in Hungary, since he finds it impossible for him to carry out any coercive measures against the spirit of his fellow-countrymen. The majority of the Reichrath, or Council of the Empire -- a deliberative body recently reconstituted, for the purpose of helping the Emperor to organize his dominions on a tenable system -- have adopted the programme of the Hungarian leaders, demanding a complete domestic independence for every State of the Empire, and a federative government for the whole. The centralization experiment of Prince SCHWARTZENBERG has utterly failed, and the attempt to parody on the Austria of 1860 the experience of the France of RICHELIEU and LOUIS XIV. has ended in the irresistible outbreak of a Congress of nationalities demanding justice, freedom and internal developments. A compromise between the views of this formidable majority and the obstinate illusions of the Court party has been brought forward by a section of the Hungarian nobility; but it is understood that this compromise will find no favor with the people of any considerable portion of the Empire, and that if any attempt is made seriously to evade the exigencies of the moment by palliatives and half-measures, the Hungarian Councilors will retire in a body, making a formal and conspicuous protest, and that a general explosion will follow throughout the Empire, from Crotia to the Tyrol.

abstract: FIRES AND NARROW ESCAPE FROM SUFFOCATION. -- Early yesterday morning a fire occurred at No. 33 1/2 Chatham-street, occupied by MARK LUTTER as a jewelry-store and dwelling-house. It was caused by a candle which had been left burning in the bedroom of Mrs. LUTTER, who was sick, and when her husband awoke, so dense was the smoke that both had a narrow escape from suffocation in escaping from the building. The stock was damaged to the extent of $400. Insured for $1,750, in the Merchant's and Importer's and Trader's Companies. The building, owned by JOSEPH HART & SON, was slightly injured. Insured in the Bowery Company.....Another fire happened in the lager-bier saloon, No. 400 Canal-street, kept by a man named MILLER. The premises were unoccupied at the time, and the Fire Marshal has the origin of the fire under investigation. Between three and four hundred dollars' loss was suffered on stock, &c.

abstract: Sauvan vs. Kelly. -- This was an action against the Sheriff, for an alleged wrongful taking of the plaintiff's goods. The complaint alleged that the defendant on the 22d day of May 1860, took and carried away from the possession of the plaintiff, the entire stock and fixtures of the plaintiff's store in this City, consisting of laces, ribbons, dress and hat trimmings, worsted, ruches, skirts, toilet articles, gloves and other goods, wares and merchandise, usually kept in a fancy goods furnishing store, -- and stated the value of the property in a gross sum.

abstract: The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 29th, and Queenstown on the 30th ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Her advices, which are two days later than those received by the Prince Albert, were briefly telegraphed from Cape Race. We obtain the City of Washing-
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 29th, and Queenstown on the 30th ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Her advices, which are two days later than those received by the Prince Albert, were briefly telegraphed from Cape Race. We obtain the City of Washington's mails some interesting details of GARIBALDI's invasion of Calabria, and of the success that has so far attended his movements. The Calabrians are in revolt, and the spirit of insurrection has reached the Neapolitan capital. The report that the King of Naples has fled appears to have been premature; we may look, however, for the announcement by the next steamer. An important political speech, by Count DE PERSIGNY, in which the policy of the French Emperor is defined, will be found among our extracts. As already announced, the British Parliament has been prorogued by commission. We give elsewhere the text of the Royal speech. The weather in England was more favorable for the crops.

abstract: Monday night was rife with the horrible. At about the same hour that the murder of RICHARD GRAY occurred in Clarke-street, a man named JAMES FARRELL was mortally stabbed in Fortieth-street, near Tenth-avenue, by one JOHN FITZPATRICK. The parties to the affray lived in contiguous shanties in the localty in question, and became involved in a quarrel. They had not disputed long ere FITZPATRICK drew a knife, and stabbed his opponent three times in the breast and abdomen, and the injuries resulted in his instantaneous death.
lead_paragraph: Monday night was rife with the horrible. abstract: This most important subject was discussed at the last meeting of the New-York Sanitary Association, the recent death of a girl from arsenic, which she had purchased at a drug-store, and which was not labeled according to law, eliciting various comments from members present. The girl in question appears to have destroyed herself with premeditation, but there is reason to believe that had the druggist complied with the requirements of the statute her death would have been prevented.

abstract: The Forty-seventh Anniversary of the Battle of Lake Erie was celebrated at Cleveland, Ohio, on the 10th, by the inauguration of a statue in honor of Commodore PERRY. Among the distinguished strangers who filled Cleveland to overflowing, were Governor SPRAGUE and Staff, of Rhode Island, Commodore PERRY's native State; O.H. PERRY, of Boston, and Mrs. VINTON, of New-York, children of the Commodore, a large number of military companies and delegations from Buffalo, Rochester, Detroit, Sandusky, Toledo, Columbus, Pittsburgh and other cities.

abstract: Captain STURGE'S report of a battle with the Kiowa Indians states that, accompanied by friendly red skins, he pursued the enemy for some days in the neighborhood of Fort Arbukle and Fort Cobb, and finally had an engagement, the result of which was the total route of the Kiowas, of whom 43 were found dead on the field. The battle took place near Fort Kearney.
lead_paragraph: Captain STURGE'S report of a battle with the Kiowa Indians states that, accompanied by friendly red skins, he pursued the enemy for some days in the neighborhood of Fort Arbukle and Fort Cobb, and finally had an engagement, the result of which was the total route of the Kiowas, of whom 43 were found dead on the field. The battle took place near Fort Kearney. The soldiers who participated in the engagement belonged to companies A, B, C, D, E and I, First Cavalry, about 300 men all told. Captain STURGES, on the 27th of August, was at Fort Riley, Kansas Territory, where he arrived to recruit "man and horse." Like all other officers writing from the West, he complains of the emaciated condition of the horses of his regiment, owing to the dearth of grass, &c.

abstract: The People vs. Nicholas Miller. -- The prisoner in this case was convicted at the Special Sessions on a charge of soliciting emigrants for certain routes, without a license, and sentenced to three months imprisonment. The case now came up before Justice SUTHERLAND at Chambers of the Supreme Court, on an application for a writ of certiorari to take the case to the General Sessions, it being alleged that the commitment did not inform the prisoner of his right to select either of the two tribunals. The writ was granted and the case will go to the General Sessions for review.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Nicholas Miller. -- The prisoner in this case was convicted at the Special Sessions on a charge of soliciting emigrants for certain routes, without a license, and sentenced to three months imprisonment. The writ was granted and the case will go to the General Sessions for review.

abstract: A FIGHT WITH SLEDGE-HAMMERS, Two blacksmiths, named JOHN PUMPHREY and PATRICK DORAIN, employed in a shop near the railroad depot, Bedford, had a quarrel on Tuesday evening, when each seized a sledge-hammer and commenced the fight in earnest. Both were seriously, if not fatally, injured, and were carried away by their friends in an insensi-  ble condition.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--To-night this popular establishment will be open for the regular Fall and Winter season, under the personal management of the dramatic veteran himself, with Mr. LESTER WALLACK as stage-manager. During the brief recess, since the departure of Miss JANE COOMBS and her company, the interior of the building has been thoroughly renovated and redecorated. The company engaged are
lead_paragraph: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--To-night this popular establishment will be open for the regular Fall and Winter season, under the personal management of the dramatic veteran himself, with Mr. LESTER WALLACK as stage-manager. During the brief recess, since the departure of Miss JANE COOMBS and her company, the interior of the building has been thoroughly renovated and redecorated. The company engaged are mostly the old-established favorites -- Mr. BROUGHAM being absent in Europe, but soon to return -- and among them the public will be glad to recognize Messrs. BLAKE, LESTER WALLACE, WALCOT, A.H. DAVENPORT, SLOAN, NORTON, and others, with whose talents and faces they have long been familiar; while Mrs. HOEY, Miss MARY GANNON, the ever-young and always cherished Mrs. VERNON, with Miss FANNY MORANT, Mrs. SLOAN, Mrs. WALCOT, and other ladies, offer ample assurance that the performances of the ensuing season will certainly not fall short of the best things yet done here. By what is already foreshadowed, we predict an unusually splendid result for the forthcoming Autumn and Winter months.

abstract: As the time of the National election approaches, its usual effect of increasing activity at the Naturalization Office becomes apparent. For the past few days the number of persons taking out papers of citizenship has been nearly double the ordinary rate. During the present week no less than a hundred and fifty American citizens have been manufactured at the City Hall from stock of various origin and growth. The books of the Commissioner show that nearly two-thirds of all the foreigners naturalized are from Germany, the remaining third consist big almost entirely of Irish. The patriotic spirit of Englishmen prevents the most of that class among us from renouncing allegiance to the plum pudding and roast beef of "Hold Hengland;" and our Gallic citizens are generally unwilling to exchange imperial glories for Republican freedom. Quite a number of Italians take out the "first papers," but for the most part remove to the more genial climate of California before the time arrives for taking the oath of allegiance. A private arrangement of the Commissioner for furnishing certificates of citizenship, executed in different styles of art, furnishes an excellent means fur illustrating the difference of national characteristics belonging to the various patrons of his office. At first, in addition to the ordinarily printed forms which are furnished at the public expense, engrossed parchment certificates were provided, very elaborately adorned with illuminated headings, and colored seal and ribbon. This was furnished to those who were willing to pay a small amount for a more durable and showy evidence of their dignity as citizens of a free country, than the ordinarily printed form. Many of these were taken by the Germans, who deemed the event of their citizenship of sufficient importance to merit such commemoration. But the Celtic love of getting the best at the price of the poorest, induced the Commissioner to make a compromise between the two extremes, and furnish certificates less elaborate than the best, but more so than the forms provided by the office. The medium certificates are those which the Irish usually select.

abstract: details of the loss of the steamboat Lady Elgin come tardily. Little else is ascertained than that at 3 1/2 o'clock on Saturday morning, when off Waukegan, and about thirteen miles from land, she was run into by a schooner called the Augusta, and that in twenty minutes the steamer sunk, carrying down nearly all of some three hundred and fifty or four hundred passengers. The night is represented as being extremely dark and rainy, the wind blowing a gale, and the schooner under great headway. That the steamer showed lights sufficient to have notified the sailing vessel of her whereabouts, may be inferred from the fact that parties were dancing and music playing in the saloon at the moment of collision. As to the means of rescue provided upon the sinking vessel, it would seem that a sufficient number of life-preservers were supplied; and that three boats, capable of saving fifty persons, and which did actually land thirty in safety, were on board. These are all the facts bearing directly upon the question, of the responsibility for the accident, which have reached us, and upon evidence thus slight it would be the extreme of rashness to pronounce sentence of guilty of an event so fearful in its consequences upon any possible parties. It is painfully evident, however, that the provision for safety upon the steamer, would have left a multitude to perish had the weather been calm, and the hour mid-day, so sudden was her fate. Whether any precautions for safety would have availed under such awful conditions as those which the doomed vessel, thus heavily freighted with life, and exposed to risk in the crowded waters of Lake Michigan, actually encountered, is a point yet to be cleared up by the investigation of the Coroner. The courts of law will afterward determine where the accountability for the collision rests. Until these inquiries have been terminated, it is the most palpable justice that the popular judgment be suspended.

abstract: The projected consolidation of the Democratic factions in New-York has obviously no sympathy in the soul of Mr. DOUGLAS. Heretofore, and upon manifold occasions, that candid leader has avowed his aversion to entangling alliances, and especially empha
lead_paragraph: The projected consolidation of the Democratic factions in New-York has obviously no sympathy in the soul of Mr. DOUGLAS. Heretofore, and upon manifold occasions, that candid leader has avowed his aversion to entangling alliances, and especially emphasized his hostility to any conciliation with the adherents of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. He has excommunicated all Democrats who declined the test of loyalty to the Cincinnati Platform; exposed the disunionist tendencies of the Southern conspirators in whose hands Mr. BRECKINRIDGE permits himself to be a passive, and professes to be an unconscious, tool; and in thus defining the position of the schismatics has shown that covenants with them are politically and morally impossible. We are obliged to assume, what we conceive to be absurd, that Mr. DOUGLAS has forgotten his acknowledged craft as a politician, in the ardor of his private animosity against the Southern leaders; or else admit that his earnestness upon these points is the fruit of sincere convictions, which he will never consent to sacrifice on the altar of temporary expediency. But, notwithstanding these clear expressions of his views elsewhere, a portion of his friends in this State appear to have been persuaded that New-York might be made an exception to the Senator's general principle; that the prize of the Empire State might be sufficiently tempting to relax the rigor of political sentiments, which so seldom are found to resist the inducements of those gentle casuists, the friends of a candidate. It was hoped that in his New-York speech, to be delivered at Jones' Wood, symptoms of this conciliatory and compliant temper would be found, thus enabling the diplomatists who have thus far conducted the negotiations between the dissenting factions, to procure the final and sufficient sanction of the Committees, and so consolidate a trinity of discordant and repulsive factions in opposition to the Republicans.

abstract: ESCAPE AND CAPTURE OF A BURGLAR. -- On locking up the Sing Sing prison on Tuesday night, it was found that a convict named GREEN was missing. The watch was doubled, and everything done to prevent his passing the guards, but he was not found. A complaint was made that the matron's room had been entered and robbed during the night, and a tobacco-box and other articles dropped were recognized as belonging to GREEN. He had, no doubt, entered the building to procure a change of dress. A person was been lurking about Sparta, a short distance below the prison, and Officers LEGGETT and SARLES took the night train. Arriving at Glenwood, a station one mile above Yonkers, a man was seen dodging about towards the end of the train, and when it started he sprang on the rear platform. LEGGETT went to the platform and arrested him, when, sure enough, he was found to be the missing convict.
lead_paragraph: ESCAPE AND CAPTURE OF A BURGLAR. -- On locking up the Sing Sing prison on Tuesday night, it was found that a convict named GREEN was missing. abstract: THE FIVE POINTS CHILDREN AT A PALACE GARDEN, With the hope of replenishing the exhausted funds of the Five Points House of industry, rendered so necessary by the near approach of cold weather, the managers yesterday held a Picnic and exhibition at Palace Garden.
lead_paragraph: THE FIVE POINTS CHILDREN AT A PALACE GARDEN, With the hope of replenishing the exhausted funds of the Five Points House of industry, rendered so necessary by the near approach of cold weather, the managers yesterday held a Picnic and exhibition at Palace Garden. The National Guard Band was engaged for the occasion, and long before the hour for beginning the exercises, discoursed inviting music from the stand inside the inclosure. The children were there also at an early hour, to the number of over two hundred, tidily dressed, who rollicked, frolicked, danced and marched over the grounds, waiting for their friends and the needful quarters to come in. The day, however, was inauspicious, and few except some old familiar friends of the Home found their way through the gusty, dusty streets, to the place of exhibition. At the hour designated for the exercises to begin not over fifty or sixty persons had assembled, the large majority being ladies. Nothing discouraged, however, Mr. BARLOW, the Superintendent of the Institution, proceeded with the programme, which consisted of singing by the children, interspersed by music from the band. The principal features of the entertainment were the performance of several very clever tricks of magic and attempts at ventriloquism by Mr. BACON, who is connected with the Sunday School. Two bright little girls, named KATE and LENA FOX, were introduced by Mr. BARLOW, and a brief but touching history given of the circumstances under which he found them, living in a miserable garret in Leonard-street, their mother having died, and the father being incapable, from drunkenness, of providing for them. They sang "I ought to love my mother," which moved many to tears. It is to be regretted that the exhibition should have realized so little.

abstract: The Douglas Democrats held a large meeting at Jones' Wood yesterday. The "Grand Political Carnival and Ox-roast," so extensively advertised, drew together an assemblage of from 20,000 to 30,000 people. The monstrous blue eagle in the poster, that stared citizens in the face from every board fence and new brick wall, from whose beak streamed the pleonastic placard, "Popular Sovereignty of the People, was not limned for nothing. Early in the day the beef-eating Democrats began to gather without the inclosure from which the viands were to be dispensed. The native voters and the unnaturalized votaries of the party on empty stomachs wended to the Wood, and awaited the feast for which they had reserved their appetites. But disappointment waits on expectation. Of all those who for hours stood there in hungry anticipation, comparatively few obtained a dinner. An ox, a sheep, a calf, and a hog, were the sacrifices by which the people were sought to be propitiated. The ox, it is said, weighed 2,200 pounds before it was slaughtered, and was from Kentucky. All were presented by New-York butchers, and were killed on Monday. At 6 P.M. on that day the cooking commenced. In a trench sixteen feet long, eight feet wide, and five feet deep, lined with stone, a fire was built, and when the heat became intense the ox spitted on a young hickory tree, forty-eight feet long, was laid across the hole. Every now and then the spit was turned, that the meat might be equably roasted on all sides. The fire occupied only a portion of the bottom of the trench. On the other part tin pans were laid, in which the juice of the meat was caught. Into these the necessary condiments were thrown, and the cooks, with long dippers, poured the gravy thus seasoned upon the beef. With long-handled pitchforks they supported the huge roasting piece when it needed support, and from time to time tested the tenderness of the side turned towards the fire. The veteran PALMO was chief cook, and four assistants divided his labors. Councilman CAMPBELL had the general superintendence of the barbecue. The cooking of the ox occupied twelve hours, and was completed early yesterday morning. The other animals were first prepared for food. Besides these, there were 2,000 loaves of bread, and 10 barrels of Boston crackers. Most of those who went to the Wood at a seasonable hour supposed that the roasting would take place before their eyes, and were by no means pleased to find the cooks already engaged in cutting the meat into slices.

abstract: One of our cotemporaries, who exercises in common with the Irish Orangemen the high vocation of "applying religion to politics," in making proper comments a few days ago upon the recent misconduct of its coadjutors in Canada, fell into the somewhat comical error
lead_paragraph: One of our cotemporaries, who exercises in common with the Irish Orangemen the high vocation of "applying religion to politics," in making proper comments a few days ago upon the recent misconduct of its coadjutors in Canada, fell into the somewhat comical error of saddling the Celtic portion of the Irish people with the responsibility of the late outrages at Kingston and Toronto. The Celts, and especially the Paddy variety of the species, have faults enough to answer for, but there is something exquisite in the ignorance which gravely reprehends them for the misdeeds of Orangemen. The truth is that the men who have been recently pouring out the vials of their partisan wrath upon the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Newcastle, are of as purely and thoroughly English, or Anglo-Saxon breed, as any Massachusetts Yankee or Virginia planter. They are the descendants of English colonists, planted in Ireland at a period as recent as, and even more so, than that of the settlement of New-England, and they have been infinitely less exposed than any of the North American colonists to intermixture with any other race. With the exception of a few dozen French Huguenots, Englishmen and Lowland Scotch are the only strangers who have ever settled in Ireland; and so far from being Celts, it has been the pride and boast of Orangemen, for half-a-dozen generations, that no Irish Catholic blood ever mingled with the pure Protestant current in their veins. The fact of any one in the least familiar with Irish history during the last three hundred years, holding up the follies of Orangemen as an illustration of the inherent absurdity and indiscretion of the Celtic race, is about as absurd as pointing to an encounter with bowie knives between two Mississippian doctors, as a proof the irreclaimable babarism of the Choctaws or Sioux.

abstract: The consecration of the new building erected by the congregation "Shearith Israel," of this City, situated on Nineteenth-street, west of Fifth-avenue, took place yesterday afternoon. The edifice is a magnificent one, built of Dorchester drab stone, and combining the Corinthian and Doric styles of architecture. The interior is handsomely fitted up, and decorated with Scagliola columns and entablatures. The ark is a very beautiful structure of rich marbles and rosewood, flanked by four columno of marble, splendidly grained, and the whole is surmounted by a very handsome dome of iron, which is lit with 600 jets of gas. Among the gentlemen present were Rev. Dr. Beeswick of the Swedenborgian Church, Rev. Dr. Bardy, Rev. M.R. de Leeuven, Hon. Charles King, President of Columbia College, Messrs. R.L. Stuart, A.H. Green, P.J. Joachimssen, and many other prominent citizens. At 5 P.M. the ceremonies commenced by the chazan (minister) knocking at the door three times and chanting, "Open the door of righteousness that I may enter and praise the Lord. The choir responded, "This is the gate of the Lord; the righteous shall enter therin." The Trustees of the congregation then entered, bearing the scrolls of the Law handsomely decorated with silver ornaments. They made seven circuits of the building, the Reader and choir chanting a different hymn at each circuit. The ark was then opened, and the perpetual lamp lit. After the circuits were concluded the scrolls of the Law were returned to the Ark, when Rev. Dr. FISCHELL, the Rabbi preacher, ascended the pulpit and preached from the following text: "Those that be planted in the House of the Lord shall flourish in the courts of our God." (Psalm xcii., verse 13.) The minister then offered up a prayer for the welfare of the President of the United States and the General Government, followed by another for the congregation. A prayer was then chanted by the same gentleman, when the proceedings concluded with a hymn sung by the choir.

abstract: -- The latest foreign advices announce the intended return of the Great Eastern to this port, her day of departure from England having been fixed for Oct. 17. Upon what errand of commerce the great ship thus comes to us, at a season of the year so unpropitious for business, we are at a loss to conceive. Possibly the proprietors reckon upon the negotiations of Mr. LINDSAY to procure a continuance of that exemption from the penalties of our coasting laws, which they found so profitable during the Summer. Perhaps New-York is selected as a port of call between Mr. DUDLEY MANN's still nameless harbor on the Chesapeake and Milford Haven. Perhaps, again, a series of Winter excursions to the tropics, the passengers finding themselves, and not finding the invisible YATES, may be contemplated. In any event, upon one thing New-York has a right to insist. Let the Great Eastern by no means bring back to us Cox. Let Cox be left in Cocaigne. Cox has no Box waiting for him in New-York, unless in Eldridge-street Jail. He is loved and longed for only by half-a-score of creditors, a Sheriff's officer or two, and possibly some handful of vindictive Cape May excursionists. The rest of the community demands that the gates of the harbor be forever barred against Cox. The bar which will admit the leviathan so easily is become morally impassable for Cox and his Directors. Of them, as connected with the great ship, we feel as Mr. EMERSON impolitely felt of New-Hampshire and her sons -- that

abstract: We learn, from Washington, that the Secretary of the Treasury opened, on Tuesday, the bids for the construction and use by the Government of a telegraphic line to the Pacific, and that his decision upon the subject may be expected in the course of the week.
lead_paragraph: We learn, from Washington, that the Secretary of the Treasury opened, on Tuesday, the bids for the construction and use by the Government of a telegraphic line to the Pacific, and that his decision upon the subject may be expected in the course of the week. The work is regarded with a deeper concern by our California brethren than any political issue at stake, and it is one which no political bias or partisanship should be allowed to disturb or interrupt. We trust -- but can scarcely hope -- that a matter which has such an important bearing upon the integrity of the Union will receive from the Secretary the prompt and impartial consideration that it merits.

abstract: Harry Smith, an Englisman, who claims to have been a waiter at the Palace Garden ever since the establishment has been open, was taken before Justice CONNOLLY on a charge of having passed a counterfeit $2 bill on the Bank of Middlebury, Vt., at the store of Benjamin Hadley, No. 70 Sixth-avenue, in payment for an earthenware jar, worth 37 cents, and also another bill, of similar description, for refreshments at the Charter Oak saloon, corner of Broadway and Eighth-street. The accused stated that the worthless bills had been given him by the proprietors of the Malta Saloon. Broadway, with directions to purchase hams and other provisions for the Douglas barbecue. He was committed for examination. Another man, named Thomas Flynn, attempted to swindle the keeper of the drinking-place. No. 80 West-street, with one of the same counterfeits. He was arrested by Officer Codett, of the First Ward, and Justice KELLY hold him for trial.

abstract: Judge Morton, of the Superior Court, in Boston, had a curious case before him on Friday; suit was brought upon a bond, for the recovery of a small claim. The defendant was a member of the Suffolk Bar, and it appeared that he himself drafted the bond, and made it so legally imperfect that he had the
lead_paragraph: -- Judge Morton, of the Superior Court, in Boston, had a curious case before him on Friday; suit was brought upon a bond, for the recovery of a small claim. The defendant was a member of the Suffolk Bar, and it appeared that he himself drafted the bond, and made it so legally imperfect that he had the assurance to defend the suit under it, claiming that the instrument was of no value. Upon this revelation the Judge remarked that he considered such conduct as almost meriting contempt of the Court. The defending counsel stated that there were certain circumstances in the case which he thought justified him in his course. The Judge replied that he could scarcely conceive of any circumstances in which counsel could come into Court and claim benefit from his own errors. And thus the matter dropped without further explanation.

abstract: The Douglas Democracy of this and surrounding cities held a monster meeting at Jones' Wood yesterday. There were from 20,000 to 30,000 persons present, and the "grand political carnival and ox-roast" was considered a success. Prior to
lead_paragraph: The Douglas Democracy of this and surrounding cities held a monster meeting at Jones' Wood yesterday. There were from 20,000 to 30,000 persons present, and the "grand political carnival and ox-roast" was considered a success. Prior to listening to the speeches, the Kentucky ox, the calf, the sheep and the hog, which had been roasted whole, were devoured by the multitude, in the open field, with apparent relish. When the meats had been disposed of, Messrs. DOUGLAS and JOHNSON spoke from the main stand to a vast concourse of people. There was nothing new in either of the speeches. Both were determined to "stand by the Union, the Constitution, the enforcement of the laws, and non-intervention." In relation to the fusion movement, Mr. DOUGLAS said, in answer to a question, that when Mr. BRECKINRIDGE answered the question put to him (Mr. DOUGLAS) at Norfolk, and by it showed himself to be a staunch Union man, it would be time enough to talk of fusion. Several speeches were made by much less important men at other stands. During the evening Messrs. DOUGLAS and JOHNSON were serenaded at the Fifth-avenue Hotel.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER was unable, yesterday, to prosecute an investigation of the circumstances attending the murder of JAMES FARRELL, an Irish laborer, in Fortieth-street, on Monday evening. In the first place he was engaged in the case of RICHARDSON GRAY, who was murdered in the Eighth Ward, and had he not have been thus occupied, the inquest upon FARRELL must have been postponed, as no witnesses of the murder, excepting the wife of deceased, have presented themselves. The police have not met with success in their search for JOHN FITZPATRICK, the alleged murderer, and the supposition is that he has fled from the City. Drs. HOUTON and WELTJE, on Tuesday evening, made a post-mortem examination of the body of the murdered man, which resulted in the discovery of several frightful wounds in the left side and back, two of which would each have proved fatal. An effort will be made to hold the inquest to-day.

abstract: The graceful little  flotilla of swans, who have been the objects of curiosity and admiration to explorers of the Central Park for several months, have received a vigorous reinforcement. In the present case the popular benefactors are the venerable guild of Vintners, one of the oldest of the London trades corporations, who, sympathising with the ill-fortune which befell the Hamburg donation, have sought to repair the loss by the dispatch hither of fifty beautiful birds.
lead_paragraph: The graceful little flotilla of swans, who have been the objects of curiosity and admiration to explorers of the Central Park for several months, have received a vigorous reinforcement. In the present case the popular benefactors are the venerable guild of Vintners, one of the oldest of the London trades corporations, who, sympathising with the ill-fortune which befell the Hamburg donation, have sought to repair the loss by the dispatch hither of fifty beautiful birds. That the Company may acquire untold riches from the new French treaty and its liberal tariff upon wines, is the most apposite aspiration we can offer in return. One of the flock died upon the passage; the remainder have reached the City, and been presented through Mr. AUGUST BELMONT to the Commissioners of the Central Park. Most of the strangers have made themselves at home in the artificial lake.

abstract: M. NAPOLEON III, has done enough for the eagles of the Empire; and no man who knows the tastes and tendencies of the French population of to-day.
lead_paragraph: M. DE PERSIGNY's formal declaration that France has done with the role of the soldier, and only asks now to be permitted to beat the sword of Austerlitz and Solferino into a plowshare, is no doubt exactly true as a description of the prevalent feeling of the French people. NAPOLEON III, has done enough for the eagles of the Empire; and no man who knows the tastes and tendencies of the French population of to-day, will need to be assured that the desire of worldly well-being has really gained enormously upon the passion for glory in the national heart during the last twenty years. So far as France is concerned, two great wars have virtually liberated her from the intolerable pressure put upon her by the short-sighted sovereigns of the Holy Alliance, and restored her to a voice in the councils of Europe, so potent and formidable, that it may honorably be raised for peace.

lead_paragraph: The wind on Wednesday was very heavy from the North-West, but was not attended with any serious results. The brig Loranna, from Ceinfuegos, while at anchor in the Lower Bay, dragged her anchor, and after thumping over the South-West Spit, was drifting out of the Hook, when the mate, who was the only person on board, except the cook, set a signal of distress. The Pilot-boat David Mitchell, No. 5, went to her assistance, and placed on board of her two of her pilots -- Mr. THOMAS CONKLING and WALTER BREWER -- and one seaman. In doing so their yawl was capsized and lost. The men who were in the yawl were picked up by Mr. ALEXANDER COCHRAN, one of the pilots in charge of the pilot-boat. The brig was then securely anchored.

abstract: -- The Captain General of Cuba has addressed a new circular to his subordinate officials on the subject of the Slave-trade. He earnestly entreats them to keep a faithful watch upon the movements of the traders, and to prevent the landing of any more African negroes on the Cuban coast. His Excellency goes further than this, and threatens disobedient magistrates and public functionaries with suspension, if it should turn out that Africans have been landed in their jurisdiction, without their having used every exertion to prevent such a violation of law. The "circular" which the Captain-General of Cuba has now issued, in obedience to instructions from home, is precisely similar to others that have previously emanated from the Vice-Regal Palace. It is quite notorious that the orders then promulgated were so utterly disregarded that, immediately after the publication of the official injunction, the Slave-trade became more active than ever. We do not believe that the punishment of a single offending public functionary is upon record, and it is farcical to say that slaves can be landed anywhere on the coast of Cuba without the full knowledge and consent of the local authorities. The very wording of the present circular shows a disinclination to perform the duty which the home Government has imposed upon him at the instigation of Great Britain; and there is unfortunately every reason to believe that, like other documents of the same nature, it will not afford even a passing check to the flow of the Slave-trade.

abstract: JOHN S. It was stated that the accused for eight months past had been employed as entry clerk by the complainants,...
lead_paragraph: JOHN S. BRUSH, a fashionably-attired individual, aged 19, was brought before Justice BRENNAN yesterday, on a charge of having stolen a quantity of stella and broche shawls from Messrs, MILLS RAY, importers, at No. 318 Broadway. It was stated that the accused for eight months past had been employed as entry clerk by the complainants, and that the robberies had been perpetrated in the interval between the 10th of June last and the 7th inst. During this time the shawls have disappeared from the store in large quantities, and the merchants had no doubt that one of their clerks was the thief, but every effort on their part failed to discover the delinquent. Recently the matter was brought to the attention of Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Ward, who soon obtained information which led him to watch particularly the movements of young BRUSH, and a night or two since, having followed him through various streets, the policeman saw him enter Odd Fellow's Hall in Centre-street, where he remained a short time. When he came from the saloon GOLDEN noticed that BRUSH brought out with him a bundle, which he did not have before, and seeming to exercise much caution in his actions, he went to PECARE's pawn-office in Grand-street, near Mott, where he rang the bell of the private door. The officer, in plain clothes, obtained admission to the establishment at the same time, pretending that he wanted to pledge his watch, and thus satisfied himself as to the contents of the young man's package. This accomplished, he engaged in conversation with the youth, and having invited him to take some refreshments, beguiled him into the Station-house. When the knowledge that he had been trapped dawned upon the young man's mind, he became very indignant, and protested his innocence of any crime. Finally, however, he made a full confession of the robberies. He stated that he had stolen as many as sixty-one shawls from his employers, and that the aggregate value of that property was about $600. These goods he had disposed of at thirteen pawn-offices for sums by no means equivalent to their value. For at least ten days previous to his arrest he had taken four shawls each day, all of which he hnd disposed of at PECARE's. His manner of bringing the articles from the store was to wind them around his body, beneath his shirt, and it was a very easy thing to find a place wherein he could take the goods from their concealment when he wanted to do so. Upon the information thus obtained, Officer GOLDEN has already recovered thirty-eight of the shawls, and the remainder, it is thought, will also be obtained. Thirteen of the shawls were found in PECARE's establishment, and he denied that he had any more in his possession, strengthening his statement by exhibiting his books, which show that the others had been redeemed by BRUSH. The latter denies, however, having ever redeemed one of them. BRUSH, among his other confessions, stated that the extravagant demands of a young woman with whom he had been intimate, compelled him to commit the robberies. A quiet little supper together had often cost him $20 each, and a running account which he kept at a livery-stable demonstrated that a week's bill for horses several times amounted to $40. His salary of $350 per annum, of course, was insufficent for a person of such luxurious habits, and he entered upon his career of dishonesty to make up the deficiency. The magistrate required the friends of the prisoner, who are persons of respectability, to furnish bail for his appearance to answer at the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: -- On Tuesday night, as a train of cars on the Old Road was running through a piece of wood west of Geneva, the head-light of the locomotive was suddenly extinguished. FRANK MOSHIER, the engineer, went forward to see what was wrong and found in the reflector an owl, which had gone through the glass and was still alive within. The bird had made a dash for the light as the engine came along, and had thus been trapped.

abstract: The outworks were stormed after a short engagement outside the fort. A sharp fire was kept up by the latter for upwards of two hours; the artillery of the place, though not very numerous, being well served. But the outworks being taken, Gen. VIALA was forced to capitulate. The artillerymen were the first to refuse doing their duty any longer. The Neapolitans had 500 killed or wounded, and 500 made prisoners. GARIBALDI's loss was severe, but is not stated. Col. BIXIO was slightly wounded in the arm.

abstract: The opera of "La Traviata" cannot get itself sung this season. Perhaps this indicates an improvement in the morale of the Opera; and we hope that this may be the true explanation of a very curious but indubitable fact. Last night, for the second time, Violetta was cut off before she was born, and Mme. CORTESI went on, strangled with bronchial emotion. We were to have had "La Traviata" and we had ...
lead_paragraph: The opera of "La Traviata" cannot get itself sung this season. Perhaps this indicates an improvement in the morale of the Opera; and we hope that this may be the true explanation of a very curious but indubitable fact. Last night, for the second time, Violetta was cut off before she was born, and Mme. CORTESI went on, strangled with bronchial emotion. We were to have had "La Traviata" and we had -- nothing -- not even an explanation. On Wednesday we had, however, "I Puritani," with the exquisite voice of BRIGNOLI, who might have been in better humor, were it only for the pleasure of hearing himself sing; and without the orotund organ of SUSINI, who ventured upon the privilege of tenors and soprani, and was indisposed.

abstract: THE MURDER OF JAMES FARRELL. An investigation was made yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER of the facts in relation to the death of JAMES FARRELL, a native of Ireland, 27 years of age, who was fatally
lead_paragraph: THE MURDER OF JAMES FARRELL. An investigation was made yesterday by Coroner SCHIRMER of the facts in relation to the death of JAMES FARRELL, a native of Ireland, 27 years of age, who was fatally stabbed on Monday night last by a man named JOHN FITZPATRICK, with whom he had engaged in an altercation. PATRICK FITZPATRICK, a son of the accused, deposed: "About 11 o'clock on Monday night my father had a fight with deceased; I heard father ask deceased to fight; deceased was sitting on a rock at the time, and he replied, "Hold on till I put on my boots;" after he had got them on, he walked up to father and squared off at him; I cannot tell who struck the first blow, as it was pretty dark; they fought about two minutes; I was close to them, and two other men also stood near, but neither of them interfered; one of these men attempted to get father away before the fight commenced; after the fight I took, father to our house; he had blood upon his hands and got some on my sleeve; I did not see a dagger in his hand at the time of the fight, but afterwards I saw him have a butcher's knife; he ran away soon after the fight." MICHAEL TRACY, residing in Ninth-avenue, near Fortieth-street, testified that FITZPATRICK came to his house on the night of the murder, while he was in bed, and wanted to be admitted; his hands and face were covered with blood, and he was drunk; witness refused to admit him, and has not seen him since. Drs. BOUTON and WELTJE testified to having found five wounds, each three inches in depth, in the chest of deceased. Some unimportant testimony was taken from other witnesses, when the case was submitted to the jury, who returned a verdict of "Death from hemorrhage, caused by wounds inflicted by JOHN FITZPATRICK." The Coroner thereupon issued his warrant for the arrest of the accused.

abstract: Matter of Henry Mills. The relator was now brought before Justice SUTHERLAND, sitting at Chambers of the Supreme Court, on a writ of habcas corpus, and asked to be discharged from arrest under the ...
lead_paragraph: Matter of Henry Mills. The relator was now brought before Justice SUTHERLAND, sitting at Chambers of the Supreme Court, on a writ of habcas corpus, and asked to be discharged from arrest under the Non-Imprisonment act of 1831. The facts of the case are as follows: Judgment was entered against the defendant in favor of Robert G. Nellis on the 14th of August last for $200 and costs, before Justice STEWART, of the First District Court. The complaint is for money demand, on contract. On the 11th of September, as alleged in the petition, Justice STEWART indorsed on the papers: "Defendant liable to arrest and imprisonment." Execution against the person was then issued.

abstract: John Miller, a German shoemaker, residing in Baxter-street, was, yesterday, tempted to appropriate a case of gentleman's furnishing goods, which lay in
lead_paragraph: John Miller, a German shoemaker, residing in Baxter-street, was, yesterday, tempted to appropriate a case of gentleman's furnishing goods, which lay in front of Mr. Wm.F. Karkright's store, No. 29 Murray-street. Placing it upon his shoulder, he ran off, but was overtaken by Robert McCutcheon, the porter, who witnessed the transaction, and who took the thief in custody, with the goods in his possession. Subsequently the prisoner was taken before Justice KELLY, who committed him for trial, notwithstanding his excuse that he had been employed by a stranger to carry away the goods.

abstract: Matter of Edward O. Schevalgerl. -- The petitioner in this case is a French lad of seventeen or eighteen years of age. His father is an officer in the French Army, and his mother is also in France. The lad has crossed the Atlantic three times, and at last enlisted in the United States Army, in search of military glory. Tired of the life, however, he now applied to the Court for a discharge, on the ground that he was not yet eighteen years of age.

abstract: -- There was a terrible affray at Dedham, Mass., on Tuesday last. A new Court-house is in course of construction there, and on the night in question the stone-culters cave a ball, which was attended by a large party from Roxbury. Some of the members of this company went into the bar-room of the Norfolk House to get some liquor, and met there a number of the Roxbury stone-cutters. Some trifling dispute ended in a general fight, in which knives and chairs were freely used. Among those of the Roxbury party most seriously wounded were, WM. CAMPBELL, THOMAS MCCANN, JOSEPH BAXTER and JOSEPH LENNON. The latter is not expected to recover. One man from Dedham had his ear bitten off. JAMES THYE, MARTIN SPELLMAN and THOMAS BURNS were arrested on a charge of having been engaged in the affray, and were held to bail in $800 each.

abstract: HOAB. -- The Cincinnati Gazette notices extensive frauds which have been perpetrated on the Pennsylvania Railroad by the conductors. It states "that the Vice-President, Mr. SCOTT, had ascertained that one conductor had purchased a property in Philadelphia for which he paid $12,000 cash. Another conductor was paying $800 rent, while his salary was but $750. These and other men who were living beyond their income were watched, but nothing wrong could be detected. It was clear, however, that a large amount of the cash collections were being withheld daily, and it is stated that as much as 60 per cent. of the amount collected by certain conductors was retained. As the money did not come in fast enough under this system, a combination was formed between some ten or twelve conductors and some half dozen ticket agents or sellers on the Penntsylvania Central, who were in league, it is believed, with similar employes on the other roads, direct connections of the Pennsylvania Central, by which a certain amount of tickets taken up daily should not be punched, as required, but should be returned to the ticket agents to be resold. Mr. SCOTT has been at Pittsburgh for several days, making a thorough investigation. Eight conductors and four ticket agents have already been suspended. They had regular offices in Pittsburgh, Harrisburgh and Philadelphia, and were systematically organized. It is believed that two or more conductors on the Pittsburgh and Fort Wayne Road are implicated, and it is feared that employes on the other Ohio roads are equally guilty."

abstract: A number of incidents occur in every Presidential campaign which seem to fully warrant  the presumption that a large number of our fellow citizens take leave of their common sense during the months of July, August, September and October of every fourth year of the Republic. We have already drawn attention more than once to the hallucination which causes the Republicans to dwell upon ...
lead_paragraph: A number of incidents occur in every Presidential campaign which seem to fully warrant the presumption that a large number of our fellow citizens take leave of their common sense during the months of July, August, September and October of every fourth year of the Republic. We have already drawn attention more than once to the hallucination which causes the Republicans to dwell upon ABRAHAM LINCOLN's rail-splitting as the most notable pursuit in which he has been engaged. At any other period than the last year of the presidential term, Mr. LINCOLN's legal or political pursuits would be considered alone worthy of admiration, because the wonder really is, not that he should ever have split rails, but that having once been obliged to split rails for a livelihood, he should now be a successful lawyer. It is as a lawyer alone that he is really a marvel. It is not improbable that during the period of his career in which he wielded the maul and axe, Mr. LINCOLN being unable to procure new clothes as often as he needed them, may have mended his own pantaloons. In ordinary times the public mind would never dwell upon this little circumstance as worthy of remark; but during the "campaign," such is the diseased state of the popular imagination, that it would, if his rail-splitting had not first seized hold of it, in all probability, dwell upon his care of his damaged inexpressibles as an indication of his fitness for office, and we should have processions of gentlemen wearing patched breeches as party badges.

abstract: The conical-capped, broad-phylacteried, awfully-erudite Hudibrastic 'pothecary, in his chymist-shop decorated with pendant crocodile, and surrounded by crucibles and retorts, pipes and brazier, the "strange hermetic powders," and mystic essences, all the properties of all of which he knew so well, should hardly be mentioned in company with the snug apothecary of modern days, who, from his dazzling bazaar, dispenses soda-water, ...
lead_paragraph: The conical-capped, broad-phylacteried, awfully-erudite Hudibrastic 'pothecary, in his chymist-shop decorated with pendant crocodile, and surrounded by crucibles and retorts, pipes and brazier, the "strange hermetic powders," and mystic essences, all the properties of all of which he knew so well, should hardly be mentioned in company with the snug apothecary of modern days, who, from his dazzling bazaar, dispenses soda-water, liquors, cigars, candies, camphene, toothpicks, fancy articles, all the odds and ends of toilet-ware and quack nostrums, and retails drugs only as an addition to the other and more extensive branches of his business. In one respect, however, the apothecary of to-day (so far as he is legitimately such) still closely resembles his ancient prototype, and that is in the impenetrable mystery which, for the general public, hangs around his many-hued jars and bottles, his essences, extracts, syrups, cerates, powders and pills. Here, even to the intelligent, the unknown is still as tenfold to the known. As Mr. COLCORD, of Boston, said the other day, in his address before the Pharmaceutical Association, now in session in this City: "The consumers of drugs as a general thing are unacquainted with the properties of the articles we daily deal out to them, and consequently rely upon us (druggists) to protect them. In regard to other articles of commerce, the consumer is capable of judging for himself; but in drugs and medicines it is the vender and not the consumer who knows the quality and value of the article sold." And so it must be, we suppose, as long as men continue to be afflicted by disease, or drugs continue to be used for its cure.

abstract: One of the most stupendous political gatherings ever seen in the City took place in and around Cooper Institute last evening, on the occasion of the Republican ratification of State and National nominations. There was not room in the large hall for another auditor, and the Wide-Awake procession numbered several thousands. Mr. PELATIAH PERIT presided at the meeting, and addresses were made by the President, Mr. JAMES O. PUTNAM, Hon. CARL SHURZ, of Wisconsin, and W.E. DODGE. The appearance of Mr. PUTNAM -- who was elected State Senator by the Americans -- and of Mr. DODGE, who presided at a late Bell and Everett meeting in this City, were significant of the recent powerful additions to the Republican Party. The speech of Mr. SHURZ was an able review of the position of Mr. DOUGLAS, and he handled the Little Giant without gloves. The subsequent Wide-Awake procession, with the ten thousand torches, numerous bands of music, uniforms, military drill, pyrotechnics and general enthusiasm, surpassed in novelty any demonstration of the kind ever seen in the City.

abstract: ANTI-SLAVERY SERMONS -- STARVING OUT A CLERGYMAN. -- The pastor of a church in the Eastern District has several times recently thrown into his sermons a little Anti-Slavery sentiment, which the Trustees objected to. It is said they attempted to get rid of his services by refusing to pay his salary. The pastor, not to be tampered with in this way, at a recent meeting of the Society, publicly announced to the astonished audience that he was in want of money to buy the necessaries of life for his family. The Trustees became indignant at this exposure in a promiscuous audience, and remonstrated with their pastor. A war of high words followed. Since then the pastor has been requested to resign, but this he won't do, and further difficulty is apprehended.
lead_paragraph: ANTI-SLAVERY SERMONS -- STARVING OUT A CLERGYMAN. -- The pastor of a church in the Eastern District has several times recently thrown into his sermons a little Anti-Slavery sentiment, which the Trustees objected to. abstract: Hetzel vs. Harmann, Reinhardt and Reimer and Louis Mandell. This is a controversy concerning the rents of the "Volks Garten," a well-known German theatre in the Bowery.
lead_paragraph: Hetzel vs. Harmann, Reinhardt and Reimer and Louis Mandell. This is a controversy concerning the rents of the "Volks Garten," a well-known German theatre in the Bowery. As the rent of this place of amusement amounts to $12,000 per annum, the strife to obtain or retain it is somewhat fierce. The plaintiff now moves, before Justice PIERREPONT, at Special Term of the Superior Court, for an injunction restraining the defendant Mandell from collecting the rents in [???]ute. The plaintiff claims to be a judgment creditor a [???]gainst Messrs. Reinhardt & Reimer, and that they were the owners of the "Garten" on the 9th of June, 1859, at which time the judgment was obtained. The defendants claim that before the recovery of the judgment, Harmann was also a joint owner of the premises, and that on the 25th of May, 1859, they executed a conveyance of the same to Mandell. The grantors in that conveyance joined in executing a defeasance instrument, to which Mandell also was a party, and by which he was created a trustee to carry out the trusts created by the defeasance instrument.

abstract: SHOCKING SUICIDE A melancholy case of suicide occurred in Newburgh, Blizzard's Hotel, a day or two ago. It appears that Mr. JOSEPH CUDDEBACK, a respectable farmer, residing in Cuddebackville. Orange County, had been indicted by the Grand Jury for assault and battery.
lead_paragraph: SHOCKING SUICIDE A melancholy case of suicide occurred in Newburgh, Blizzard's Hotel, a day or two ago. It appears that Mr. JOSEPH CUDDEBACK, a respectable farmer, residing in Cuddebackville. Orange County, had been indicted by the Grand Jury for assault and battery. The friends of Mr. CUDDEBACK did all in their power to settle the matter, and were in a fair way to do so, when the affair so worked upon the mind of Mr. CUDDEBACK as to drive him to desperation. He came down into the bar-room of the hotel and asked for a pencil, and returned to his room. Shortly after the report of a pistol was heard. Mr. BLIZZARD hastened to his room and found him seriously wounded. The landlord instantly started for a physician, but before he returned another report was heard, and on entering the room a second time the unfortunate man was found quite dead. He had shot himself through the head and instantly expired.

abstract: The Observer suggests a problem for Christians. Ten years ago, it says, a father in the Church discussing the pressing needs of the American Board, declared that a revival of religion, and that only, could give a fresh impulse to the missionary work.
lead_paragraph: The Observer suggests a problem for Christians. Ten years ago, it says, a father in the Church discussing the pressing needs of the American Board, declared that a revival of religion, and that only, could give a fresh impulse to the missionary work. The great awakening which was so ardently desired has come, its power has passed by, and what is the result? From 1848 to 1851, a period of four years, the receipts of the Board were $1,072,000; from 1852 to 1855, $1,233,000 -- an increase of about three per cent. per annum; from 1856 to 1859, inclusive, $1,381,000, or an increase of only 2 1/2 per cent. per annum. Are these results, it asks, equal to the anticipations which were entertained? The Churches, in connection with the American Board, shared as largely as any in the work of grace; but its receipts last year were less by one-tenth than during the year which preceded the Pentecostal rain. The Missionary Board enters on its jubilee year, having just been relieved of its debt, which accumulated at a fearful rate, and now the question is, when and where shall retrenchment begin? This question, and others like it, the Observer urges upon its readers.

abstract: The prominence which has recently been given to the subject of the Slave-trade of this port, and the profitable use which the Republican Press has been
lead_paragraph: The prominence which has recently been given to the subject of the Slave-trade of this port, and the profitable use which the Republican Press has been making of it, is said to have attracted the attention of the Administration, and is supposed to account for the sudden zeal displayed by the authorities in arresting suspected vessels. The bark Weather Guage, which was arrested on Tuesday last, by order of the Collector, was about to clear, according to her manifest, for Hong-Kong, via. Ambriz, ANTHONY LUCRE being the name of the shipper. Surveyor HART and some Revenue officers boarded the vessel off the Battery late on Tuesday night. She was in charge of four stevedores, who stated that the Captain's name was CUTTER. On the manifest the name is given as MAXWELL. The crew and officers were ashore. Yesterday, she was unloaded at the public store at the Atlantic Dock, and her cargo was found to consist of 1,120 kegs of gunpowder, 10 hogsheads, 10 tierces and 135 bbls, of rice; striped cotton goods, denins, drills, & 320 muskets, 10 barrels New-England rum, 10 barrels wine, 10 cooking furnaces, 57 barrels mess beef, 100 casks of water, staves, coopers' tools, 36,000 feet of timber, 8,282 feet of pine boards, and four small boats, two of which are surf boats. The entire cargo is estimated to be worth $100,000, and is just such as is required for a slaver's outfit, but nothing different from the general cargo sent to the coast for purposes of trade.

abstract: When in his speech at Jones' Wood on Wednesday, Ex-Gov. JOHNSON, of Georgia, denounced the existence of a design on the part of the South, to dissolve the Union in a "certain contingency," the report proceeds to say that the announcement was received by a...
lead_paragraph: When in his speech at Jones' Wood on Wednesday, Ex-Gov. JOHNSON, of Georgia, denounced the existence of a design on the part of the South, to dissolve the Union in a "certain contingency," the report proceeds to say that the announcement was received by a previously boisterous audience, in profound silence, and the reader is left to the presumption that awe and horror were the source of the transition. We suspect that no sentiment so profound was in the least concerned. The change had its origin doubtless in the curiosity of the hearers -- in their natural desire to court further developments, and in their anxiety to understand the exact nature of the contingency in which these anonymous conspirators will rush to the achievement of their undefined purposes. There is a mystery about this much-mentioned plot of impending Disunion which very naturally excites attention, even where it fails to inspire apprehension; and it strikes us that the time has fully come when we should know more of the dreadful things prepared for an evil and perverse generation at the hands of the "united South." The advocates of three Presidential Candidates have now distinctly asserted that the election of Mr. LINCOLN is the contingency referred to -- the cardinal pivot upon which the second American revolution is to hinge. A correspondent of a city print states that at a meeting last week of former supporters of Mr. DOUGLAS in Virginia, men of substance and intelligence, assembled at no more obscure a place than the White Sulphur Springs, it was resolved to abandon that candidate, because he had publicly declared at Norfolk his conviction that the election of LINCOLN would not justify the South in secession. The leaders of the disunion movement at the South, the RHETTS, the YANCEYS, and the DAVISES, who, for the moment, sustain Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, and in sustaining him avow their allegiance to the existing Union, disavow at the same time all allegiance to a Union of which LINCOLN, and not BRECKINRIDGE, shall be the federal head. These indications, if they have any meaning, demonstrate a settled and mischievous purpose on the part of these desperate political gamesters; and it is but equitable that the country, upon whose conduct the event depends, should know the precise condition in which it stands, and the nature and full extent of the penalty to be paid for a certain course of action. It is more than probable, indeed, that the result, so far as popular action is concerned, will not now be altered by the disclosure; but we may at least be placed upon equal terms with our antagonists, and the Federal authority may have some chance to assert itself. If the persons suspected of complicity in these purposes care to avoid the undesirable fame of GUY FAUX and FIESCHI, they will throw aside their slouched hats and cloaks, and let the intended victim recognize the intending assassin.
headline: {'main': 'A Certain Contingency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Certain Contingency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The closing nights of a rather chaotic week at the Academy have been balanced with no little taste. The fresh and floral grace of FLOTOW's "Martha," on Friday, makes a cheerful contrast with the solemn intensities of "Norma," advertised, most remarkably, for to-night. Remarkably, we say, because we do not remember that a Saturday night opera has ever before been attempted in Italian at the Academy. "Martha" has undergone this extremity of social wrong in times past, but why should the CORTESI and her lyric rage be subjected to so depressing an experience? And why, on the strength of a single discouragement, is the New-York of crinoline to be robbed of its matinees!

abstract: European advices two days later are received by the Melita, which was boarded off Cape Race yesterday afternoon by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. She left Liverpool on Wednesday, the 5th inst. The intelligence is highly important.
lead_paragraph: European advices two days later are received by the Melita, which was boarded off Cape Race yesterday afternoon by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. She left Liverpool on Wednesday, the 5th inst. The intelligence is highly important. Sardinia was about to interfere in Neapolitan affairs, and it was reported that Gen. LA MARMORA was to leave for Naples with thirty thousand troops -- the object being, as stated in our dispatch, "to prevent Naples from becoming a prey to anarchy in view of the fall of the Bourbon Dynasty." All the disposable vessels of the Sardinian Navy were to be sent to the scene of operations, and the military preparations were being prosecuted with the utmost vigor. Every available transport was being put into service, and the Pope would be asked to allow the passage of troops through his dominions in case it should be found impossible otherwise to move so large a body of troops with sufficient rapidity. Meantime insurrections continued, the Province of Terra di Lavoro having revolted, and large bodies of insurgents being in motion. A communication had been received at Naples from GARIBALDI stating that he would be there about the 8th to assume the Dictatorship. From China we learn that on June 26 hostilities were about to commence at the Pei-ho. The statement relative to the mission of Mr. LINDSAY to the United States is qualified somewhat by the London Observer. This journey, it seems, is a private one, though as a representative of the shiping interest, he has consented to use his influence to induce the American Government to negotiate for the adjustment of various matters affecting that interest, and the British Government has furnished him with all the correspondence between the two countries, which may be necessary to enable him to understand the matter thoroughly.

abstract: In pursuance of a proviso in the naval appropriation act of 22d June, 1860, the Secretary of the Navy has appointed a Board of "naval officers, engineers and constructors, to examine into the condition of the
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of a proviso in the naval appropriation act of 22d June, 1860, the Secretary of the Navy has appointed a Board of "naval officers, engineers and constructors, to examine into the condition of the sailing vessels of the navy, and the cost of giving them, or any of them, full steam power, together with the expediency of making such change, in view of the cost, condition, model and general character of such vessels so altered." The Board is composed of Commodore GEORGE W. STORER, Commodore S.H. STRINGHAM, Engineer-in-Chief SAMUEL ARCHIBOLD, Chief Engineer B.F. ISHERWOOD, JOHN LENTHALL, Esq., Chief of the Bureau of Construction, and Naval Constructor B.F. DELANO, and will commence their examinations immediately of the vessels at the Portsmouth, N.H., Navy-yard, and then examine those at Boston, New-York, Philadelphia and Norfolk successively.

abstract: A LAMENTABLE CASE. An Irishwoman was wandering about Washington street and vicinity yesterday with a babe, nearly dead from disease, in her arms. She asked every one she met what she should do with her "poor baby dying in her arms in the public streets" To each the story was told that she...
lead_paragraph: A LAMENTABLE CASE. An Irishwoman was wandering about Washington street and vicinity yesterday with a babe, nearly dead from disease, in her arms. She asked every one she met what she should do with her "poor baby dying in her arms in the public streets" To each the story was told that she had been refused admission into several hospitals, because she had no money, and she did not know where to go. It appears that this woman, to avoid paying a fee for medical attendance, which she was perfectly able to do, went to the hospitals, not for the purpose of benefiting the child, but to save the expense and secure a certificate of the cause of death when the child should die. In one instance at least, she refused to remain when invited to do so without charge, but demanded a certificate of the cause of death in advance of the child's decease. Several gentlemen to whom the story was told, offered to pay the hospital expenses, but this favor was declined, and the woman finally started for home, complaining bitterly because no one would give a certificate to enable her to bury the child without an inquest.

abstract: THE SEVENTH REGIMENT GYMNASIUM. The new gymnasium of the National Guard will be opened early in October. Mr. ABNER S. BRADY, a member of the Regiment and a gymnast of note, is its proprietor and projector.
lead_paragraph: THE SEVENTH REGIMENT GYMNASIUM. The new gymnasium of the National Guard will be opened early in October. Mr. ABNER S. BRADY, a member of the Regiment and a gymnast of note, is its proprietor and projector. It will stand near the new Armory of the Regiment on Seventh-street, and extend to St. Mark's-place. The entire Regiment supports it, and with the exception of a limited number of outsiders, none but members of the Regiment will be permitted to exercise there. There is promise that it will be complete in all its appointments; and the design is to render it the most perfect establishment of the kind in the country. The sparring, fencing, dressing, bathing and reading rooms will be in the large dwelling-house No. 20 St. Marks-place, 82 feet deep, which is undergoing extensive alterations. The gymnasium itself will be in the new buildings on Seventh-street, of which GRIFFITH THOMAS is the architect, BLACKSTONE & RYERSON are the builders, and WILLIAMS & FELTER the masons. Mr. JAMES B. REYNOLDS will have charge of the sparring, and M. MULLER, who has seen service as an officer of the Chasseurs d'Afrique, will be master of fencing.

abstract: WONDERFUL ESCAPE OF A BALLOONIST. -- Prof. SHOTTS, the aeronaut, made a balloon ascension at Marrietta, Ohio, on Wednesday evening about 5 o'clock. When he had reached a height of about one hundred feet, the balloon burst. He came down standing on his basket, alighting on the levee. Singular as it may seem, the only injury he sustained was a badly mashed ankle.

abstract: Mrs. Deborah P. McLane, residing at No. 427 Eighth-avenue, yesterday caused the arrest of a woman named Elizabeth Lloyd, on a charge of having forged her name to an order for $250 on the Third-avenue Savings Bank. The complainant alleged that the accused and herself lived together, and that while she was absent in the country on her Summer vacation, Elizabeth took her bank-book from the place of deposit in the bureau drawer, forged the order and drew the sum named from the bank, after which she replaced the book in the bureau, hoping by this means to escape detection. Justice CONNOLLY detained the accused for a hearing.
