abstract: The London Times has given importance to a Montreal municipal dispute, which only a local paper noticed at the time, by making it the subject of a leading editorial, and an opportunity for denouncing French Canadian ingratitude. The Times enumerates the benefits...
lead_paragraph: The London Times has given importance to a Montreal municipal dispute, which only a local paper noticed at the time, by making it the subject of a leading editorial, and an opportunity for denouncing French Canadian ingratitude. The Times enumerates the benefits that the French population of the Province have derived from British rule; and they are so far correctly stated that there is probably no dependency of the British Crown more favored at the present day than that of Lower Canada. Every effort has been made to conciliate her people -- their national prejudices have been respected, their language has been preserved, and their religion has been placed on a footing of perfect equality with that of the Episcopal establishment. If Lower Canada had remained a French colony, it could not have been as politically free as it is now; if it had been absorbed by the United States, or by the English colonies that sweep around it, the anomaly of an unprogressive Province in the centre of the North American Continent would not be witnessed, nor would a crop of ungenial prejudice be found flourishing in the midst of an Anglo-Saxon empire. In the nature of things French Lower Canadian influence ought long ago to have been swamped; and it undoubtedly would have been swamped if it had not been for the protecting aegis of British Rule. Many people, on both sides of the line, imagine that the policy of the British Government in this respect has not proved beneficial to the best interests of Canada, and was not adopted and pursued from purely unselfish motives. The French population in Canada -- the most peaceful and contented probably in the world -- were once goaded to rebellion, and American sympathy, then displayed in their behalf, opened the eyes of the Home Government to the danger of having a discontented colony lying within the very shadow of the great Republic. Ever since 1838, the fullest liberty has been granted to the French Canadians. They have been allowed and encouraged to retain a nationality of their own, and their religion, especially, has been fostered. They dislike, at present, no people more than they do the Americans. They detest our democratic institutions, and dread nothing so much as an influx of American ideas, which would soon overturn the little idols they have set up to worship.

abstract: The name of IRVING has been made respectable in theology and in literature but neither the apocalyptic orator, upon whose lips the noblest and wisest of England hung in listening wonder, nor the gracious prose-poet, whose spirit still lives to enchant unborn generations into peace and charity, ever enjoyed such high prerogatives as belong to Mr. JAMES IRVING, of New-York, politician, Superintendent ...
lead_paragraph: The name of IRVING has been made respectable in theology and in literature but neither the apocalyptic orator, upon whose lips the noblest and wisest of England hung in listening wonder, nor the gracious prose-poet, whose spirit still lives to enchant unborn generations into peace and charity, ever enjoyed such high prerogatives as belong to Mr. JAMES IRVING, of New-York, politician, Superintendent of Markets, and general Boanerges of the advanced Democracy. It is not very easy to conceive of any circumstances in which EDWARD or WASHINGTON IRVING could have properly been brought before the bar of justice; but if our readers will pardon us for the bare suggestion of such a contingency, they will also agree with us, we are sure, that in the event of its occurrence, neither the eloquence of the preacher nor the genius of the author would have availed to elevate either of them above the reach of the tribunals of his country. For these men, with all their gifts and all their glory were simply good citizens, and, indeed, would have spurned the thought of belonging to any privileged class, enjoying rights peculiar to itself, and exempt from the duties incumbent upon all other men.

abstract: -- Joshua Shaw, the celebrated landscape painter, died at Burlington, N.J., on the 8th inst., at the advanced age of 83. He was born in Bellingbroke, Lincolnshire, England. Early left an orphan he was successively a farmer boy, post boy and apprentice to a country sign painter. Young Shaw found this last occupation the most congenial as he had greater opportunities to indulge his taste for painting, and by persistent effort he succeeded in bringing his name before the public, through the excellence of his landscapes. In 1817 he determined to remove to this country. He brought over with him the great picture which West executed and presented to the Pennsylvania Hospital, "Christ healing the Sick." Mr. Shaw was distinguished as well for his Invention as his artistic talent. Improvements which he made in gun-locks were adopted by our Government, and according to statistics preserved in the Department at Washington, he was entitled to commissions amounting to $170,000. For many years he petitioned Congress for some substantial reward, and in 1848 an act was passed granting $25,000, provided that the Secretary of War considered the award equitable and just; $18,000 was allowed by the Secretary, and handed over to Mr. Shaw. The balance, $7,000, still remains unpaid, although Secretary Floyd has since decided the said balance to be justly due. The Secretary of the Treasury, however, declines payment, upon the ground that it has reverted to the surplus fund. The Emperor of Russia also awarded a premium to Mr. Shaw for improvements in naval warfare, and also promised a commission on his patents, which are extensively used throughout that Empire. It is said that Mr. Shaw's heirs are to bring a suit to recover this commission. Some years since, in experimenting upon a new invention in gunnery, Mr. Shaw lost the use of an arm; for seven years previous to his death he was afflicted with paralysis, and for the last twenty-four months was confined to his bed. He retained his faculties, however, to the last.

abstract: Under the heavy pressure of European public opinion, and of the threatening demonstrations of the Great Powers, the Ottoman Government has been swift to punish the authors and abettors of the late Syrian massacres. The "sick man" has displayed unwonted energy, and, in the selection of FUAD PACHA as his executive, has evinced unusual sagacity.
lead_paragraph: Under the heavy pressure of European public opinion, and of the threatening demonstrations of the Great Powers, the Ottoman Government has been swift to punish the authors and abettors of the late Syrian massacres. The "sick man" has displayed unwonted energy, and, in the selection of FUAD PACHA as his executive, has evinced unusual sagacity. Again the streets of Damascus have been the scene of a dreadful tragedy; but, on this occasion, the guilty, and not the innocent, have been made to suffer. On the 20th of August last, 167 criminals were publicly executed. All of them were Turkish officials, and 110 of the number were members of the local police. According to the official report -- confirmed by private letters -- justice is administered with an impartial and unsparing hand, and no one implicated in the outbreak has been able to screen himself behind his rank, however high, or his social position, however eminent. The prompt energy manifested by FUAD PACHA has imparted confidence to the Syrian Christians, and has terrified the Mahommedan instigators of the late conspiracy.

abstract: Hon. CALEB CUSHING spoke at a Breckinridge and Lane ratification meeting in Boston, on Wednesday evening. He did not see how either Mr. DOUGLAS or Mr. BELL could hope to obtain a single electoral vote in any of the Northern States, except by the aid of the supporters of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE.
lead_paragraph: Hon. CALEB CUSHING spoke at a Breckinridge and Lane ratification meeting in Boston, on Wednesday evening. He did not see how either Mr. DOUGLAS or Mr. BELL could hope to obtain a single electoral vote in any of the Northern States, except by the aid of the supporters of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. AS regards Mr. DOUGLAS he could not have received a single Northern electoral vote, had he received the united vote of his party. Mr. CUSHING believed that the South would yet cast a unanimous vote for Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. He alone exhibits any chances or possibilities of success against Mr. LINCOLN. The speaker ventured the following prediction: -- "The Republican Party has been conceived, born and nurtured into strength, in order, if possible, to force or seduce the Federal Government into abolitionism, or else the Republican Party is a monstrous and ridiculous abortion, a gigantic falsehood, swindle and fraud. And I reassert confidently, if Mr. Lincoln is elected, the Republicans will have to burst up at once, or to attack the domestic rights of the States.

abstract: Maria B. king vs. Richard Ackerman. This is an ejectment to recover an undivided sixth-part of a parcel of land described as "The Homestead," in the will of Lawrence Benson, and situate at Harlem in the Twelfth Ward of the City of New-York.
lead_paragraph: Maria B. king vs. Richard Ackerman. This is an ejectment to recover an undivided sixth-part of a parcel of land described as "The Homestead," in the will of Lawrence Benson, and situate at Harlem in the Twelfth Ward of the City of New-York. The testator died leaving a son, Benjamin L. Benson, and three grandchildren, the children of a daughter, Susan, the wife of Rev. Dr. Milldeoler. By his will, he devised, first, to B.L. Benson, the son, a parcel of land designated as then in the occupation of one George Williams, "to do and dispose of as he may think proper;" also, the homestead, where he then lived, situate on Harlem River; and second declared his will and intention to be that his son (B.L.B.) should give unto his grandchildren, after the decease of his wife, the sum of $1,500; and third, gave the income of the legacies, and of his estate, real and personal, unto his wife, Maria, during her widowhood, "to do and dispose of as she may think proper." B.L. Benson, the son, died the 4th of October, 1852. This suit is brought by Mrs. King, one of the grandchildren, on the ground that the son (B.L.B.) took only a life estate in the homestead. The defendant claims under a title in fee derived from the son.

abstract: We published in our report of the proceedings of the last meeting of the Mozart Hall General Committee, the fact that WM. J. BRISLEY, a delegate to that Committee from the 9th Ward, one of the firmest supporters of FERNANDO WOOD, and a follower of his fortunes, had sent in his resignation as such delegate, stating that he would at a future day publicly advise his friends the reasons for the course then pursued.
lead_paragraph: We published in our report of the proceedings of the last meeting of the Mozart Hall General Committee, the fact that WM. J. BRISLEY, a delegate to that Committee from the 9th Ward, one of the firmest supporters of FERNANDO WOOD, and a follower of his fortunes, had sent in his resignation as such delegate, stating that he would at a future day publicly advise his friends the reasons for the course then pursued. On Saturday Mr. BRISLEY wrote a letter to Mayor Wood, giving his reasons as promised. Mr. BRISLEY has been a life-long Democrat, is an Ex-Alderman, and has a host of friends, and consequently great influence in his own Ward and throughout the City. We give below a copy of his letter.

abstract: That decisive crisis which recurs three or four times a year in Mexico threatens a fresh visitation. The Liberals, by dint of mustering strongly, and having enough commanders to keep the courage of all at a sticking point through force of numbers, have met the reactionists at the North and in the South, and have succeeded in exterminating all the armies maintained by that party outside the capital.
lead_paragraph: That decisive crisis which recurs three or four times a year in Mexico threatens a fresh visitation. The Liberals, by dint of mustering strongly, and having enough commanders to keep the courage of all at a sticking point through force of numbers, have met the reactionists at the North and in the South, and have succeeded in exterminating all the armies maintained by that party outside the capital. The most important action took place on the 10th ultimo at Silao, where MIRAMON, brought to bay by a superior force of the enemy, found himself obliged to risk a fight. The action commenced at 8 o'clock in the morning, the combatants chiefly relying upon their artillery, of which the Conservatives possessed twenty-four and the Federalists thirty-two pieces. The exchange of fires threatening the destruction of his forces if they retained a defensive attitude, MIRAMON presently formed his troops into three columns and advanced to the attack. They were gallantly met by the cavalry of the enemy, but held their ground against the charge with great courage, until larger masses of their antagonists were flung upon them, and the conflict was converted into a rout. MIRAMON early fled from the field, attended only by one General and four Aids-de-Camp. His army was captured with all its arms, equipage, munitions, and a large amount of specie. The Liberal Army of the North, after this victory, instead of hastening its march upon the capital so as to forestall the creation of a fresh army by the beaten party, appears to have rested upon its laurels, leaving MIRAMON opportunity to prepare for another campaign.

abstract: "General" WILLIAM WALKER, with his army of two companies, has been unceremoniously turned out of Truxillo by the British, owing to the possession by the Government of Her Britannic Majesty of a mortgage upon the Customs duties of that port. If we are to judge from what passed between the commander of the Icarus and himself, the "General " owes all his misfortunes in this instance to a too hasty abandonment of a protective policy.
lead_paragraph: "General" WILLIAM WALKER, with his army of two companies, has been unceremoniously turned out of Truxillo by the British, owing to the possession by the Government of Her Britannic Majesty of a mortgage upon the Customs duties of that port. If we are to judge from what passed between the commander of the Icarus and himself, the "General " owes all his misfortunes in this instance to a too hasty abandonment of a protective policy. He had no sooner seized upon the town than, in an ardor of devotion to free-trade, which all friends of humanity must admire, he declared it a free port, and shut up the Custom-house. The result has shown that he was too far in advance of his age. The dues had been pledged to the British -- the British demanded them, and WALKER having failed to collect them, was obliged to make a return of nulla bona. Her Britannic Majesty's man-of-war forthwith desired him to quit the place; and the great captain and philanthropist desirous, no doubt, of avoiding the effusion of blood, packed up his baggage and left for parts unknown. At the date of the last accounts he was said to be at Limas with a force of eighty men, or thereabouts, and undergoing very pertinacious, if not very formidable attacks from the natives.

abstract: One of the series of international cricket matches between the American and English members of this club, took place on Friday, and was played out from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The English bowling was very good; some excellent batting was shown by several of the Americans, for whom Dr. Trenor bowled splendidly, and Mr. Dakin kept wicket in the second innings in excellent style, only letting three balls pass him, and even stopping the wides. The bowling of Dakin, in the first innings, was worth three wickets if the fielding had been equal to it. The batting of Messrs. Bainbridge, Bailey and Herbert was very fine. The day's play was a most agreeable one for a large number of the members and their friends. The English won with two wickets to spare. The following is the score:

abstract: Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening a fire occurred from some unascertained cause, in the stables of the Consolidated Stage Company, located in East Sixteenth-street, near Avenue B. The damage to buildings and stock will scarcely exceed $1,000, and it is fully covered by insurance. Messrs. THOMAS MURPHY and HUGH SMITH are the owners of the premises ...
lead_paragraph: Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening a fire occurred from some unascertained cause, in the stables of the Consolidated Stage Company, located in East Sixteenth-street, near Avenue B. The damage to buildings and stock will scarcely exceed $1,000, and it is fully covered by insurance. Messrs. THOMAS MURPHY and HUGH SMITH are the owners of the premises Shortly before 10 o'clock another fire broke out in the frame stable owned by GEORGE MURPHY, at No. 231 East Thirteenth-street. Before the flames could be extinguished four horses, valued in the aggregate at $400, were burned to death. The owners of the animals were MICHAEL BONE, MICHAEL MCNALLY, JAMES LESTRAIN, and a rag peddler, neither of whom had any insurance upon their property. Loss on building, $75; uninsured.

abstract: A MAN BURIED ALIVE. -- The residents of Farmingdale and vicinity have been laboring under a terrible excitement for two weeks past, over a current rumor that a resident of that place, named POWELL, had been buried alive. The deceased was quite advanced hi years, and was buried the third day after he was taken sick. A minister, a friend of the family, who saw the body after it was laid out for the grave, said that if it was a friend of his he should not be buried. He said this because the body was still warm, and by pressing a finger upon the skin the color would come and go, as it will upon the skin of a person alive. Several persons, it is said, witnessed this, and others declare that they saw a twitching of the muscles of the face. No reason is assigned by Madame Rumor for the hurried manner in which the body was placed in its last resting place, other than that the deceased was not on the best terms with his children. One of his sons was married within a week after the funeral, and this manifestation of a want of feeling for his father after all, may have contributed much to giving point to the rumor.

abstract: ANOTHER PECULATING POSTMASTER. -- For some time letters passing through mails in the Northern part of the State have been missed. Col. NORTH was removed in the midst of his investigations into the matter, and the newly appointed Agent, Mr. BULL, on coming into office immediately took it up. He addressed a letter containing several bills to himself, under an assumed name, to Perry's Mills, Clinton County, and upon applying to the Post-office at that place for it, was informed by the Postmaster, Mr. WHIPPLE, that such a letter was received there, but as he knew that no such person resided in the place, and as the letter contained money, he had forwarded it to another place. Mr. BULL, not satisfied with this explanation, left for the cars, and upon the arrival of the pouch from the Perry office, he took charge of and opened it. Among the letters was one marked "free," addressed to a firm in Troy, which he opened and found to contain two of the identical bank bills which he had put into the decoy letter. He thereupon caused HENRY A. WHIPPLE, the Postmaster of Perry's Mills, to be arrested upon a charge of embezzlement, and took him to Albany. An investigation was had on Wednesday, before U.S. Commissioner HILTON, which resulted in Mr. WHIPPLE being held to bail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: These South Brooklyn Clubs played a match on Saturday, on the Excelsior Ground, and although the Excelsiors had a large majority, the Independents or their catcher, right and left fields, and second and thirds bases did pretty well against the terrific batting, of the Excelsiors, and some considerable good batting for themselves. A liberal entertainment and compliments occurred between the parties, after the match.

abstract: On Friday night, when Mrs. Hoey, the celebrated actress, had arrived at her residence, No. 231 West Twenty-third-street, from Wallack's Theatre, she discovered that a leather satchel containing about $1,500 worth of diamond jewelry, which she had worn in performing her part of the Countess, in the play of "The Royalist; or, Forty Years Ago," had been left in the carriage which had brought her home. Her husband immediately started in pursuit of ...
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, when Mrs. Hoey, the celebrated actress, had arrived at her residence, No. 231 West Twenty-third-street, from Wallack's Theatre, she discovered that a leather satchel containing about $1,500 worth of diamond jewelry, which she had worn in performing her part of the Countess, in the play of "The Royalist; or, Forty Years Ago," had been left in the carriage which had brought her home. Her husband immediately started in pursuit of Henry Kelly, the driver of the vehicle, who for some time past has been engaged to convey the lady to and from the theatre, but before Mr. Hoey reached the stable Kelly had put up his horses, and gone home. Not being able to ascertain where he lived, Mr. H. deferred further action until Saturday morning, when he learned that Kelly lived at No. 120 West Nineteenth-street. On going to his house, Mr. H. saw the satchel upon the mantel-piece and observed that the wife of the driver had one of Mrs. H.'s diamond rings upon her finger. Kelly was questioned as to his reason for not restoring the bag on the previous night, and he replied that he had intended to send it home in the morning. Upon examining the bag it was found that a portion of the jewelry, consisting of two diamond finger-rings, a diamond breast-pin and a diamond hair-pin, had been taken out, and Kelly refused to give any account of them. Mrs. H. thereupon quietly secured the services of Officer Hughes, of the Sixteenth Ward, who took Kelly into custody. After her husband's arrest, Mrs. Kelly gave up the ring, which she had on her finger, and said that the other ring and hair-pin were on the floor of the adjoining apartment, occupied by Thomas Cauldwell. Her statement was found to be correct, and only the brooch remained to be accounted for. Meantime Kelly had made the following confession to Mr. Hoey: Having found the bag in the coach he brought it home, fully intending to restore it in the morning. Before going to bed he went down stairs into the liquor store, and drank several glasses of ale with his neighbors, Thomas and Bernard Cauldwell. Subsequently the party went to his room and renewed their conviviality. During the time that they were drinking, Bernard took the satchel and picked the lock, but with what instrument Kelly was too drunk to see. Thomas Cauldwell then selected some of the jewelry for his daughter, and the others took what pleased them, and they separated for the night. The prisoner did not think anything more of the matter until he became sober and was arrested. Upon this information, the brothers Cauldwell were also apprehended, and the three prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, who committed them for trial, each in default of $1,000. The missing brooch was afterwards found, wrapped up in a piece of tin-foil, in the pocket of Thomas Cauldwell. In the examination of the accused before the magistrate, Kelly made a similar statement of the affair to that related by him to Mr. Hoey. Bernard Cauldwell admitted having picked the lock of the satchel, but said that he was requested to do it by Kelly, and Thomas Cauldwell refused to say anything at all about the matter.

abstract: SATURDAY'S CONCERT AT THE CENTRAL PARK.  The Central Park was the centre of attraction last Saturday afternoon. Thither all classes and conditions of people, upon whose hands hung a leisure hour or two, wended their way on foot, on horse-back and in all manner of vehicles.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY'S CONCERT AT THE CENTRAL PARK. The Central Park was the centre of attraction last Saturday afternoon. Thither all classes and conditions of people, upon whose hands hung a leisure hour or two, wended their way on foot, on horse-back and in all manner of vehicles. It was the largest gathering that the Swans have looked upon this season. Apropos of Swans, the newly imported birds, recently received by Mr. AUGUST BELMONT, from London, were in the lake, floating or at anchor, the observed of all observers. The mall was alive with gentry in gay garb; hundreds thridded the mazy windings of the Ramble; and the rumble, -- the appropriate name of the adjacent roads when countless wheels are plying over them; -- was so crowded with carriages and equestrians that life assurance companies might well receive the suggestion that they should require of all who pay them premiums that they will never cross it of a Saturday afternoon in concert-time. It was worth one's vital spark to navigate there on foot yesterday. The concert was good; the Police arrangements admirable; the temper of the people amiable; and order in an excellent state of preservation. As the Frenchman wrote at the end of his affidavit, "Furder de deponent don't say."

abstract: The pilot boat Washington, No. 4, makes the following report: Sept. 12, lat. 40 13, lon. 71 40, while lying too under double-reefed foresail, shipped a sea which carried away both yawls, forward companionway, port bulwarks; also breaking the squaresail boom, which, was lashed to the deck. The gale lasted for 17 hours, during which it blew a complete hurricane from W.N.W. Sept. 13, daylight, spoke ship E. Bulkley, who wanted a pilot, but having no boat, Capt. R. very kindly cleared away his quarter-boat and sent her to us, to finish the cruise. Same day, 4 P.M., spoke Br. schr. Gulnair, of Cambridge, N.S., from Nova Scotia for New-York, 20 days, but she had been knocked down in a gale the day previous, which stove her water casks -- supplied her. Same day, spoke bark Edward Everett, of Boston, also brig Orazimbo, from Alexander for Boston. Mr. Murphy, of the W., wishes to return his thanks to Capt. Ross, of the E. Bulkley, for his kindness in letting him have his boat.

abstract: The fusion movement does not prosper. The Sub-Committee appointed by the Douglas State Committee to endeavor to negotiate a union with the Breckinridge Democracy, met on Saturday at the St. Nicholas Hotel and resolved to reject the terms of the "National volunteers." The latter were made acquainted, verbally, with the ultimatum of the Douglas men: that the Breckinridge ...
lead_paragraph: The fusion movement does not prosper. The Sub-Committee appointed by the Douglas State Committee to endeavor to negotiate a union with the Breckinridge Democracy, met on Saturday at the St. Nicholas Hotel and resolved to reject the terms of the "National volunteers." The latter were made acquainted, verbally, with the ultimatum of the Douglas men: that the Breckinridge party should have six of the electors and four more in a certain uncertain contingency; that Breckinridge candidates should be substituted for Lieutenant-Governor and Canal Commissioner; but that all the men substituted should be new men. To this the Volunteers would not accede, and there the negotiations ended. In view of this failure to fuse, the Breckinridge State Committee have issued a manifesto, in which they concede the election of LINCOLN, and throw the responsibility for that dire calamity upon the Douglas Democracy.

abstract: YOUNG MAN KILLED BY A RUNAWAY NEGRO. -- A correspondent, writing from Swift Creek, Craven County, N.C., under date of Sept. 9, to the Newbern Progress says: Mr. JOHN CHAPMAN, one of our most prominent and promising young men, having learned from some sonree that there was a parcel of runaway negroes lurkings near the residence of his mother, Mrs. JULIA CHAPMAN, started out yesterday accompanied by Mr. ABRAHAM JACKSON and his brother NOAH CHAPMAN, a youth some 16 years of age to find where they had secreted themselves. After considerable search they succeeded in finding the negroes, camp, but before they could learn anything or make any examination, Mr. CHAPMAN was fired upon and killed, the shot striking him full in the breast. The two young men made their escape. There is no evidence as yet that will identify the (negro) assassin who committed the cowardly act. He is supposed to be a negro of very bad character, who has been run away for several years, belonging to WM. GRIMES, of Pitt County. Our whole community is completely aroused, and a great deal of excitement prevails. Every step is being put forward to raise a company to scour the whole neighborhood, and hunt until they are found; there is every probability that they will be taken. Mr. A. JACKSON stated that he saw two negro men and one negro woman; how many more there were in the gang, he knows not.

abstract: THE SLAVE TRADE. -- "Scarlet," writing for the Charleston Courier from Key West on the 30th ult., says: The excitement consequent upon the attempt to steal the bark William has died out, and the parties are snugly caged for trial. The bark is now owned by ANTONIO PELLETIER, of New-York, who has obtained a register, and she cleared hence on the 28th for Mobile. From Havana, I learn of the arrival of slaves on the night of the 26th, in Spanish smacks -- landed at the Fish wharf, and carried from thence in lighters to Regla. A schooner, with slaves, was captured, or rather given up to a Spanish-man-of-war brig, off Matanzas. She was chased by the Crusader, and preferred delivery to her own flag. From, the Bahamas, we have news of the total loss of ship Wabash on the Bruimiss -- sugar loaded, from Matanzas -- part of cargo saved; also that bark Liberty, from New-York to New-Orleans, was ashore, on Morrello Shoal, but got off.

abstract: The business preliminaries of the firm of RICHMOND, HUNT and GREEN appear difficult of adjustment. A fortnight has elapsed since the negotiations were opened by the prospective junior partner, who proposed to bring into the firm not only a substantial capital of some 75,000 votes, but the good-will and fixtures of the expiring establishment of JAMES BUCHANNAN.
lead_paragraph: The business preliminaries of the firm of RICHMOND, HUNT and GREEN appear difficult of adjustment. A fortnight has elapsed since the negotiations were opened by the prospective junior partner, who proposed to bring into the firm not only a substantial capital of some 75,000 votes, but the good-will and fixtures of the expiring establishment of JAMES BUCHANNAN. The overtures of Mr. GREEN were received with favor by some members of the Albany concern; but were so clearly. distasteful to others, that instead of the prompt admission upon which the applicant reasonably counted, long deliberations ensued, and have been protracted, until at last, a decision adverse to the representative of the Breckinridge interest has been arrived at. The Douglas Committee has resolved not to fuse with the Administration Party.

abstract: The "Union" men are making great efforts for a grand meeting to-night at the Cooper Institute. The officers include gentlemen from every State in the Union, and speakers from all sections will be present.
lead_paragraph: The "Union" men are making great efforts for a grand meeting to-night at the Cooper Institute. The officers include gentlemen from every State in the Union, and speakers from all sections will be present. It is said that Gen. SCOTT will preside, and make a speech. After the speaking is over, a grand torchlight procession will take place. About 300 clubs from all sections of the country have announced their determination to participate. Among the probabilities is one, that a fusion electoral ticket, satisfactory to the supporters of BELL, BRECKINRIDGE and DOUGLAS, will be presented and adopted.

abstract: -- Two eminent American artists, Messrs. CHURCH and EASTMAN JOHNSON, appear for the first time as illustrators in Dr. PALMER's forthcoming and unique treasure-book of Folk-Songs. Mr. CHURCH illustrates TENNYSON's "Evening," in a sketch of characteristic beauty. Mr. JOHNSON's original design of WHITTIER's "Barefoot Boy," an exquisite little creation, originally prepared expressly for this work, has since been committed to canvas, and may be seen at Nichols' Crayon Art Gallery.

On Wednesday the "Trovatore" was substituted for the "Traviata," and on Thursday, of the last moment, when numerous carriages were drawn up at the doors, ready to set down their lovely burdens, an announcement was put forth that there would be no performance, "owing to the illness of CORTESI," ...
lead_paragraph: The opera has been sickly this last week, and is reputed to be suffering from a complaint in the chest. On Wednesday the "Trovatore" was substituted for the "Traviata," and on Thursday, of the last moment, when numerous carriages were drawn up at the doors, ready to set down their lovely burdens, an announcement was put forth that there would be no performance, "owing to the illness of CORTESI," who had been seen sunning herself on Broadway but a few hours before. It seems now that CORTESI has seceded, and, with a wing of the operatic army, embracing MUSIANI and AMODIO, with ANSCHUTZ as conductor, has gone over to Niblo's, where she will open a season on Tuesday, in "Traviata," and will play on alternate nights with the great American tragedian, Mr. FORREST. We are, therefore, to see, as in the Spring, a repetition of the operatic war of the rival roses, which, however amusing to the public, must end, of course, in the ruin of one or both the contending houses. The upshot of this sort of thing will be to make operatic enterprise so perilous as to do a fatal injury to art. The opening of two rival operas in London has had that effect, the competition raising the demands of artists to a point at which it was impossible for opera to "pay." The secession of the Cortesi party must, at this moment, seriously derange Mr. STRAKOSCH's plans and involve him in considerable difficulties He had, previously to the secession, engaged the Academy of Music at Philadelphia, and intended opening there on Monday with CORTESI. The duty of sustaining that branch must now rest with COLSON and PATTI, who is too tender and delicate a plant for such tough times. To-night STRAKOSCH brings out FABBRI, who led the opposition at the Winter Garden last Spring with so much brilliancy, and on her hang the fortunes of the house of STRAKOSCH and ULLMAN. If she fails to attract, who can prophesy that the sceptre of song will not once more pass into the hands of the indomitable MAX? In the meantime the burden of battle belongs to STRAKOSCH. His little companion is in Europe, building a number of castles most pleasant to look on at a distance, but which when touched are too often found to be but rosy fictions. The battle cannot now be checked. We can only cry "Vie Victis."

abstract: We learn unofficially from Fort Buchanan that Capt. EWELL has received dispatches from Gov. He desires the witnesses to be sent to Hermosillo, to testify against the prisoners on their trial, and promises that they shall be shot upon conviction.

abstract: On Monday last Senator BRIGHT, of Indiana, delivered an address to the friends of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE, in the Methodist Church in Patriot, Switzerland County. He introduced his speech by comment-
lead_paragraph: On Monday last Senator BRIGHT, of Indiana, delivered an address to the friends of BRECKINRIDGE and LANE, in the Methodist Church in Patriot, Switzerland County. He introduced his speech by commenting on the chaotic state of parties, and reiterated the statement which he has heretofore made, that the Democrats had no regularly nominated candidate in the field, but that he designed to vote for Mr. BRECKINRIDGE as the representative of their principles. He mentioned the names of some of the more prominent supporters of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, and asked: "Are they all bolters, and all wrong, and this little immaculate squatter sovereign from Illinois right? I answer, sad criticism -- sad commentary on the history of the Democratic Party, if all its brains and all its heart is merged in the person of one single little man. Then having sketched the proceedings of the Conventions and expounded the platforms, Senator BRIGHT touched upon the Dred Scott decision, and told how it was regarded by the two sections of the Democracy. The rest of his speech the Cincinnati Commercial thus reports:

abstract: The intelligence which reaches us to-day from Europe, by steamer at Quebec, makes it morally certain that GARIBALDI, at the head of his liberating army, must have entered the capital city of the Neapolitan mainland a fortnight since. On the 6th of September the victorious deliverer had reached Salerno, and from that picturesque and historical city, distant but a few hours by railway from the palaces of Naples, was organizing his forces for a triumphant entry upon the abandoned inheritance of the weakest and worst of the Bourbon dynasty. The telegram which carried this decisive news within a single day to the furthest corners of Europe carried with it the natural corollary that "FRANCIS II. was preparing to take refuge at Gaeta." For months before the death of FERDINAND great sums were expended by the Government upon the fortifications of this splendid and defensible harbor. Capua, the northern terminus of the railway leading from Naples in the direction of Gaeta, is also a strong and formidable post, and if the young Bourbon King had or could hope to have any party within his Kingdom, or any valuable support from abroad, his retreat upon the finest maritime fortress of his dominions might be regarded as postponing the hour of the final fall of his execrated House. But it is hardly possible that FRANCIS II. should have taken this step in the present posture of affairs, with any other purpose than to secure his leisurely escape from a country which he can no longer hope to rule in peace or honor. The presence at Naples of a powerful foreign force, including eight Sardinian men-of-war and two regiments of Sardinian bersaglieri, will doubtless have secured the quiet of the capital after the flight of the Government, and it is not probable that the entrance, of the liberal army was attended by any scenes of bloodshed, or even of disorder. It must not be forgotten, however, that FRANCIS II. at Gaeta is dangerously near the Papal frontiers. A brief day's march would put the Ex-King within the reach of Gen. DE LAMORICIERE's army, and if the son of FERDINAND should ask of PIUS IX. a return of the hospitality which that pontiff received, eleven years ago, from his Royal father, in similar circumstances, the Italian drama would receive a new and rather perplexing turn. Such an event is by no means impossible; and the next steamer from Europe will be expected with no ordinary impatience by those whose wishes and whose hopes go with the Italian people in their arduous and glorious movement towards independence, unity, and peace.

abstract: By the steamship Teutonia, at this port, and the Jura, at Quebec, we receive advices from Paris and London to the 6th and 7th inst. respectively. The news is important. GARIBALDI's progress in Southern Italy has been marvelously successful. He was, by last advices, at Salerno in the immediate neighborhood of Naples. A telegram from the latter place asserts that the King would leave on the 6th inst. Every preparation for flight was completed, but whether the fugitive will seek shelter in Gaeta, Vienna, or Madrid, is not known. We have received particulars of the Sardinian plan of intervention to prevent anarchy and unnecessary effusion of blood in Naples after the flight of the King. The Piedmontese Bersaglieri are to land forthwith from the Sardinian ships, and afterwards Gen. LA MARMORA will arrive with 30,000 men to organize the decomposed army. It is semi-officially announced in the Patrie that Austria will confine herself to the defence of Venetia in case it is attacked, and that France will only intervene for the protection of the Pope and the City of Rome.
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Teutonia, at this port, and the Jura, at Quebec, we receive advices from Paris and London to the 6th and 7th inst. respectively. The news is important. abstract: ARRIVAL OF SENATOR SEWARD's HORSES AT BOSTON. -- The bark Speedwell, Capt. MAYO, arrived at this port to-day, from Beyrout, Syria, bringing two of the horses which were presented to Senator SEWARD during his recent tour in that country. They were a gift from an officer in the Turkish Government. The lot comprised three animals, but unfortunately on the sixth day out the mare died of some disease contracted before embarking, as she gave unmistakable signs of sickness when brought on board. The others are in fine condition, and being of the celebrated Arabian breed, they will attract considerable attention in this country. The Speedwell was in the harbor of Beyrout during the late excitement growing out of the massacre of Christians near that place, and Capt. MAYO has been highly commended for the prompt and efficient aid which he rendered to the flying fugitives from Moslem revenge. Large numbers sought refuge on board his vessel, some returning on shore during the day, but coming back at night. On some occasions he had over three hundred persons on board. They were all kindly treated. -- Bost. Journal, Sept. 12.

abstract: HORRIBLE FRATRICIDE. -- The St. Louis Evening News of the 8th details a revolting fratricide which was recently perpetrated at Steelville, Crawford County, Mo. Three brothers, by the names of DAVIS, resided at that place, and the elder on the day preceding the murder had sold a large amount of property, and then started, for St. Louis, leaving some of the money which he had received with his youngest brother. The second brother slept in the same room with the latter on the night in question with the intention of getting possession of the money which had been left with his younger brother. He arose sometime during the night, got an axe, and with it attempted to sever the victim's head from his body. The weapon struck the cheek-bone and then glanced down and carried away part of the chin, inflicting a wound which must speedily have terminated fatally. It was found next morning in the yard beneath the window of the room where the two had slept. It was covered with the blood and beard of the murdered man. The guilty man was arrested and committed to prison.

abstract: Up to 9  o'clock the only political devices borne upon the banners and transparencies which arrived upon the ground, in front of the Cooper Institute, were for DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, and these came from three or four Wards only.
lead_paragraph: Up to 9 o'clock the only political devices borne upon the banners and transparencies which arrived upon the ground, in front of the Cooper Institute, were for DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, and these came from three or four Wards only. Towards 10 o'clock, when the crowd had become somewhat thinned out, a procession of the Bell and Everett organizations arrived, marching up Broadway, and passing through Eighth-street into the Square. It consisted of delegations from Brooklyn, Eastern District, some of the Wards of this City, Jersey City, Newark, Paterson and other places. In the ranks were banners and transparencies, variously inscribed, and each platoon carried bells, with which they produced a constant tintinabulation. This reinforcement saved the reputation of the outside demonstration. They filled the square, a densely packed multitude, and these continued cheering and cheered for some time. The procession was some twenty minutes in passing the corner of Eighth-street and Broadway, and probably numbered two thousand persons. It was joined by the various Ward organizations, and continued its march through the Bowery and other of the principal thoroughfares.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday at 11 A.M., for the purpose of balloting for Inspectors of Registry, in accordance with the requirements of the Stale law. As the Committee was not prepared to report, an informal ballot was had in order to comply with the letter of the law, at which James Buchanan received two votes; John Bell, one; E.F. Purdy, two, and O. BLUNT the same number. The Board then took a recess until Monday at 3 P.M., for the purpose of proceeding with the regular balloting, and until Thursday at the same hour when the regular business of the Board will be taken up.

abstract: The Union was again saved at the Cooper Institute last evening. The country was lifted from the verge of the frightful abysm over which the Republicans were pushing it with split-rails, and placed under the protection of Mr. JOSHUA J. HENRYS, a highly respectable merchant, of the firm of HENRY SMITH & TOWNSEND, largely engaged in Southern trade. And thus it happened. At 7 o'clock a cannon, stationed in front of the temple dedicated to Science and Art, commenced booming; and during the rest of the evening it was employed in firing every now and then a feu de fusion. Rockets rose at intervals; tar-barrels blazed incessantly; here and there torches were gleaming; and a calcium light shone brightly over all. The people soon began to gather; some surrounded stands erected in the streets, and listened to words of wisdom from the Ward-politicians who held forth there; but all who could force their way into the large hall of the Institute sat and awaited the coming of the distinguished gentlemen whose appearance on this occasion had been promised in the partisan papers and hand-bills. It had been announced that Gen. SCOTT would preside, and the following was the advertised list of speakers:

abstract: THE BYRONIC BLACKSMITH. -- The London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian mentions "the curious fact that the son and heir of Lord LOVELACE, late Lord OCKHAM, and now by Lady BYRON's death, Baron WENTWORTH, and heir to the very large landed property bequeathed by the poet's widow, is now working at Woolwich Arsenal, as a smith, at weekly wages." This is a very pretty story, which loses nothing in the hands of a translator and correspondent of the Independance Belge, who adds, with fine dramatic instinct, bringing in the inevitable "Helen of Troy:"

abstract: Up to 9  o'clock the only political devices borne upon the banners and transparencies which arrived upon the ground, in front of the Cooper Institute, were for DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, and these came from three or four Wards only.
lead_paragraph: Up to 9 o'clock the only political devices borne upon the banners and transparencies which arrived upon the ground, in front of the Cooper Institute, were for DOUGLAS and JOHNSON, and these came from three or four Wards only. Towards 10 o'clock, when the crowd had become somewhat thinned out, a procession of the Bell and Everett organizations arrived, marching up Broadway, and passing through Eighth-street into the Square. It consisted of delegations from Brooklyn,. Eastern District, some of the Wards of this City, Jersey City, Newark, Paterson, and other places. In the ranks were banners and transparencies, variously inscribed, and each platoon carried bells, with which they produced a constant tintinabulation. This reinforcement saved the reputation of the outside demonstration. They filled the square, a densely packed multitude, and these continued cheering and cheered for some time. The procession was some twenty minutes in passing the corner of Eighth-street and Broadway, and probably numbered two thousand persons. It was joined by the various Ward organizations, and continued its march through the Bowery and other of the principal thoroughfares.

abstract: HORRIBLE FRATRICIDE. -- The St. Louis Evening News of the 8th details a revolting fratricide which was recently perpetrated at Steelville, Crawford County, Mo. Three brothers, by the names of DAVIS, resided at that place, and the elder on the day preceding the murder had sold a large amount of property, and then started for St. Louis, leaving some of the money which he had received with his youngest brother. The second brother slept in the same room with the latter on the night in question with the intention of getting possession of the money which had been left with his younger brother. He arose sometime during the night, got an axe, and with it attempted to sever the victim's head from his body. The weapon struck the cheek-bone and then glanced down and carried away part of the chin, inflicting a wound which must speedily have terminated fatally. It was found next morning in the yard beneath the window of the room where the two had slept. It was covered with the blood and beard of the murdered man. The quilty man was arrested and committed to prison.
lead_paragraph: HORRIBLE FRATRICIDE. -- The St. Louis Evening News of the 8th details a revolting fratricide which was recently perpetrated at Steelville, Crawford County, Mo. abstract: THE EUROPEAN HARVESTS AND AMERICAN SPECULATION. -- We warned our readers some time since against the perils of a premature speculation, upon the hypothetical failure of the European harvests. Our prospects of a domestic demand for the splendid crops of the northwest, ought of themselves to have prevented our speculators from risking such adventures abroad as, if defeated by a decline in the European demand, must necessarily result in blockading our transportation lines, depressing freights, elevating rates of exchange, and discomposing the financial balance of commerce. Nevertheless we have had our brief riot of grain speculation, and now, at its height, we are greeted with the news of a general improvement in the weather throughout the west of Europe, with a consequent fall in the price of breadstuffs. For this, of course, our reviving commerce will be called upon to pay, and we shall have the satisfaction of buying another lesson in that science of practical economy which practical men seem, of all others, to be the last to learn in theory, or to apply to their own affairs.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF SENATOR SEWARDS HORSES AT BOSTON. -- The bark Speedwell, Capt. MAYO, arrived at this port to-day, from Beyrout, Syria, bringing two of the horses which were presented to Senator SEWARD during his recent tour in that country. They were a gift from an officer in the Turkish Government. The lot comprised three animals, but unfortunately on the sixth day out the mare died of some disease contracted before embarking, as she gave unmistakable signs of sickness when brought on board. The others are in fine condition, and being of the celebrated Arabian breed, they will attract-considerable attention in this country. The Speedwell was in the harbor of Beyrout during the late excitement growing out of the massacre of Christians near that place, and Capt. MAYO has been highly commended for the prompt and efficient aid which he rendered to the flying fugitives from Moslem revenge. Large numbers sought refuge on board his vessel, some returning on shore during the day, but coming back at night. On some occasions he had over three hundred persons on board. They were all kindly treated. -- Bost. Journal, Sept. 12.

abstract: THE SLAVE-TRADE. -- The British Anti-Slavery Society has issued another of its periodical lamentations, and, for a wonder, the subject discussed is not altogether of an impracticable nature. The Society having learned, possibly by experience, that appeals to the pocket are more forcible than appeals to the morality or humanity of a people, demonstrate to the British nation that, for forty years past, it has annually expended a million sterling in its endeavors to abolish the Slave-trade. Even the London Times is staggered at the aggregate expenditure of forty millions, sterling so hopelessly squandered; for it not only appears from the Society's report that the Slave-trade still lives in spite of every effort to suppress it, but, as far as Cuba is concerned, is carried out upon a scale quite as large as that which prevailed before its abolition was agreed upon by civilized nations. The remedy for the evil proposed by the Anti-Slavery Society is one which the British Government are unwilling to adopt, though it is notoriously the only practical one that has ever been suggested. The Society has requested Lord JOHN RUSSELL to demand of Spain the immediate cessation of the Slave-trade, or to intimate that Great Britain will require the reimbursement, with interest, of the Â£;,400,000 compensation money, paid to Spain in 1817 for her discontinuance of the traffic, and the cessation of diplomatic intercourse. Doubts are entertained by the London Times whether Spain would either assent to the proposition or be much alarmed at the alternative. But such an objection can hardly be considered a valid one. The responsibility of continuing the Slave-trade, in defiance of public opinion throughout Christendom, belongs to Spain; and it is completely in the power of her Government to put a stop to the traffic whenever it pleases. Remonstrance has been ineffectual; but this is no reason why England should shrink from a duty that a specific treaty has imposed upon her. Until Spain has been made to feel the pressure indicated by the Anti-Slavery Society, it is premature for the Times to urge that that pressure would be unheeded. It ought, at least, to be tried by a Government which alone is in a position to make the experiment, and which is so earnest in its desire to see the Slave-trade abolished.

abstract: Pursuant to the established policy of the TIMES in giving a fair and impartial representation of the various contending parties before the people, we surrender a large portion of this morning's issue to the cause of Messrs. BELL and EVERETT. Much of this ocean of oratory was discharged last evening at the Cooper Institute, where there was an unprecedented rally of over-zealous friends of the Union and Constitution, to be instructed and strengthened by the exhortations of various partisan evangelists. The occasion was well improved. The addresses deserve the praise of producing some new and highly satisfactory variations upon that exhausted theme, Union-saving. Mayor WOOD, for example, placed before the eyes of the dazzled audience the figure of Commerce, surrounding it with a blaze of rhetorical and statistical fire-works, and traits of thorough reading, that must have misled an unprepared auditor into the belief that his Honor really knew something of the profound subject he was rashly discussing. No mistake could have been greater. The Mayor merely exalted the pecuniary goddess, to show in what constant danger she stood, environed as she is by the clamor of parties, and imperiled by thick-vollied threats of disunion. To appreciate the masterly facility with which Mayor WOOD handles these weighty matters, we need only refer to his statement that England borrowed free-trade from America; and, beaten in competition for the world's trade, she now looks to the event of the actual Presidential canvass, in the eager hope of seeing the Union dissevered and our commerce annihilated. But in permitting himself to add that, "Slavery in the Territories has ceased to be a political question; it has no bearing, upon the results of the contest; it is but the pretext for the exhibition of a growing spirit of aggression and repugnance," did not the Mayor, carried away by his novel company, lose sight of the fact that he is an avowed supporter of Mr. DOUGLAS, whose whole political capital is the agitation of this question of Slavery in the Territories?

abstract: With the single and not very fortunate change of Signor FERRI for Signor SUSINI in the important role of the Duke Alfonso, the opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" was last night successfully sung, according to the programme, at the Academy. The Lucrezia of Madame FABBRI is a creation of no ordinary power, and although it was admired and appreciated last Spring at the Winter Garden, it is but just to a very brilliant artiste to say that it was never fully felt till it received last night the development permitted by the nobler scale of the Academy building. Supported in her dramatic intensity and genuine abandon, by the exquisite musical perception, and the delicious voice of Signor BRIGNOLI, who sang with extraordinary force and expression, Madame FABBRI made, in the finale of the second act, the most truly operatic success of the present season. The duo of Lucrezia and Gennaro, fairly electrified the house; and had the leading, singers been more adequately relieved in the preceding trio, than they were, or could be, by Signor FERRI, we should not have grudged them a single one of the shower of bouquets which rained upon them at their recall on the fall of the curtain.

abstract: At an early hour on Saturday night the extensive piano-forte manufactory of BOARDMAN, GRAY  Co., corner of Broadway and North Ferry streets, Albany, was discovered to be on fire. The alarm was instantly given, but the exertions of the firemen succeeded in saving little beside the drying-rooms, which were separated from the rest of the building by fireproof walls and iron doors. In the yard were 50,060 feet of lumber, which barely escaped destruction.

In the yard were 50,060 feet of lumber, which barely escaped destruction.

abstract: A BRIG WRECKED OFF CAPE COD -- SEVEN LIVES LOST. -- In the gale of Sunday last, which was quite severe on the Atlantic coast, the brig Mary Pierce, Capt. CLIFFORD, from Bangor bound for this port, with a cargo of lumber consigned to Messrs. PIERCE & ROWLAND, was capsized about twelve miles east of Chatham Lights, Cape Cod. There were on board the Captain, mate, steward, four hands, and the Captain's son, an intelligent lad about seven years of age. This was about 9 o'clock in the forenoon. When the vessel capsized she lay at first on her beam-ends, and while in this condition the crew made endeavors to get out lumber for the purpose of making rafts, but before this could be accomplished she rolled entirely over. The Captain and steward sot to a boat, leaving the mate and the crew on the bottom of the brig and in the water. The mate, FRANK VARNUMS, 21 years of age and without family, was the only one known to have been saved. VARNUMS clung to the wreck, and kept the Captain's child with him until the poor boy died from exposure and was washed away. He kept his place upon the wreck by thrusting his knife into a worm-eaten spot upon the keel, and "holding on." During the day one after another of his comrades was washed off or died from chill, the storm raging with great fury.
lead_paragraph: A BRIG WRECKED OFF CAPE COD -- SEVEN LIVES LOST. -- In the gale of Sunday last, which was quite severe on the Atlantic coast, the brig Mary Pierce, Capt. CLIFFORD, from Bangor bound for this port, with a cargo of lumber consigned to Messrs. PIERCE & ROWLAND, was capsized about twelve miles east of Chatham Lights, Cape Cod. There were on board the Captain, mate, steward, four hands, and the Captain's son, an intelligent lad about seven years of age. This was about 9 o'clock in the forenoon. When the vessel capsized she lay at first on her beam-ends, and while in this condition the crew made endeavors to get out lumber for the purpose of making rafts, but before this could be accomplished she rolled entirely over. The Captain and steward sot to a boat, leaving the mate and the crew on the bottom of the brig and in the water. The mate, FRANK VARNUMS, 21 years of age and without family, was the only one known to have been saved. VARNUMS clung to the wreck, and kept the Captain's child with him until the poor boy died from exposure and was washed away. He kept his place upon the wreck by thrusting his knife into a worm-eaten spot upon the keel, and "holding on." During the day one after another of his comrades was washed off or died from chill, the storm raging with great fury.

abstract: Wm. Hanley, an Irishman, was taken yesterday before Justice WELSH to answer a charge of having conducted himself in a disorderly manner on Sunday night, while he was intoxicated, and also for examination on the graver charge of having attempted a cowardly assault upon Mary McNulty, a domestic, employed at the hotel No. 77 Cortlandt-street. When his case was called on for examination, it was found that the woman McNulty had disappeared from Court. The Justice, therefore, imposed a fine upon the prisoner as the penalty for conviction of the minor charge, and he was committed to prison in default of paying the amount. Subsequently however, the young woman presented herself before the magistrate, and represented that she would have appeared sooner had not officer Miller, one of the attaches of the tribunal, detained her in conversation until Hanley's case was disposed of. He had implored her, she said, not to press the complaint, adding that the accused was a man of good family, and that she would be handsomely remunerated for her kindness if she consented to let the matter up easily. She had rejected all of Miller's overtures, and now expressed herself ready to make an affidavit against the prisoner, which she did, alleging that he had beaten her with his fists, and detailing the other particulars of the assault. Upon this complaint Hanley was detained to await an examination. At the suggestion of the magistrate, Miss McNulty also subscribed to a statement, in which was narrated the substance of what transpired at the interview between herself and the officer. The latter was interrogated on the subject by Justice WELSH, and he admitted the truth of the young woman's story. In explanation of his conduct, however, he stated that he believed the offence committed by the prisoner to be of a trivial character, and as he had known him for a long time, and he was a person for whom he entertained friendly feelings, he had been induced to make the effort for his release. From first to last, however, he had not had the slightest intention to interfere with the administration of justice. The magistrate was not satisfied with the explanation, and he suspended the officer from duty pending an inquiry into the facts. Miller is an old man, having served in the navy during the War of 1812. This is the first time that a complaint has been made against him.

abstract: The Committee of Councilmen who are considering the charges brought by the Mayor against Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPAN, seem disposed to redeem the character of the parent Board. Precedent was not wanting to authorize an immediate decision against the accused, as soon as their unanswerable defence had been exhibited. Such a course would, we think, have been accepted by the public as in strict keeping with the antecedents of the Common Council; and neither surprise nor indignation would have been extracted from a community whose apathy is the natural result of persistent and uniform wrong-doing on the part of the civic legislature. These subdued expectations have been disappointed. The Committee has listened patiently to the defendants, and has gone so far on the direct route to justice, as to require the Mayor either to make good his charges or submit to have the innocence of his intended victims declared. Nor has the equitable temper of the tribunal ended in these manifestations. Senator WADSWORTH, whose direct or indirect concern in the conduct of the Croton Works must puzzle conjecture, has insisted on recognition as a prosecuting attorney against the accused. Unable to define his own connection with the case, and unwilling to disclose the names of the principals, for whom in this vexatious and frivolous business he has been induced to appear, Mr. WADSWORTH has been refused a hearing, the Committee very properly regarding their commission as restricted to the investigation of the Mayor's indictment; and believing that to obtain jurisdiction of other charges, they would have to obtain new powers from the Board. This course is at once regular, just and sensible. On every principle, Mr. WADSWORTH lacks standing before the Committee. Had he appeared as a witness, called to substantiate some count in the official indictment, recognition might have been proper. As a principal or as an advocate he was clearly out of place; and met with precisely the treatment his intrusion deserved.

abstract: AFFRAY ON SHIPBOARD -- A RUNNER DANGEROUSLY SHOT. -- Between 6 and 7 o'clock, last evening, a man named CHARLES LEONARD, who is by occupation a runner for a seaman's boarding-house, in West-street, was shot, it is thought mortally, by Capt. ADOLPH B. ELFSWORD, of the Swedish bark Maria Matilda, during the progress of an altercation between them on the deck of the vessel, at pier No. 6, North River. It is said that LEONARD visited the bark, and the captain; who had previously lost several of his men through the agency of the boarding-house runners, believing that the man had come to entice more of the crew away, ordered him to leave the ship. LEONARD reluctantly complied, first abusing Gapt. ELFSWORD in a very aggravating manner. He soon returned to the vessel, however, and coolly seated himself on the quarter-deck. This impudence on the part of the runner greatly enraged the Captain, who comanded that he should go on shore without further delay. Instead of obeying, LEONARD stopped to argue the matter, insisting that the Captain knew nothing of Ameeican law, and interspersing his remarks with offensive epithets. Unable longer to brook the insults of the ruffian, Capt. ELFSWORD procured a revolver and discharged one barrel of the weapon at him. The ball took effect in the man's thigh, and inflicted a wound which caused him to fall helplesss to the deck. The Captain at once went to the Sub-Station-house in Trinity-place and delivered himself into the custody of Capt. SILVEY, who detained him until to-day, when he will be taken before a magistrate. The injured man was subsequently conveyed by Officer ROWLAND to the New-York Hospital and placed under the care of Dr. WEIR. An effort was made to extract the ball, but it was not successful, and the probability is that LEONARD will not survive the wound.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board last evening, the following resolution was referred, the preamble setting forth that in the year 1817 the revenue arising from auction duties was ceded to the State Government to aid in the completion of the Erie Canal, and upon its completion such duties were to revert to the City, and as the Canal has long since been completed, the Finance Committee were directed to report at an early day as to what steps are necessary to be taken to recover back the duties for the use of the City Treasury, as well as the balance therefrom, since the object for which they were ceded has ceased to exist, together with all other information on the subject which they may be able to communicate.

abstract: The Union was again saved at the Cooper Institute last evening. The country was lifted from the verge of the frightful abysm over which the Republicans were pushing it with split-rails, and placed under the protection of Mr. JOSHUA J. HENRYS, a highly respectable merchant, of the firm of HENRY SMITH  TOWNSEND, largely engaged in Southern trade.
lead_paragraph: The Union was again saved at the Cooper Institute last evening. The country was lifted from the verge of the frightful abysm over which the Republicans were pushing it with split-rails, and placed under the protection of Mr. JOSHUA J. HENRYS, a highly respectable merchant, of the firm of HENRY SMITH TOWNSEND, largely engaged in Southern trade. And thus it happened. At 7 o'clock a cannon, stationed in front of the temple dedicated to Science and Art, commenced booming; and during the rest of the evening it was employed in firing every now and then a feu de fusion. Rockets rose at intervals; tar-barrels blazed incessantly; here and there torches were gleaming; and a calcium light shone brightly over all. The people soon began to gather; some surrounded stands erected in the streets, and listened to words of wisdom from the Ward-politicians who held forth there; but all who could force their way into the large hall of the Institute sat and awaited the coming of the distinguished gentlemen whose appearance on this occasion had been promised in the partisan papers and hand-bills. It had been announced that Gen. SCOTT would preside, and the following was the advertised list of speakers:

abstract: The Board met at 5 o'clock P.M., Alderman PECK in the chair. Among the petitions was one numerously signed for a ferry from the vicinity of Canal-street to a point in New-Jersey not named. Also one from the Second-avenue Railroad, asking for the passage of an ordnance, subject to the approval of the Legislature, permitting that Company to extend its track through Pearl-street to Burling-slip, and along South-street to Peck-slip. Also, a double track to their track in the Bowery, and a track through Seventy-ninth-street and Fifth-avenue. Referred to the Committee on Roads. Alderman BRADY reported the draft of an ordinance in Amendment to the City ordinances, creating the office of City Railroad Inspector, salary $3,000 a year. Laid over. The Communication from the Croton Board, asking for the confirmation of contract for laying the large water-pipes in Fourth-avenue to A.J. Hackley was called up, and was defeated 13 to 3. The Board adjourned to Thursday next, at 5 P.M.

abstract: WANTON ATTACK UPON THE HEALTH OFFICER -- TWO men, named WM.H. CHAMBERLAIN and JAMES CAMERON, at a late hour on Saturday night, made a most wanton and unprovoked attack upon Dr. J.B. JONES, Health Officer of this city, and President of the National Base-Ball Association. He was walking at the time on Fulton, near Tillary-street, when his assailants threw a coat over his head and commenced beating and kicking him, apparently with a view to robbery. With the assistance of an officer, he succeeded in capturing both of his assailants, and lodged them in the First Precinct Station-house. Yesterday morning the accused were brought before Justice CORNWELL, but Dr. JONES refused to make any complaint against them -- for what reason does not appear. He is severely bruised about the shoulders, and has a severe cut over the right eye.

abstract: The amount of ponderous stupidity which is expended in some quarters on Mr. SEWARD's recent admission that the extension of Slavery is not possible without the reopening of the Slave-trade, is a curious example of misdirected patience and industry. Nothing that simple toil can do to deduce from it the conclusion that the Republican Party has no basis, and no real object, has been left undone. The Republican Party, it is said, professes to have in view the restriction of Slavery to the territory it already occupies, but its chief concedes that, unless the Slave-trade be reopened, no extension of the "institution" can take place. No party now in the field proposes to reopen the Slave-trade; therefore the Republicans are fighting against a figment of their own imagination, are disturbers of the public tranquillity, and ought to go home and desist from agitation.

abstract: The war of the operas began in earnest last night, with the performance, by the Servadio troupe, of "La Traviata," at Niblo's Garden. We have already expressed our sense of the great mistake which artists and impresarii make in organizing a double opera where a single one can barely live, and in doing this at the suggestion of passions anything but harmonious. If we are to believe the story told by the people of the Academy of the causes which have led to the Servadio defection, it would not be easy to find terms of reprobation too strong for the conduct of Madame CORTESI's special manager, in compelling that lady to play fast and loose with the public, as well as with the Irving-place impresarii. Still all this cannot modify the fact that Madame CORTESI herself is a great lyric artist of rare dramatic ability, and that, when supported by that most robust of tenors, Signor MUSIANI, and by Signor AMODIO, she can make the role of "La Traviata" an inevitable success.
lead_paragraph: The war of the operas began in earnest last night, with the performance, by the Servadio troupe, of "La Traviata," at Niblo's Garden. abstract: We have received advices from Buenos Ayres, by way of England, to the 28th of July. President DERQUI and Gen. URQUIZA had paid a visit extending from the 7th to the 24th of that month on the invitation of Gen. MITRE, who thought that the 46th anniversary of the day on which the Argentine nation declared their absolute independence -- viz., the 9th of July -- would be an excellent opportunity for bringing together the leaders of the parties so recently antagonistic. The distinguished guests arrived at Buenos Ayres on the 7th from Parana and San Jose, each attended by a numerous suite and accompanied by his family, and experienced a most cordial reception from the populace, A review of the troops took place on the 9th in the Plaza Victoria, and receptions, banquets, balls, and other public displays were continued throughout the whole period of the visit, which closed on the 24th, when URQUIZA embarked on board the Government steamer 25 de Mayo, and DERQUI on board the Spanish steamer Concordia, and they took their departure amid general salutes from the ships-of-war and the batteries on shore.

abstract: In the succession of blunders made by the Democratic State Central Committee, in its negotiations for a fusion of all the Anti-Republican elements, we have the clearest evidence that those astute politicians forming the Regency must have a lost all hopes of success in the pending Presidential contest, and that their state of despair is shared by the rank and file of what was once their obedient army.

abstract: While the world has been quite aware that the melodrama of WALKER was in its closing act, it has been unprepared for the suddenness of the final scene. Nothing was more likely than that his expeditionary force would be expelled from Central America by the combined efforts of the natives and the British; and it was probable that some of the more destitute and disabled of the number might fall into the hands of the incensed pursuers. But either fortune or a shrewd outlook for self-preservation has thus far interposed to save WALKER himself from the hands of those whom his reiterated outrages have made implacable enemies, and it seemed also within the range of probability that his skill or luck would stand him in equally good stead in the actual emergency. The event is otherwise. WALKER has been captured by the English, and by them given over to the Hondurenos, to whom has descended an endless legacy of vengeance from all Spanish Americans. It is absurd to suppose that the arch-fillibuster is to be again turned loose as the pest and persecutor of these incapable peoples. Every consideration of security requires his immolation, even had mercy any plea to offer for reprieve. But mercy is not a characteristic of the Spanish, and still less of the Spanish-American, character. It could obtain no hearing in the present case, even were it disposed to speak. When, therefore, we read of the death sentence having already been passed upon the chief and his immediate aid, we can well understand that nothing can interpose to stay or mitigate the event. The condemned are certainly to die.

abstract: EXHIBITION OF A NEW STEAM FIRE ENGINE. -- A new steam fire engine, called the "Minnehaha," built by the Amoskeag Company, of Manchester, N.H., for the Exempt Engine Company, of Newark, N.J., was on exhibition in this City yesterday, and will probably play again in the Park to-day. It is a first-class engine, arranged to be drawn by horses. It was taken to the liberty pole in Franklin-street, at 11 o'clock, to test its power of throwing water. Three minutes and forty seconds sufficed to get ready for action, and then two streams were thrown, one through an inch nozzle, and the other through a 1 1/2 inch nozzle, and both streams went over the pole, which is 186 feet high. Through a nozzle of 1 7-16 inches in diameter, a stream went above the pole about five feet. A similar trial was made in the Park in the afternoon, where Steam-engine No. 38 of this City was also present. A friendly test match between the two machines was talked of, but no arrangement for it was made. The exhibition attracted a large crowd, which included a good many firemen, several of whom were heard to speak favorably of the new "steamer." In playing on the City Hall, one of the streams hit the gilt eagle on the west flagstaff, and was so powerful as to send the wings flying -- a natural though unlooked for exhibition of the real purposes which they mimically represented.

abstract: -- The Directors of the Princeton Theological Seminary have arranged for the inauguration of Prof. C.W. Hodge, on the first Thursday in November, at 3 o'clock. Rev. Dr. McPhail, President of Lafayette College, is to preach the installation sermon; Rev. Dr. Phillips, of New-York, is to propound the questions, and the Professor elect deliver his inaugural address. The disposal of the Chair assigned to Rev. Dr. Palmer, who declined, will not be definitely arranged until after Dr. McGill's return from Europe, who was to sail in the Europa on Saturday last.
lead_paragraph: -- The Directors of the Princeton Theological Seminary have arranged for the inauguration of Prof. C.W. Hodge, on the first Thursday in November, at 3 o'clock. Rev. abstract: After long and hitherto fruitless efforts on the part of his counsel to escape from the clutches of the law and the consequences of his alleged complicity in the slave-trade by straw bail, Da Costa and his friends have adopted the only alternative left, viz.: they have raised $5,000 and deposited it as security with responsible parties, in the event of his failure to appear for trial. The trial was set down for the October term, and there was little time left. The bail in the present case is Philo Beebe, Esq., brother of ex-Judge Beebe, Da Costa's counsel, a gentleman abundantly able to stand in the gap, but who, in this case, is understood to be entirely on the safe side, having the necessary security in his own hands. Da Costa has been imprisoned in Eldridge-street Jail until quite recently, when, in consequence of the escape of some prisoners from that institution, he was transferred for safe keeping to the Tombs. The bark Kate, which was some time since released on bond, is understood to be getting ready for sea.
