abstract: Adolph B. Elfwerson, captain of the Swedish bark Maria Matilda, who surrendered himself into custody on Monday night after having shot Charles Leonard, a sailor boarding-house runner, was yesterday arraigned before Justice WELSH for examination. A...
lead_paragraph: Adolph B. Elfwerson, captain of the Swedish bark Maria Matilda, who surrendered himself into custody on Monday night after having shot Charles Leonard, a sailor boarding-house runner, was yesterday arraigned before Justice WELSH for examination. A partial inquiry into the facts connected with the case showed that Leonard and a number of other runners had induced several of Capt. Elfwerson's crew to desert. On Monday, evening Leonard went on board probably to decoy more of the sailors away, when he was ordered to go on shore. He obeyed, but soon returned to the vessel, and immediately a dispute occurred between him and the Captain, during which the latter was grossly insulted. In his excitement Capt. E. drew his pistol and shot the runner. The Magistrate fixed bail for the accused in the sum of $10,000 to await the result of Leonard's injury. Mr. James Boorman Johnson, of No. 56 Tenth-street, entered into the necessary bonds, and the Captain was discharged. Leonard's condition is still regarded as precarious.

abstract: -- The Philadelphians, who grudge us every new school-house that we build, may prepare to die of despair on learning that we have permanently established a new college which threatens to flourish amain. The Trustees of the Homoeopathic Medical College have secured a building on the corner of Twentieth-street, in the rear of the Gramercy Park Hotel, and in the immediate vicinity of the Bellevue Hospital. In spite of the frowns and winks of a few of the more venerable Galens of the old practice, homoeopathy has at last made a place for itself in the world; and the new institution promises in the names of its officers, as well as in the curriculum of its studies, a real addition to the resources of the healing art in our City and country.
lead_paragraph: -- The Philadelphians, who grudge us every new school-house that we build, may prepare to die of despair on learning that we have permanently established a new college which threatens to flourish amain. abstract: The Europa, with London dates to the 9th inst., passed Cape Race on Sunday evening, and a brief summary of her news appears in this morning's paper. It is of an important character. The King of Naples has fled to Gaeta, en route, it is affirmed, for Madrid. He is said to have accepted the refuge and hospitality tendered him by the Queen of Spain. GARIBALDI, on the 6th inst., was at La Cava, within twenty miles of Naples. It was believed that he would be in the capital on the 7th of the current month. The intelligence of the fall of the Bourbon dynasty is accompanied by rumors of scarcely less importance. An insurrection had broken out in Pesaro, in the Roman territory, and the people had defeated the Papal troops. The advance guard of the Piedmontese army had entered the Marches, to preserve order. In Venitia, too, a formidable Garibaldian conspiracy had been discovered. Austria is making immense defensive preparations in her Italian territories. Details of intelligence by the Jura, whose arrival at Quebec has been announced, and by the Kangaroo, which arrived at this port yesterday, will also be found in this morning's TIMES.

abstract: We are beginning to see the fruits of Mayor WOOD's seizure of the public patronage. He removed Mr. STOUT as City Chamberlain, and got control of the City funds by placing them in a Bank known to be weak, and suspected of being more or less under corrupt influences. The Mayor's action was notoriously based on personal and political grounds; it had no regard whatever for the public welfare.

lead_paragraph: Further foreign news is obtained by the Europa, whose arrival at Halifax is telegraphed. The most important item is the announcement of the prevalence of a rumor that the British Government had already received a dispatch stating that GARIBALDI had made a triumphant entry into Naples on the 7th inst. Sardinia is displaying great activity in her preparations to intervene in Naples and in the Roman States. It is now stated that the Ex-King of the Two Sicilies will take refuge in Austria, and not in Spain, as originally intended. The Emperor of Austria has announced his intention to inaugurate important reforms in Hungary.

abstract: Mr. LINDSAY, whose mission to the United States has been the subject of such varied comment on both sides of the Atlantic, is a passenger by the Europa, due at Boston to-day. The resolution of the British shipowners against the mission, and the objections raised by the London Times, have not shaken the determination of the Government to send Mr. LINDSAY to Washington. The precise nature of this gentleman's visit does not seem to be generally understood. He does not come to this country in any representative capacity, or to interfere in any way with the duties or prerogatives of the recognized Ambassador. As a business man, largely engaged in the shipping interest, Mr. LINDSAY goes to Washington to discuss, in a friendly way, subjects with which he is perfectly familiar, and to aid Lord LYONS with his practical experience and knowledge. Mr. LINDSAY visits this country as Mr. COBDEN recently visited France; and though the latter did not undertake to perform any of the legitimate duties of the British Ambassador at Paris, his aid was willingly accepted and his services proved to be of the very greatest value. There was every probability that, with the aid of so practical, intelligent, and business-like assistant as Mr. LINDSAY, Lord LYONS would have succeeded in arriving at some understanding with our Government on those very important questions of shipping and commerce that both countries are anxious to see adjusted. Unfortunately, however, for British shipping interests, and for the furtherance of British free trade policy, we have been warned by British journals and British shipowners to look with distrust upon this mission, and with disfavor upon the gentleman to whom it has been confided. The London Times and the Society of British Shipowners have acted unwisely, for the maritime interest of their country, in attempting to throw discredit on Mr. LINDSAY's mission. They would have done better to have remained silent; for the course they have thought proper to pursue can have no other effect than that of heaping fresh difficulties in the envoy's path.
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINDSAY, whose mission to the United States has been the subject of such varied comment on both sides of the Atlantic, is a passenger by the Europa, due at Boston to-day. abstract: On various occasions of sacrifice to the Almighty Dollar we have called attention to the fact that perhaps ten thousand more victims would be drowned, roasted and quartered, to satisfy the greed of counting-room engineers.
lead_paragraph: On various occasions of sacrifice to the Almighty Dollar we have called attention to the fact that perhaps ten thousand more victims would be drowned, roasted and quartered, to satisfy the greed of counting-room engineers. However familiar the public may have become with the details of these regularly-recurring ceremonials, the slaughter of three hundred innocents at a time may afford an apology for throwing out some hints as to better steamboat construction. We are aware that we contend against fearful odds in criticizing the present practice. American boats are the cheapest and lightest in the world, for their speed -- their slender wooden hulls, girded by stiff "hogging frames," are so much better than iron bottoms and decks; the uninterrupted promenade from stem to stern, under the main deck and below the water line, is so much more attractive and convenient for the waiters, than narrow compartments dammed up by grim iron bulkheads; wooden clothing for boilers is never so much cheaper than iron jackets, and a pine tinder-box, generally, is a more cheaply-constructed and transported structure than a salamander safe. And, after all, there are millions of people who were never shipwrecked, just as there are millions of dollars that never were stolen.

abstract: An intense excitement was occasioned on Wednesday morning in Morgan-street, Jersey City, in consequence of a man named JAMES GATHREY having attempted to murder his daughter CATHARINE. 14
lead_paragraph: An intense excitement was occasioned on Wednesday morning in Morgan-street, Jersey City, in consequence of a man named JAMES GATHREY having attempted to murder his daughter CATHARINE. 14 years of age, and then attempting to destroy his own life by cutting his throat and inflicting wounds upon his arm. GATHREY is a Scotchman, about 40 years of age, a ship carpenter by trade, and has resided in Jersey City about six weeks, having removed there about six weeks since from Williamsburgh. The girl states that her father had made several attempts to violate her person, and that she recently caused his arrest in Williamsburgh for that offence.

abstract: The Emperor of the French is tormented, like other fortunate people, by needy and ambitious relations. His cousin, the Prince NAPOLEAN ...
lead_paragraph: The Emperor of the French is tormented, like other fortunate people, by needy and ambitious relations. His cousin, the Prince NAPOLEAN son of JEROME, has given him a world of trouble, by proving himself a most fretful soldier in time of peace, and a most laggard citizen in time of war, exciting all the disorganizing elements of French society by constant outbreaks of opposition to the policy of his imperial cousin, and seriously endangering the relations of France with the rest of Europe by his open intrigues for the Etrurian crown during the period of the Italian war. It is indeed asserted, and very positively, by persons who should be well informed, that the revelations with which Mr. KINGLAKE from time to time astounds the English House of Commons on the subject of the French Emperor's policy and intentions, come to that worthy gentleman from his intimate friend of the Palais Royal, and are intended to thwart and embarrass the Imperial action to the possible profit of Prince NAPOLEON. A new annoyance of the same kind has just been evoked by the critical position of the Neapolitan dynasty. Prince LUCIEN MURAT has advanced the most emphatic pretensions to the crown of the Two Sicilies, and having been rebuked by the official Moniteur, has replied in a justificatory letter, in which he assumes that if the popular vote of Naples should call him to the throne, the Emperor would be bound by his proclaimed policy of non-intervention to permit this new elevation of the House of Murat. The too aspiring representative of the soldier-king who failed the first NAPOLEON in his hour of need, forgets that he is now a French Prince, and that the consent of his imperial cousin, while it would not, of course, be necessary to his election by the people of Naples, would be absolutely essential to his acceptance of their proffered gift. This is a most important element in the calculations of the would-be successor of young BOMBA, and there can be small question that in the present state of European feeling, NAPOLEON III, will put a very decisive veto on any course of action which might for a moment warrant the Anti-Napoleonic parties of England and Germany in the supposition that he means to repeat the great error of his uncle's life, and set about tormenting Europe and embarrassing France with a network of petty Bonapartist monarchies. If Prince MURAT longs for a throne, he will do well to return to Florida, and take his chances in the chaos of our coming Southern Confederacy.

abstract: The Nineteenth Annual Exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society was held at Jamaica yesterday. The exhibition was one of the best ever got up by this Society, and there was a larger attendance than on any previous occasion. It is estimated that not less than ten thousand people ladies, gentlemen and children visited the grounds during the day.
lead_paragraph: The Nineteenth Annual Exhibition of the Queens County Agricultural Society was held at Jamaica yesterday. The exhibition was one of the best ever got up by this Society, and there was a larger attendance than on any previous occasion. It is estimated that not less than ten thousand people ladies, gentlemen and children visited the grounds during the day. The grounds where the exhibition was held was on the Flushing road, not far from Fulton-street, and near the residence of Gov. KING, and were peculiarly adapted to the purposes of the Society. A tent covering 15,000 square feet -- the largest every erected by the Society -- was on the ground, in which was a fine display of grain, vegetables, fruit, flowers, butter and domestic manufactures, together with carriages, farm implements and other articles connected with the mechanic arts. The display of fruits, flowers and vegetables was the best ever made by this Society. There was a great variety of horses -- from the little Shetland pony, hardly large enough, apparently, to carry the smallest boy, up to the monster stallion and draught-horse. There was also a good display of cows, bulls, oxen, hogs, sheep and brood mares.

abstract: -- Mrs. Harney, wife of Gen. Harney, of the United States Army, died at her residence, No. 28 Rue de Berri, Paris, on Monday, 27th ult. The funeral services over her remains took place at the Church of St. Phillippe, Faubourg St. Honore, with all the solemn and imposing ceremonials of the Roman Catholic Church, of which she was a member. Among those who did honor to her remains, were her son, son-in-law and nephew; Mr. Faulkner, the American Minister, Mr. Calhoun, a planter from Louisiana, Col. Stewart, son of Commodore Stewart, and many others. The services at the church occupied more than an hour, and were very grand and impressive.

abstract: WELCOME TO JOHN B. GOUGH IN BOSTON. -- The Tremont Temple was crowded last evening to its utmost capacity by the friends of temperance who had gathered to extend a welcome to their eloquent champion, Mr. JOHN B. GOUGH, on his first appearance in this city since his return from Europe. The meeting was called to order by Rev. HENRY M. DEXTER, of this city, who stated that Mr. GOUGH was here at the solicitation of over 500 clergymen, who wished the cause of temperance to receive a new and fresh impetus from the eloquence of his lips. The mention of the name of Mr. GOUGH, and his appearance on the platform, was greeted with immense applause. He was then introduced to the audience, and was received with a perfect outburst of applause, which concluded with three hearty cheers, which were called for by Rev. Dr. KIRK, who gave the "hip!" "hip!" and led off. Mr. GOUGH then proceeded to express his thanks for the very kind and cordial welcome which had been extended to him, and then continued in a discursive, rambling, entertaining, pleasant, pathetic, humorous, familiar and most eloquent address, in which he detailed much of his experience in England and Scotland, and leading all his audience quite away with him by the moving pathos of his relations. He closed with an appeal to Boston men to go on and overthrow the dram-shop, and announcing his intention to devote himself to the crusade.

abstract: We publish this morning a highly interesting correspondence between Ex-Speaker ORR and Hon. AMOS KENDALL on the subject of ...
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a highly interesting correspondence between Ex-Speaker ORR and Hon. AMOS KENDALL on the subject of Secession. We commend it to the attention of the old Jackson Democrats, North and South. It will abundantly repay perusal, and may open their eyes to the dismal abyss of folly and ruin into which an active gang of political conspirators are endeavoring to plunge the people of the Southern States.

abstract: QUARTERLY MEETING OF SUNDAY SCHOOL TRACHERS. The Quarterly Meeting of Teachers connected with the Sunday Schools of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this City, was held last night in the new and beautiful Church in Fourth-street, near Washington-square, at present occupied by the congregation formerly worshipping in the Sullivan-street M.E. Church. The building was crowded with ...
lead_paragraph: QUARTERLY MEETING OF SUNDAY SCHOOL TRACHERS. The Quarterly Meeting of Teachers connected with the Sunday Schools of the Methodist Episcopal Church in this City, was held last night in the new and beautiful Church in Fourth-street, near Washington-square, at present occupied by the congregation formerly worshipping in the Sullivan-street M.E. Church. The building was crowded with teachers representing over twenty churches of this City, and the meeting was presided over by Mr. C.C. NORTH. The object of the meeting, which is held quarterly, is to discuss subjects connected with the Sunday-school cause, and to devise means for augmenting the usefulness of the Association. To this end questions are proposed for discussion by the teachers, and suggestions are offered as to the best means of increasing the number of attendants upon the schools and imparting the most thorough instruction, the meetings thus partaking of a colloquial character, in which any teacher may take part. The proceedings of last evening were opened by a hymn, exceedingly well sung by a large and thoroughly drilled choir, followed by a prayer by Rev. Mr. PUTNEY, of Williamsburgh, after which the exercises were opened for the discussion of the following subjects, in which many of the teachers took part: 1. "Ought any but deeply pious persons be placed at the head of our classes?" 2. "Are our Anniversaries conducted on Christian or worldly principles?" The Association represents some thirty Churches of the Methodist Episcopal persuasion, having in charge over 15,000 scholars, and from its first organization thirty-three years ago up to the present time, has continued to thrive and increase annually. The large attendance of last evening and the deep interest taken in the proceedings afford abundant evidence of the deep interest felt by those engaged in this good work.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon the Comptroller, on behalf of the City, took legal possession of the stands in West Washington market, by virtue of a warrant issued by Judge INGRAHAM to the Sheriff. The tenants, some four hundred, in number, were all at their stands, and acquiesced in this disposition of the case. The rents will hereafter be paid to the Collector of the City Revenue, the issue to abide the result of the amended complaint of Messrs. TAYLOR & BRENNAN, in which they claim $1,500,000 for back rents.

abstract: A heavy rain-storm at 8 o'clock this morning flooded the city, filled cellars and basements and drove people from the breakfast table. It destroyed property, furniture and eatables to the amount of $20,000 at least. Engines are now pumping the water out. Several places were struck by lightning but no one was killed.

abstract: The regular weekly meeting of this Board took place Wednesday afternoon, at Castle Garden. Commissioner VERPLANCK presided. According to the weekly statement, the number of emigrants arrived at this port during this year, amounted to 77,526, against 55,658 arrived here during the same time last year. The number arrived here last week amounts to 2,535. The number of inmates in the various institutions under the care of the Board amounted to 786. The aggregate receipts during the past week amounted to $5,432, while the disbursements during the same time amounted to $8,140 56, leaving a balance of $12,828 34 of the commutation fund in the bank. A communication of the Counsel of the Board was received, citing the State law regarding the authority claimed by Br. JEROME, the resident Physician at the Marine Hospital, to give permits to enter the Quarantine Grounds, which right the Commissioners are not willing to grant to Dr. JEROME. He advised the Commissioners to have a policeman stationed at the gate, who should refuse admittance to every person having a permit signed by any other person than Dr. GUNN, the Health Officer. The report was adopted. The salary of Mr. DEVELIN, the Counsel of the Board, was raised from $1,500 to $2,500. The sum of $3,000 was granted to the Ward's Island Committee, to have the Lunatic Asylum on Ward's Island completed forthwith. No other business being before the Board, it adjourned.

abstract: Two young men, giving the names of James Hennessey and William Conroy, were arrested, last evening, by Detectives Roach and Williamson, on suspicion of having stolen a set of jewelry, valued at $1,400...
lead_paragraph: Two young men, giving the names of James Hennessey and William Conroy, were arrested, last evening, by Detectives Roach and Williamson, on suspicion of having stolen a set of jewelry, valued at $1,400 from the residence of F.M. Vesey, Esq., of this City. It appeared that the prisoners were recently employed to do some painting at Mr. Vesey's house, and they suddenly disappeared, leaving their work unfinished. About the same time it was found that the jewelry had been stolen from a bureau drawer, and the painters, very naturally, were suspected of having appropriated it. The Police were informed of the matter, and last evening the prisoners were seen to leave a Hudson River Railroad train which had just arrived from Albany. Their appearance corresponding with the description that had been furnished of the supposed thieves, both were at once taken into custody and detained for examination, but the stolen property was not recovered.

abstract: The Tammany Hall Judiciary Convention met last night in Tammany Hotel, Supervisor WM. M. TWEED in the Chair, and GEORGE A.JEREMIAH and HENRY A. WEST acting as Secretaries.
lead_paragraph: The Tammany Hall Judiciary Convention met last night in Tammany Hotel, Supervisor WM. M. TWEED in the Chair, and GEORGE A.JEREMIAH and HENRY A. WEST acting as Secretaries. A full delegation -- seven from each Ward -- were present. Two sets of delegates claimed admission from the First, Eleventh and Nineteenth Wards. The First Word delegations were headed by NICHOLAS DIMOND and MICHAEL HALPIN. The Dimond delegation was admitted. The Eleventh Ward delegations were headed by Alderman BOOLE and BERNARD KELLY -- the Boole delegation was admitted. The Nineteenth Ward delegations were headed by ex-Alderman HERRICK and ex-Alderman MCSPEDDON -- the Herrick delegation was admitted.

abstract: Some five years ago, the bold attitude assumed by the Socialists, in this City, drew public attention to them, and the iniquitous deeds of that extreme section which came to be known as "Free-Lovers," were exposed from time to time in the columns of the Daily Press.
lead_paragraph: Some five years ago, the bold attitude assumed by the Socialists, in this City, drew public attention to them, and the iniquitous deeds of that extreme section which came to be known as "Free-Lovers," were exposed from time to time in the columns of the Daily Press. The first local development of Socialism, however, dates back through a period of twenty years. Free-Love, the bolder and more immodest phase of the Fourierite philosophy, is comparatively recent. Its progress has been remarkably rapid, -- either because the license which it permits is peculiarly suited to the disposition of the lower classes existent in a great city, or, as pietists will contend, from the proneness of mankind to commit wickedness. Be the reason what it may, the growth of this ulcerous abomination of unrestrained lust is constant, and is virtually unchecked by legal enactment or by the general condemnation of the community. Occasional raids of the Police force upon public places, like that which resulted in the discomfiture of the Free-Love League in the Fall of 1855, effect only a temporary diversion, -- the routed parties are quite sure of retaining a degree of vitality which enables them to reappear in a shape even more formidable and mischievous than before.

abstract: THE THIRD PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH DIFFICULTIES. It will be recollected that a difficulty occurred some few weeks since between Rev. JAMES GUBBY, pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Jersey City, and some of the elders and members.
lead_paragraph: THE THIRD PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH DIFFICULTIES. -- It will be recollected that a difficulty occurred some few weeks since between Rev. JAMES GUBBY, pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Jersey City, and some of the elders and members. Affidavits from both parties of a criminal nature were made before a Justice of the Peace, and bonds were given for an investigation before the Courts. A meeting of the Presbytery was held in the First Presbyterian Church the present week, and after a full hearing from Mr. JAMES WILSON on the part of the prosecution, and Rev. Mr. GUBBY for the defence, it was decided by a unanimous vote that the charges were not sustained. The principal charge was, that Mr. GUBBY had conveyed property to his wife in order to avoid paying a debt. Messrs. WILSON, ATCHISON, STERLING, and others resigned their positions as elders and members of the church.

abstract: One of the pieces of advice which Southern sages are constantly offering to Northerners is, to turn their attention to some other subject than Slavery, or as it is sometimes forcibly put, to "cease their eternal clatter about niggers."
lead_paragraph: One of the pieces of advice which Southern sages are constantly offering to Northerners is, to turn their attention to some other subject than Slavery, or as it is sometimes forcibly put, to "cease their eternal clatter about niggers." They constantly assure us that if we in these latitudes would only divert our thoughts from the institution, and spare ourselves the pain of dwelling on woes which we grossly exaggerate and can do nothing to alleviate, the halcyon days of the Republic would speedily return, and all sectional controversy be forever at an end.

abstract: It has been very difficult to ascertain what the South is afraid of in the event of LINCOLN'S election. The Herald has been assuring them that LINCOLN intends to take out writs of habeas corpus for the purpose of freeing the slaves, and that the Wide Awakes are a posse comitatus, organized for the purpose of serving the papers.
lead_paragraph: It has been very difficult to ascertain what the South is afraid of in the event of LINCOLN'S election. The Herald has been assuring them that LINCOLN intends to take out writs of habeas corpus for the purpose of freeing the slaves, and that the Wide Awakes are a posse comitatus, organized for the purpose of serving the papers. There is only now and then, however, a Southern fool foolish enough to give any heed to such trash. But many persons in that latitude seem to apprehend proceedings of some kind against their peace, -- some interference of Congress with their rights, -- some invasion of their Territories, -- or some marked interference with their domestic institution, -- the nature of which they do not understand, but which will demand armed resistance.

abstract: A SENSIBLE SLAVEHOLDER. -- A Maryland farmer who owns fifty slaves writes to the Baltimore Patriot arguing against the profitableness of slaveholding in the State, He says: "Does the income we receive from our slaves, repay us for the depreciation of our property? The cash value of the corn, wheat and tobacco crops of Maryland in 1850, at present prices, would be about $14,905,308; the slaves on farms, were 65,509, or about one-fifth and a fraction of the agricultural population; their proportion of the crops made, $3,726,326; set down their expenses at $50 each, it comes to $3,475,450, almost as much as they make. The cash capital they represent, is $30,000,000, or more. Who will call it capital well invested? This calculation may appear exaggerated, yet it is fairly drawn from our State statistics, and the experience of very many of our own slaveowners will pronounce it rather under, than overstated.
lead_paragraph: A SENSIBLE SLAVEHOLDER. -- A Maryland farmer who owns fifty slaves writes to the Baltimore Patriot arguing against the profitableness of slaveholding in the State, He says: "Does the income we receive from our slaves, repay us for the depreciation of our property? The cash value of the corn, wheat and tobacco crops of Maryland in 1850, at present prices, would be about $14,905,308; the slaves on farms, were 65,509, or about one-fifth and a fraction of the agricultural population; their proportion of the crops made, $3,726,326; set down their expenses at $50 each, it comes to $3,475,450, almost as much as they make. The cash capital they represent, is $30,000,000, or more. Who will call it capital well invested? This calculation may appear exaggerated, yet it is fairly drawn from our State statistics, and the experience of very many of our own slaveowners will pronounce it rather under, than overstated.

abstract: A dense fog enveloped this City on Wednesday night, followed yesterday morning by a heavy fall of rain, which has continued, with brief intermission, ever since. Rain commenced falling all along the Hudson River as early as Wednesday evening, and a thick fog prevailed, which interfered seriously with navigation -- it being almost impossible to distinguish the lights on the steamers and other vessels for any considerable distance. The fog was also very dense last night. The storm, fortunately, has thus far been unaccompanied by the high winds which usually mark the Equinoctial, and the shipping in our harbor and on the coast has consequently escaped any measure of the devastation which swept along the Gulf coast on Saturday last. The only damage reported thus far has been from the flooding of cellars and basements.

abstract: We have from Honduras, by way of Havana, the intelligence that Gen. WALKER with his principal officer had been shot. No one can hesitate to say that his fate was just.
lead_paragraph: We have from Honduras, by way of Havana, the intelligence that Gen. WALKER with his principal officer had been shot. No one can hesitate to say that his fate was just. He had braved it over and over again, and would have been the last, we presume, to complain of it. When he made a private and therefore a piratical war upon a foreign State, he deliberately took all the chances of such war. He knew perfectly the penalties of failure, and understood thoroughly the public necessities which would compel their enforcement. His name had become a terror to all the States of Central America. Their Governments, with reason, regarded him as their enemy, and found their only security against a renewal of his attacks in his death.

abstract: Hon. ELI THAYER announces himself an independent candidate for Congress from the Ninth District of Massachusetts. In reply to a letter of solicitation to this effect, together with a request signed by nearly five hundred Republicans, Mr. THAYER gives...
lead_paragraph: Hon. ELI THAYER announces himself an independent candidate for Congress from the Ninth District of Massachusetts. In reply to a letter of solicitation to this effect, together with a request signed by nearly five hundred Republicans, Mr. THAYER gives his reasons for this step. He complains that the established usages of the party have been violated out of hostility to him. The Convention was designedly called before he could have time to address his constituents in many of the towns. The Republican Press of the District, he says, has been and is "a mere instrument in the hands of a conspiracy to misrepresent and abuse me." He concludes his letter as follows:

abstract: Alas! for the fashion-loving ladies of NewYork! they have, it seems, no friend in the clerk of the weather, for that mythical personage invariably spoils the brightness of that day which they would fain have the brightest of all the year. We must think that old Jupiter Pluvius has a mortal hatred o pretty bonnets and rich silks.
lead_paragraph: Alas! for the fashion-loving ladies of NewYork! they have, it seems, no friend in the clerk of the weather, for that mythical personage invariably spoils the brightness of that day which they would fain have the brightest of all the year. We must think that old Jupiter Pluvius has a mortal hatred o pretty bonnets and rich silks. No matter what the season or the day the ladies may set apart for a grand carnival of fashion, there is pretty sure to be an opening after another fashion in the clouds, that will be quite sure to cause everything in Broadway, in the millinery and dry goods line, to look dull and dismal. Yesterday being the opening day of the season, when all the pretty things were laid out for pretty eyes to gaze upon, Aquarius began, as usual, to pour out his wrath, and to shut out the sun with thick leaden curtains, so that the ladies should not see to try on their bonnets, or distinguish the beauties of delicate shades. But the ladies begged and implored. They reminded him at last that the Prince was coming, and that they had to select various beautiful things to receive him in; and at length the stern old fellow relented, and about 11 o'clock allowed the sun to show a corner of his eye for an hour or so, to light the delighted ladies on their path through Broadway and other haunts of fashion.

abstract: HOME ADULTERATION OF DRUGS. At the meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Assocition, in this City, on the 11th inst., a paper was read by Mr. CARNEY, of Boston, on the frauds and deceptions practiced on the public by adulterations of drugs.
lead_paragraph: HOME ADULTERATION OF DRUGS. At the meeting of the American Pharmaceutical Assocition, in this City, on the 11th inst., a paper was read by Mr. CARNEY, of Boston, on the frauds and deceptions practiced on the public by adulterations of drugs. The public have but little idea of the extent to which they are tampered with in this matter, nor would any intelligent community submit to the imposition were they once fully aware of the danger and risk they are exposed to. It is indeed a horrible thought that the very drugs we take to cure disease may be unconsciously but surely planting the seeds of death in our system. Adulterations he divided into three classes: 1. For making the drug more salable by improving its appearance by the addition of some body either innocuous or otherwise; 2. Depreciating the quality, by adding some substance which will diminish the real without altering the apparent strength or general appearance. This is generally a very deadly fraud. 3. Depreciating the quality and extending the quantity by the addition of some simple substance, as water; or, if a solid body, as sand, gypsum, &c. The past year has seen opium held at a high price, and in consequence a case of this article has been met with liberally charged with shot. All the shot that could be sold at $5 50 a pound, would be, of course, regarded as a mere pecuniary transaction, paying well; as a remedy, however, the opium would outweigh the lead in value. A specimen of nitrate of silver, also, sold by a New-York house for a pure article, contained but 30 per cent. of silver -- it should, if pure, have yielded 64 per cent. "Pure chloroform" has been found containing more than 12 per cent. of alcohol, and its specific gravity below 1.40. When remonstrated with, the vender said that the alcohol was necessary to preserve the chloroform! And so with many other articles.

abstract: The Regulars having disastrously failed in their attempts at fusion, the Volunteers have taken it up with as much earnestness as if they had any prospects of success.
lead_paragraph: The Regulars having disastrously failed in their attempts at fusion, the Volunteers have taken it up with as much earnestness as if they had any prospects of success. The Committee of Fifteen, authorized to be appointed at the meeting on Monday night, held a session yesterday at the Assay Office of Mr. BUTTERWORTH, and appointed a Sub-Committee, consisting of Messrs. TILDEN, BUTTERWORTH, CROSWELL, J.J. HENRY, and BARLOW, to confer with the two Democratic organizations.

abstract: The Committee met yesterday, pursuant to adjournment. Mr. GENET asked Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPAN if they had anything further to say, to which both responded, that inasmuch as no evidence had been furnished to oppose their statements, they had of course no evidence to offer, but were prepared to substantiate the truth of their explanations. After consultation, the Committee announced, through the Chairman, Mr. GENET, that inasmuch as the Mayor had not thought proper to produce any evidence in substantiation of his charges, the Committee had nothing further to do but to examine those charges and the answers thereto, and to report the conclusions which they might reach. Promising to report at the earliest possible day, the Committee was declared adjourned sine die, and its labors closed. It was intimated, however, that Mr. WADSWORTH (who was not present,) might prefer charges against Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPAN to the Board of Aldermen, and the Committee would carefully and thoroughly investigate them.

abstract: A German in Rochester had a narrow escape from being killed on Monday. He was crossing the railroad bridge over the Genesee River, wheeling a barrow before him, when he saw a train approaching.
lead_paragraph: -- A German in Rochester had a narrow escape from being killed on Monday. He was crossing the railroad bridge over the Genesee River, wheeling a barrow before him, when he saw a train approaching. He immediately saw the predicament in which he was placed, abandoned the wheelbarrow, and perched himself on the railing of the bridge. He had hardly done so when the engine struck the barrow, smashing it into splinters, one piece hitting the German and cutting a large hole over one of his eyes; and if he had not had a good hold on his perch he would have been knocked into the river. From thence he would have undoubtedly gone over the Falls.

abstract: As the waves of popular emotion which run before the advance of GARIBALDI and his liberating forces, rise higher and higher towards the north of Italy, it becomes more and more important for all who are interested in the future of Europe to satisfy themselves as to the position in which Austria will find herself whenever events shall compel her, as compel her in all human probability they must, to take the field in defence of her Italian possessions. A single-handed conflict between Austria and Italy might very well be fought out to the end without involving the general peace of the world; and in spite of all that is to be said of the military advantages with which Austria would enter upon such a conflict, it may reasonably be doubted whether the military skill of GARIBALDI and of the Piedmontese Generals leading on the enthusiasm of twenty-five millions of Italians already flushed with victory and fighting on their own soil, must not prove an overmatch for the discipline of the Austrian masses, uninspired either by confidence in their leaders, or by the character of their cause, and harassed by all the ills which a baukrupt exchequer can prepare for an expeditionary army. But Austria cannot enter Italy with an ally, and Europe remain tranquil. Is it, then, probable, that in any circumstances Austria can count upon any one of the great Powers for armed support in a Venetian campaign?

abstract: The latest joke perpetrated by the playful people of Arkansas deserves something more than passing mention in a newspaper paragraph; it should be placed on record as an enduring monument to the virtues of Southern extremists.
lead_paragraph: -- The latest joke perpetrated by the playful people of Arkansas deserves something more than passing mention in a newspaper paragraph; it should be placed on record as an enduring monument to the virtues of Southern extremists. A newsdealer, by the name of MARSH, for vending a few copies of the Tribune in Arkansas, was captured by a delegation from that State, tried and sentenced to be hung. Now, to circulate the Tribune may be a crime, very probably it is, yet it scarcely merits so severe a punishment as death at the hands of the hangman. At the worst it can only be construed as an error in taste and judgment, and as Mr. MARSH did not order the copies for personal perusal, but only to fill a special demand, the sin does not lie at his door. The gentlemen guilty of longing for the Tribune are certainly amenable to punishment, and as it might be difficult to point them out in so thickly settled a State as Arkansas, an indiscriminate hanging of the whole population would insure an individual retribution and subserve the ends of justice generally.

abstract: DISCHARGING VAGRANTS. Very great inconvenience is experienced by the Commissioners of Charities from the fact that persons committed as vagrants are constantly discharged, by order, or at the request of Police Magistrates, some of whom seem to exercise very little discretion in regard to the matter.
lead_paragraph: DISCHARGING VAGRANTS. -- Very great inconvenience is experienced by the Commissioners of Charities from the fact that persons committed as vagrants are constantly discharged, by order, or at the request of Police Magistrates, -- some of whom seem to exercise very little discretion in regard to the matter. The Commissioners have investigated some of the cases which have occurred, and found reason to believe that the whole operation is a flagrant swindle. A woman named WATSON, for example, was recently committed by Justice CONNOLLY as a vagrant: a few days after, a man appears, and presents an affidavit purporting to be made by PETER DE NOLLE, to the effect that he had long known her and her friends, -- that she lived in Newark, where she had a family, -- that this was her first offence, and that he desired to take her home. The affidavit purported to have been taken before ASA BUTMAN, Commissioner of Deeds, -- but it was evidently, signatures, and all, in the same handwriting. On the back was an order of Justice CONNOLLY, consenting to her discharge. The Commissioners, however, looked a little further into the matter, and on applying to the woman herself, found that she knew nothing whatever of DE NOLLE, had never lived in Newark, had no family and no home, and, in short, that the whole story was utterly false. These are things of very common occurrence, and demand public attention. Whether it is sheer carelessness on the part of Justices or not, it is a gross abuse, and should be stopped.

abstract: SINGULAR DISPOSITION OF A DEAD BODY. On Monday last, a man, while passing through the woods at Lloyd's Neck, about one mile from the residence of J.C. BRANDAGEE, discovered the body of a man in nearly a nude state.
lead_paragraph: SINGULAR DISPOSITION OF A DEAD BODY. -- On Monday last, a man, while passing through the woods at Lloyd's Neck, about one mile from the residence of J.C. BRANDAGEE, discovered the body of a man in nearly a nude state. He notified Coroner HAWXHURST, when an inquest was held, and the body was buried in a hole near the spot, without coffin or other covering. A correspondent states that the Jury made no effort whatever to discover the cause of death, while at the and time there were indications of violence about the head, which may or may not have been inflicted before death. The citizens of Huntington, upon learning what had been done, were quite indignant about the matter, and a Committee was appointed to disinter the body, examine it with a view to ascertain the cause of death, if possible, and give the body decent burial.

abstract: Yesterday, at the opening of this Court, Mr. A. Oakey Hall submitted a petition from Charles Jefferds, now confined in the City Prison, for the alleged double murder of Messrs, Walton and Mathews, in Fourthavenue, in July last.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at the opening of this Court, Mr. A. Oakey Hall submitted a petition from Charles Jefferds, now confined in the City Prison, for the alleged double murder of Messrs, Walton and Mathews, in Fourthavenue, in July last. The petition set forth that the defendant prayed to be released on bail, inasmuch as he was not committed by virtue of any writ or by the action of any proper tribunal, he being detained in prison solely on the verdict of a Coroner's Jury, no action having been taken against him by the public prosecutor, in bringing the matter before the Grand Inquest. Mr. Hall, therefore, asked the Court to grant an order, releasing the prisoner on bail.

abstract: Without waiting for the particulars of the closing catastrophe to Gen. WALKER'S eventful career, we may assume that he died like a soldier in the truest sense of the term. His friends in this City attribute his fate to an unyielding moral courage and proud contempt of the consequences before him, which forbid the slightest approach to a...
lead_paragraph: Without waiting for the particulars of the closing catastrophe to Gen. WALKER'S eventful career, we may assume that he died like a soldier in the truest sense of the term. His friends in this City attribute his fate to an unyielding moral courage and proud contempt of the consequences before him, which forbid the slightest approach to a petition, on his personal account, for leniency or mercy. Their present belief is, that he must have refused the mediation of the English commander on terms which, besides being a humiliating apology to the Honduran authorities, may have looked to the unconditional abandonment of his claim upon Nicaragua, and his aims, of every nature, upon that and all other of the Central American Governments. In other words, that he must have declined giving the parole which was probably demanded of him as the condition precedent to pardon or reprieve. They are quite sure that if there was aught in such demand, which implied, directly or remotely, personal humiliation or public disgrace, he did decline it, promptly and fearlessly, without the quiver of a muscle, or the superfluous or doubtful use of a single word; thus yielding up his life on a punctilio of honor as readily as he had often before risked it on the hazard of imminent and extraordinary dangers, voluntarily assumed, on other fields. Such was the man, and as such we have every reason to believe he died.

abstract: Ball vs. Mander. -- Mr. Mander was in a drinking saloon one day, playing a game of cards. Somebody came in and served a summons upon him. It was a summons from a Justice's Court; what is called a short summons, returnable in this instance in two days. He put the paper in his pocket to continue his game, but unluckily forgot all about it until the return day had passed. Meanwhile, the plaintiff appeared before the Justice, and, in defendant's absence, obtained a judgment. Defendant then applied to the General Term of the Common Pleas, on appeal, to excuse his default.

abstract: Frederick W. Hoffman, a middle-aged man, of gentlemanly appearance and address, was apprehended yesterday, by officer Pross, of the Seventeenth Ward, at the instance of Mathew Reicharts, a German, residing at No. 30 Avenue A, who charges him with having swindled him out of fifty cents, under the following circumstances: About two months since, the prisoner called at the complainant's house and represented that he had been authorized to collect funds for the purpose of building a Catholic Church and school-house, somewhere in the State of Pennsylvania. At the same time he exhibited a paper which bore the names of several persons as having subscribed for the purpose in question, and who recommended the project to the favorable consideration of the benevolent. Among the names on this subscription list the complainant observed that of the Rev. Mr. Brookmayer, a Catholic Clergyman residing in Second-avenue, and being well acquainted with that gentleman, he believed the prisoner's representations to be true, and subscribed fifty cents toward building the church, &c. Subsequently he learned that Mr. Brookmayer had never signed any such paper, and in the belief that Hoffman was an imposter, he had him arrested as soon as he could be found. The accused was taken before Justice BRENNAN, who committed him for examination. In his possession, besides the subscription-list for the Catholic Church, another document was fonnd, showing that he had also been soliciting aid for a Lutheran Congregation. The names of the subscribers are quite numerous, and the sums donated by each person range in amount from 50 cents to $10.

abstract: The declaration of Mr. KENDALL, that in case any overt act of resistance to Mr. LINCOLN's inauguration, in the event of his election, were attempted, or any disposition were shown by any of the States to secede in consequence of it, 200,000 men would be found ready to volunteer for the execution of the laws and maintenance of the Union, has, it is said, created such a sensation amongst the extreme section of the Pro-Slavery Party, that they have already began to denounce him as "an Abolitionist."

abstract: The Committee appointed by the Committee that was appointed by Mr. JOSHUA J. HENRY held a preliminary meeting yesterday at the Assay office. The failure of the Douglas and Breckinridge men to unite on local nominations was talked ever and regretted. It was hoped, however, that the failure to unite upon local officers would not operate against a fusion on the State and Presidential tickets. It is expected that the Sub-Committee will report to-day.

abstract: Jesse W. Benedict vs. The New-York and Erie Insurance Co. -- This case was before the Common Pleas, at General Term, on an appeal. It appears that the defendants executed a policy of insurance on property belonging to August Jansen, who afterwards sold his claim to the plaintiff. The Insurance was for $2,000. The policy contained a clause in these words, "Privileged for $4,500 other insurance." This was written. The printed portions of the policy contained a provision that if other insurance should be made upon the property, and notice thereof not given to the defendants with all reasonable diligence, and acknowledged by them, either by indorsement on the policy or otherwise in writing, the policy should cease and be of no further effect.

abstract: The dwelling-house of Mr. JAMES BUCHAN, No. 376 Fourth-street, was visited by burglars on the night of the 11th inst., at which time the occupants were absent in the country, and robbed of a very considerable amount of property. The thieves gained access to the premises by wrenching the shutters from the rear windows of the basement, and then thoroughly ransacked the place. Among the property which they carried away was about $400 worth of clothing, some silver ware, and very nearly $44,000 in bonds and certificates of stock on various railroad and insurance companies. These bonds and certificates were the property of Mr. ADAM PEARSON, who is now traveling in Europe, and for whom Mr. BUCHAN is acting as agent. As soon as the robbery was discovered, which happened the day subsequent to its perpetration, printed descriptions of the bonds, &c., were furnished to all the brokers in the City, and the request was made that any person offering to negotiate any of the scrip might be detained. On Wednesday last Mr. SMITH TUTTLE, a lawyer, doing business at No. 5 Beekman-street, offered to dispose of three of the stolen bonds at the office of a Wall-street broker, but they were at once recognized as corresponding in description to a portion of those which belonged to Mr. PEARSON. Accordingly the brokers requested that the scrip might be left with them until the following day, when, should they decide to purchase it in the interval, the money would be handed him when he called. Information of this attempt to sell these bonds was at once given by the brokers to Bank-Detective HAYS and Special Officer FLAVIN, of the First Precinct, who duly awaited next day the appearance of Mr. TUTTLE at the broker's office. As soon as he presented himself he was taken into custody, and upon being interrogated as to the manner in which the bonds came into his possession, he replied that he had received them from JULIUS M. STICH, a client of his, who then could be found at his (TUTTLE's) office, in Beekman-street. The officers went there, accompanied by Mr. TUTTLE, and found STICH, who was at once arrested. Both prisoners were taken before Justice WELSH at the Tombs, where a partial examination of the matter resulted in the discharge of Mr. TUTTLE, who was shown merely to have acted as the agent of STICH, without having any criminal knowledge as to the character of the bonds he had endeavored to sell. Yesterday afternoon, STICH, who had been temporarily committed to prison, was arraigned before Justice WELSH on a charge of having committed the burglary at Mr. BUCHAN's residence, and stolen the bonds, and other property. He stated in his examination that he was a broker by occupation, and that he had obtained the three bonds, which he had commissioned TUTTLE, from an old gentleman named ISAACS, a perfect stranger to himself, whom he casually met on Wednesday morning at French's Hotel, and who represented that he was from Cincinnati, Ohio. Believing the representations of the old gentleman to be true, he had purchased the bonds, and found himself in difficulty as the consequence. To procure the attendance of other witnesses, the investigation was adjourned to this morning. Meantime STICH is a prisoner in the Tombs, the magistrate having decided not to admit him to ball until the grade of the crime of which he is alleged to be guilty can be determined on. The value of the bonds recovered is $1,500, but no trace of the remaining bonds, certificates of stock, or other proceeds of the burglary, has so far been obtained.

abstract: The Prince of Wales on Thursday evening, at Detroit, experienced a very decided foretaste of the receptions which await him in his brief tour through the United States. He reached Windsor at 8 o'clock, and went on board the Detroit and and Windsor ferry-steamer Windsor, where he was received by the Governor of Michigan, the Mayor and Councilmen of Detroit, and a number of prominent citizens. When the steamer reached American waters, the Mayor welcomed the Prince, as Baron RENFREW, to the United States. The river and the city presented a magnificent spectacle, the steamers and other vessels in the former being hung with variegated lamps, and decorated with banners and emblems, and the latter being splendidly illuminated. Rockets and other fireworks were let off continually, and the river was a blaze of light, the whole forming the grandest display witnessed by his Highness during his sojourn in America. The crowd was so dense at the landing-place that it was found impossible to form the procession which had been arranged to escort him to his hotel, and after several ineffectual attempts it was found necessary for him to enter a private carriage and proceed through by-streets. His suite followed him shortly afterwards, escorted by the firemen of Detroit. The enthusiasm of the crowd was something tremendous, and found vent in cheer upon cheer. Yesterday, after a drive through the city with the Mayor, his progress being impeded at every step by enthusiastic crowds, the Prince with his suite proceeded to the Railroad depot and took his departure for Chicago, where, after a somewhat tedious journey, he arrived at 7 1/2 o'clock last evening: Here, as at Detroit, an immense concourse awaited his arrival, though, through the admirable regulations of the Police, everything was done "decently and in order." The party will leave for St. Louis this afternoon.

abstract: AID FOR GARIBALDI Last evening the opening of Mr. BREGEN'S new concert and ball-room at No. 97 West Thirty-second-street, took place. The owner very kindly tendered the use of hip place to the Garibaldi Aid Committee, to give a festival for the benefit of the Garibaldi Fund.
lead_paragraph: AID FOR GARIBALDI Last evening the opening of Mr. BREGEN'S new concert and ball-room at No. 97 West Thirty-second-street, took place. The owner very kindly tendered the use of hip place to the Garibaldi Aid Committee, to give a festival for the benefit of the Garibaldi Fund. The room was elegantly and tastefully ornamented by means of garlands of green leaves and fresh flowers, and numerous banners, bearing the colors of different nationalities. One of the most prominent was the banner of the Polish emigrants residing here, being of red silk, bearing the white eagle and the motto in their own language, "God and the People." The two ribbons pending from the staff, bore the inscriptions, "Death to all Tyrants," and "Poland is not Lost yet." The festival consisted of a concert, both vocal and instrumental, by Frischman's band and the German Glee Clubs, Social Reform Gesangverein, Loreley Maennerchor and Bloomingdale Frohsimr, and a ball. Speeches by Mr. GUSTAPHUS STENVE, the President of the Committee, in German, and Mr. ISAAC DAYTON, in English, were delivered and well received by the numerous audience. Over the orchestra were several wreaths of oak leaves inclosing the letters G. and M., (GARIBALDI and MAZZINI,) and "Welcome to the Friends of Liberty." The letters were made of living flowers.

abstract: The salutary uses of affliction are seldom so well illustrated as in the cotemporary history of Tammany. Had that rollicking and reckless Corporation, or Order, or Society, or whatever else in these days of dilapidation it may claim to be, enjoyed the full assurance of power and success which it possessed five years ago, there is no means of predicting the character of the nominations for City officers which it might have forced upon the party in this actual year of grace. Mr. ABRAHAM RUSSELL might have been once more City Judge, and Mr. MICHAEL CONNOLLY might have been made Recorder. We might have judicial officers as diligent as the present District-Attorney; we might have had Justices of the higher Courts as swift and impartial as -- let us be retrospective, and say SCROGGS or JEFFRIES.
lead_paragraph: The salutary uses of affliction are seldom so well illustrated as in the cotemporary history of Tammany. abstract: Among the various classes of scoundrels that infest this community, there are none who thrive so well and defy the law with such impunity as ticket swindlers. Their victims are generally strangers, who have no acquaintance with the means of redress which the law has placed in their reach, or who are not disposed to stop midway in their pilgrimage from Europe to the distant West, to make a complaint against the villains who cheat them, and suffer a two or three months detention as witnesses in prosecutions, which, after all, most frequently result in the criminals acquittal. Consequently the swindlers are very seldom brought to justice. In view of this fact, it is to be especially regretted that when the vigilance of officers results in the arraignment of any of this class of criminals before the legal tribunals, the Court itself should interfere in their behalf, and exercise a lenity in its treatment of them which no other prisoners experience, and which frequently goes to the length of nullifying the enacted penalties of the law.

abstract: The United States vessel Crawford arrived at this port from Holmes Hole at 9 o'clock on Thursday evening, and came up to the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The United States vessel Crawford arrived at this port from Holmes Hole at 9 o'clock on Thursday evening, and came up to the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday morning. She has been engaged in connection with the United States Coast Survey at Damariscotta, on the coast of Maine. Her officers are: Lieut. BANKHEAD, A. CORKEY, R.J. FOLEY, H.B. DUSENBERRY, and J.G. MCCAULEY. The Crawford awaits orders from the authorities at Washington.

abstract: The Citizens' Committee, who have undertaken the arduous task of preparation for the grand ball in honor of the Prince of Wales, are very busily engaged. The arrangements are still incomplete, and the programme is carefully reserved from publicity.
lead_paragraph: The Citizens' Committee, who have undertaken the arduous task of preparation for the grand ball in honor of the Prince of Wales, are very busily engaged. The arrangements are still incomplete, and the programme is carefully reserved from publicity. Sufficient information, however, has transpired to warrant the assumption that the ball will be the most elegant affair of the kind that has taken place in this City for many years. The members of the Committee are bestowing a large share of their personal attention upon the management of details, and the office of the Secretary is daily thronged by parties who come laden with new suggestions. The occasion being an extraordinary one, the degree of enthusiasm which it calls forth is correspondingly great.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The benefit of Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, of course, drew a crowded house last night, as it would have done without the attraction of a new play. The new play cannot be called a success, and the management will probably resort, in the ensuing week, to something more attractive. Its title is "Phelim O'Donnell, or the Leprechaun," of which we will only say that it was sufficiently attractive to, retain the attention of the audience, without eliciting their applause. Mr. BARNEY WILLIAMS and Mr. DAVIDGE did all they could for it; but, notwithstanding, it is a piece that is doomed to early death. Happily for Mr. WILLIAMS, his fame does not rest on the success of such an ill-conceived and misconstructed play. The other performances were "The Customs of the Country" and "Bryan O'Linn," which brought forth Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS in all their perfection. In their old and favorite characters they are inimitable, but the "Leprechaun" is not suitable to the abilities of Mr. WILLIAMS, and Mrs. WILLIAMS, very wisely, does not take part therein. They will play during the next week, we trust, in their renowned and unexcelled parts.

abstract: Our special correspondent informs us of the arrival of the Prince of Wales in Detroit. His Royal Highness has left the British dominions, and, for the first time, has entered the territory of the United States. His reception, of course, has been warm and enthusiastic. Though he cannot, by any possibility, have found fault with the Nova Scotian and Canadian ovations, he was well aware that their chief promoters -- Governors, Mayors, Aldermen, and other Provincial officials -- had expectations, more or less vague, of being rewarded for any extra devotion they might exhibit to the heir apparent of the British Crown. One or two possibly aspired to baronial honors; some sighed after inferior titles, and all were only exhibiting a natural loyalty to their future sovereign.
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent informs us of the arrival of the Prince of Wales in Detroit. abstract: The steasmhip Adriatic, from Havre and Southampton on the 13th inst., with three days' later European advices, arrived off Sandy Hook about 11 o'clock last night, and reached her dock before 1 o'clock this morning. The advices are highly...
lead_paragraph: The steasmhip Adriatic, from Havre and Southampton on the 13th inst., with three days' later European advices, arrived off Sandy Hook about 11 o'clock last night, and reached her dock before 1 o'clock this morning. The advices are highly important. GARIBALDI had entered Naples, accompanied only by his staff, and had been received in the most enthusiastic manner by the people. The Ex-King was still at Gaeta, and some doubt existed as to whether he would eventually go to Spain or to Austria. The insurrections still continued in the Papal States, and Sardinia was still making preparations for intervention.

abstract: The war in Ecuador of the different factions seems drawing toward a close. Gen. FLORES, on the 20th of August, was in the immediate vicinity of Guayaqull, where a battle must ere this have taken place between his forces and those of Gen. FRANCO, with the probable defeat of the latter.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ecuador of the different factions seems drawing toward a close. Gen. FLORES, on the 20th of August, was in the immediate vicinity of Guayaqull, where a battle must ere this have taken place between his forces and those of Gen. FRANCO, with the probable defeat of the latter. How Peru, or rather CASTILLA, will relish the defeat of his protege, and the consequent failure of his Ecuadorian policy, remains to be seen.

abstract: The American ship Chatsworth, Capt. HORN, of Boston, of 1,150 tons register, went ashore in a gale, on the l3th of July last, off the coast of Chili, 150 miles south of Valparaiso, and broke to pieces.
lead_paragraph: The American ship Chatsworth, Capt. HORN, of Boston, of 1,150 tons register, went ashore in a gale, on the l3th of July last, off the coast of Chili, 150 miles south of Valparaiso, and broke to pieces. The officers and crew, with the exception of one man -- JAMES DAVIS, of England -- saved themselves by running a line to the shore, which was made fast to a rock. Nothing was saved except the log and a few articles of clothing. The first officer and crew were taken charge of by the United States Consul at Valparaiso, and the Captain goes home on the Ariel to-day.

abstract: Grant H. Adams vs. The Mayor,  This case has been several times fully stated in the TIMES. The plaintiff was a Health Warden of the Eighteenth Ward, and was removed from office on the 15th of May, 1858, but still claimed title thereto, and brought his action for salary claimed subsequently to the date of his removal.

abstract: The system of an elective Judiciary, it is well known, has been undergoing a pretty severe test in the City of New-York. However...
lead_paragraph: The system of an elective Judiciary, it is well known, has been undergoing a pretty severe test in the City of New-York. However satisfactory its workings may have been in the "rural districts," there can be no doubt that here many men have been led to doubt whether it were not better to return to the old system of appointment. The abuses which have appeared in the administration of our criminal laws, the comparative impunity of ticket swindlers, gamblers, shoulder-hitters and kindred criminals who happen to be active in the party organization of the ruling powers; the use of the power of the Judiciary to aid political maneuvers; the lowering of the tone of the Bench of our civil courts; the slight difference which the character and fitness for the post of any judicial candidate makes in the vote cast for him by his party; all these things have gone far to bring about a change in public sentiment on this question, and now-a-days many men may be found among all parties who, seeing these evils, are not slow to express their opposition to the system of an elective Judiciary as the source from whence they spring.

abstract: President GUARDIOLA on the 21st. August issued a proclamation against WALKER, calling upon the people to arm in defence of the State, decreeing a forced loan of $9,000 per month until the invader is driven out, requiring foreigners entering or traveling through the country to have passports, ordering the people to destroy all provisions and supplies that might otherwise fall into the hands of WALKER, and to make war against him in any manner that may best suit their means and convenience.

abstract: THE COOLIE TRADE. -- Statistics of the coolie trade with Cuba show that up to the 18th of December, 1859, there had been 42,501 Chinese coolies landed at the different island ports. Between that date and the 12th of August last, 5,569 additional coolies were landed out of a total of 6,069 shipped, showing a mortality of nearly ten per cent during the passage. While the trade in Chinese coolies exhibits this great mortality, it is quite impossible for the Government of the United States to lend it aid or countenance. The distinction that is drawn between this kind of "immigration" and the African Slave-trade is practically, no distinction at all. Lord JOHN RUSSELL, who has been endeavoring to induce our Government to support coolie immigration as a means of suppressing the Slave-trade, knows perfectly well that the one is quite as immoral as the other. We are perfectly willing to admit that the coolies taken to British Islands are much more humanely treated than those taken to Cuba, but this fact does not effect the argument. The United States Government cannot countenance coolie immigration without giving direct support to the Spanish trade; it can draw no invidious distinctions between that and the British and French schemes. We have enough kindred sins of our own to answer for without being made responsible for the iniquities practiced under the cloak of "coolie immigration."

abstract: Italy," replied the Italian. "But from what particular nation? From Naples, Sicily or Sardinia?" "From the nation of Italy," replied the Captain. The perplexed official again busily searched the official book containing the flags of the different nationalities, and then remarked, "I find here no flag of Italy." "But there is an Italy," replied the Captain, and from no other nationality would he report his vessel. Our Government has received no official notice of any change of government in Sicily, and must, therefore, act for the present under the existing regulations, though in the present case the Captain persists in reporting that he neither sails under the Sardinian, the Sicilian, the Neapolitan, but under the flag of Italy!" -- Boston Traveller.
lead_paragraph: Italy," replied the Italian. "But from what particular nation? From Naples, Sicily or Sardinia?" "From the nation of Italy," replied the Captain. The perplexed official again busily searched the official book containing the flags of the different nationalities, and then remarked, "I find here no flag of Italy." "But there is an Italy," replied the Captain, and from no other nationality would he report his vessel. Our Government has received no official notice of any change of government in Sicily, and must, therefore, act for the present under the existing regulations, though in the present case the Captain persists in reporting that he neither sails under the Sardinian, the Sicilian, the Neapolitan, but under the flag of Italy!" -- Boston Traveller.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN'S efforts to settle the American claims against Peru are not likely to be crowned with more success than his efforts in the same direction in other quarters have been.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN'S efforts to settle the American claims against Peru are not likely to be crowned with more success than his efforts in the same direction in other quarters have been. It is generally understood that our Minister, in July last, was instructed to demand a settlement of the damages for the seizure of the Georgiana and Lizzie Thompson within four days, in default of which he was to suspend diplomatic relations, and to agree to an arbitration in the case of the whaleship William Lee, and in the, matter of the other two claims for the imprisonment and cruelties inflicted upon Mr. SARTORI, and the destruction of the property of Dr. CHARLES ESTON by Government troops. When these instructions reached Mr. CLAY, (his "peremptory demand" for a settlement three months previously having failed,) the Peruvian Secretary of Relations had just resigned; so Mr. C. had to wait some time for the appointment of a new one on whom to make the demand. Then, before the new Secretary was fairly installed, somebody shot at and severely wounded President CASTILLA, and Mr. CLAY has to wait till he recovers, as the Secretary dare not move without his master's consent. But as the President is said to have so far regained his strength as to "ride out in his carriage on the Alameda, guarded by fifty horsemen," it is fair to presume our Minister will not much longer postpone his demand. The result, however, cannot be doubtful. CASTILLA will never pay a dollar for the Georgiana and Lizzie Thompson until compelled by force to do so. He is willing to refer the matter to the arbitrament of a foreign Power -- but as no foreign Power would be likely to admit the doctrine that a small revolutionary party occupying but one or two ports of a country has a right to bind the Government to its contracts, the United States Government will not accede to that proposition. In the meantime an American agent passed through Panama the other day for Peru, and it is rumored he took out instructions to Mr. CLAY modifying his previous ones -- which would not be surprising, considering the vacillating temper of Mr. BUCHANAN, and especially in view of the wet blanket application of Mr. CAVE JOHNSON in the matter of the Paraguan claims of Mr. HOPKINS. Had Mr. CLAY been properly supported by the United States Executive at the outset, in these claims, they would have been paid long ago -- but now they must wait the more energetic action of a new Administration.

abstract: MORTALITY One hundred and eight deaths were reported to the Health Department during the week ending Saturday classified as follows:
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY One hundred and eight deaths were reported to the Health Department during the week ending Saturday classified as follows: Men,25; women, 17; boys, 34; girls, 32. Adults, 42; children, 66; males, 59; females, 49. Sixty-one were under five years of age; five were between five and ten[???] between 10 and 15, one; 15 and twenty, one; 20 and 25, eight; 25 and 30, five; 30 and 40, seven; 40 and 50, three; 50 and 60, six; 60 and 70, six; 70 and 80 four; 80 and 90, [???]one. Seventy-nine were natives of the United States, 18 of Ireland, 6 of Germany, 3 of England, and 2 of British America. The greatest mortality by any disease was by cholera infantum, which caused 20 deaths. Fever carried off 11 -- six of which were typhoid, four scarlet, and one bilious. Marasmas (infantile), seven; diarrhoe and dysentery, five each; consumption, six. The deaths occurred in the several Wards as follows: First Ward, 4; Second Ward, 5; Third Ward, 3; Fourth Ward, 7; Fifth Ward, 7; Sixth, Ward, 18; Seventh Ward, 4; Eighth Ward, 4; Ninth Ward, 8; Tenth Ward, 10; Eleventh Ward, 13; Twelfth Ward, 10; Thirteenth Ward, 2; Fourteenth Ward, 2; Fifteenth Ward, 2; Sixteenth Ward, 3; Seventeenth Ward, 1; Eighteenth Ward, 2; Nineteenth Ward, 3.

abstract: "His Honor" the Mayor continues to give periodical proofs that he retains a very fair share of that useful quality which, in newsboys or hackmen, would be termed impudence, but which, when displayed by great public functionaries, is usually termed audacity.
lead_paragraph: "His Honor" the Mayor continues to give periodical proofs that he retains a very fair share of that useful quality which, in newsboys or hackmen, would be termed impudence, but which, when displayed by great public functionaries, is usually termed audacity. His last display of it fortifies the claim he has already so often put forward to the character of wag, as it bears the strongest resemblance to a bad joke. Our readers may remember that the work of laying the new pipe in the Aqueduct at High Bridge was interrupted, owing to "His Honor's" refusal to countersign the warrant for the payment of the expenses of the work. This bit of interference was simply a preliminary to the execution of a scheme for the removal of Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPAN, the engineers, because they had not shown themselves sufficiently pliant in the matter of allowing the conversion of the employes of the Croton Board into His Honor's political tools. The scheme has failed, as our readers know, owing to His Honor's total inability to prove a single charge of the many which he made against these gentlemen; but during the four months occupied by the quarrel and investigation, the water-pipes now in use on the aqueduct, which had to be stopped preparatory to putting down the new one, have lain exposed to the weather, all owing to the Mayor's obstinate refusal to let the work proceed, until he had got rid of Messrs. CRAVEN and TAPPAN. In the interval the Board have frequently drawn attention to the danger of allowing these pipes to be exposed to the frost, and have three times urged it on that of the Mayor, and have announced their intention, in case "His Honor" carried on his opposition till the Winter set in, to place a temporary wooden roof over them as a measure of precaution. "His Honor," now finding the public indigation becoming pretty strong, has addressed the following humorous epistle to the President of the Board:

abstract: Theodore P. Edgerton vs. Albert W. Page  This case was before the General Term of the Common Pleas on appeal from an order at Special Term.
lead_paragraph: Theodore P. Edgerton vs. Albert W. Page This case was before the General Term of the Common Pleas on appeal from an order at Special Term. The facts were that the plaintiff on June 26, 1857, recovered a judgment in this action against the defendant for $546 13, from which an appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals. On Aug. 16, 1858, and pending the appeal, the plaintiff assigned the judgment to David Winebrener for a valuable consideration, and thus divested himself of all interest or claim respecting it. The judgment having been affirmed, and an execution having been issued to collect the amount due upon it, the defendant moved to set aside the execution, and have the judgment declared satisfied; upon the ground that he had paid in good faith to the Sheriff, who holds the execution, a sum equal to the amount due on it, upon an execution heretofore issued to the same Sheriff, founded on a judgment recovered in this Court, against the plaintiff in this case in favor of William Barker and others, and that such payment was made under the provisions of sec. 293 of the Code, and without knowledge or notice of the fact that the plaintiff had previously assigned the judgment thus obtained by him. The motion was denied, and the defendant appealed from the order entered.

abstract: From the South American intelligence, to be found in another column, we ascertain the claims of the United States upon Peru to be as far as ever from settlement. The story of...
lead_paragraph: From the South American intelligence, to be found in another column, we ascertain the claims of the United States upon Peru to be as far as ever from settlement. The story of wrong upon which the claims rest is an old one, so old as to require perhaps a brief restatement. At the close of 1857, Gen. VIVANCO, who is in a state of irrepressible revolt against the Government of Peru, made himself master of the Guano Islands, whither came in January, 1858, two American vessels, the Georgiana and the Lizzie Thompson, to obtain loads of the manure. Dealing, as they were warranted by the laws of nations in doing, with the authorities they found there, the masters of the two vessels took from VIVANCO licenses to procure loads, and were in the act of completing their cargoes when a Peruvian war steamer boarded them, turned the men loose upon the high seas in rafts and without provisions, and deposited the captains in prison at Callao. The two brigs were confiscated.
