abstract: Emil Kanter vs. John N. Genin. -- In this case an order supplementary to execution for the examination of the judgment debtor was granted by Justice SUTHERLAND on the 17th day of August, 1860. Pending the continuance of the order a discharge from all indebtedness was granted to Mr. Genin by the City Judge, upon the application of two-thirds of his creditors. The counsel for the defendant now moved before Justice INGRAHAM, at Chambers, Special Term of the Supreme Court, that the order supplementary to execution be vacated and set aside upon the ground that the judgment upon which the plaintiff's order was predicated, was extinguished by the discharge, and that as a consequence the order ceased to have any force or effect. The Court granted the motion and vacated the supplementary order.
lead_paragraph: Emil Kanter vs. John N. abstract: In contrast with all that we have gained upon our fathers, by the rapid and almost indefinite multiplication of the facilities of human intercourse and of the dissemination of knowledge, one is sometimes tempted to set...
lead_paragraph: In contrast with all that we have gained upon our fathers, by the rapid and almost indefinite multiplication of the facilities of human intercourse and of the dissemination of knowledge, one is sometimes tempted to set the unquestionable fact that the very abundance of the sources from which information pours in upon us, and the uninterrupted force of the tide in which it flows, tend to deaden our sensibility and to deprive us of those thrilling emotions of interest and delight in which our ancestors found a compensation for what we now regard as the intellectual "short commons" of their times. Great revolutions, stupendous battles, catastrophes of all kinds, overcome us now like Summer clouds, "without our special wonder." When we read the language of those who lived when COLUMBUS opened a new world to mankind, or in still later days pursued with awe-struck eyes the colossal movement of the French revolution, "strange stories of the deaths of kings," and the eagle flight of the first NAPOLEON from Marengo upwards to that crowning scene at Tilsit, when all the monarchs of the Continent assembled in the anteroom of the great conqueror's tent, we cannot easily persuade ourselves that the day of great things has not forever passed, and that we ourselves are not living in the decadence of time.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, Thomas Hayes, an Englishman, 26 years of age, was stabbed while standing in the liquor store of Nicholas Murray, No. 75 Mulberry-street, by a man named John Hoy, and so se  verely hurt that his life was despaired of.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Thomas Hayes, an Englishman, 26 years of age, was stabbed while standing in the liquor store of Nicholas Murray, No. 75 Mulberry-street, by a man named John Hoy, and so se verely hurt that his life was despaired of. Hoy, it appeared, went into the bar-room, and being somewhat intoxicated, lay dawn to sleep on a lounge. By way of a joke, while he was taking his nap, his face was smeared with soot, or some other black substance, and when he awoke and discovered the trick that had been played he was much enraged. Falling to learn the name of the person who had offended him, he determined to have satisfaction of Hayes, who was laughing, with the other occupants of the place, at what they considered a good joke. Accordingly, Hoy seized a knife and rushed upon Hayes, whom he stabbed in the neck, breast and abdomen. Great excitement followed, in the midst of which Hoy endeavored to run away, but he was pursued and taken into custody. His victim was removed to the City Hospital and his wounds are said to be of a very dangerous character. The prisoner was taken before Justice WELSH, to whom he admitted that he had inflicted the violence, and was locked up.

abstract: SATURDAY AT THE CENTRAL PARK The Central Park was teeming with teams and fairly peopled with people again, last Saturday afternoon. A larger mass-meeting of music's votaries has not been held on the Mail this season.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY AT THE CENTRAL PARK The Central Park was teeming with teams and fairly peopled with people again, last Saturday afternoon. A larger mass-meeting of music's votaries has not been held on the Mail this season. There were fewer strangers, perhaps, and more townspeople there than on any previous day of those consecrated to the concert-loving; for, at this season more than at any other, the travelers and the swallows fly homeward. Gotham is again Gothamite; and Southern, Eastern and Western visitors -- the pleasure-seekers that is, not the business-bound -- are turning their faces toward the light of their own firesides. There were more elegant equipages, more daintily attired damsels, more young gentlemen, caparisoned entirely regardless of expense, on foot and on horseback, at the Park day before yesterday, than were wont to be there a month ago when it was vulgar to be in town. The horsemen were especially numerous. From a single Riding School on Fifth-avenue, thirty steeds saddled and bridled, went forth. The proprietor endeavored to deter the applicant for the thirty-first from his persistent design of riding horseback on the worst animal in the stable. In vain he showed him his list of prices, assured him that he himself was a charger, -- in vain said "nay" full twenty times. The horse was brought, mounted, and led forth into the open street. He plunged, he reared, he pawed the air, and endeavored to jump fences. He was constantly in motion, yet did not progress an inch. He was taken back into the school, and the master promised that he should have a good training. Apparently every equine quadruped in City livery stables that would carry a saddle and a man on his back was pressed into the service for an excursion to the Park. Then; the cars were crowded, and hundreds of pedestrians wended their way thither. The highly-respectable performances of the band, the inhalation of fresh air, and a view of the prettiest park scenery in this counter, even at this day, amply repaid all who took the jaunt, whatever their means of conveyance.

abstract: THE JOHN BROWN FUND IN HAYTI. -- Mr. R.J. HINTON writes to the Boston Traveller as follows: "I am glad to be able to give the friends, as well as those who indulged a short time since in derisive comments upon the small sum reported, some reliable information as to the real amount of the fund raised in Hayti for the benefit of JOHN BROWN's family and the survivors of the Harper's Ferry movement. My friend, JAMES REDPATH, writing from Port au Prince under date of August 27, says in substance: The amount of the fund so far collected and in the hands of the authorities at Port au Prince, is nearly 4,000 American dollars. This amount was mostly subscribed in the department of which Port au Prince is the chief town. Returns are to come in from the other departments of the Republic, eight in number. It may be reasonably expected that the above sum will be still further increased when all sections of the island shall have been heard from."

abstract: SPAIN AS AN AMERICAN POWER. -- That favorite dream of the American Democracy -- the annexation of Cuba -- seems to have vanished into empty air, and the boastful programme of the present Administration remains unaccomplished in this as in other particulars. Spain is rising in the world, and as she rises, she assumes a haughtier and more dictatorial attitude. Never at any time disposed to sell the ever-faithful island, she now spurns the mere mention of such a bargain with contempt.
lead_paragraph: SPAIN AS AN AMERICAN POWER. -- That favorite dream of the American Democracy -- the annexation of Cuba -- seems to have vanished into empty air, and the boastful programme of the present Administration remains unaccomplished in this as in other particulars. abstract: In the sky of the distance shines one bright particular star, Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN. On Monday week she opens at the Winter Garden. When Greek meets Greek, when the intellectual and the physical schools come into conflict, when CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN and EDWIN FORREST, both representatives of distinct and rival schools of American art, play at the same time at different theatres -- then comes the tug of war. Round the one will be gathered the poets, the artists, the sculptors, all who delight in what is delicate, refined and exquisite in art -- round the other the rude mass who love the broad breast, and the coarse vigor, and the riot of strong passion which belong to physical power. As this is the era of muscularity the contest may indicate the public current of the day. It is not, we believe, yet settled in what character Miss CUSHMAN will appear, but there are not a few who would wish to see her in that character which approaches nearest to woman's in its exquisite sensibility and quick transitions of light and shade. The Company at the Winter Garden will be strengthened on her appearance, by the addition of Messrs. COULDOCK and DYOTT, and Mrs. DUFFIELD and Miss CLIFTON.

abstract: FIFTH REGIMENT OFFICERS AT BEDLOE'S ISLAND.  Yesterday the following officers of the Fifth Regiment, and several invited guests, chartered a small
lead_paragraph: FIFTH REGIMENT OFFICERS AT BEDLOE'S ISLAND. Yesterday the following officers of the Fifth Regiment, and several invited guests, chartered a small steamer and visited Bedloe's Island, viz.: Col. SCHWARZWAELDER, Brigade Major Alford, Major Burger, Paymaster Fearing, Quartermaster Dalton, Chaplain Eddy, Capts. Hertman, Gerdes, Mander, and Hinslage; Lieuts. Schaefer, Bretman, Meyer and Luke; Orderly Sergeant Leitz, and Lieut. Wm. Sinclair, of the Third Artillery, U.S.A. The object of the visit was to inspect the barracks of the fort, where the Fifth, as it has already been fully announced, is "to encamp," (that is according to the order,) but in reality is to perform thorough garrison duty, and practice gunnery) for a week, commencing to-morrow morning. Four barbette guns were found mounted on the south "terre plain." These were mounted last Monday by 20 men from Fort Hamilton, under the command of Lieut. SINCLAIR, and are to be used daily by detachments of the Fifth, until every man of the 500 is initiated into the artillery drill. The East and West Barracks, consisting of four large rooms, are to be used by the privates; the North Barrack is to be used by the line officers, and the Hospital by the Field and Staff; all are in excellent condition. There are two large kitchens and plenty of bath-rooms. The men will sleep in the old-fashioned double wooden bunks formerly used in the army. Gen. SANFORD will be invited to inspect the garrison next Tuesday or Wednesday. The expense of the week's duty will be for rations alone 70 cents per day to each man, and then the ammunition, locks and friction tubes, both of which are to be used, are also to be paid for by the Regiment. Maj. ROBERT ANDERSON, of the First Artillery, U.S.A., who is to instruct the Regiment, was not present yesterday. At about 4 o'clock the party returned highly pleased with the quarters. After the Regiment is garrisoned tickets will be issued to spectators, but none will be allowed in the garrison until the latter part of the week.

abstract: A meeting of British residents in New-York was held yesterday afternoon, at the once of the British Consul, No. 17 Broadway, to hear the report of the Committee appointed to communicate with the Prince of Wales, touching his proposed visit to this City, and the proposed demonstrations in his honor by the English residents. Mr. ARCHIBALD, the British Consul,
lead_paragraph: A meeting of British residents in New-York was held yesterday afternoon, at the once of the British Consul, No. 17 Broadway, to hear the report of the Committee appointed to communicate with the Prince of Wales, touching his proposed visit to this City, and the proposed demonstrations in his honor by the English residents. Mr. ARCHIBALD, the British Consul, briefly stated that the original Committee was increased to forty, and that, with the approval of the Mayor and the leading members of the City (Banquet) Committee, they decided to get up a ball. A liberal beginning had been made with the subscriptions to defray the expenses, when, it being ascertained that a ball would be more agreeable to the Prince than a banquet, the citizens changed their original plan, and decided upon a ball at the Academy. Being well represented in these latter arrangements, the British residents decided not to make any distinctive demonstration, except to tender the Prince an address, if that should be found agreeable. This proposal was conveyed to the Duke of NEWCASTLE, through Lord LYONS. In response, the Duke, with the approval of Lord RENFREW, referred to the invitation already received through the Committee of Citizens, and respectfully declining the proposed demonstration, for the offer of which, however, he was very grateful and obliged. Similar demonstrations, had been offered in other places in the United States, and declined. A general satisfaction was expressed at the result of the correspondence, and the Committee were, on motion, discharged.

abstract: The General Committee of the "National Democracy" (Mozart) met at Mozart Hall at 8 P.M. last evening, Judge SCHERMERHORN presiding. A long discussion took place with regard to the propriety of appointing a Committee to settle differences in various Wards concerning the appointment of Inspectors of Election. A Committee of five were finally appointed for that purpose, and were instructed to issue a call for the Primary meetings. The Committee then adjourned.

abstract: Nathan Peck, Esq., father of the President of the Board of Aldermen, died on Friday last, at Greenwich, Conn., in the very house in which, 80 years ago, he was born. His golden wedding was celebrated on the 3d of February last, in this City. Mrs. Sarah Peck, his wife, survives him. They have had forty-one lineal descendants, of whom thirty-two are yet living. Mr. Peck had been ill for several weeks. His funeral took place yesterday.

abstract: DEDICATION OF A WIGWAM. The Seventh Ward Republican Club having completed their wigwam, at the corner of Classon and DeKalb avenues, it was appropriately dedicated last evening, by holding a public meeting therein.
lead_paragraph: DEDICATION OF A WIGWAM. The Seventh Ward Republican Club having completed their wigwam, at the corner of Classon and DeKalb avenues, it was appropriately dedicated last evening, by holding a public meeting therein. The building is a regular wigwam in shape, about fifty feet in diameter, and capable of holding about two thousand persons. The meeting was organized by electing MITCHELL SANDFORD, Esq., Chairman, who opened the proceedings with an address suitable to the occasion. The Rocky Mountain Club held their regular weekly public meeting at the wigwam on Fulton-street, opposite the City Hall, which was well filled. Addresses were made by CYRUS NORTHRUP, Esq., of Connecticut, Mr. VELE, of New-York, and others. A public meeting was also held last evening in the South Brooklyn Wigwam on Court-street, where HENRY HILL, Esq., made a speech. The meeting was largely attended. The Republicans of the Eleventh Ward met last evening at Granada Hall, and organized a Wide Awake Club, and elected FRANCIS B. KIRBY as Commander. Over one hundred persons signed the roll last evening, and the Club, armed and equipped in the usual fashion, joined the meeting in the Seventh Ward.

abstract: We have several days later news from the Western Army Departments, by the California mail. LANDER'S wagon-road party had completed its operations and returned to Marysville and Sacramento, where
lead_paragraph: We have several days later news from the Western Army Departments, by the California mail. LANDER'S wagon-road party had completed its operations and returned to Marysville and Sacramento, where the stock of the expedition would be disposed of. Col. LANDER had a very satisfactory interview with the Indian war chief WINNEMUCEA, who is described as being "thirty years of age, six feet high, and as straight as an arrow." The chief promised that his yellow-skinned friends would be quiet, and not annoy travelers. Lieut. WHITE, of the Third Ariillery, recently attached to MULLAN's expedition, arrived at Fort Randall, Nebraska, on the 6th of September, from Fort Benton. MULLAN's road is only partially finished, and will require another season's labor. The distance between Walla Walla, where it commences, and the head of steamer navigation on the Missouri, is set down at 618 miles.

abstract: The annual Fair of the American Institute was opened last evening at the Palace Gardens in Fourteenth-street, and under circumstances which promise an auspicious termination.
lead_paragraph: The annual Fair of the American Institute was opened last evening at the Palace Gardens in Fourteenth-street, and under circumstances which promise an auspicious termination. The exhibition of the present season is confined exclusively to floricultural and pomological specimens, with such agricultural implements as might be presented. Of the latter class the show is at present exceedingly meagre, but will doubtless improve with the opportunity afforded by the promise of a two weeks' exhibition. The fruits were not fully arranged, and it would be unjust to criticise them further than to say, that the promise held out by the first days' show will amply repay a visit to the grounds.

abstract: It is hard to say whether good sense or good nature is the most marked characteristic of Lord RENFREW's American tour. Throwing aside all affectation of dignity or reserve, and surrendering his incognito wherever he goes at the demand of the naturally curious, but not always decorous, mob, he submits to be the object of vulgar inspection, without the slightest snobbishness, and in fact as if Princes and Barons were actually the two-penny shows for which the mass of our people accept them. At Chicago, for instance, where his Lordship encountered the genuine sovereigns of the New World, notwithstanding they pressed upon and jostled him rudely, and quite dispersed his suite, we find him subsequently indulging the popular curiosity by displaying himself on the balcony of his hotel, and pacing up and down within the bars, as if he were the British Lion incarnate, caged after the fashion of BAJAZET, and inevitably fated to be thus exposed and explored. Surely the credit of unlimited good temper must be assigned to the Prince, in thus elevating the attributes of the genial and kindly gentleman above the etiquette of royalty.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to say whether good sense or good nature is the most marked characteristic of Lord RENFREW's American tour. abstract: RESPONDENCE. -- The recent address of condolence of the Baltimore Bishops to the Pope, owing in some degree, no doubt, to its being indited in ecclesiastical Latin in the original is a very good specimen of the unfortunate and almost ludicrous inflation of style, by which all the addresses and documents issued by the clergy during the present troubles of the Papacy have been characterized, and which has damaged their cause almost as much as the arms of GARIBALDI. The popular heart, if it were ever so sympathetic, can hardly be touched by language possessing so little of the simplicity and terseness with which political discussions are now carried on, and in which all real feeling is expressed. The ponderous periods in which the clergy discuss the woes of the church, are almost as much out of place, as strange in the ears of this generation, as the conceits and euphemisms in which lovers breathed their passion two hundred years ago. Whatever pain might be excited by seeing an old gentleman of the age and position of PIUS IX. shorn of his dominions, few people are much moved, when they are asked to drop a tear over the storms which "toss the sacred bark of blessed Peter." In like manner, when the excommunication directed against VICTOR EMANUEL, and the whole of the Italian Liberal Party -- which was stuck up on the church doors in Rome last Spring, and to which no human being seems to have since paid a particle of attention is called "a drawing of the sword of the Spirit worn by divine appointment, a proof that there still remains in the Catholic Church the divine power to oblige her children to walk rightly in the Lord," -- there is such a ludicrous contrast between this description of its potency and the results it seems to the profane vulgar actually to achieve, that we are afraid the rebels will only wax the fiercer in their rebellion. This language might have been addressed to HILDEBRAND, but the sword, unfortunately, is plainly the sword of PIUS IX.

abstract: The news of the departure of the King of Naples for Capua and Gaeta is now certain. This news has been expected for some days. It still produces,never-...
lead_paragraph: The news of the departure of the King of Naples for Capua and Gaeta is now certain. This news has been expected for some days. It still produces,nevertheless, a considerable effect, for it had been imagined that the King would make, under the walls of his capital, with the troops that have remained faithful to him, a last attempt at resistance. It is at Gaeta -- that is, in the strongest position there is in the Kingdom, regarded in a military point of view -- that he will await a return of good fortune, or endeavor to provoke it. He withdraws with a contingent of troops still respectable enough -- being 30,000 strong, it is said -- and which, considering the excellence of the position, must be taken into account. In fact, if in a political point of view the abandonment of Naples is quite a revolution of itself, in a military point of view it is an act of dexterity, or at least of prudence. Naples is open, or rather it opens itself spontaneously. Before even the King left it, FRANCIS had, we may say, ceased to reign there. The movement of men's minds there, the impulse that carries away the population and drives it to throw itself into the arms of GARIBALDI, might cause a complete dissolution of the last nucleus of strength at the young King's disposal. The city, it is true, is entirely commanded by Fort St. Elmo, a stronghold not easily to be taken, cut out of the rock, and at some places standing on an elevation of eighty feet. But to remain master of that point would be to put himself under the necessity of a painful, and probably a fruitless operation -- that of bombarding the Capital of the Continental Kingdom, as he had the Sicilian Capital -- an inhuman proceeding, and, therefore, most impolitic. The young King, yielding to the advice of his most prudent friends, has preferred retiring to Gaeta, where he will add to the advantage of a royal residence, and of a still stronger military position, that of remaining master of a part of his States, and approaching nearer to the only ally he has preserved -- the Pope -- whose Government has at its disposal 25,000 men, pretty well organized, it is said, by Gen. LAMORICIERE. Gaeta, a fortified town of 14,000 inhabitants, including its three suburbs, is situate in the Terra di Lavoro, of which the administrative capital is Caserta, between Capua and Naples. It consists of Irregular works, rising in terraces one above the other, on a rocky headland of the Mediterranean Coast. On the land side the narrow approach is closed by strong batteries; a fort commands the harbor, and at the extremity of this point there is the old tower called Rolando's. Gaeta was besieged in 1800 by the French, and in 1815 by the Austrians. Very strong by nature, this position is rendered yet stronger by the configuration of the surrounding locality. For any one master of Gaeta, and having a sufficient number of troops at his disposal, it is easy to defend San Germano on the northeast, and Capua on the southeast; and these three points form a triangular district, in which the last efforts of the Bourbon monarchy will probably be concentrated. San Germano and Capua are both situate about ten leagues from Gaeta; San Germano, on the Fiume-Rapido, is at the foot of Mount Cassino, the summit of which is crowned by the ancient and vast abbey of the same name. This position may be used as a military retreat, and can easily be defended. Capua, on the Volturno, possesses an arsenal, a military hospital, and 8,000 inhabitants. The Volturno is crossed there by means of a stone bridge, and on the right bank of the river there is a strong tete-de-pont. A strong casemate has been constructed to the east of the town. Capua lies, as is well known, half-way between Naples and Gaeta. It is from that point that the King will reach his last asylum. Doubtless he would leave behind him at this intermediate station a sufficient number of troops to defend it, if the war now being waged by him were a regular war, but he is rather a spectator than an actor in the scene. The situation is controlled by unexpected events; and, if he merely intends waiting for events, he will perhaps do nothing more than concentrate his forces in Gaeta. This we shall soon learn by news from the Two Sicilies.

abstract: A very great excitement was occasioned on the west side of the First Ward yesterday forenoon, by the attempt on the part of HENRY N. PIERREPONT, a shoemaker, living at No. 46 Greenwich-street, to murder a woman named HANNAH JONES, to whom for a few weeks past fee has been under an engagement of marriage. In July last Mrs. JONES, who keeps a boarding-house and drinking-place at No. 22 1/2 Morris-street, became a widow, PIERREPONT had been an intimate friend of her husband's, and after the decease of the latter he had endeavored to do all in his power for the bereaved wife. He assisted in settling up the affairs of deceased and by his management Mrs. JONES was enabled to retain possession of the business. In all her troubles the widow found in PIERREPONT a counselor in whom she could rely, and finally he seemed so indispensable to her that when he made an offer to marry her, it found on her part a ready acceptance. Such has been the condition of affairs for some weeks, during which time the ardent shoemaker has invested all his spare cash in presents for his affianced, and the course of their true love seemed to show an exception to the old adage. Late on Sunday night, however, PIERREPONT's short dream of happiness was disturbed. An acquaintance called upon him, and inquired if he would go and witness for himself the infidelity of this betrothed. He doubted the truth of his friend's words, but consented to go with him. Accordingly, they obtained admission by stealth to the rear yard of the premises occupied by Mrs. JONES, and raising the window-curtain, PIERREPONT saw the widow under circumstances which excited his jealousy and indignation. His first impulse was to avenge himself upon his rival, but his friend restrained him, and he returned home without having discovered himself to his deceiver. After nursing his jealous feelings all night, in a state bordering upon frenzy, he went to Mrs. JONES' house, and demanded an explanation of the conduct he had witnessed the previous evening. She replied that the person he had seen in her company was an employe of one of the Express Companies in Broadway, and being desirous that he should board with her, she had endeavored to secure his favor. The explanation did not satisfy PIERREPONT, who upbraided the woman, until finally she said that the engagement between them would be broken. She also offered to restore what presents he had given her, and to reimburse him for whatever else she had received from him. As she was in the act of leaving the room PIERREPONT caught her by the hand, and drawing a shoemaker's knife from his breast pocket, he thrust it into her right arm. The blow severed the large artery lengthwise, and caused a dangerous wound, from which the blood poured copiously. The injured woman escaped from the grasp of the desperate man, and ran screaming across the street into the liquor-store of JAMES FITZGERALD, No. 21 Morris-street, where she ran into a bed-room on the second floor, and attempted to close the door. FITZGERALD and the family were at dinner at the time, and Mrs. JONES, to reach the apartment where she had taken refuge, had to pass through the room in which they were eating. Mrs. FITZGERALD and another woman followed her up stairs but almost at the same moment PIERREPONT ran up also, and discharged one barrel of a horse-pistol in the direction of the closed door. The ball nearly grazed Mrs. FITZGERALD's face and entered the head of Mrs. JONES, a short distance in front and directly above the left ear. PIERREPONT immediately placed the pistol to his own head, and doubtless would have killed himself had not Mr. FITZGERALD seized the weapon and struggled to obtain possession of it. Meantime a crowd had been drawn together and some of the men made an attack upon PIERREPONT, who was knocked down and beaten in a shameful manner. In fact, he would probably have been lynched, in accordance with a cry to that effect, but for the timely arrival of Officer GEO. ROWLAND, of the First Ward, who rescued him from his assailants, and took him to the Police Sub-Station, which is near by, in Trinity-place. Sergt. WEMYSS having been informed of what had transpired, promptly repaired to the scene of the occurrence, and caused the wounded woman to be removed to the New-York Hospital. She was placed in the hands of Dr. WEIR, the House Surgeon, who, after probing her wound for several inches, was unable to find the ball, which has lodged in the brain. Her condition is pronounced to be beyond all hope. PIERREPONT at a late hour in the afternoon was taken before Justice KELLY at the Tombs, who committed him to await the result of the injuries he had caused. The prisoner is a native of Liverpool, England, aged 40, and he has lived in the First Ward about twelve years. He has always borne a good reputation, and his appearance would not warrant a belief that he could have perpetrated so terrible a crime. He expressed himself sorry that the attempt that he made on his life was a failure, but said he felt no remorse for what he had done to the woman, whose conduct, he thought, sufficiently justified him. Mrs. JONES, his victim, is an Irishwoman, about 25 years of age. At a late hour last evening she remained at the Hospital in the semi-conscious condition in which she was when admitted.

The explanation did not satisfy PIERREPONT, who upbraided the woman, until finally she said that the engagement between them would be broken. She also offered to restore what presents he had given her, and to reimburse him for whatever else she had received from him. As she was in the act of leaving the room PIERREPONT caught her by the hand, and drawing a shoemaker's knife from his breast pocket, he thrust it into her right arm. The blow severed the large artery lengthwise, and caused a dangerous wound, from which the blood poured copiously. The injured woman escaped from the grasp of the desperate man, and ran screaming across the street into the liquor-store of JAMES FITZGERALD, No. 21 Morris-street, where she ran into a bed-room on the second floor, and attempted to close the door. FITZGERALD and the family were at dinner at the time, and Mrs. JONES, to reach the apartment where she had taken refuge, had to pass through the room in which they were eating. Mrs. FITZGERALD and another woman followed her up stairs but almost at the same moment PIERREPONT ran up also, and discharged one barrel of a horse-pistol in the direction of the closed door. The ball nearly grazed Mrs. FITZGERALD's face and entered the head of Mrs. JONES, a short distance in front and directly above the left ear. PIERREPONT immediately placed the pistol to his own head, and doubtless would have killed himself had not Mr. FITZGERALD seized the weapon and struggled to obtain possession of it. Meantime a crowd had been drawn together and some of the men made an attack upon PIERREPONT, who was knocked down and beaten in a shameful manner. In fact, he would probably have been lynched, in accordance with a cry to that effect, but for the timely arrival of Officer GEO. ROWLAND, of the First Ward, who rescued him from his assailants, and took him to the Police Sub-Station, which is near by, in Trinity-place. Sergt. WEMYSS having been informed of what had transpired, promptly repaired to the scene of the occurrence, and caused the wounded woman to be removed to the New-York Hospital. She was placed in the hands of Dr. WEIR, the House Surgeon, who, after probing her wound for several inches, was unable to find the ball, which has lodged in the brain. Her condition is pronounced to be beyond all hope. PIERREPONT at a late hour in the afternoon was taken before Justice KELLY at the Tombs, who committed him to await the result of the injuries he had caused. The prisoner is a native of Liverpool, England, aged 40, and he has lived in the First Ward about twelve years. He has always borne a good reputation, and his appearance would not warrant a belief that he could have perpetrated so terrible a crime. He expressed himself sorry that the attempt that he made on his life was a failure, but said he felt no remorse for what he had done to the woman, whose conduct, he thought, sufficiently justified him. Mrs. JONES, his victim, is an Irishwoman, about 25 years of age. At a late hour last evening she remained at the Hospital in the semi-conscious condition in which she was when admitted.

abstract: The annual renewal of cart licenses at the Mayor's Office, commenced yesterday, and brought a goodly crowd of carmen. Owing to the absence of the first Marshal, Col. J.C. BURNHAM, detained at home by the sudden death of an elder brother, his duty devolved upon the Assistant Marshal, Mr. HINCHMAN, who discharged the duties promptly, and to the satisfaction of all. The Mayor's Office will be closed at P.M., to-day, to enable the clerks to attend the funeral of Marshal BURNHAM's brother.

abstract: It will be remembered that about a year ago some excitement was created in the billiard circles of the Metropolis by the announcement of a prospective
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that about a year ago some excitement was created in the billiard circles of the Metropolis by the announcement of a prospective match between the respective champions of Europe and America. Owing to more profitable engagements of Mr. BERGER, the proposed match could not be brought about, but he then expressed his intention to visit this country at some future time. Those who take their cue from Mr. PHELAN were delighted a few weeks ago by the announcement of a letter from the French Champion fixing his arrival for next month, and now he has surprised most agreeably the followers of "ye champions" by a sudden irruption in their midst -- he having arrived in the steamer Adriatic on Monday.

abstract: A Communication was received by the Board of Councilmen last evening from the Counsel to the Corporation in answer to an inquiry as to the legality of pursuing the work on the Fourth-avenue mains without contract, but as it was entirely non-committal, and afforded no information as to the matter inquired of, it was ordered to be entered on the minutes without discussion.
lead_paragraph: A Communication was received by the Board of Councilmen last evening from the Counsel to the Corporation in answer to an inquiry as to the legality of pursuing the work on the Fourth-avenue mains without contract, but as it was entirely non-committal, and afforded no information as to the matter inquired of, it was ordered to be entered on the minutes without discussion. The communication states that all work exceeding $250 in amount must be done by contract, except in cases where the work is "necessary to complete or perfect a particular job," but entirely ignores the fact that the Common Council is authorized, by a three-fourths vote, to direct any work to be done by the day. And as an evidence that the Board was quite familiar with the power intrusted to them, they passed during the evening a report directing a drill-room over Jefferson Market to be fitted up at an expense of $750, the work to be done, without contract.

abstract: The Adriatic arrived at such an unseasonable hour that only a brief summary of her news could appear in the morning editions of yesterday's TIMES. The details that we are enabled to give a to-
lead_paragraph: The Adriatic arrived at such an unseasonable hour that only a brief summary of her news could appear in the morning editions of yesterday's TIMES. The details that we are enabled to give a to-day are important and extremely interesting. Though we have not yet received particulars of GARIBALDI's triumphal entry into Naples, we now know most of the events which preceded that culmination of the Neapolitan war. The situation of the Ex-King is said to have been so deplorable as to have excited the compassion of his enemies. He has taken refuge in his own fortified town of Gaeta, whence, as soon as the time comes, he will pass to Capua and to Austrian territory, for he has been advised by the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH not to go to Madrid. The most important news brought by the Adriatic is the announcement of a rupture between Piedmont and Rome. The latter is said to have demanded peremptorily the dissolution of the free corps, enlisted under the orders of Gen. LAMORICIERE, as being a body hostile to the peace of Italy. According to latest advices, no Sardinian troops had, as yet, crossed the frontiers, but they were being collected in large numbers in the Cattolica, at Piazenza, and at Arezzo, in Tuscany. France, in the semi-official columns of the Constitutionnel, protests against this aggression of Piedmont, and asserts that it "will separate it from the Emperor's policy." Austria, too, is again making extensive warlike preparations, having concentrated a corps d'armee of 50,000 troops in the Mantuan territory. It is officially announced from St. Petersburgs that the Emperors of Austria and Russia are once more friends, and that the meeting of reconciliation between the two Sovereigns will take place at Warsaw. The miscellaneous intelligence received by the Adriaiic is also of an interesting character.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. It is a burlesque written by the brothers BROUGH, the death of one of whom we had but a short time since to chronicle, and was played for a long time in London, with marked success.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. Another attraction, and one of most fortunate consequences, inasmuch as it will assuredly attract large audiences every night it is played, was produced at this theatre last night. It is a burlesque written by the brothers BROUGH, the death of one of whom we had but a short time since to chronicle, and was played for a long time in London, with marked success. Its title is "The Magic Joke, or Prince Doloroso." Of plot, there is only a thread, which, were it describable, need not be described, it being the essence of all burlesque that the plot should be indescribable. Assuredly it is so in this instance, although there is as much coherency in the piece as in one of the stories of the Arabian Nights.

abstract: SOUTHERN IMPROVEMENTS. -- The people of North Carolina are enjoying their first excitement over the completion of their initial public improvement. The deepening, widening, and straightening of the channel of the Deep River, projected some years ago, has at last been accomplished, and improved navigation is to be brought into use in a few days. Deep River, navigable heretofore for only about 160 miles from the seaport (Wilmington), has been so improved as to afford safe transit for barges equal in capacity to our largest canal boats, as far as Farmville, something over two hundred miles from Wilmington. By this improvement the great coal and iron beds of the Farmville region have been reached, and facilities obtained for the cheap transport of ore and coal to the seaboard. The public inauguration of the completion of this work is to take place about the first of October. So much importance is attached to it, and so much pride is felt by the people of "Old Rip Van Winkle," that the Governor and State Officers have determined to commemorate the event by a grand public festival.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHERN IMPROVEMENTS. -- The people of North Carolina are enjoying their first excitement over the completion of their initial public improvement. abstract: The Republican Convention meets to-night for the nomination of Judges. We hope the members will take good care to give us good candidates.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Convention meets to-night for the nomination of Judges. We hope the members will take good care to give us good candidates. The public has become thoroughly disgusted and somewhat alarmed, by the class of men who have been placed in the most solemnly responsible positions known to political life, -- that of administering justice to a great community. Unless we can have reform in the elections, the whole system of an elective judiciary will be swept away, or, what is more likely and very much worse, it will fall into contemptuous neglect, and our scoundrels, of every grade, will be left perfectly free to select their own Judges and regulate their own affairs in their own way.
headline: {'main': 'Judicial Nominations.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Judicial Nominations.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The principal event of yesterday, in this Court, was to have been the renewal of the argument by Messrs. James T. Brady and A. Oakey Hall, for the
lead_paragraph: The principal event of yesterday, in this Court, was to have been the renewal of the argument by Messrs. James T. Brady and A. Oakey Hall, for the discharge of Charles Jefferds, charged on the verdict of a Coroner's Jury with the "Walton and Mathews murder, on bail, the District Attorney having failed to send the papers in the case to the Grand Jury. On Thursday last, it will be remembered that the argument, after two previous postponements, was commenced, but nothing satisfactory could be arrived at on the subject, owing to the absence of the District Attorney, Mr. Waterbury. It was then arranged that he should be present yesterday, and that the argument should proceed. He was still absent, however, during the first hour of the Court, and a postponement till 1 o'clock took place. At that hour he was still not found, and the case went over till next term. We believe that Mr. Waterbury has not tried a single case in this Court during the last four months.

abstract: The opportunity of rapping Republican America over the knuckles, combining with the dearth of topics which afflicts English journalism in the dry season, after Parliament has
lead_paragraph: The opportunity of rapping Republican America over the knuckles, combining with the dearth of topics which afflicts English journalism in the dry season, after Parliament has risen, tempt our cotemporary, the London Times, into a solemn sermon, of which Gov. BANKS and his resignation supply the text, upon the diversion in the United States of the highest ability from the service of the State into the paths of private enterprise. The inadequacy of American salaries in the leading positions of public life is assumed by the Times to account in a very considerable degree for the unhappy results which it deplores, and the inference is left to be drawn that in America we systematically starve talent and character out of national fame into the obscurity of fortune, and fairly force genius into abdicating the laurel wreaths of history and accepting the loaves and fishes of the hour. There can be little doubt that men of the first force do not seek public posts so generally and so naturally as they once did, either in the United States or in Europe. The case of Gov. BANKS, however, can scarcely be quoted in illustration of this truth without implying a rather scurvy compliment to that gentleman, who has done nothing to escape and much to deserve the honors of political life, and whose present action in leaving the Executive chair of Massachusetts for a comfortable commercial post in Illinois is not necessarily to be interpreted as a definite abandonment of a career which had reached its term in the East, and could only be prolonged by opening new channels for itself in the West.

abstract: The Republican County Convention, comprising five delegates from each Ward, met at No. 618 Broadway last evening. AMOR J. WILLIAMSON, Esq., pre-
lead_paragraph: The Republican County Convention, comprising five delegates from each Ward, met at No. 618 Broadway last evening. AMOR J. WILLIAMSON, Esq., presided, and Messrs. THAYER, of the Ninth Ward, and CLEVELAND, of the Fifteenth, were chosen Secretaries. The only contested seats were those representing the Twentieth and Eleventh Wards. From the Twentieth Ward there were two delegations, one headed by. D.D. CONOVER, and another by P.C. BULKLEY, each representing a rival association -- the latter an offshoot from the former.

abstract: The Fusion Committee fulfilled its mission yesterday, and made up a new electoral ticket. All that this action amounts to thus far, however, is that fifteen gentlemen, all of them
lead_paragraph: The Fusion Committee fulfilled its mission yesterday, and made up a new electoral ticket. All that this action amounts to thus far, however, is that fifteen gentlemen, all of them Anti-Republicans, and nearly all Democrats, have nominated a list of electors which they hope the three political parties will consent to vote for instead of their own. This list comprises 18 Douglas men, 10 Bell-Everett men and 7 Breckinridge men, -- the Douglas men having thus a majority of one over both the others. We do not understand that thus far either of the two Democratic organizations has assented to the arrangement. The ticket is simply one that has been put in nomination by a private party of 15, -- who have no hope of electing any President of their own and who concentrate their energies, therefore, on the task of defeating their principal opponent.

abstract: Pennoyer vs. Brennan. This case was stated in the TIMES some months since, at which time the plaintiff obtained a temporary injunction against
lead_paragraph: Pennoyer vs. Brennan. This case was stated in the TIMES some months since, at which time the plaintiff obtained a temporary injunction against the defendant restraining him from fencing up the road or lane leading to Stryker's Bay Hotel, kept by plaintiff. The plaintiff alleged that this way to the hotel had been open for thirty years, and was the only means of approach to and exit from his premises. The order to show cause why that injunction should not be made permanent, was now returnable before Justice INGRAHAM at Chambers of the Supreme Court. The defendant now claimed that the way was originally opened through Stryker's property, by Stryker himself, who had erected the hotel, and that it was never considered anything else than private property -- to be closed whenever the owner thereof might desire. Besides, the plaintiff was the defendant's tenant, and had not paid his rent. Means had been taken to dispossess the plaintiff prior to fencing up the way, which the defendant had a right to do, he being the owner of the property.

abstract: This Association met yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the German Society, E. JELLINGHAUS in the Chair. The following Societies were represented:
lead_paragraph: This Association met yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the German Society, E. JELLINGHAUS in the Chair. The following Societies were represented: German, St. George's, St. Andrew's, F.S. of St. Patrick, St. David's, French-Swiss, Portuguese, Hebrew, Scandinavian and Hebrew Benevolent. After the reading of the minutes, Mr. ROBT. JOHNSON, Counsel to the Board, read his report; in which he stated that since the organization of this Board ticket-swindling had been suppressed, and instead of twenty complaints a day, which they were accustomed to receive, that since May last only seven complaints have been made.

abstract: A large mass meeting was held at the hall of the City Wide-Awakes, No. 638 Broadway, last evening. The "Prairie Songsters," during the evening, sang several songs, Messrs. J.W. GREEN, JOSEPH C. JACKSON, W.B. WISTER, of Pennsylvania, and F.S. LAMBERT of the Irish Wide-Awakes, delivered stirring addresses. Mr. JACKSON made a very thorough statement of the causes which led to the present condition of the country, and urged them to see to it that the United States Government was a fair reflection of the principles of the American people. It was a very enthusiastic meeting.

abstract: -- The metropolitan character of New-York is about to be vindicated in her medical institutions, a field in which Philadelphia has so long claimed to lead. We are glad to observe that the profession is waking up from its lethargy, and seems determined that its colleges shall take that rank which the position of New-York fairly entitles them to do. The New-York Medical College has begun its eleventh session under auspices which promise more than well. The Trustees, at the head of whom is the Governor of the State, have decided to inaugurate a new regime; the faculty, which now includes Dr. DOREMUS, (the Dean,) Dr. CARNOCHAN, Dr. REESE, and other men of similar standing, are cooperating vigorously in the measures just introduced. These are of a character to interest the general public, which is vitally affected, not only by whatever concerns the progress of our noble City, but especially by whatever, concerns the advancement of medical science and education among us.

abstract: The Twentieth Ward Douglas and Johnson Club held a meeting last evening at No. 465 Eighth-avenue. The speakers were Messrs. MCSWYNEY and JOHN H. MCCUNN -- the latter is the Tammany Hall candidate for the office of City Judge. After a speech from Mr. MCSWYNEY, Mr. MCCUNN was introduced and spoke briefly. He said he had just come from Ireland. While he was there he heard of the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS, and he left immediately, weighing twenty-seven pounds more than he did when he went there. He also remarked that his bones and sinews were made up of Irish beef, Irish potatoes, and a small taste of whisky. He concluded with the promise that if elected to the City Judgeship he would not forget his friends or his party and would do his duty, and a request to the President of the meeting to put him down for whatever sum he liked and he would give a check for the amount.

abstract: -- A few days ago two postulants of the Order of Immaculate Heart of Mary. Miss E. Cassidy, of this City, (in religion Sister Mary Pauline,) and Miss O'Connor, of Philadelphia, (in religion Sister Nepomercene, (were received into the novitiate of the Sisterhood, at Reading, Tenn. Sister Mary Alphonsus made her vows, finally renouncing the allurements of this wicked world, and is now a professed Sister of the order. abstract: SEMI-ANNUAL REPORT OP THE WATER COMMISSIONERS. -- The Water Commissioners have prepared their semi-annual report for the half year ending July 1 last, and it will probably be presented to the Board of Aldermen on Monday evening next. By this report it appears that up to July 1 124 1/2 miles of iron pipe and 2 1/2 miles of cement pipe had been laid. This pipe ranges from 4 to 36 inches in diameter, but the most of it is only six inches, having 730 stop-cocks. Five hundred and sixty hydrants have been erected. Four hundred and forty-six complaints were made for misuse of water, and during the same time 465 new buildings were reported to the Department. Water has been cut off from 104 buildings for violation of the regulations of the Board. The following table is given to show the value of the water in extinguishing conflagrations.

abstract: A man over sixty years of age, giving the name of Edward Carter was yesterday brought before Justice KELLY at the Tombs, on a charge of having defrauded Mr. Lewis L. Whitehead, a merchant of No. 33 Cortlandt-street, to the extent of $30, by means of false representations. The prisoner, a few weeks since, called upon the complainant and exhibited bills of lading for 56 cases of boots and shoes, which he represented had been consigned to him by Wm. Totten & Son, of Portland, Me., and desired to transfer the goods to Mr. Whitehead to sell. The old man, in course of conversation, remarked that he had until a short time previous been a merchant in Massachusetts, where he was still possessed of considerable property. He also stated that he was going to Baltimore, and asked Mr. Whitehead to advance him $30 upon a check on the Massachusetts Bank for $100, representing that he kept an account in that institution. This check, signed James Adams, which the prisoner stated was his name, was left with Mr. Whitehead as collateral security, and the money having been advanced the old gentleman promised to call on his return from the South and receive the balance of $75 Mr. White-house subsequently forwarded the check to the Boston Bank, and in due time received an answer that Adams had no deposit in the institution. The consignment of boots and shoes having failed to arrive, Mr. Whitehead was forced to the conclusion that he had been swindled, and, consequently, has since sought to find the prisoner, not meeting with success, however, until yesterday. When his examination before the magistrate was in progress, Carter stated that he was guilty of the crime charged, and had been forced to commit it to save himself from starvation. The prospect of a shelter, even though it was no better nor respectable than a cell in the prison, he considered preferable to wandering homeless and destitute about the streets. He also said that he had formerly been engaged extensively in a mercantile business in this City, but that a series of reverses had reduced him to penury. Among his acquaintances in his prosperous days were Simeon Draper and other well-known merchants, and he still had wealthy sisters in Cambridge, Mass., of whom, however, he could not bring himself to ask relict. He added that on several occasions he had applied to the Commissioners of Public Charities and Corrections for relief, but no notice had been taken of his petition. It is difficult to say whether the old man's statement is reliable or the reverse, but, at any rate, it needs confirmation, particularly as two worthless checks, amounting to over $300, were found in his possession. The magistrate committed him for trial.

abstract: In spite of the great efforts that have been made to conceal from the world the actual Condition of Turkey, the utter rottenness of the whole empire has been laid bare by the late outbreak in Syria. Those dreadful massacres have served at least to exhibit the feebleness and corruption of a Government that secretly abetted, because it feared to oppose
lead_paragraph: In spite of the great efforts that have been made to conceal from the world the actual Condition of Turkey, the utter rottenness of the whole empire has been laid bare by the late outbreak in Syria. Those dreadful massacres have served at least to exhibit the feebleness and corruption of a Government that secretly abetted, because it feared to oppose them. They made many people think, possibly for the first time, that the Christian subjects of the Porte -- a very formidable Greek population -- are as much entitled to sympathy for wrongs sustained, and to support in their desire for independence, as the Neapolitans or the Hungarians. The declaration of Lord PALMERSTON, that England would preserve, at every cost, the integrity of the Turkish Empire, is no longer indorsed by intelligent Englishmen, though jealousy of Russia would probably induce them to oppose her schemes of Southern annexation, and her wish to gather under the protection of the Czar all the Christian subjects of the Sultan.
headline: {'main': 'Turkish Authority in Syria.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Turkish Authority in Syria.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: --The failure of a leading dry goods house in this City, with a statement of its affairs not eminently encouraging to creditors, excites attention to the nature and safety of our jobbing credits. The house referred to is known to have been almost exclusively engaged in the Southern trade. Misled by the extremely auspicious promise of the cotton crop early in the season, it appears to have gorged itself with an unusually heavy stock of goods for the Southern market, not without reasonable hope of heavy business and unprecedented profits. Ruin has come from the failure of the crop. Southern customers, with unaccustomed prudence, have reckoned upon contracted trade, and have bought sparingly. The strongest houses, therefore, who had prepared for a different event, find themselves staggering under a very difficult burden, while those of narrower resources are obliged to succumb.
lead_paragraph: --The failure of a leading dry goods house in this City, with a statement of its affairs not eminently encouraging to creditors, excites attention to the nature and safety of our jobbing credits. abstract: A number of men employed on board the canal-boats lying at C[???]enties-slip engaged in a brawl yesterday, with reference to a woman named Frances Guy, who had been living on intimate terms with Thomas Flitchcraft, one of the combatants. In the affray one of the boatmen, known as John Dunn, was knocked down, beaten and kicked on his head and face, and also received a compound fracture of one of his legs, which will make amputation necessary. Officers Gaffney and Myers, of the First Precinct, hearing of the fight, went to the place and arrested the woman Guy, as well as the man Flitchcraft, and another boatman named George Dunn. The prisoners were all taken before Justice KELLY, who, upon the complaint of George Stannard, a hand on the canal-boat Leviathan, lying at Pier No. 7 East River, committed the accused for trial, in default of $1,000 bail each. Dunn, the injured man, was sent to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: In another column we publish a reply to the communication in yesterday's TIMES defending Judge RUSSELL's action in the cases, recently tried, of SMITHURST, WARD and GILBERT, charged with ticket-swindling. The issues made by these correspondents turn exclusively upon matters of fact; and we leave their letters to speak for themselves. We feel compelled to add, however, that we see no reason to doubt the substantial truth of the statements embodied in our original article upon the subject.

abstract: Harriet M. Keegan vs. Daniel E. Keegan. -- This was a motion for alimony and counsel fee during the pendency of this action. The action is for a separation from bed and board forever, on account of desertion and cruel and inhuman treatment. The complaint alleges that the plaintiff was married to defendant on the 13th of June, 1859; that she and the defendant, lived together as husband and wife from that time up to November, 1859, and from that time the defendant ceased to live regularly with her, and only visited her from time to time afterwards, and that from February to August, 1860, defendant paid to her a certain amount monthly towards her support; but from that time he has refused to provide for her, has totally abandoned her, and refused to permit her to return to his residence; that in November, 1859, he struck the plaintiff on the face with such violence, as to loosen three of her teeth, and in April, 1860, he also struck her on the head with such violence as to cause blood to flow from her ear; that while the defendant lived with her he removed the beds and other furniture but of his house and left her no suitable place to sleep in, and refused to provide for her, so that she was in great want of necessary food, and obliged to seek food in a charitable way from persons living near her; that he called her opprobrious names, used and uttered other indignities, publicly and privately, to and of her, and notified persons from whom she might receive assistance and sympathy against giving her anything. The plaintiff alleges that this conduct on the part of her husband renders it unsafe for her to cobalt with him any longer.
lead_paragraph: Harriet M. Keegan vs. Daniel E. Keegan. -- This was a motion for alimony and counsel fee during the pendency of this action. The plaintiff alleges that this conduct on the part of her husband renders it unsafe for her to cobalt with him any longer.

abstract: Hon. Mr. LINDSAY, whose unofficial mission to the United States has already been widely noticed by the Press of both countries, met the Boston Board of Trade on Monday, and addressed them at some length on the purposes and objects which had brought him to this country. Though he had no official character whatever, he did not conceal the fact that he sought to-obtain concurrent action of the two Governments upon certain commercial topics of mutual interest. What these topics were, he proceeded state. The first related to the responsibility of shipowners for damage at sea. If a British ship, coming to an American port, runs down another vessel the liability of the owner is not limited in the United States to the value of the vessel which does the damage, as it is in England. What Mc. LINDSAY proposes is, that a law be passed by both countries limiting the liability of shipowners to the amount of Â£15 per ton; and that by a convention the ships of Great Britain and the United States respectively shall be placed upon an equal footing in regard to the loss of life, personal injury, &c., by collisions at sea, and that the liability of the owners of the ship running down another shall be limited the same amount, whether the ship belong to Great Britain or the United States; and that the mode of procedure shall be in accordance with the law of the country in which the claim is made.

What Mc. LINDSAY proposes is, that a law be passed by both countries limiting the liability of shipowners to the amount of Â£15 per ton; and that by a convention the ships of Great Britain and the United States respectively shall be placed upon an equal footing in regard to the loss of life, personal injury, &c., by collisions at sea, and that the liability of the owners of the ship running down another shall be limited the same amount, whether the ship belong to Great Britain or the United States; and that the mode of procedure shall be in accordance with the law of the country in which the claim is made.

abstract: The Republican Judiciary Convention met last night at No. 618 Broadway. There were five delegates from each Ward, including a number of the most promonent members of the Party. HALL, of the Ninth and SHEPHARD, of the Fifth, Secretaries.

abstract: BRECKINRIDGE had an immense demonstration to-night in front of Congress Hall. Mr. BRADY'S speech is regarded as a death blow to fusion. He denounced DOUGLAS and his doctrines, and gave it as his opinion that he would not carry a single State. He characterized CAGGER and RICHMOND as tricksters. The meeting was a great success.

abstract: At the Academy to-night we are promised the magnificent opera of "Robert Le Diable," "in the natural French," and with French artists to fill the principal roles, including Madame COLSON, the most graceful and pathetic imaginable Alice. Monsieur GENEBREL. the Bertram of the cast, will hardly, however, make us forget the triumphs of FORMES in this grand representative character. In fact, one might almost suspect that SUSINI's Leporello and GENEBREL's Bertram are sacrificial offerings, intended to prepare the way for the return of the wonderful basso.

abstract: The steamship Anglo Saxon, from Liverpool on the 13th, via Londonderry on the 14th inst., with two days' later European advices, passed Father Point on her way to Quebec yesterday afternoon, but owing to the disarrangement of the telegraph wires between Father Point and Montreal, we are unable to publish her news this morning. She is due at an early hour at Quebec, from which point the news will be forwarded in time for our afternoon editions.

abstract: The sales opened, yesterday, at the principal yards on Forty-fourth-street, with a supply of about 3,900 head of all sorts of cattle -- a few good, more of medium quality, and most of poor. In number, the supply is some 500 less than were offered here last week. Besides being fewer in numbers, they were not as good as one week ago, although of only medium quality then. After an hour or two of dull sales, in the morning, the trade became quite animated, and an unusually large number of cattle were disposed of in a brief space of time. Business then fluctuated during the remainder of the day, and closed dull, a large number of buyers preferring the noted horse-race to the monotony of the cattle-yards. About two-thirds of the cattle were disposed of yesterday, leaving a scarcity of good ones, but plenty of poor quality for to-day. On the best droves prices varied little from last week, but on common to poor there was a decline of 1/4c.@1/2c., lb., and as to-day is a holiday among the Jews, who are the largest buyers of this class of cattle, the decline may be still greater before the close of the market. We saw no cattle bring 10c. The market may be quoted 9c.@9 1/2c. for prime -- a very few 9 3/4c. -- 8c.@8 1/2c. for medium to fair, and 6c.@7c. for poor.
lead_paragraph: The sales opened, yesterday, at the principal yards on Forty-fourth-street, with a supply of about 3,900 head of all sorts of cattle -- a few good, more of medium quality, and most of poor. In number, the supply is some 500 less than were offered here last week. Besides being fewer in numbers, they were not as good as one week ago, although of only medium quality then. After an hour or two of dull sales, in the morning, the trade became quite animated, and an unusually large number of cattle were disposed of in a brief space of time. Business then fluctuated during the remainder of the day, and closed dull, a large number of buyers preferring the noted horse-race to the monotony of the cattle-yards. About two-thirds of the cattle were disposed of yesterday, leaving a scarcity of good ones, but plenty of poor quality for to-day. On the best droves prices varied little from last week, but on common to poor there was a decline of 1/4c.@1/2c., lb., and as to-day is a holiday among the Jews, who are the largest buyers of this class of cattle, the decline may be still greater before the close of the market. We saw no cattle bring 10c. The market may be quoted 9c.@9 1/2c. for prime -- a very few 9 3/4c. -- 8c.@8 1/2c. for medium to fair, and 6c.@7c. for poor.

abstract: This race was ran yesterday on the Fashion Course, and notwithstanding the absence of Boone, who met with an accident to one of his legs last Saturday while taking his gallop, the thousands who had made up their minds to see the race, did so, and came away disgusted, for the race had hardly begun before it commenced raining in torrents; and then Congaree was distanced by Planet, who made the four miles in excellent time, considering the state of the track. Planet who is owned by the Messrs. DOSWELL, of Virginia, is [???] years old and carried 11[???] lbs. Congaree is 3 years old; carried 104 lbs. and is owned by Mr. PURYEAR, of South Carolina.

abstract: THE GERMAN FREE SCHOOL FAIR. -- The Fair at the German Free School in Fourth-street, which was arranged by the mothers of the children attending the school, and the wives of the shareholders, by whose contributions the managers of the establishment succeeded in erecting the building, was concluded yesterday afternoon. The number of shares given out amounted to 3,200, and there were 1,200 prizes, many of them quite costly. They consisted of articles of furniture, needlework of every description, pictures, wearing apparel, fancy wares and jewelry. The monotony of drawing the lots, which was done by two little girls, was greatly relieved by the declamatory performances of several of the pupils. The prizes will he distributed to-day. During the past Summer months, the number of the pupils greatly decreased. It is, however, rapidly increasing. There are at present about 700 children attending the school, who are instructed by nine male and four female teachers. At a meeting held by the members of the New-Yorker Furnvereim, it was resolved to give a public exhibition for the benefit of the institution at the end of next month.

abstract: Last evening, a deputation of Wide-Awakes, under command of Gen. J.H. HOBART WARD, were attending the raising of a Lincoln and Hamlin pole in front of the Republican Central, Campaign Club Head-quarters, No. 722 Broadway. While the Wide-Awakes were drawn up in line on the sidewalk, a number of members of the Bell and Everett and Democratic Clubs hissed them, and applied sundry opprobrious epithets, and, it is said, made several personal assaults. Gen. WARD gave the order to "charge!" and a general melee ensued. The Republicans drove their opponents into the New-York Hotel, and were themselves in turn driven back, with the loss of a number of their torches.

abstract: -In ordinary war  fare one effective bullet in fifty is considered a fair average. Chinese fighting is done largely with gongs : women and children get sadly frightened, but there is little work for the surgeon. It is an economical mode of warfare, too; the gong is always loaded, and if it does not go off, it allows the enemy to do so.
lead_paragraph: -In ordinary war fare one effective bullet in fifty is considered a fair average. Chinese fighting is done largely with gongs : women and children get sadly frightened, but there is little work for the surgeon. It is an economical mode of warfare, too; the gong is always loaded, and if it does not go off, it allows the enemy to do so. We find a very excellent analogy to this in the crusade so clamorously and perseveringly waged by one of our cotemporaries upon the movements of what is styled the "Sabbath Committee." It has lost up occasion during the last three years of vituperating the men and the measures concerned in effecting one of the most quiet and successful reforms of our times. It has printed the names of the several members of that Committee -- than which none stand higher in this community for all that is honorable, virtuous and Christian -- in libelous connection with the charge -- that "the practice of the Sabbatarians is to give six days to the Devil -- to lying and slandering, and cheating, and to nine-tenths of the vices and crimes prohibited by the Decalogue -- and then to give the seventh day. to God, when they are tired of sinning all the week." It has exhausted the vocabulary, of billingsgate in its abuse of these "Aminadab Sleeks," "Sniveling Mawworths," "Brutal Fanatics " and "Parvenu Snobs." The documents of the Committee, which have confined their discussions solely to the claims of the civil Sabbath, and the invasions of it which constitute a breach of the public peace, were. Characterized in the last Sunday's issue "of this discriminating sheet as "most intolerant and benighted, worthy of Hayti and Dahomey." And an inflammatory appeal is made to "the Germans to right themselves and lay the insolent usurpers low, by united action at the ballot-box, where it is always the peculiar privilege of American citizens to make a peaceful and bloodless revolution."

abstract: The resolution which the Government of VICTOR EMANUEL appears at last to have taken, of intervening openly and decisively in the affairs of the Roman States, and arresting at...
lead_paragraph: The resolution which the Government of VICTOR EMANUEL appears at last to have taken, of intervening openly and decisively in the affairs of the Roman States, and arresting at Rome the revolution which it has controlled at Naples, is the most cheering sign which could be given to us, at once of promise for the complete independence of Italy, and of permanence for the general peace of Europe.

abstract: The United States vs. The Bark Orion, &c. -- This was a motion in the United States District Court, before Judge BETTS, for leave to execute the decree. The vessel and her cargo were libeled as forfe[???]d for being engaged in the Slave-trade. The Court g[???]ea decree against the vessel, from which an appeal was taken to the Circuit Court, but the appeal was never perfected by the giving the requisite security. A long delay having elapsed and the appeal still remain in unperfected, the District-Attorney made this motion, which was resisted by the appellants on the ground of an understanding between them and the District-Attorney's office that the appeal should not be prejudiced by the delay. The Court decided that verbal understandings, as to which there was always conflict, could not be regarded, and that that was the settled rule in the Court, and granted the motion.

abstract: There is some probability in the report, which reaches us from New-Orleans, that Spain is fitting out an expedition in Havana to give effect to her intervention in Mexico. Her designs in that quarter have been apparent for some time.
lead_paragraph: There is some probability in the report, which reaches us from New-Orleans, that Spain is fitting out an expedition in Havana to give effect to her intervention in Mexico. Her designs in that quarter have been apparent for some time. It is perfectly well understood that, throughout the present civil war, MIRAMON has been aided and abetted by Spanish power, and that if the Liberal army are again successful, and the Dictator is driven from his last stronghold in the Capital, a new enemy will be found in the Spanish army now being organized in Havana. The presence of an unusually large and powerful Spanish fleet in the Gulf of Mexico, is not without significance; and every move made by Spain during the past twelve months indicates an intention on her part, not merely to interfere in Mexico, but to reassert her pretensions as a first-class American Power. We recently published intelligence, received on good authority from Havana, that a large Spanish force has been dispatched to San Domingo to "regulate" the affairs of that Republic; and this proceeding, as well as the intervention in Mexico, is probably but a part of a preconcerted programme.

abstract: -- One Mr. BEALL, it seems, has found that the majority of passengers who travel over the Georgia Railroad are opposed to Mr. Douglas politically, and he has not hesitated to state the fact in the newspapers. For this that model sheet, the Atlanta Confederacy reproaches him gently, thus: "Who is this W.T. Beall? He is a long, lank, whining old sycophant, that has been sticking like an insatiate leech to the Federal teat for the last ten years, as a route agent on the Georgia Railroad. He is a slimy creeper, that can't talk without hissing -- and he is the delectable personage to take the vote upon the cars! If he would attend to his business -- distribute his mail -- and like an honest man disobey instructions, and not suppress Douglas newspapers, and miscarry letters from and to Douglas Democrats, he would discharge that duty which the Government pays him to perform. But instead of that, he has hired himself to a corrupt and foul Administration for the purpose of falsifying the truths of history -- and is to-day a pimp of deception."

abstract: AN IMPORTANT DECISION -- THE RESPONSIBILITY OF EXPRESS COMPANIES. -- Our readers will not have forgotten the case of J.S. WILLIAMS, who was convicted some months ago in the United States Circuit Court in this City, of having taken from the Post-office here a letter addressed to one F.A. WILLIAMS. F.A. "WILLIAMS had sent a note for $3,000 at three months to the Norwalk Bank, at Norwalk, Conn., for discount. The cashier returned the note to him in a letter declining to discount it, but promising to do so if it were made a note at two months instead of three. This letter, by some means, did not reach F.A. WILLIAMS, but was advertised by the Post-office. J.S. WILLIAMS got it from the office, altered the note from three months to two, and sent it to the Bank again through Adams' Express Co., who got the proceeds of the discount from the Bank, and returned it to J.S. WILLIAMS, who was afterwards found guilty of the offence, and sentenced to the State Prison for ten years.
lead_paragraph: AN IMPORTANT DECISION -- THE RESPONSIBILITY OF EXPRESS COMPANIES. -- Our readers will not have forgotten the case of J.S. abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Tammany Convention of the Eighth Congressional District was held last evening in the Eighth-avenue, and, after thirty unsuccessful ballots, adjourned to meet again on Tuesday evening next. abstract: The Academy was last night filled with a brilliant and appreciative audience, to do honor to MEYERDEER'S scientific and yet passionate masterpiece, "Robert le Diable." The cast was strictly French, and it is but justice to the leading artists, Mme. COLSON, GENEBREL and PHILIPPE, to say that they evidently...
lead_paragraph: The Academy was last night filled with a brilliant and appreciative audience, to do honor to MEYERDEER'S scientific and yet passionate masterpiece, "Robert le Diable." The cast was strictly French, and it is but justice to the leading artists, Mme. COLSON, GENEBREL and PHILIPPE, to say that they evidently felt themselves much more at home in warbling their "native wood-notes wild," through the consonants and elisions of the Parisian stage, than in attempting the liquids and vowels of Italy. Mme. COLSON makes a captivating rather than an overpowering Alice, but sings her music with the genuine and peaceful sentiment of its significance, which belongs to her fine artistic culture. The Robert whom she loves was decorously presented to the house by Mons. PHILIPPE; and Mons. GENEBREL did, we presume, his best to prove that he, at least, comprehends the capabilities of the grand role of Bertram. "Robert le Diable" will be repeated to-morrow evening. To-night we are to have "Lucretia Borgia" at the Academy, with FABBRI and STIGELLI; and, at Niblo's, Mme. CORTESI, with her brilliant little army, will declaim for us the moving music of Medea.

abstract: It is understood that the Douglas State Committee has informally notified Mr. HENRY, Chairman of the Committee of Fifteen, that they will substitute fix of the seven names proposed by the latter, for an equal number of Douglas Electors who have declined; and as to Mr. RAHDALL, the seventh name proposed, they will answer as soon as they learn whether any vacancy can be made. Mr. WALWORTH, in whose place it was preposed to substitute Mr. RANDALL, had not been heard from.
lead_paragraph: It is understood that the Douglas State Committee has informally notified Mr. HENRY, Chairman of the Committee of Fifteen, that they will substitute fix of the seven names proposed by the latter, for an equal number of Douglas Electors who have declined; and as to Mr. RAHDALL, the seventh name proposed, they will answer as soon as they learn whether any vacancy can be made.
