abstract: The Douglas County Convention met in Flatbush last evening. An organization was effected by electing A.M. WOOD, Chairman, and GEORGE L. Fox, Secretary. There were contesting delegates from the Twelfth, Fourteenth, Fifteenth, Eighteenth and Nineteenth Wards.
lead_paragraph: The Douglas County Convention met in Flatbush last evening. An organization was effected by electing A.M. WOOD, Chairman, and GEORGE L. Fox, Secretary. There were contesting delegates from the Twelfth, Fourteenth, Fifteenth, Eighteenth and Nineteenth Wards. Their claims were laid before a Committee, and the difficulties settled without much delay. A motion to take an informal ballot for Sheriff was carried, and JAMES SHARKEY and THOS. MURPHY were appointed tellers, The ballot resulted as follows:

abstract: -- The body of a man was found at Goose Creek, Jamaica, L.I., on the 18th instant, which has been identified by Miss LEETE as that of her brother JONATHAN, the captain of the sloop Spray. Upon the forehead of the dead man were found two distinct wounds, as if the result of blows from a hatchet or hammer. These were sufficient, in the opinion of the Coroner, to have caused death. The theory entertained by the family, of the manner of the murder is, that ELIJAH was at the wheel, JACKALOW on the look-out, while JONATHAN lay asleep in his berth, there being no other person on board; as was their usual custom, and that JACKALOW in some way managed to kill the man at the wheel, and then with a hatchet to kill his brother in his berth. A further connecting link of identification is the fact that both the brothers LEETE were in the habit of retiring in their clothing, without removing coat, vest, shoes or stockings, and this is the condition of the body found at Jamaica. Portions of the clothing have been forwarded to the mother of the deceased at Guilford, Ct., for the purpose of more positive identification.
lead_paragraph: -- The body of a man was found at Goose Creek, Jamaica, L.I., on the 18th instant, which has been identified by Miss LEETE as that of her brother JONATHAN, the captain of the sloop Spray. Upon the forehead of the dead man were found two distinct wounds, as if the result of blows from a hatchet or hammer. These were sufficient, in the opinion of the Coroner, to have caused death. The theory entertained by the family, of the manner of the murder is, that ELIJAH was at the wheel, JACKALOW on the look-out, while JONATHAN lay asleep in his berth, there being no other person on board; as was their usual custom, and that JACKALOW in some way managed to kill the man at the wheel, and then with a hatchet to kill his brother in his berth. A further connecting link of identification is the fact that both the brothers LEETE were in the habit of retiring in their clothing, without removing coat, vest, shoes or stockings, and this is the condition of the body found at Jamaica. Portions of the clothing have been forwarded to the mother of the deceased at Guilford, Ct., for the purpose of more positive identification.

abstract: Letters from China state that the French forces would land to the south, and the English to the north, of the Taker forts. The whole British force, consisting of 12,110 men, with seven batteries of artillery and a siege train, had reached the rendezvous at Ta-lien-Whan. The commencement of operations was delayed solely on account of the French, not being ready.

abstract: BURGLARS ARRESTED. -- TWO burglars entered the house of Mr. YOUNG, corner of Gold and Concord streets, Tuesday afternoon, and after collecting about $200 worth of valuables, were about taking their departure, when their presence was discovered by Mrs. YOUNG. She seized one of the burglars, and in the struggle which followed he dragged her down a flight of stairs. The noise attracted the attention of Officers KELLY and GAYNOR, of the Second Precinct Police, who arrived in time to capture both thieves and recover the stolen property.
lead_paragraph: BURGLARS ARRESTED. -- TWO burglars entered the house of Mr. YOUNG, corner of Gold and Concord streets, Tuesday afternoon, and after collecting about $200 worth of valuables, were about taking their departure, when their presence was discovered by Mrs. YOUNG. She seized one of the burglars, and in the struggle which followed he dragged her down a flight of stairs. The noise attracted the attention of Officers KELLY and GAYNOR, of the Second Precinct Police, who arrived in time to capture both thieves and recover the stolen property.

abstract: The annual Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New-York commenced its session in St. John's Church, Varick-street, yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The annual Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of New-York commenced its session in St. John's Church, Varick-street, yesterday morning. The customary devotional exercises were conducted by the Right Reverend HORATIO POTTER, Provisional Bishop, assisted by the Lord Bishop of Victoria, Dr. LITTLEJOHN, who read morning prayer, and Drs. WHITE and RUDDER, who read the lessons. Drs. CUTLER, BROWN, J.C. SMITH, MCVICKAR, S.H. WESTON and CREIGHTON occupied seats in the chancel.

lead_paragraph: We alluded some weeks since to the fact tha some naval officers were collecting reports of the success or failure of the new gunboats built for the United States Navy. The craft chartered for the Paraguay expedition, and subsequently purchased, are not included, of course.

abstract: The initial chapters of the Prince's Progress promised anything but a pleasant conclusion to the volume.
lead_paragraph: The initial chapters of the Prince's Progress promised anything but a pleasant conclusion to the volume. They bore a striking resemblance to the early pages of the Pilgrim's Progress, without, however, in the slightest degree foreshadowing the beatific result which BUNYAN's hero in the end achieved. Between the obtrusive civilities of fawning sycophants, and the brutal feuds of rival religious factions, the Prince seemed destined to wear a martyr's crown instead of the Crown of England; but he was threatened with martyrdom, simply for being a Prince, and not because he advocated a principle. However glorious it may be to die for opinion's sake, there is nothing very pleasant in the idea of being sacrificed for refusing to embrace and advocate the extreme religious opinions of others. It must also have occurred to the Prince, that if thus treated during a tour through his own Provinces, he must expect to encounter unmitigated tribulations while sojourning among a people bound to him by no hereditary ties, and accustomed to view Royalty in the abstract with little respect. The fictions of DICKENS, to say nothing of the pleasant inventions of other Trollopian travelers, could not have impressed him with a favorable estimate of our morals and manners.

abstract: Will of Isaac Bell, Sen. -- This will was now admitted. The testator was formerly a wealthy merchant, and died leaving a large estate. Mr. Bell was about 92 years of age at the time of his death. His entire estate, real and personal, or the rents and profits thereof, go to his widow during her natural life, and then to his three children -- Mr. Supervisor Bell, Edward Bogart Bell, and Fanny Farnum, widow of Ellis Farnum, who will execute the will, and share alike in the estate.

abstract: We have European advices four days later, by the Anglo Saxon at Quebec, and the Persia at this port.
lead_paragraph: We have European advices four days later, by the Anglo Saxon at Quebec, and the Persia at this port. The former arrived yesterday morning, and the latter at 1 o'clock this morning. The news, which is to the 16th inst., is of a very important character. Sardinia, it appears, has not waited from Rome a reply to her ultimatum demanding that Gen. LAMORICIERE's troops be disbanded as hostile to the peace of Italy, but has invaded Roman territory with 50,000 men. The town of Pesaro had already been attacked and captured. According to the latest advices, a battle might take place at any moment, between the Sardinians and Gen. LAMORICIERE. Several Powers had protested against the action of Piedmont as an attack upon international rights, and France, in accordance with the policy foreshadowed in the Constitutionnel, is so much opposed to the aggression, that a rupture between the two Governments is not deemed an impossible event. Indeed, it is reported that the French Minister had already left Turin. The French army at Rome is to be increased, and has been placed under the command of Gen. GUYON. The Ex-King of Naples, it appears, has decided to make Spain his place of refuge, as his departure for that country is announced. The miscellaneous European news by this arrival is not important. From New-Zealand we learn that the British had suffered a severe defeat in their attempt to quell the insurrection at Martard. The British forces were surprised by superior numbers; and the officer in command had been severely censured for not summoning more troops to his assistance.

abstract: A LIGHTERMAN DROWNED CARELESSNESS OF  THE CAPTAIN OF A TUG-BOAT. Coroner SOHIRMER yesterday held an inquest at Pier No. 30, N.R., upon the...
lead_paragraph: A LIGHTERMAN DROWNED CARELESSNESS OF THE CAPTAIN OF A TUG-BOAT. Coroner SOHIRMER yesterday held an inquest at Pier No. 30, N.R., upon the body of PATRICK QUIGLEY, an Irishman, aged 35, who was drowned on Friday last, by the capsizing of the lighter Suffolk. It appears from the testimony of CORNELIUS DOCHERTY, a hand on board the lighter, that on the day the occurrence transpired, deceased and himself were on board their vessel at the foot of Jay-street, N.R. They desired to haul the lighter to the next pier, and got out a line for that purpose. They had partially accomplished their design when the steamboat Aurora came out of the dock and hailed them to get out of the way. The Captain of the steamer was requested to wait a few moments, but he did not comply, and his vessel came in contact with the lighter's hawser which was fastened to the capstan, and the effect was to capsize her. Witness extricated himself from the lighter, but QUIGLEY was caught in the rigging and drowned. A verdict of death by drawing was returned.

abstract: The invitation addressed to Irishmen to rally at the Republican head-quarters in Broadway, last evening, was responded to by a large number of persons at the Stuyvesant Institute, among whom were...
lead_paragraph: The invitation addressed to Irishmen to rally at the Republican head-quarters in Broadway, last evening, was responded to by a large number of persons at the Stuyvesant Institute, among whom were noticed many adopted citizens for whose particular benefit the meeting was called. In the absence of the President, WM.W. BADGER called the meeting to order, and briefly explained its origin and objects. He said that several Irish gentlemen, whose sympathies had heretofore been with the Democratic Party, but who had become disgusted with the recent attempts at fusion, and to allure Irishmen into voting for S.A. DOUGALS, in conjunction with the Know-Nothings, had suggested the calling of a meeting of Irishmen, to protest against being thus sold and delivered over to the service of their ancient enemies. With proper effort, he believed that ten thousand Irishmen in this City would cast their votes for the Republican candidates. In the First Ward, where there were not one hundred and fifty Republican votes for FREMOST, in 1856, there were now over four hundred pledged to go for LINCOLN and HAMLIN. Irishmen were informing themselves everywhere as to Republican principles, and when they found that this party was the same as the Democratic Party at home, which went for the rights of the working man, they would gladly join their ranks, and labor with the party of freedom.

abstract: Mr. BRADY, the Breckinridge candidate for Governor of this State, does not view the fusion movement of the Committee of fifteen in so rosy a light as some other Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRADY, the Breckinridge candidate for Governor of this State, does not view the fusion movement of the Committee of fifteen in so rosy a light as some other Democrats. He quite ignores their existence. His speech at Albany, of which we give a report in another column, discusses only the attempt of the two Democratic State Committees to form a coalition. That was a lamentable failure. The more recent experiment of the Volunteers, who were acting for no party but assumed to dictate to all parties, is not so much as mentioned by Mr. BRADY.

abstract: Senator SEWARD is not always perfectly precise and clear in defining the meaning of his public statements on the subject of Slavery.
lead_paragraph: Senator SEWARD is not always perfectly precise and clear in defining the meaning of his public statements on the subject of Slavery. We have more than once expressed the wish, which has been shared by a large portion of the public, that he would leave less room for misconception or misconstruction. Nearly the entire stock-in-trade of his opponents consists of the bug-bears they have been able to make out of his sweeping phrases, innocent and perfectly true in themselves, but susceptible of perversion by their vagueness.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Commissioners of Public Charities and Correction, the weekly report was submitted showing the number of persons remaining in the Institutions Sept. 15, to have been 7,903; the number admitted during the week, 2,001, making a total of 9,904. Of these 25 died; 1,570 were discharged; 445 were sent to the Penitentiary, and 14 to the State Prison; so that on the 22d inst. there were 7,850. The regular report from the Committee of the Whole was presented, but it did not contain any items of special-interest.

abstract: The Water Police connected with the Croton Aqueduct Department held a meeting yesterday morning, when an order was read from the President of the Croton Board, requiring each man to ascertain the number and location of fire hydrants in his district. The object of this movement is to get an accurate map showing, at a glance, the locations of all the fire hydrants in the City, as only an imperfect directory of their particular localities and numbers now exists. The Chief-Engineer of the Fire Department has complained that the fire hydrants are not properly distributed, being in some cases too near together, and again, in other sections of the City, too far apart. Rightly equalized in this respect, however, they would be far more serviceable than they could be as they now are, in the event of a wide-spread conflagration.

abstract: The telegraph is not conspicuous for consistency. The various and irreconcilable dispositions it has made of Gen. WALKER; its contradictory representations as to the condition of his band previous to the reported capture; the doubts it left surrounding the capture itself; and its successive averments that
lead_paragraph: The telegraph is not conspicuous for consistency. The various and irreconcilable dispositions it has made of Gen. WALKER; its contradictory representations as to the condition of his band previous to the reported capture; the doubts it left surrounding the capture itself; and its successive averments that WALKER was to be shot, and that he had been shot, and that after all he is not to be shot; render its testimony exceedingly suspicious; and repeat to us the moral that facts by lightning are less-trustworthy than those attested by that tardier witness, the mail. And to complicate the matter still further, we have now a repetition of the statement that WALKER has been actually shot, though no date or details are given.

abstract: ATTEMPTS AT SELF-DESTRUCTION.--ANN HAMILTON, a married woman, residing in Delancey-street while wandering in mind, on Wednesday night, attempted to drown herself at the foot of Twenty-fifthstreet, North River. Her intention was frustrated,
lead_paragraph: ATTEMPTS AT SELF-DESTRUCTION.--ANN HAMILTON, a married woman, residing in Delancey-street while wandering in mind, on Wednesday night, attempted to drown herself at the foot of Twenty-fifthstreet, North River. Her intention was frustrated, however, by Officer FISHER, of the Sixteenth Ward, who took her out of the water. In the morning she was taken before Justice CONNOLLY, to whom she stated that trouble in her domestic relations had induced her to make the attempt upon her life. As her reason had returned, and she appeared to have repented of her conduct, the magistrate permitted her to go home.....CONRAD WANDER, a German, by occupation a machinist, having no home nor friends, also sought to make away with himself by swallowing a large quantity of laudanum. His condition was discovered, and the poison was taken from him by means of a stomach-pump. The man seemed to be partially deranged, and he was sent to the Almshouse.

lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES T. BRADY, while speaking at Albany the other night, probably did not expect to be reported, or he would not have departed so widely from the candor and fairness which usually characterize his speeches. When he asserted that "the Republicans gravely argue that a man ought to be made President of the United States because he once split rails," he must either have supposed himself to be talking confidentially and without any danger of being overheard, or else he must have become singularly reckless as to the general tenor of his political statements.

abstract: The Official Gazette of Turin, in its issue of the I4th inst., publishes a Government memorandum, addressed by the King of Sardinia to his representatives abroad, and dated the 12th of September. The memorandum explains the state of things in Italy since the peace of Villafranca. It adverts to the refusal of the
lead_paragraph: The Official Gazette of Turin, in its issue of the I4th inst., publishes a Government memorandum, addressed by the King of Sardinia to his representatives abroad, and dated the 12th of September. The memorandum explains the state of things in Italy since the peace of Villafranca. It adverts to the refusal of the Court of Rome to accede to the demand of Sardinia to disband the foreign legions, and justifies by imperative reasons the step taken by Sardinia. The Sardinian Government could not allow the Italian movement to dissipate itself in anarchy and disorder. The memorandum confirms the assurance already given that the Royal troops will scrupulously respect Rome and the surrounding territory, and makes an appeal to the Holy Father, who some years ago inaugurated the national movement. The memorandum thus concludes: "When the Pope shall recognize the regeneration of Italy, which enters among the designs of Providence, he will again become the Father of the Italians, as he has never ceased to be the august and venerable father of all the faithful."

abstract: Mr. LINDSAY, that uncommissioned commissioner of the British Government, has laid the particulars of his errand before the Boston Chamber of Commerce. He hopes to effect various ameliorations in our international maritime system, seeking several important concessions from the American Government, and offering valuable returns on the part of his own country. His demands relate to our
lead_paragraph: Mr. LINDSAY, that uncommissioned commissioner of the British Government, has laid the particulars of his errand before the Boston Chamber of Commerce. He hopes to effect various ameliorations in our international maritime system, seeking several important concessions from the American Government, and offering valuable returns on the part of his own country. His demands relate to our present laws regarding the responsibility of shipowners for damages at sea, the rule of the road at sea, crimes committed on the high seas, and he also desires a modification of our system of signal lights, so as to coincide with that used by English merchantmen. Little difficulty need be apprehended in obtaining a ready and favorable response upon all these points. They have long been called for by our own shipping interests; and it is only because great interests seldom condescend to invade the lobby and employ the ordinary methods of expediting beneficial legislation, that the desires of Mr. LINDSAY have not been anticipated.

abstract: IMITATING BLONDIN -- A FATAL FALL. -- A man named ROBERT WINCHELL, residing in Shokan, Ulster County, met with a fatal accident, a few days since, while trying to imitate BLONDIN. A traveling company had arrived at Shokan, and part of the performance was an out-door tight-rope exhibition by Mme. CAROLISTA. A rope had been stretched from a high pole to the top of a tannery, and the lady had accomplished her part, when WINCHELL proposed to go over the rope in a new style, and ascending the started to cross by seizing the rope with both hands, allowing his body to hang downwards. He actually accomplished this feat to the opposite side, but could not gain a footing, and being completely exhausted, he let go his hold, and fell to the ground, a distance of about thirty feet. His right arm and several ribs were broken, besides other internal injuries. He lingered three or four days and expired. WINCHELL was a married man, about 30 years of age.
lead_paragraph: IMITATING BLONDIN -- A FATAL FALL. -- A man named ROBERT WINCHELL, residing in Shokan, Ulster County, met with a fatal accident, a few days since, while trying to imitate BLONDIN. abstract: POLITICAL MEETINGS AT BABYLON.--A large Republican meeting was held in Babylon, Wednesday evening, when addresses were made by JOSEPH CONCE and C.J. JACK, Esqs., of Brooklyn. A Democratic meeting was held in the same village at the same time. A Committee of Republicans was appointed to
lead_paragraph: POLITICAL MEETINGS AT BABYLON.--A large Republican meeting was held in Babylon, Wednesday evening, when addresses were made by JOSEPH CONCE and C.J. JACK, Esqs., of Brooklyn. A Democratic meeting was held in the same village at the same time. A Committee of Republicans was appointed to wait upon the Democratic meeting, and propose that the people assemble at one place, and that the time be divided between the Republican and Democratic speakers. The proposition was declined by the Democrats, they giving as a reason that their meeting was already organized.

abstract: LAMORICIERE, who seems to have no more than 8,000 men at his disposal, has fallen back upon Ancona before the rapidly advancing Piedmontese. Gen. CIALDINI, on the 12th, advanced as far as Fano, a fortified town in Urbino, where he made some prisoners; and a second Sardinian corps d'armee, which has been recently "mobilized," was following in his steps. It was expected that the lines of defence of the Pontifical army would shortly be attacked by an overwhelming force of 45,000 men, so that resistance is utterly hopeless.

abstract: The new armory and drill-rooms of this famed regiment, over the Tompkins Market, will be formally opened about the 15th of October. The officers' rooms, which have been fitted up at an expense of nearly $2,000, borne entirely by the officers of the Regiment, will be ready for occupancy on Monday. The company drill-rooms, which are also fitted up at private expense, by the members of the various companies at an average expense of $1,500, will be opened for public inspection at the same time as the regimental drill-room. The whole expense incurred by the members of the Regiment in fitting up and decorating the drill-room and company armories will reach over $15,000.
lead_paragraph: The new armory and drill-rooms of this famed regiment, over the Tompkins Market, will be formally opened about the 15th of October. abstract: A Turin letter in the Paris Constitutionnel says that GARIBALDI states that his mission will only terminate at Rome and Venice. He is desirous of availing himself of the resources which the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies furnishes to attain that object, which he says he could never accomplish if the annexation took place immediately, for all liberty of action would then be interdicted to him.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, last evening, a resolution was passed calling upon the Counsel to the Corporation to inform them what means could be taken to compel the Hudson River Railroad Company to keep their cars from being an obstruction on the streets. The Committee appointed some time since to investigate the affairs of the office of the Corporation Attorney were directed to report at the next meeting of the Board. A resolution was referred to the Committee on Streets which proposes the widening of Catherine-street twenty feet on the west side, and to extend the street its full width so as to intersect Canal-street, near the corner of Mulberry.

abstract: A communication from Turin would have us attribute marked significance to the arrival there, at this juncture, "of an Austrian General, accompanied by an aide-de-camp," and who is "supposed to be charged" with some mysterious inission; and it further said that "a formal threat of a landing al Ancona is hinted
lead_paragraph: A communication from Turin would have us attribute marked significance to the arrival there, at this juncture, "of an Austrian General, accompanied by an aide-de-camp," and who is "supposed to be charged" with some mysterious inission; and it further said that "a formal threat of a landing al Ancona is hinted at as soon as the Piedmontese troops cross the frontier." But there is no doubt that Austria is merely occupied with providing suitable measures of defence against an attack in Venetia or elesewhere, which she is certainly fully justified in anticipating; and it is quite as reasonable to suppose that the object of the General Officer's visit to Turin was to demand explanations respecting the intentions of Sardinia, as to give explanations respecting those of Austria.

abstract: A telegram from Rome says that the Papal Government is about to address a memorandum to all the European Powers, protesting against the Sardinian invasion of the Roman territory. This memorandum explains that the enrolment of foreign volunteers, of which Sardinia complains in her ultimatum, was principally due to the counsels of Austria and France, the latter Powers having, after the Paris Congress in 1856, insisted on the formation of a Papal Army.
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Rome says that the Papal Government is about to address a memorandum to all the European Powers, protesting against the Sardinian invasion of the Roman territory. abstract: The Fifth Regiment New-York State Militia, under the command of Col. SCHWARZWAELDER, left the City yesterday afternoon for Bedloe's Island, where then are nominally to "encamp" for a week, but in
lead_paragraph: The Fifth Regiment New-York State Militia, under the command of Col. SCHWARZWAELDER, left the City yesterday afternoon for Bedloe's Island, where then are nominally to "encamp" for a week, but in reality to occupy the United States Barracks, perform garrison duty, and practice gunnery under the instruction of Major ANDERSON, of the First Artillery, U.S.A. The Regiment formed in line on Bond-street at 1 1/2 o'clock, and, preceded by the drum corps, nineteen in number, marched down Broadway to the Battery, where two tow-boats, were in waiting to convey them to Bedloe's Island. Each company was very fully represented, and the Regiment mustered altogether about 375 men, as follows:

abstract: Gen. GUYON, an officer whose sympathies are warmly enlisted in behalf of the Pope, left Paris on the 12th inst. to take command of the French troops in Rome, which have been increased to 10,000 men. It was only very lately that Gen. GUYON was superseded in his command by Gen. DE NONE, and it was understood at the time that the reason of Gen. GUYON's recall was that he stood committed, by personal promises to the Pope, to a degree of protection which the Emperor was not then disposed to afford him. The restoration of this General to his command is therefore highly significant. The Pays says that "the Emperor, under existing circumstances, desired to give the Holy Father a new proof of his entire sympathy."
lead_paragraph: Gen. GUYON, an officer whose sympathies are warmly enlisted in behalf of the Pope, left Paris on the 12th inst. to take command of the French troops in Rome, which have been increased to 10,000 men. It was only very lately that Gen. GUYON was superseded in his command by Gen. DE NONE, and it was understood at the time that the reason of Gen. GUYON's recall was that he stood committed, by personal promises to the Pope, to a degree of protection which the Emperor was not then disposed to afford him. The restoration of this General to his command is therefore highly significant. The Pays says that "the Emperor, under existing circumstances, desired to give the Holy Father a new proof of his entire sympathy."

abstract: Capt. EGBERT L. FARNHAM seems to be afflicted with a chronic weakness of having his name before the public. Not content with the fame he achieved by his brilliant exploits in Nicaragua, and the glory that has been still later shed upon his name through his connection with the yacht Wanderer at Savannah, he has sought since his arrival in this City to add to his notoriety by causing himself to be extensively advertised in the police reports. A few days since he entered an overcrowded Broadway stage and shamefully beat one of the passengers who refused to vacate his seat at his command, and for the offence he was duly punished. Wednesday evening he again made himself conspicuous in the bar-room of the St. Nicholas Hotel, by blustering around generally. He commenced to argue with Mr. SAMUEL BRENNAN, a guest from California, and the discussion finally became so exciting in its character that FARNHAM drew a pistol and threatened to shoot his opponent. At this BRENNAN also produced a weapon, and it would be difficult to state what the consequences might have been had not the disturbance which was raised attracted the attention of officer MINGAY, of the Sixteenth Ward, who succeeded in preventing extreme measures on the part of the disputants. Before, however, the officer could accomplish this, he experienced a great deal of difficulty. Many of the witnesses of the occurrence wanted to "see the fun out," as they termed it, and among others who threw obstacles in the way of the policeman, was Mr. THOS. REED, also a boarder at the house, whose boisterous conduct resulted in his arrest. Meanwhile FARNHAM, in the confusion, effected his escape. This morning BRENNAN and REED were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, at Jefferson Market Court, and required to furnish bail to keep the peace for the period of six months. Mr. TREADWELL, of the St. Nicholas, became their surety. The magistrate issued a warrant for FARNHAM's arrest.
lead_paragraph: Capt. EGBERT L. FARNHAM seems to be afflicted with a chronic weakness of having his name before the public. abstract: According to a telegram from Turin the Sardinian troops attacked and took Pesaro on the 12th inst. The losses sustained by the Sardinians under Gen. CIALDINI were trifling. Twelve hundred German soldiers, under the command of Monsignor BELLA, who were shut up in the fortress, were made prisoners. Monsignor BELLA, who had ordered the sack of the town, had been brought to Turin.

abstract: Pursuant to a call issued by the Seventeenth Ward National Union Club, a meeting of "electors, without distinction of party, opposed to sectionalism, and who are in favor of a union of the States, and the election of Union Electoral ticket," , was held last
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to a call issued by the Seventeenth Ward National Union Club, a meeting of "electors, without distinction of party, opposed to sectionalism, and who are in favor of a union of the States, and the election of Union Electoral ticket," , was held last evening at the "Tilford House," Seventh-street. The meeting was called to order at 8 o'clock by Mr. E.M. CARRINGTON, President of the Club. Hon. CHARLES C. EGAN, of Brooklyn, was introduced as the first speaker. He, in a brief speech, proceeded to present the aspects of the present campaign as foreboding anything but peaceful and prosperous results to the country. To sustain his views he cited the action and progress of the Republicans, whom he denounced as a sectional and fanatical body.

abstract: The Congressional Convention, which nominated AMOR J. WILLIAMSON for Congress by acclamation, on Wednesday evening appointed a Committee of One from each Ward to make arrangements for a grand ratification meeting. After the labors of the delegates were over, a retreat was beaten to the head-quarters of the District Campaign Club in Murray-street, where Mr. WILLIAMSON was found, (after having been sent for,) and where the nomination was tendered to him, on behalf of the delegates, by Mr. KINGSLEY, in an appropriate speech relating to the alleged frauds of the preceding Congressional election. Mr. WILLIAMSON curtly but happily responded, and promised to deliver, soon, a speech m which he would fully define his political position. A collation closed the ceremonies of the evening. Mr. WILLIAMSON appears to be very popular in his District.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- FAREWELL BENEFIT OF MR. AND MRS. BARNEY WILLIAMS. -- To-night these favorites of the public take their farewell benefit at this theatre. Their engagement has been so successful that it is to be regretted it could not have been longer extended. The arrangements of the management, however, completed some time since, render their departure unavoidable, as Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN will appear on Monday, to commence a course of her celebrated characters. The performances of Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS, on the occasion of their benefit to-night, will be the successful burlesque of the "Magic Joke, or Prince Doloroso," "Phelim O'Donnell, or the Leprechaun," and "Born to Good Luck." GABRIEL RAVEL's pupil "Young America," will also appear in El Trapaza and in his celebrated Chinese Pas. On Saturday Mr. and Mrs. WILLIAMS will appear for the last time, probably, in New-York, for a considerable period.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- FAREWELL BENEFIT OF MR. AND MRS. BARNEY WILLIAMS. -- To-night these favorites of the public take their farewell benefit at this theatre. abstract: On Wedneseay evening, when the purchasers of tickets were plentiful about the box-office of Niblo's Theatre, a somewhat notorious pickpocket, named James Brown, mingled in the crowd, flourishing a dollar bill, as if intent upon buying a ticket. He allowed himself to be jostled from side to side, and availed himself of the opportunity to explore the pockets of the parties with whom he came in contact. His manoeuvres, however, were observed by Detective Eustace, who arrested him at the moment when he was throwing away a porte-monnaie, from which he had not taken all the change. The prisoner, who is about 40 years of age, and is said to be a recent graduate of the Moyamensing Prison, Pennsylvania, was taken yesterday before Justice KELLY, by whom he was committed for trial.

abstract: The King of Sardinia did not wait for a reply to his ultimatum, which, as every one foresaw, was absolutely rejected. A horrible massacre, by the mercenaries of LAMORICIERE, of the inhabitants of Fossombrone, a town in the delegation of Urbino, after a victory obtained over them by dint of overpowering numbers, afforded him, as King of Italy, a pretext for entering the Papal territories at the head of his troops. On the evening of the 11th inst. 25,000 Sardinian troops entered Umbria, and on the morning of the 12th they were followed by another 25,000.
lead_paragraph: The King of Sardinia did not wait for a reply to his ultimatum, which, as every one foresaw, was absolutely rejected. abstract: The Southern Disunionists are exercising a good deal of prudence in their plans and projects for carrying their schemes into execution. They evince very little of that headlong zeal which has sometimes characterized them. They are not disposed to rush to arms instantly and wage a war of extermination upon the North as they have at times threatened to
lead_paragraph: The Southern Disunionists are exercising a good deal of prudence in their plans and projects for carrying their schemes into execution. They evince very little of that headlong zeal which has sometimes characterized them. They are not disposed to rush to arms instantly and wage a war of extermination upon the North as they have at times threatened to do hitherto -- but are suggesting various modes of accomplishing their object, with a view of selecting the one which shall involve least risk. Part are opposed to any one State seceding alone. Some want one State to take the lead, and some another. One man thinks it madness to move until Virginia and the other border States are disposed to join in the movement, and others think it much greater madness to dream that they will ever do so. And there is a still greater diversity of opinion as to the time of secession, -- whether they should secede at once, or wait for some "overt act."

abstract: The additional details of European news, published in this morning's TIMES, are highly important. We give a succinct account of the events that have lately occurred in Italy. King FRANCIS II. has left Gaeta for Madrid. The particulars of his flight, and of the public entry of GARIBALDI into Naples, will be found interesting in the extreme. The Revolution has already extended-from
lead_paragraph: The additional details of European news, published in this morning's TIMES, are highly important. We give a succinct account of the events that have lately occurred in Italy. King FRANCIS II. has left Gaeta for Madrid. The particulars of his flight, and of the public entry of GARIBALDI into Naples, will be found interesting in the extreme. The Revolution has already extended-from Naples to the Roman States, and many towns in the latter are in open revolt. General LAMORICIERE, according to latest advices, was in Ancona with some 8,000 troops. An overwhelming Sardinian force was in his immediate vicinity, and a battle was daily expected. The recall of the French Ambassador from Turin is not regarded as evidence of a Diplomatic rupture, but rather as a French protest against the invasion of the Pontifical Dominions. Some authorities go so far as to say that it was with the consent of France that Sardinian troops crossed the Roman frontiers. Austria is making great warlike preparations, but they are limited to the defence of Venetia, whose turn will come after Rome has been liberated. VICTOR EMANUEL is even now, in reality, "King of Italy."

abstract: The races were not as well attended yesterday in consequence of the great disappointment of the public in the four mile race, on the first day of the meeting. It seems that whenever there is the least attendance, there is sure to be first-rate running on the Fashion Course. Such was the case yesterday, when but about 200 vehicles, and about 1,500 persons were at the Course. Among them were very many Southerners, including Hon. John M. Botts, O.P. Hare, the owner of Oysterman, John Hunter, T. Doswell, Beau Hickman, and numerous New-Yorkers of distinction among turfmen.

abstract: -- Judge John C. Richardson, of St. Louis, died on the 21st, after a week's illness. He was born in Lexington, Ky., on the 26th of March, 1819, was educated for the legal profession at Centre College, Danville, and emigrated to Missouri in 1840. For ten years he lived in Boonville, when he removed to St. Louis. In 1857 he was elected Judge of the Supreme Court by an overwhelming majority, but resigned in 1859. He had taken a prominent stand for BELL and EVERETT in the present campaign, and was working zealously to advance their interests when he was seized with the illness which proved fatal. At a meeting of the Bar of St. Louis, to do honor to Judge Richardson's memory, Judge Bates made a feeling address.

abstract: That a few days, or at most, weeks, must bring to a crisis Italian affairs, is the universal conviction. The recent greatly increased activity in this part of the Sardinian Kingdom, is to us sufficient evidence that the Government is persuaded that important movements are soon to succeed immediately south of us, and of the necessity to be prepared for any emergency.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The investigation, by Coronor GAMBLE, into the circumstances attending the death of THOMAS MCKEON, the man who was fatally injured near Fordham, Westchester County, on the 22d inst., in consequence of a wagon in which he was riding having come in contact with a locomotive of the Harlem Railroad Company, was resumed and concluded yesterday. Mr. A.H. CULVER, a passenger on the 5 o'clock P.M., train, deposed that he left the cars at Fordham Station, and as he walked up the road he observed deceased driving down in a buggy. He called to him to stop, as a train was just coming down. Deceased stopped for a moment, and then attempted to cross in front of a train, but the locomotive struck the wagon, and he fell upon the cow-catcher, which bore him along for some distance. The brother of deceased testified that he witnessed the occurrence. He believed that the train was going at the time at a speed of 20 or 25 miles an hour. A flagman was usually stationed at the crossing, but he was not there on this occasion. This flagman, in addition to the duties of that position, also divided his time by filling the offices of postmaster, ticket agent, freight agent, express agent and switchman. He was also required to attend to both depots -- upper and lower -- and to superintend the furnishing of water to the engine. As soon as deceased was picked up he was taken to his residence in Eighty-fifth-street, where he died in a few minutes after his arrival. Upon this testimony a verdict was rendered as follows: "That THOMAS MCKEON came to his death by fracture of the skull, the result of being struck by a locomotive of the Harlem Railroad Company, at Fordham Station, on the 22d of September. Further the jury censure the said company for not placing a flagman to warn persons crossing the track where the accident occurred." Deceased was 35 years of age, and a native of Ireland.

This flagman, in addition to the duties of that position, also divided his time by filling the offices of postmaster, ticket agent, freight agent, express agent and switchman. He was also required to attend to both depots -- upper and lower -- and to superintend the furnishing of water to the engine. As soon as deceased was picked up he was taken to his residence in Eighty-fifth-street, where he died in a few minutes after his arrival. Upon this testimony a verdict was rendered as follows: "That THOMAS MCKEON came to his death by fracture of the skull, the result of being struck by a locomotive of the Harlem Railroad Company, at Fordham Station, on the 22d of September. Further the jury censure the said company for not placing a flagman to warn persons crossing the track where the accident occurred." Deceased was 35 years of age, and a native of Ireland.

abstract: BLONDIN AT JONES' WOOD. This intrepid ropewalker appeared for the third time, and, we understand, the last but one of the present season, at Jones' Wood. Considering the disadvantages of wind and temperature of the air, which was quite cool, even for September, the accomplishment of his wheelbarrow performance and other achievements were attended with laudable success.
lead_paragraph: BLONDIN AT JONES' WOOD. This intrepid ropewalker appeared for the third time, and, we understand, the last but one of the present season, at Jones' Wood. Considering the disadvantages of wind and temperature of the air, which was quite cool, even for September, the accomplishment of his wheelbarrow performance and other achievements were attended with laudable success. No new features by whichto astonish the assemblage, which numbered something above a thousand persons, was introduced. He appeared at the appointed time in tights, ascending the ladder-pole -- from which the rope is suspended -- with the dexterity of a cat. With but little delay, after securing an exact equilibrium by means of his balance-pole, he started in quick step to the music of the band, running rather than walking to about the middle of the rope, where he proceeded to maneuvre in his peculiarly adventurous way by laying down, turning summersaults, both forward and backward, never for a moment exhibiting the slightest error of movement which might give rise to fear upon the part of his audience. After the performance of the wheel-barrow, which was trundled twice across the entire length of the rope. Mons. BLONDIN was escorted by a dense crowd to the hotel on the grounds.

abstract: The People ex rel. John McGinn. -- This is another one of those proceedings arising out of a conflict of Federal and State authorities. The plaintiff piloted the ship Webster to sea, when another pilot had brought her in. As this act was in violation of the 28th section of the By-laws of the Pilot Commissioners, which provided that any pilot bringing in a vessel should be entitled to take her out, unless, in the meantime he should be complained of for incapacity or misconduct, the Commissioners notified the plaintiff that they should proceed against him for the purpose of revoking his license. He thereupon obtained a writ of prohibition against the Commissioners, restraining them from proceeding against him. The matter now came up before Justice INGRAHAM at Chambers of the Supreme Court, on a motion to quash that writ, the Commissioners alleging that it could not issue to them, it not being a proper remedy.

abstract: The speech of Mr. DAVIS, of which we published a telegraphic synopsis yesterday, will commend itself to general perusal. It is one of the ablest and most eloquent speeches made in any part of the country during this campaign. It is marked not less by the independence of its tone than by the eloquence of its style. Mr. DAVIS holds a more peculiar position, in many respects, than any other public man of the day. He lives in a Slave State, but makes no secret of his opinion that Slavery is an evil to the society in which it exists. He wages uncompromising war upon the disunionists, and upon all who would bring the whole legislation of the country into subordination to Slavery. In the present canvass he supports Mr. BELL for President, but he considers the election of Mr. LINCOLN as far preferable to that of either of the candidates of the Democratic Party. The reasons for this opinion, which differs widely from that of leading members of the same party in this State, will be found clearly and forcibly presented in the speech.

abstract: It is now ascertained, we believe, beyond a peradventure, that Gen. WALKER was executed on the 12th inst., as stated in yesterday's TIMES. The British war-steamer Gladiator brought the news to New-Orleans, together with the remnant of WALKER'S "army." Ten shots, it is stated, were fired at him, amid the cheers of the native, and he was afterwards buried by foreigners. Col. RUDLER has escaped with a sentence to four years' imprisonment.

abstract: The Metropolitan Record is alarmed; at the course which affairs are taking in Italy. It is convinced that NAPOLEON will betray both the revolution and Sardinia. From the day that he encouraged, the latter to display her, banner in the Crimea he has wished and worked for a change of dynasty in Turin, and now he hopes, according to the Record, through the interposition of the treaty of Villafranca to leave to Austria the work of accomplishing both in another war; he himself enjoying the profit of his combination by placing Prince NAPOLEON on the throne of Sardinia, and a Murat on that of Naples. The Record concludes as follows:

abstract: New-Orleans is an uncertain point for the radiation of news, or rather it is a point for the radiation of uncertain news. In regard to the Walker expedition against Honduras we have received, from the quarter indicated, some half-dozen telegrams that should be preserved as specimens of curious contradictions.
lead_paragraph: New-Orleans is an uncertain point for the radiation of news, or rather it is a point for the radiation of uncertain news. In regard to the Walker expedition against Honduras we have received, from the quarter indicated, some half-dozen telegrams that should be preserved as specimens of curious contradictions. On the 18th inst. we published a dispatch announcing that WALKER was to be shot; on the 21st we published another stating that he was shot; on the 25th this information was declared incorrect -- WALKER was only on the eve of being shot; on the 27th fillibusters were overjoyed at the intelligence, contradicting all previous reports, that WALKER was not to be shot at all; and yesterday we were called upon to state, by telegram No. 5, that WALKER was actually and positively shot on the 12th of September, inst. And this morning we have a repetition of the statement, with such details as leave little room to doubt its truth.
headline: {'main': 'Walker and His Captors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Walker and His Captors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The grand torchlight procession of Wide-Awakes which is to take place in this City on Wednesday evening next, promises to be by far the most imposing political demonstration ever witnessed in this country. From a careful calculation made yesterday by the Committee of Arrangements, and based upon positive assurances received from deputations in various parts of the country who propose to unite in the demonstration, it is estimated that not less than 30,000 will join in the procession. The magnificentspectacle presented by such an array of burning torches, borne by uniformed men, and accompanied by numberless bands of music, it is safe to say, has never been equaled in the previous history of this country, and probably will not be again until some rare and extraordinary juncture in our political affairs shall again arouse a feeling among the American people similar to the Wide-awake spirit which exists in the present campaign. Even should the estimate of the Committee fall short one-third, it will still surpass in numbers and brilliancy any political demonstration ever before seen in this City. It is expected that nearly every State in the Union, where a Republican organization exists, will be represented in the procession. New-York and Brooklyn will probably furnish about one-half the force, or between ten and twelve thousand men. The largest deputations from abroad will be from the following cities:

abstract: Mr. YANCEY, the eloquent advocate of Union, whose arguments always tend to make Disunionists, has reached this city on his Northern stumping tour. It is his purpose, I believe, to stump Pennsylvania, and he expects, doubtless, to frighten the good people of that State into the support of BRECKINRIDGE, by telling them of the fearful things which the election of LINCOLN will bring upon them.

abstract: Some three weeks ago the dwelling of Mr. Frederick Grace, No. 175 Elm-street, was broken into and robbed of jewelry and other property. The burglar paid a second visit to the premises on Sunday night last, and carried off more of Mr. Schaeffer's goods, making the aggregate value of the jewelry, &c., that had been stolen amount to $250. Officer Sanford, of the Fourteenth Precinct, investigated the circumstances of the case, and from the developments which were made he suspected William Grace, a young man of disreputable character, whose family formerly resided in a portion of Mr. Schaeffer's house. Yesterday he was successful in his search for Grace, whom he discovered in Canal-street, but whose apprehension he did not effect until after he had chased him a long distance through alley-ways, and over fences, which were threaded and scaled in his effort to escape. He was finally cornered, however, in the rear of a grocery at the corner of Broome and Sullivan streets. After conducting his prisoner to the Station-house, the latter informed the officer that he was guilty of the burglaries, and told where he had disposed of most of the property. He had on one of the shirts which had been stolen from Mr. Schaeffer, and in his possession was found a jimmy and dirk-knife. He was held for examination.

abstract: It was wisely resolved, while the American Institute was seeking a new home, not to undertake the cost and uncertainty of a general mechanical Fair. But two members of the direction were extremely anxious to try the experiment of a Horticultural Fair for two weeks. These gentlemen, the one for flowers and the other for fruits, pledged their utmost exertions to the attempt, and staked their reputation on the character of the exhibition. Their pledge is redeemed, and their reputation is advanced by the show of fruits which fills one of the great halls, and the worldwide collection of plants and flowers which makes a new Eden of the other.

abstract: The people of the quiet village of Flushing were shocked on Thursday morning by the rumor that a poor man who had been lodged in the cells the night previous had been found dead in the morning, and the body partially devoured by rats. The name of the unfortunate man was GEORGE HOFF, who was discovered lying on the ground at Stratton's Hill, near Flushing, on Wednesday afternoon, by Constable HANBIEL. He complained of being ill, but believing him to be intoxicated, the officer committed him to to the lock-up in Flushing, a damp, filthy place. In the morning the man was found dead, and a portion of his forehead and the whole of one hand had been devoured by rats. A post-mortem examination held upon it by Drs. ALLIN and VEDDER developed the fact that death resulted from disease induced by intemperance and exposure. The Jury rendered a verdict in accordance with these facts, and took occasion to denounce the village cells as unfit for the detention of prisoners. The place is very seldom used, and the authorities were not cognizant of their unsuitable condition. The occurrence was greatly regretted by all, and will lead to the erection of better accommodations for the temporary detention of prisoners.

abstract: Maller of Theodore Agnew. This is a writ of habeas corpus, sued out by Mrs. Henrietta Agnew, to recover the custody of her grandchild, Theodore Agnew.
lead_paragraph: Maller of Theodore Agnew. This is a writ of habeas corpus, sued out by Mrs. Henrietta Agnew, to recover the custody of her grandchild, Theodore Agnew. The petitioner alleges that the lad is detained by the respondent, whose name she has now ascertained to be Charles Morris Jenks, though she says that for five or six years she has known him only by the name of "Charles." The petitioner states that her daughter gave birth to the boy at petitioner's house, No. 315 Bowery, some years ago. The daughter died in April last. Previous to her death she requested petitioner to provide for and educate the child, stating that she had never been married to "Charles," but that he had seduced her, and was thus the father of the boy.

abstract: Hon. W.S. ASHE, of North Carolina, in replay to an invitation to address a public meeting at Lillington, writes at some length concerning the present condition of public affairs. He thinks the approaching contest is purely sectional, the North having declared their purpose, if successful, "to deprive the South of the condition of equality in the Union." He regrets the division of sentiment which prevails in the Southern States, but thinks that, "as it is founded not on any difference of opinions or principles, but merely [???]n preferences for men," it will not be lasting. The anticipated results of a Republican victory he thus states:

The latter were without distinction of party one of the military companies being almost wholly Douglasites.

abstract: Judge DOUGLAS is gradually drawing his weary pilgrimage to a close. At the latest advices he had reached Cincinnati, where he enjoyed a brilliant reception and again made the speech which has delighted and edified the inhabitants of the route he has traversed. Mr. DOUGLAS is a good stump speaker, accustomed to study the character and tastes of his audiences, and ready and able always to meet them at least half way.
lead_paragraph: Judge DOUGLAS is gradually drawing his weary pilgrimage to a close. At the latest advices he had reached Cincinnati, where he enjoyed a brilliant reception and again made the speech which has delighted and edified the inhabitants of the route he has traversed. Mr. DOUGLAS is a good stump speaker, accustomed to study the character and tastes of his audiences, and ready and able always to meet them at least half way. We do not think his speech improves in its tone or temper with age. Occasional indications of ill-nature, -- a fretful discontent, either with his topics or his prospects, give to his discourse a harsher and less pleasing tone than it bore in the days of its youth. Still, his style of speech is always vigorous, even if sometimes coarse, -- always filled with sharp and telling hits, though often at the expense of justice and of truth, -- always logical in form, and never more so than when utterly destitute of everything like sound argument and fair reasoning.

abstract: In July last, Detectives RAYNOR and VAN WAGNER, of the Deputy Inspector's Office, Brooklyn, received information that a large amount of counterfeit Haytian scrip had been put into circulation, and it was believed that it was manufactured in the United States. The officers named commenced to "work the case up," and on the 21st of July arrested a Belgian named ADRIAN HARCQ in the act of selling $15,000 worth of the scrip for $500, to the mate of the brig Baltimore, then lying near Catherine-slip, and about to sail for Port-au-Prince. HARCQ was locked up, but for severaldays he refused to divulge where he obtained the money, but the officers finally ascertained that he occupied a small house in the outskirts of Williamsburgh, On proceeding thither, they discovered the plates, dies and some other materials with which the counterfeit money was manufactured; $100,000 of the money, in packages of $100 each, and a large quantity of prepared paper ready for the press. These articles were all taken possession of. When the accused learned what the officers had found he became much alarmed, and finally consented to give an order for the plates with which the water-lines are made in the paper when it is manufactured. The order was sent to a place in Belgium and in obedience thereto, last evening the Detectives had the satisfaction of receiving the articles called for in the order.

abstract: AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC QUID NUNCS IN CONCLAVE. European journals are greatly alarmed and well they may be that the late meeting of United States Representative at Hamburg may lead to another Ostend Manifesto, and the consequent disturbance of the peace of the world.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC QUID NUNCS IN CONCLAVE. European journals are greatly alarmed and well they may be that the late meeting of United States Representative at Hamburg may lead to another Ostend Manifesto, and the consequent disturbance of the peace of the world. The Hamburg correspondent of the London News, writing on the 8th inst., thus describes the event: "Last week a meeting of diplomatic representatives of the United States of America was held in this city, and amongst those present were Mr. JOS. A. WRIGHT, the United States Envoy to the Court of Prussia, Mr. BUCHANAN, from Copenhagen, and Mr. JOHN APPLETON, the newly-appointed American Ambassador to St. Petersburg. The immediate object of their conferences, which lasted several days, was to take into consideration the present unsettled state of Europe and enter into mutual arrangements for joint action on several points, one of the most important of which is the protection to be effectively afforded by the United States flag to the numerous naturalized Germans who have become citizens of the United States. Mr. APPLETON has already left this city for Lubeck, en route for St. Petersburg, where he will relieve Mr. PICKENS, hitherto the representative of the United States in Russia, who has tendered his resignation and only remains at St. Petersburg till the arrival of his successor."

abstract: -- Hon. F.W. Finking, of Grahamville, S.C., Rev. W. Richards, of St. Helena, J.C.H. Claussen, of Beaufort, and a slave, the property of Hon. B.F. Johnson, had a narrow escape from drowning on the 11th inst. They were in a stage-coach which was about crossing the Port Royal Ferry, near Beaufort, when the horses became frightened, and dashed into the river. All the passengers except Mr. and Mrs. Fickling succeeded in getting out of the coach before it was submerged, but they were on a back seat of the vehicle. After vain efforts to disengage his wife, Mr. Fickling was compelled to rise to the surface. He was just about plunging under again, to make another effort, when Mrs. Fickling managed to free herself. A negro who had witnessed the disaster immediately pushed off from shore, and succeeded in rescuing the whole party. The horses were drowned.
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. F.W. Finking, of Grahamville, S.C., Rev. W. Richards, of St. Helena, J.C.H. Claussen, of Beaufort, and a slave, the property of Hon. B.F. After vain efforts to disengage his wife, Mr. Fickling was compelled to rise to the surface. He was just about plunging under again, to make another effort, when Mrs. Fickling managed to free herself. A negro who had witnessed the disaster immediately pushed off from shore, and succeeded in rescuing the whole party. The horses were drowned.

abstract: Senator DOUGLAS arrived here at 8 o'lock-tonight by a special train from Cincinnati, and was received at the depot by a very large crowd of citizens and escorted to the Bates House. He speaks here tomorrow at the State Democratic mass meeting. At Lawrensburgh, Greensburgh, Shelbyville, and other places along the route, Mr. DOUGLAS made short speeches to crowds assembled at the depots. Extensive preparations have been made for the demonstration to-morrow.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS, Thursday, Sept. 27.
